webTitle: English regions a step nearer directly elected assemblies

fields.headline: English regions a step nearer directly elected assemblies
fields.trailText: The government today took a further step towards directly elected assemblies in England when the deputy prime minister and the chancellor of the exchequer joined forces to deliver a package of measures aimed at giving the regions more economic freedom.
fields.body:
The government today took a further step towards directly elected assemblies in England when the deputy prime minister and the chancellor of the exchequer joined forces to deliver a package of measures aimed at giving the regions more economic freedom.

The package includes ending the single regeneration budget (SRB) - the nationwide fund for urban regeneration. Regional development agencies (RDAs) will be able use resources already earmarked for the sixth round of the SRB to implement their own strategies.

John Prescott and Gordon Brown announced the measures to enable RDAs to decide their own budget priorities in return for delivering agreed targets on employment, growth, skills and business creation.

The targets were agreed at a meeting between Mr Prescott, Mr Brown and the RDA chairs in Middlesbrough. The two ministers announced that for meeting the new challenges, the development agencies' budget would increase from £1.2bn this year to £1.7bn in 2003-04.

The government is also strengthening the hand of watchdog organisations set up to monitor the development agencies outside London, with a further £5m to help regional chambers and assemblies increase their scrutiny of the RDAs' activities.

Each watchdog will be asked to put forward proposals for claiming up to £500,000 to develop its scrutiny role. A further £1m will be available for projects supported by the chambers collectively to bolster the expanded monitoring regime. These new resources will give them a greater say in the way RDAs approach regional strategies.

Mr Prescott said regional imbalances held back national economic performance. Regionally balanced growth, led by the regions themselves, was not only desirable but was also an essential element of the government's approach to raising productivity.

"Today we are setting out new and challenging targets which the RDAs collectively will need to deliver," the deputy prime minister said. "We are giving them maximum flexibility to decide budget priorities within their growing resources to meet their regions' targets without unnecessary restrictions."

The chancellor said the RDAs were the key drivers of economic growth in the regions and had now been given the tools to encourage innovation, raise skills and promote enterprise.

fields.headline: Blair's response to Hammond Inquiry
fields.standfirst:
When questioned earlier today, Mr Blair paid tribute to both Sir Anthony Hammond and Peter Mandelson

Special report: Peter Mandelson
fields.trailText: Mr Blair paid tribute to Sir Anthony Hammond for producing what he described as "a painstaking and  extraordinarily detailed" report into the Hinduja affair.
fields.body:
Mr Blair paid tribute to Sir Anthony Hammond for producing what he described as "a painstaking and extraordinarily detailed" report into the Hinduja affair.

He said he was extremely grateful that it had shown the central allegation of impropriety to be totally false.

"I hope very much in respect of Peter, he is allowed to rebuild his life and get on with it in the way he has described.

"I said all the way through that the key allegation had to be investigated thoroughly and it has shown to be false."

Asked about the circumstances about Mr Mandelson's resignation, the Prime Minister said it was "over and done with".

He described Mr Mandelson as someone with "great ability and had a lot to give".

fields.headline: FA Cup Previews
fields.trailText: LIVERPOOL v TRANMERE
fields.body:
LIVERPOOL v TRANMERE

Gerard Houllier has warned his side that Tranmere could be a potential "banana skin" if they are not careful. "They have beaten seven Premiership sides," he admitted. "This is a real banana skin and we must be mentally prepared for the occasion."

Houllier expects to be without Stephane Henchoz with a knee injury, but Jari Litmanen will be available. Liverpool are also hopeful that Steven Gerrard and Danny Murphy will overcome their injury problems. Igor Biscan or Gary McAllister will replace the suspended Dietmar Hamann in midfield.

ARSENAL v BLACKBURN

Matt Jansen believes that Blackburn can cause a shock at Highbury tomorrow. "We have already been to Derby in the Cup and put five past them," he said. "While that is unlikely to happen again tomorrow, who knows what we could achieve if we play to our top form?"

Blackburn go into the game having suffered only two defeats in 24 games stretching back to last November, and should be at full strength with influential England U-21 midfielder David Dunn returning from a toe injury.

Arsenal meanwhile are depleted through injuries and international call-ups. Martin Keown (knee), Edu (hamstring) and Ray Parlour (hamstring) are all ruled out, while Kanu is on international duty with Nigeria. Silvinho, who only flew back from international duty today, could start on the substitutes' bench.

Thierry Henry will still have a late fitness test after taking a knock during the Champions League game against Spartak Moscow in midweek.

WEST HAM v TOTTENHAM

West Ham manager Harry Redknapp will make a last minute decision over whether to risk Stuart Pearce, who sprained his ankle in Wednesday night's 2-0 defeat at home to Chelsea. But Pearce is the only Hammers doubt: Michael Carrick, Freddie Kanoute, Nigel Winterburn and Igor Stimac all return and Sebastien Schemmel will start after being rested on Wednesday.

LEICESTER v WYCOMBE

Robbie Savage believes his lucky silver boots are key to Leicester's bid to reach the FA Cup semi-finals for the first time in 19 years. "We won at Villa in the third round and I've worn them ever since. We have not looked back apart from the game at Everton," he said.

Of the side which beat Liverpool last Saturday, Frank Sinclair (knee) and Junior Lewis (cup-tied) are unavailable and are likely to be replaced by Andrew Impey and Matthew Jones.

webTitle: Portillo fails to make his 69p-a-week jibe stick

fields.headline: Portillo fails to make his 69p-a-week jibe stick
fields.standfirst:
Brown leaves little room for Tory manoeuvres

Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: The Tories yesterday struggled to neutralise the electoral popularity of Gordon Brown's fifth Budget by claiming that the chancellor's package gives voters a mere 69p a week in tax cuts - and does not even deliver the extra spending he promises on key public services.
fields.body:
The Tories yesterday struggled to neutralise the electoral popularity of Gordon Brown's fifth Budget by claiming that the chancellor's package gives voters a mere 69p a week in tax cuts - and does not even deliver the extra spending he promises on key public services.

In a day of skirmishing that all but confirmed a May 3 election date, Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor, clashed with Treasury ministers over his own insistence that he can match Labour's most important spending commitments and cut taxes by £8bn.

With Tony Blair putting the finishing touches to his own speech - to party activists in Scotland tonight - claiming that Labour is now the "natural party of economic competence" - Mr Portillo faced Labour charges that his own spending strategy will force him to cut Mr Brown's plans by £11bn by 2003-4.

Mr Portillo's counter-offensive included "six tax rises Gordon brushed over". They included increases on company cars, corporation tax and national insurance contributions, the latter costing 2.5m people on more than £28,500 up to £2.90 a week.

All the taxes Mr Portillo singled out were in the pipeline from previous Brown policies but come into force in the weeks ahead. In a press conference yesterday, as instant polls showed the chancellor's package has won early voter approval, he coupled them with an insistence that taxes have risen overall by £28bn since 1997.

In response, chief Treasury secretary Andrew Smith claimed Mr Portillo had conceded that by the 2003-4 spending round, a Hague government would be spending £11bn less than Labour plans to.

Mr Smith said the Budget red book showed Labour planning to increase spending by 3.7% a year over the next three years; £74bn a year by 2003-4.

At a press conference, marking out Labour's economic attack for the election, his cabinet colleague, social security secretary Alistair Darling, repeatedly challenged Mr Portillo to say whether he would stick by his commitment to increase spending by only 2.25% over three years in line with the so-called trend rate of growth in the economy.

Mr Darling said the only spending principle enunciated by Mr Portillo was that he would not allow spending to rise faster than the rate of growth in the economy. "When he is pressed he says he will match us, but then he insists he will stick to 2.25%. He either has a rule or he doesn't."

Mr Darling said the government had increased the percentage rise in spending because the base from which it was starting in the coming financial year was lower than had been envisaged at the time of the spending review last summer. He said spending levels were lower than expected due to savings on social security and debt interest payments.

Labour also acknowledged that departmental spending was £1bn lower in 2000-01 than envisaged in the pre-Budget report. Mr Darling said this money would be carried over.

webTitle: Everyone's a winner from script with a happy ending

fields.headline: Everyone's a winner from script with a happy ending
fields.standfirst: Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: "If Gordon Brown's Budget was rewritten as a Hollywood movie," said Howard Reed of the Institute for Fiscal Studies yesterday, "it would be called 'no losers' - or perhaps, 'everyone's a winner'."
fields.body:
"If Gordon Brown's Budget was rewritten as a Hollywood movie," said Howard Reed of the Institute for Fiscal Studies yesterday, "it would be called 'no losers' - or perhaps, 'everyone's a winner'."

Weeks ahead of a general election, the chancellor's fifth and final Budget of the parliament followed a familiar pattern of quiet redistribution, with most of the gains concentrated at the bottom end of the income scale.

But with middle England likely to play a crucial part in the outcome of the poll, Mr Brown also made sure that average and higher income groups did not suffer. Unlike some previous Budgets, there were gains for families in every income bracket.

"This Budget goes with the grain of previous Labour party budgets whilst offering something for almost everyone," Mr Reed said.

In its analysis of the distributional impact of the personal tax and benefit changes, the IFS said the biggest gainers in percentage terms are households in the poorest tenth of the population.

They gain on average about 1.6% of disposable income. In cash terms, that is about £1.65 a week. The main drivers are the benefit increases and excise duty changes.

Further up the income distribution scale, the widening of the 10p tax band from £1,520 to £1,880 ensures that basic and higher rate taxpayers also have some extra money in their pockets.

In percentage terms, the richest 10% of the population gains about 0.3% of disposable income - around £2 a week in cash terms.

The IFS has also calculated the effect of the Budget changes on direct and indirect tax by family type. This shows that families with children are the biggest beneficiaries.

They gain from the above-inflation increases in the working families tax credit, the children's credit and the changes to child allowances in income support. As a percentage of disposable income, single parents and non-earning couples with children gain the most. Their incomes rise by about 2% a week on average.

At the opposite end of the age range, pensioners gain little from the tax and benefit changes announced yesterday.

But they will still be better off both this year and in the years to come, thanks to the generous package of measures announced in November's pre-Budget report, including increases in the basic state pension and the minimum income guarantee. Pensioners also benefit from tax allowances rising in line with earnings from 2003 onwards, and the planned introduction of the new pension credit.

The IFS said the overall impact of the Budget on the public finances was to loosen fiscal policy by £4.4bn in the coming financial year, rising to £5.2bn in 2002-03 and £5.8bn in 2003-04.

IFS researcher Carl Emmerson said the tax cuts and spending increases announced by the chancellor had been made possible by higher than expected tax revenue - especially income tax - combined with lower than expected spending on social security and debt interest, and underspending of departmental programmes.

However, he questioned the chancellor's claim to have upped spending increases to 3.7% a year over the next three years from 3.4% previously, saying that the only reason spending was growing faster was that it was starting from a lower base.

webTitle: The great outdoors to prepare teenagers for student life

fields.headline: The great outdoors to prepare teenagers for student life
fields.trailText: A government scheme to give 16-year-olds a taste of adventure and help prepare them for student life and the outside world will be massively expanded this summer.
fields.body:
A government scheme to give 16-year-olds a taste of adventure and help prepare them for student life and the outside world will be massively expanded this summer.

The government believes sending youngsters into the great outdoors this summer will increase their self-confidence and increase their chances of reaching further and higher education. A pilot scheme last year involving 1,400 pupils has convinced ministers that activities such as kayaking and rock climbing will help ease the transition from school to college and university by teaching teenagers essential teamwork and leadership skills. This summer the project is being increased ten-fold.

An evaluation of last year's pilot revealed that 79% of those who took part felt changed as a result of the scheme, while there was an increase from 76% to 81% of those going on to school or college.

The £10m scheme will allow post-GCSE students to boost their confidence and self-esteem, preparing them for adult life. The 47 projects will run across England, organised by the new careers service, Connexions. They will be offering a range of activities from environmental conservation work to drama; local community projects to sailing.

Schools Minister Jacqui Smith was enthusiastic about the scheme: "The government is committed to ensuring that young people receive the best possible advice about their options in - but our summer activities scheme goes much further. It helps young people broaden their horizons. [The scheme] has already made a real difference to the lives of many young people and will continue to reach more and more."

webTitle: Style: Bravo! Bravo! But would you really wear it? Jess Cartner-Morley on the Milan shows.

fields.headline: Bravo! Bravo! But would you really wear it?
fields.standfirst: The good news from the Milan shows: there were some very, very nice clothes. The bad news: the little girl look is back.  Jess Cartner-Morley reports
fields.trailText: The good news from the Milan shows: there were some very, very nice clothes. The bad news: the little girl look is back. Jess Cartner-Morley reports.
fields.body:
Fashion people have an expression - "very editorial" - to describe clothes that look stunning in magazine fashion shoots but which nobody in their right mind would actually wear. Strangely, "very editorial" is generally used as a compliment. It was, in fact, just about the only compliment possible to describe the most prominent trend from the Milan fashion shows - the little girl/babydoll look.

Those with long fashion memories may remember the "Lolita" trend of a few years ago, when it was briefly de rigueur to wear over-the-knee socks and squeeze into child-sized T-shirts. As I recall, some well-known women even took to wearing their hair in bunches, though I'm not naming names. Well, this season's little girl/babydoll look has the same distinctly dodgy undertones - the difference is, this time it's uglier and less flattering.

I'm not really selling it, am I? As a fashion editor, I'm supposed to promote the "new wardrobe every six months" mantra that keeps the industry rolling. Sorry. Rest assured, there were some very, very nice clothes - coats and trouser suits in particular - and we'll come to those in a moment. But first, babydoll.

At Gucci, the babydoll silhouette of empire-line waist and extra-high hemline dominated eveningwear, with tiny evening dresses in dark velvet or in striped or spotted net. At Prada, models had grown up to school age, with apron dresses and capes. Poor Bridget Hall demonstrated the problems of an empire-line silhouette for anyone with breasts, looking mortally embarrassed in an unflattering smock dress that ballooned her svelte shape to twice its normal size.

Miu Miu took literally its role as Prada's younger line, with square-necked, big-buttoned, prep school princess coats in red and grey. Blouses had frilly cap sleeves and patch pockets at bust level. Philosophy looked positively elderly by comparison, with its sulky sixth-form chic: a long purple velvet skirt was worn with a purple ribbed cardigan and flat boots. At Lawrence Steele, ribbon-trimmed babydoll dresses were voluminous around the bottom, making stick-thin girls look as if they were wearing nappies. Square- necked sailor jackets, bermuda shorts, smocked vel vet party dresses with puff sleeves - frankly, Britney Spears would look like mutton dressed as lamb in these clothes.

That's the bad news. The good news is that sharing the same catwalks were some very good pieces. The first three-quarters of the Gucci show, before the babydoll eveningwear appeared, was sheer fantasy shopping: a perfect 10 for trousers that hit just the right note between slick and slouchy, utterly desirable coats in black and cream detailed with shiny silver zips, simple black satin cocktail dresses slashed to bare just the right amount of flesh. At Prada, there was nothing frumpy about the sleek silk shirt dresses in soft plum or in a swirly, caramel-and-cream print, or the riding school-styled grey wool trouser suit with cutaway, curvy jacket and jodhpur-seamed trousers. Miu Miu's tan leather coat dress and dark washed denim, long-legged, sexy jeans were gorgeous. At Philosophy, the petrol blue cinched-back silk dress and tobacco corduroy jackets and coats were lovely.

But best of the week came from a label that steered another course entirely. Bottega Veneta was head and shoulders above the rest of Milan, both for fresh ideas and slick execution. A tab-front jacket in the most luxurious thick, shiny red leather was cut with meticulous accuracy: shoulders pin-sharp, sleeve cuffs sitting at precisely the same height as the waistband. Neon bright jade, turquoise, yellow and red were worn with black. Bleached denim came in loose, hipster jeans, a curvy seamed dress and a zip-seamed mini-skirt, worn over thick ribbed leggings pulled low over bright, high-heeled shoes. The woven leather for which the house is known was there in an indulgent leather coat, on ponytail bands and even on leather headphones, but bags also came as shiny, shin-bruising boxy suitcases.

Less airbrushed but with the same brittle, hard-as-nails aesthetic was Luella, which occasionally looked a little like a Bottega Veneta diffusion line but mostly stood soundly on its own, with paint-striped trousers and shirts, and bumblebee- striped sweater-dresses and jackets.

Other labels stuck to their guns and produced good collections in the styles for which they are known. Alberta Ferretti's was a strong show, understated but powerful: a navy chiffon blouse with a tan leather skirt, an elegant cutaway jacket in plum velvet, a fluid satin off-the-shoulder dress in the palest silver satin. Dolce & Gabbana's "glamour hippy" look featured all their signatures. Ultra-low-riding, super-tight, extra-long leather trousers were worn with high-necked sheer lace blouses laden with strings of pearls. Corseting came in a tight black dress and a coffee-coloured bodice laced with cream ties. The shoes, as always, were fabulous: high sandals with ankle straps of pearls, knee-high white leather boots sprigged with tiny flowers. At the diffusion line D&G, rock chicks still rule, though this season Madonna gave way to Debbie Harry.

Versace, funnily enough, did glamour, too. Dramatic backless dresses, in ribbed black jersey with gold-zipped neck cuff, or in jade green silk with a black leather collar, were worn with steel-spike heels so spindly they didn't even last till the end of the catwalk. The full-length dresses were the least successful, looking a little fussy, but the trouser suit-based daywear worked well. Versus, aimed at the younger customer, was shorter, brighter and sheerer, worn with boots and stockings.

Samsonite Blacklabel was an accomplished collection from a brand that is leaving the luggage tags behind. Miniskirt suits in winter white wool, car coats in tweed, trench coats in olive leather and cosy knitwear were finished off with one of the best bags of the season, a boxy, two-piece, vanity case-style handbag with thick bright striped strap.

Alessandro dell'Acqua showed interesting eveningwear: ballet-wraps in black chiffon over bronze sequin vests, and sheer chiffon in shades of toffee and burnt orange. Missoni was a little lacklustre this season, the prints failing to sing out. Antonio Berardi pulled out all the stops with his own name collection. Trousersuits were worn back to front or with corset bodices over the top, stunning cutaway dresses came in black leather and ruffled flamenco styles in lemon and pink were topped off with spiky, sparkling Stephen Jones hats. At Exte, there were steel corsets and stiff leather armour-style cropped jackets, but better were the softer pieces - a green satin asymmetric dress layered with diagonal pieces, like giant fishscales, was stunning. Berardi was missed at Pucci, where his replacement failed to make the classic prints come to life. The swirled shirt dresses, a geometric short coat and a strawberry pink printed satin clutchbag were all perfectly fine, but somehow the fizz had gone. Pucci fans might do better to visit the vintage shops next season.

Miniskirt suits in winter white wool, car coats in tweed, trench coats in olive leather and cosy knitwear were finished off with one of the best bags of the season, a boxy, two-piece, vanity case-style handbag with thick bright striped strap. Alessandro dell'Acqua showed interesting eveningwear: ballet-wraps in black chiffon over bronze sequin vests, and sheer chiffon in shades of toffee and burnt orange. Missoni was a little lacklustre this season, the prints failing to sing out. Antonio Berardi pulled out all the stops with his own name collection. Trousersuits were worn back to front or with corset bodices over the top, stunning cutaway dresses came in black leather and ruffled flamenco styles in lemon and pink were topped off with spiky, sparkling Stephen Jones hats. At Exte, there were steel corsets and stiff leather armour-style cropped jackets, but better were the softer pieces - a green satin asymmetric dress layered with diagonal pieces, like giant fishscales, was stunning. Berardi was missed at Pucci, where his replacement failed to make the classic prints come to life. The swirled shirt dresses, a geometric short coat and a strawberry pink printed satin clutchbag were all perfectly fine, but somehow the fizz had gone. Pucci fans might do better to visit the vintage shops next season.

fields.headline: 'Worst' school wins Ofsted accolade
fields.trailText: The Ridings school in Halifax, which was briefly closed in chaos and branded the "country's worst school" in 1996, has been given good marks by Ofsted in a report published today.
fields.body:
The Ridings school in Halifax, which was briefly closed in chaos and branded the "country's worst school" in 1996, has been given good marks by Ofsted in a report published today.

The latest inspection of the West Yorkshire comprehensive describes it as "a good and improving school" with high quality teaching and an ethic of hard work.

The Ofsted team found that the school had progressed markedly since its last inspection in 1998, which registered the first signs of permanent recovery from the near anarchy two years earlier which saw pupils sent home for two days. The Ridings was removed from the list of failing schools at the time, and staff led by headteacher Anna White were praised. Today's report says that "constant attention to the quality of teaching is reaping its rewards".

Mrs White, who was awarded the CBE for her work, said: "This report is an accolade to staff, governors, parents, and above all, students of the Ridings."

The chairman of schools and children's services for Calderdale council, Bill Carpenter, said: "This is a tribute to the hard work of children, staff and governors, and to the support of parents."

fields.headline: Teachers' action for 35-hour week
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Teachers are threatening to limit their hours to 35 a week unless the government agrees to an independent inquiry into working conditions.
fields.body:
Teachers are threatening to limit their hours to 35 a week unless the government agrees to an independent inquiry into working conditions.

Four unions representing more than 500,000 teachers in England and Wales are putting identical motions for industrial action before their annual spring conferences condemning ministers for failing to relieve excessive workload.

They want an inquiry similar to the McCrone committee in Scotland, which produced an agreement to limit hours to 35, with a maximum class contact time of 22.5 hours. A survey last year showed primary teachers in England and Wales worked an average 53 hours and secondary teachers 51.

The National Union of Teachers, National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, the Association of Teachers and Lecturers and Ucac (the National Association of the Teachers of Wales) "will take effective action, short of strike action" unless the government holds an inquiry,or takes "other appropriate measures". This action which would initially limit working time to no more than 35 hours per week would require a ballot of members.

Although the NUT has a policy of protecting exams, the ac tion would be likely to slash time spent on marking and attending meetings.

The motion condemns the government and the school teachers review body, which makes recommendations on teachers' pay "for their repeated failure to take effective action to remove the excessive workload". It attacks the government's "complacent" response.

The review body itself called for an inquiry to remedy areas of excessive workload. But David Blunkett, the education secretary, has said putting limits on teaching hours in the classroom would be "cumbersome to administer".

Doug McAvoy, general secretary of the NUT, said: "Our four organisations represent virtually every teacher and a significant number of heads throughout England and Wales. We are voicing their frustrations."

Peter Smith, general secretary of the ATL, said: "Only a kamikaze prime minister would fail to listen to this."

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of NASUWT, said: "The government, together with the schoolteachers' review body, failed lamentably to respond to our legitimate concerns."

The Department of Education and Employment would not comment on the threat of industrial action.

webTitle: Blunkett happy with 'bribe' to bring back the teachers

fields.headline: Blunkett happy with 'bribe' to bring back the teachers
fields.standfirst: Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, launched a counter-attack yesterday on the critics of a new bonus scheme that encourages former teachers to return to the profession.
fields.body:
David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, launched a counter-attack yesterday on the critics of a new bonus scheme that encourages former teachers to return to the profession.

He said he had no objection to their description of it as a "bribe". Mr Blunkett is expected to announce details of the two-stage bonus on Monday, when he will also explain how the £837m earmarked in the Budget for education in England will be spent.

At the launch in east London of UK Online - a government-funded network of community computer centres - Mr Blunkett said: "I hope the package will encourage people back into teaching. If it's described as a bribe, I don't mind, if it gets people back into the profession."

The package will include £2,000 grants for returnees, £500 at first and £1,500 after a year.

Incentives for those returning to teach maths, science, technology, English and modern languages would involve a bonus of up to £4,000.

While the government had achieved a "phenomenal turnaround" in numbers applying to teaching training courses, there would still be an 18-month gap before that produced more teachers. The package was intended to address that problem in the short-term.

The National Union of Teachers and the National Association of School Masters/Union of Women were the strongest critics of the scheme.

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the Nasuwt, said: "It is not that Nasuwt opposes financial inducements to get retired people back into teaching - on the contrary we have put forward that idea ourselves. But it is no good paying out money to induce people back into teaching if the conditions which drove them out in the first place are not improved. The government needs joined-up thinking."

fields.headline: NHS names director for London
fields.trailText: One of the biggest management jobs in the health service - regional director of the NHS in London - has gone to civil servant John Bacon.
fields.body:
One of the biggest management jobs in the health service - regional director of the NHS in London - has gone to civil servant John Bacon.

Mr Bacon, who will oversee a £6bn budget and over 90 NHS trusts and health authorities, is currently acting director of London region after spending two years as its director of finance and performance.

He succeeds his former boss at London region, Nigel Crisp, who was appointed NHS chief executive in autumn 2000.

In a separate move, Ruth Carnall has been appointed as regional director of the NHS south-east region in succession to Barbara Stocking, who became director of the NHS modernisation agency in November 2000.

Ms Stocking has subsequently announced she is to leave the NHS to become chief executive of the aid charity Oxfam.

Mr Bacons appointment, which was widely expected, is one of the most demanding in the NHS, covering as it does one of the most complex and politically sensitive areas of the UK.

His predecessor won plaudits for developing close relations with London mayor Ken Livingstone at a time when many expected the mayor to take a critical stance to the NHS.

Mr Bacon will have the task of implementing the governments NHS reforms at a time when the capitals health service faces pressure on several fronts, including a chronic shortages of nurses and other key staff.

He said: I look forward to continuing the good work of the past two years in forging close links with our colleagues in local government and the voluntary sector in developing policies and strategies which will lead to the overall improvement of the health of Londoners in future.

Before joining NHS London region in 1998, Mr Bacon worked as an NHS manager in Surrey and the south-west. He joined the NHS in 1983 from the UK Atomic Energy Commission.

Ms Carnall, the chief executive of West Kent health authority, has been acting director of south-east region for the past three months. She is a career NHS manager.

fields.headline: PR Week
fields.standfirst: Publication date: March 9
fields.trailText: March 9: Public affairs agencies face a fresh threat this week as PricewaterhouseCoopers pledged to enter their market.
fields.body:
Public affairs agencies face a fresh threat this week as PricewaterhouseCoopers, the world's largest professional services firm, pledged to enter their market.

Lads' magazine Loaded is to hold a pitch for an agency as part of a review of the brand following the appointment of Keith Kendrick as editor.

The Disability Rights Commission is building its first communications team.

AMV Advance Public Relations has been selected to mastermind the relaunch of German-brewed Lowenbrau by Refresh UK.

The Labour party is using a commercial call centre to target floating voters during the election campaign.

Harrison Cowley has been stripped of its £250,000 account with utility firm npower. Hill and Knowlton has won the account.

The Economist has created a group communications role in a bid to raise the profile of its brand worldwide.

webTitle: Yahoo! brings only despair a year after Nasdaq peak

fields.headline: Yahoo! brings only despair a year after Nasdaq peak
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Yahoo!, the world's leading internet portal, demonstrated a grim sense of timing when it announced that chief executive Tim Koogle was stepping down late on Wednesday.
fields.body:
Yahoo!, the world's leading internet portal, demonstrated a grim sense of timing when it announced that chief executive Tim Koogle was stepping down late on Wednesday.

Exactly one year ago today, the Nasdaq index on which Yahoo! is listed reached its peak of 5,048.2 points, when it was worth $6.45 trillion (£4.4 trillion). The statement from Yahoo!, together with a warning that profits this quarter would be far lower than expected, combined to make this an anniversary investors would prefer to forget. In the past 12 months the Nasdaq index has more than halved in the wake of the dot.com bubble bursting and a series of profit warnings from a host of large technology firms. Yesterday it had fallen a further 60 points to 2,163 by the time London closed.

The announcement from Yahoo! dragged shares across the whole internet and related sectors down yet again. T-Online, Europe's largest internet service provider owned by Deutsche Telekom fell by nearly 6% to €11.80 (£7.50), close to its all-time low. At its peak in May last year, T-Online was trading at €48 a share.

Spain's Terra Lycos was 10% lower, and France's Wanadoo, which owns Freeserve, was 7% softer.

Stock in Yahoo! was ravaged in heavy trading, falling almost 20% to $16 during the early afternoon. "The best dot.com can't make it, and that's troubling for the entire internet economy," one trader said.

The Yahoo! warning said revenues during the current quarter would be $170m-$180m, against forecasts of $232m. Yahoo! had been regarded as one of the internet's biggest financial success sto ries, with revenue nearly doubling last year to £1.1bn.

But analysts have begun to question the very fundamentals of the Yahoo! model which relies heavily on advertising for revenues - some 90% of its total last year. The softening of the advertising market, particularly in the US, could hardly have come at a worse time for an industry still stumbling towards maturity.

Yahoo!, along with other US internet portals, relied heavily on advertising from other dot.coms and has found itself in a vicious circle. Its European peers at least are less dependent. Merrill Lynch predicts that online advertising will grow by about 25% in Europe this year, compared with a flat performance in the US.

The US also has further to fall. Estimates suggest that between $600m-$900m was spent on online advertising in Europe last year compared with $2bn in the US third quarter alone.

Silicon Valley-based online technology news provider CNET Networks, communications equipment maker Tellabs and TIBCO Software all contributed to the despair yesterday with their own profit warnings.

Not even the endorsement of one of the pioneers of the internet can see off the gloom. Loudcloud, the internet infrastructure firm co-founded by former Netscape executive Marc Andreessen, cut its offer price and raised the number of shares on offer in its imminent flotation.

Yahoo! has now begun the search for a replacement for Mr Koogle, who will remain with the company as chairman. Last month, Fabiola Arredondo, chief executive of Yahoo! Europe also quit to pursue "private business interests".

A chief executive, however, may not be the only new member of the Yahoo! board as rumours continued to circulate that the company may fall prey to a potential takeover or at least forge an alliance with a traditional media firm with some traditional media assets. Yahoo!'s market capitalisation was less than $9bn last night, down from more than $100bn at its height.

News Corporation, Disney, Viacom and Vivendi Universal have all been named. If a deal were done, it would be a similar combination of content and internet access as the AOL Time Warner model. AOL Time Warner with its broad spread of businesses maintained yesterday that it still expected to see revenues growth of 12% to 15% this year.

webTitle: CD of the week: Daft Punk: Discovery

fields.headline: Do the funky robot
fields.standfirst: Daft Punk's eclectic prog disco fails to work the magic of their debut, says  Alexis Petridis
fields.trailText: Daft Punk's eclectic prog disco fails to work the magic of their debut, says Alexis Petridis
fields.body:
Daft Punk Discovery
(Virgin)
**
£14.99

Whether you're aware of it or not, you probably already know Daft Punk's music. The French duo's 1997 debut album Homework was a record that genuinely changed things, introducing now-ubiquitous sounds and styles into pop. Twenty-something Parisians Thomas Bangalter and Guy-Manuel de Homem-Christo applied pilfered chunks of old disco records to harsh techno beats and robotic vocoded vocals. Homework sold well, and Bangalter's solo project Stardust reached Number One with the similarly styled Music Sounds Better With You, but more remarkable is the extent of Daft Punk's influence on the charts. In the last nine months, three number one singles have been deeply indebted to Homework's template: Spiller's Groovejet, Modjo's Lady and, most notably, Madonna's Music.

And it's not just dance music that the duo have influenced, or at least been startlingly prescient about. Homework's sleeve loudly proclaimed Daft Punk's penchant for the bland, critically reviled "soft rock" of Peter Frampton and Andy Gibb. Four years on, East London's voguish clubs play just that, and Toploader's anodyne mid-1970s strumming sells millions. Daft Punk are never photographed unless heavily disguised (recently they've been modelling chrome robot helmets), but the solitary extant photo of the duo sans masks - taken in 1995 - features Bangalter in 1980s garb and Homem-Christo sporting a luxuriant mullet. It looks like a painfully hip fashion spread from last month's Face. Daft Punk's speciality is rehabilitating ideas long consigned to the dustbin of history, a cocksure Gallic disregard for the accepted canon of cool.

Four years later, they're at it again. Discovery comes studded with the sort of finger-twiddling, pseudo-classical solos that aspiring heavy-metal guitarists spent the 1980s trying to perfect. It also offers pomp-rock keyboard runs of which Rick Wakeman would be proud, and the return of the smooth mid-Atlantic funk ballad, beloved of both Phil Collins and commercial local radio 15 years ago.

The bad news is that, this time, the salvage operation doesn't work. Forthcoming single Aerodynamic illustrates its failings. There are pounding house beats, metal guitars, rococo synth flourishes and a Kraftwerk pastiche, but it all sounds disjointed and episodic. You can admire Daft Punk's desire to marry wildly differing musical cultures, and their disregard for the stultifying conformity of dance music, but it doesn't make Aerodynamic any more fun to listen to.

Admittedly, Discovery's experiments occasionally come off. Nightvision condenses 10CC's breathy chart-topper I'm Not in Love into 90 seconds of rather lovely instrumental drifting. And Short Circuit begins like an early 1980s breakdance favourite, corrodes into distorted noise and manages to sound both wildly funky and slightly disturbing.

But worryingly, most of Discovery's best tracks - hit single One More Time, vocal-house closer Too Long, the relentless Superheroes - are those that stick closest to Homework's filtered disco blueprint. And what are we to make of Veridis Quo, which sounds like the incidental music from one of Channel Five's erotic thrillers, or Something About Us, featuring Bangalter's Clouseau-accented vocals over antiseptic synthesisers and Level 42 bass?

One dance-music magazine has already proclaimed Discovery "the greatest album ever", but there's the lingering suspicion that if Something About Us were the work of Mike and the Mechanics rather than two trendy French blokes wearing "ironic" robot helmets, everyone would think it was rubbish.

In an era of guileless, style-less music, when earnest men in casual dress and the blandest of rock cliches rule, it seems almost churlish to condemn an album for prizing style over content or invention over end result. Most of Discovery probably sounded like a good idea at the time, but there's not much point in having ideas if they don't work. At worst, Discovery is less a record than a hypothesis. At best - like a lot of other records these days - it just sounds like Daft Punk's first album.
fields.bodyText: Daft Punk Discovery (Virgin) ** £14.99 Whether you're aware of it or not, you probably already know Daft Punk's music. The French duo's 1997 debut album Homework was a record that genuinely changed things, introducing now-ubiquitous sounds and styles into pop. Twenty-something Parisians Thomas Bangalter and Guy-Manuel de Homem-Christo applied pilfered chunks of old disco records to harsh techno beats and robotic vocoded vocals. Homework sold well, and Bangalter's solo project Stardust reached Number One with the similarly styled Music Sounds Better With You, but more remarkable is the extent of Daft Punk's influence on the charts. In the last nine months, three number one singles have been deeply indebted to Homework's template: Spiller's Groovejet, Modjo's Lady and, most notably, Madonna's Music. And it's not just dance music that the duo have influenced, or at least been startlingly prescient about. Homework's sleeve loudly proclaimed Daft Punk's penchant for the bland, critically reviled "soft rock" of Peter Frampton and Andy Gibb. Four years on, East London's voguish clubs play just that, and Toploader's anodyne mid-1970s strumming sells millions. Daft Punk are never photographed unless heavily disguised (recently they've been modelling chrome robot helmets), but the solitary extant photo of the duo sans masks - taken in 1995 - features Bangalter in 1980s garb and Homem-Christo sporting a luxuriant mullet. It looks like a painfully hip fashion spread from last month's Face. Daft Punk's speciality is rehabilitating ideas long consigned to the dustbin of history, a cocksure Gallic disregard for the accepted canon of cool. Four years later, they're at it again. Discovery comes studded with the sort of finger-twiddling, pseudo-classical solos that aspiring heavy-metal guitarists spent the 1980s trying to perfect. It also offers pomp-rock keyboard runs of which Rick Wakeman would be proud, and the return of the smooth mid-Atlantic funk ballad, beloved of both Phil Collins and commercial local radio 15 years ago. The bad news is that, this time, the salvage operation doesn't work. Forthcoming single Aerodynamic illustrates its failings. There are pounding house beats, metal guitars, rococo synth flourishes and a Kraftwerk pastiche, but it all sounds disjointed and episodic. You can admire Daft Punk's desire to marry wildly differing musical cultures, and their disregard for the stultifying conformity of dance music, but it doesn't make Aerodynamic any more fun to listen to. Admittedly, Discovery's experiments occasionally come off. Nightvision condenses 10CC's breathy chart-topper I'm Not in Love into 90 seconds of rather lovely instrumental drifting. And Short Circuit begins like an early 1980s breakdance favourite, corrodes into distorted noise and manages to sound both wildly funky and slightly disturbing. But worryingly, most of Discovery's best tracks - hit single One More Time, vocal-house closer Too Long, the relentless Superheroes - are those that stick closest to Homework's filtered disco blueprint. And what are we to make of Veridis Quo, which sounds like the incidental music from one of Channel Five's erotic thrillers, or Something About Us, featuring Bangalter's Clouseau-accented vocals over antiseptic synthesisers and Level 42 bass? One dance-music magazine has already proclaimed Discovery "the greatest album ever", but there's the lingering suspicion that if Something About Us were the work of Mike and the Mechanics rather than two trendy French blokes wearing "ironic" robot helmets, everyone would think it was rubbish. In an era of guileless, style-less music, when earnest men in casual dress and the blandest of rock cliches rule, it seems almost churlish to condemn an album for prizing style over content or invention over end result. Most of Discovery probably sounded like a good idea at the time, but there's not much point in having ideas if they don't work. At worst, Discovery is less a record than a hypothesis. At best - like a lot of other records these days - it just sounds like Daft Punk's first album.

fields.headline: Birthday messages to Rupert
fields.standfirst: Love him or loathe him, Rupert Murdoch has had a massive impact on the world's media. As he turns 70 MediaGuardian.co.uk asked the leaders of the industry and some of those who have done battle with him over the years to send their birthday wishes.
fields.trailText: Love him or loathe him, Rupert Murdoch has had a massive impact on the world's media. As he turns 70 MediaGuardian.co.uk asked the leaders of the industry and some of those who have done battle with him over the years to send their birthday wishes.
fields.body:
Conrad Black, chairman and chief executive officer, Hollinger publishers of The Daily Telegraph
"He's had an astonishing career and I hope the best is yet to come. I wish him and Wendi many happy years ahead."

Gerry Robinson, former chairman of Granada
"People always think you have an agenda and over the years you have been demonised. But what I have always admired about you is your complete lack of pomposity and your almost childlike determination to get what you want - which I mean in a good way. It is the kind of incredible drive you have which I think is sideless and people don't always appreciate that. I wish you plenty of time to keep on with it."

Lord Saatchi, advertising guru
"Happy Birthday. It took an Australian to turn the world upside down."

Sir Martin Sorrell, chief executive of global marketing group WPP
"All of us at WPP wish Rupert Murdoch a happy birthday. We've been thinking about what would be the best present for the man who has everything. How about DirecTV?... We wish him every success in his negotiations."

Oliver Houston of Man United fans' lobby Shareholders United
"Happy Birthday Rupert. Thank you so much for making supporter-shareholders realise that our club's independence mattered more than a quick buck on the Stock Exchange. As a sign of our gratitude, please accept the enclosed £6.23p-worth of Manchester United Megastore gift vouchers."

Piers Morgan, editor of the Mirror
"Happy Birthday Mr Murdoch. You remain a handsome, powerful and brilliant newspaper genius. Which makes it all the more baffling why you continue to employ the current editor of the Sun. Still, nothing £1m and a nice new Ferrari couldn't tempt me to resolve for you. Love Piers Morgan."

Derek Jameson
"Do you remember when Hugh Cudlipp said the Sun was a comic aimed at Irish navvies? Now the Adelaide navvies have taken over Hollywood and the rest. Good on yer, son."

Julie Bindel, head of Justice For Women and anti-Page 3 campaigner
"Happy Birthday Mr Murdoch. It's a shame that you're around for another birthday given the amount of untold misery you have caused to women who have joined the sex industry and suffered sexual harassment as a result of Page 3, when your idea has been to keep alive the idea of woman as piece of meat, brainless bimbo and to encourage more men to be pigs than already are. Let's hope you don't have too many more."

Ernie Greenwood, who was trampled by police horses at the Wapping print picket line.
"Happy Birthday Rupert. I can only wish that you are treated by other people as you have treated them."

Frank Barlow, former chairman of Sky TV and former managing director of Pearson
"Whether you love him or hate him, you can't help but admire his achievements which are immense indeed."

Norman Baker, Liberal Democrat media spokesman
"Rupert Murdoch is the Mrs Thatcher of the media. He has changed the landscape irrecoverably and not always for the good. Now he's got too much power, but unfortunately he can't be sacked like Mrs Thatcher."

Ellis Watson, former 'head baker' at CurrantBun.com and marketing boss on the Sun and Times
"He came, he looked, he dabbled, he learned, he thought a bit, he threw out the bullshitters, he made the best of the opportunity, he got wiser, he got stronger... and he'll still be globally worth more on his own than the combined net valuations of the rest of the UK put together. He's clever like that. Happy Birthday Rupert."

fields.headline: Airey wants millions to take Channel 5 upmarket
fields.trailText: 5.30pm: Channel 5's Dawn Airey is bidding for extra cash to take the station upmarket, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Dawn Airey is set to go the Channel 5 board in a bid for extra cash to realise her dream of taking the station upmarket.

Ms Airey, who last year replaced David Elstein as chief executive, wants tens of millions of pounds more each year to boost the channel's share.

The broadcaster's audience is currently hovering around 6% and senior executives believe that with the right mix of programming they will be able to emulate Channel 4, which enjoys a 10%s share.

"We're conducting a business review and hope to make a compelling case to the board for additional resources," said Ms Airey.

"We're concentrating on ratings delivery between 7pm and 9pm, which is where the biggest gap exists between our current performance and the available audience."

"We want to improve the quality and range of our programming and upgrade the movie stock," she added.

The programming budget stands at just over £140m but majority shareholder RTL's plans to boost the budget to £180m has been stymied by Lord Hollick, whose United Business Media controls 35% of Channel 5.

At the moment Ms Airey and her team can go back to Channel 5's shareholders to argue for extra programming money on a case by case basis.

"Big one-hour event shows are our forte," added Ms Airey, who cited The Mole plus upcoming Touch the Truck, which starts on Sunday and the new £1m game show Greed as examples of the type of shows she is after.

fields.headline: Vivendi oozes confidence
fields.trailText: French media giant Vivendi Universal is sticking to its ambitious growth targets despite reporting maiden results below analysts' expectations, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
French media giant Vivendi Universal is sticking to its ambitious growth targets despite reporting maiden results below analysts' expectations.

Jean-Marie Messier, the group's colourful chief executive, said the group had "enormous growth opportunities".

"We are ideally positioned to provide the global consumer with seamless connectivity and competitively superior content and services - anywhere, anytime and over any device or platform," said Mr Messier.

But investors still harbour doubts about the company's ability to mould its extensive telecoms, film, music, internet and TV assets into an all-conquering media force.

Vivendi today reported an operating profit of £1.63bn, below analysts' estimates of £1.67bn.

However, investors will be more interested in the pledges behind the figures, with Mr Messier reaffirming his belief that pre-tax earnings would leap 35% by 2002 and revenues would rise 10% in 2001 and 2002.

"The company's unique combination of content and distribution assets paves the way for enormous growth opportunities," added Mr Messier.

Vivendi Universal includes the Canal Plus pay-TV station, the Cegetel telecoms company, Universal Pictures and Universal Music.

Vivendi took on the Universal brand when it merged with Canadian company Seagram late last year in a £50bn deal.

However, the group's shares have slipped 20% since the deal was struck, as investors voiced doubts over Vivendi's ability to knit the new company together.

Today's figures show that Universal Music and Universal Pictures had a bumper 12 months, with earnings at the music division rising 16% and the film operation taking over £680m at the box office.

The Canal Plus subsidiary brushed off concerns over its subscriber base by reporting a 32% increase in the number of European subscribers to 5.3m.

Although Canal's full figures were not immediately available, the company strenuously denied reports its losses were widening.

Canal Plus said 2001 would mark "a substantial increase in 2001 EBIT [earnings before interest and tax], operating profit and net profit."

Vivendi devoted surprisingly little time to its Vizzavi mobile internet service in its results presentation and repeated its target of 2m customers by this summer.

The joint venture with UK mobile phone giant Vodafone is a core part of Vivendi's future strategy, where a potential audience of 90m consumers will access the group's content.

Vizzavi is a pan-European internet operation, but analysts want Vivendi to bolster by joining with an internet service provider. Yahoo! is currently the hot favourite following its recent struggles.

fields.headline: Arriva adverts aim to make bus travel sexy
fields.trailText: 3.30pm: A public transport company will try to do for buses what Brief Encounter did for trains.
fields.body:
A public transport company will today try to do for buses what Brief Encounter did for trains - use sex to get people on board.

A £1m advertising campaign for the bus company Arriva will feature an attractive young couple engaging in a passionate kiss on the top deck of a bus.

When the woman asks provocatively, "Your place or mine?", destinations including "work", "cinema", "your place" and "his place" flash across the screen.

The advert, part of the company's "Going your way" campaign, was created by Arriva's advertising agency Cogent.

It will be screened at cinemas across the north-east of England from today.

Sunderland-based Arriva, one of the largest providers of passenger transport in Europe, hopes to extend the campaign to the rest of the country.

Celia Johnson kissing Trevor Howard on a station platform in the classic film Brief Encounter has helped imbue train travel with a certain romance.

But the humble bus has never claimed to have a glamorous image.

"Encouraging people to start thinking about and using our services is the next step in our business development," said Steve Clayton, managing director of Arriva UK Bus.

Peter Huntley, director of transport consultancy the TAS partnership, said bus travel had been in decline since 1956.

"While as a whole we are all making more journeys, there has been no real growth in the bus industry," he said.

"However, over the last four years, figures have become more stable and we can put this down to effective marketing campaigns.

"The main attraction of bus travel is that it is cheap. With an increase in bus lanes, using it to get into a city centre when parking is bad is another major benefit.

"One of the biggest downsides is time - people don't want to stand for 20 minutes at a bus stop in the middle of nowhere.

"If they know they can rely on a bus turning up on time, the battle is won," he said.

fields.headline: Lennon, Moses, and Alan Shearer
fields.trailText: BALLS TO BIGOTS
fields.body:
BALLS TO BIGOTS

Bigots; you can't beat them, but you can ignore them. Well, you can beat them as well, repeatedly in the face with a heavy plank of decorative hardwood, but no liberal tea-time take on the world of football worth its salt would suggest doing that. Much better to follow the example of Neil Lennon, who today decided to play on for Northern Ireland despite being abused by oafs during the recent friendly against Norway, just because he plays for Celtic.

"Following lengthy consideration, I have decided that I wish to continue to play at international level with Northern Ireland," Lennon told his club's official website this morning. "The level of support I have received from all sections of the community has been overwhelming and very touching and has played a major part in my decision," he went on, extremely reasonably when you think about it.

Lennon, who "urged" supporters to come together and support the team in their upcoming World Cup qualifier with the Czech Republic, explained why his decision took so long. "The decision I have made was not taken lightly as I felt it was important to consider the feelings of my family and friends as they had been through a very traumatic experience," he said. "Obviously I hope that they and myself do not have to suffer under these circumstances again." The Fiver hopes Lennon's gracious statement will bring an end to this nasty episode, and that the only suffering experienced at Windsor Park from now on will be by fans watching their team go down by the usual three-goal margin.

SIT DOWN FOR YOUR RIGHTS

One of the keys to being a successful manager - as anyone who has ever devoured Moses on Management: 50 Leadership Lessons from the Greatest Manager of All Time will tell you - is to buffer the bad news with some good. You don't say: "Sorry folks, but we've got another 39 years of this wilderness malarkey to go!" Instead, you sheepishly hula-hoop around the impending doom (loss of job as prophet, lack of stone tablet, etc.) while stressing the good ("Look everybody, more unleavened bread!"). And before you know it, everybody has gone home happy.

The Imperial Lord Ferg, being a successful manager, knows this. Which is why he spent the day warning Manchester United fans not to stand in seating areas at Old Trafford, while dropping subtle hints that he was on their side in the if-fans-stand-the-ground-could-be-closed debate. "The club has shown great vision in building a stadium which holds 67,000 and if it comes to a situation where this has to be reduced, this would affect the team," he thundered. "We're talking about a loss of seats if this threat is carried out and the fans have to pay heed to this."

A loss of seats! Perish the thought! But just as the Fiver was wondering whether Ferg could be a stooge of Trafford councillor Barry Brotherton, the man with the power to close Old Trafford, Ferg's management skills began to show. "It would be great in the future if we could have standing areas and I think I speak for all football fans and all football clubs," he suddenly admitted, causing the Fiver's empathy chakra to tingle warmly. "As a club we would welcome this as would every other club and every other fan." Unfortunately, it was at this point that Ferg bottled out completely by admitting: "But I'm sorry, it's unfortunate this law is in place and you have to change the law before you can do anything." Still, as a display of good management practice, his performance can't be beat.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"Personally, I think Anne 'The Sphinx' Robinson must be the most repulsive and obnoxious person ever to set foot on earth. She has no redeeming features. She is seriously ugly and if the BBC does as it should and she is sacked, she could start a new career advertising shaving blades for men. She is Darwin's missing link. I call upon the BBC to rid the nation of this ugly, offensive sphinx. If they don't, I will call upon all Welsh people to boycott the BBC, who would then prove themselves to be supporting racism" - Cardiff City chairman Sam Hammam pulls no punches on the club's official homepage.

FREE ALAN

Winning the Premiership. Playing for England. Encouraging children to fur up their arteries by consuming fat-drenched beef patties. Yes, football hero Alan Shearer's honourable achievements are second to none. His selfless actions haven't gone unnoticed, either, and today he was granted the freedom of his home town - which is Newcastle, fact fans. It's an honour he richly deserves, putting him as it does in the exalted company of Nelson Mandela and Bob Geldof (members of the great Bishop Auckland side of the 50s, so we're told).

"Wherever you go in the world and you mention that you're from Newcastle, the name of Alan Shearer is on everyone's lips," began a publicity-hungry councillor with a paunch and a scrapeover (we're guessing). "Alan, as the best-known Geordie," the council apparatchik continued after making sure professional northerner Jimmy Nail was well out of earshot, "I am proud to nominate you as Honorary Freeman of the city of Newcastle-upon-Tyne."

After a choral recital of Fog On The Tyne, the newly honoured freeman stepped up to speak. "When I left Blackburn in 1996, I could have gone to some great cities like Turin, Milan, Manchester, Barcelona or London," a grinning (we're guessing again) Shearer said. "But believe me, there's no place like home. I am hugely proud to be a freeman of this great city." We're sure the city of Newcastle thinks you're special too, Alan, otherwise they wouldn't have singled you out for this award. Singled you out along with agriculture minister Nick Brown, Lord Glenamara and a Tyneside computer software company, that is.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Spurs striker Sergei Rebrov will be a transfer target for AC Milan this summer if Fatih Terim takes over, and Oliver Bierhoff could be heading in the opposite direction, claims Planet Football.

Everton left-back Michael Ball will join Manchester United for £10m "in the next few days", according to Football 365.

Teamtalk claims that Parma and five other top Serie A sides are tracking Newcastle winger Nolberto Solano.

Barcelona and Real Madrid are hoping to lure Juan Sebastian Veron away from Lazio.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Tottenham are set to open talks with Darren Anderton over an extension to his contract. Director of Football David Pleat has confirmed that the club will begin discussing new terms with the England midfielder within the next fortnight.

Aston Villa manager John Gregory has leapt to the defence of goalkeeper David James and labelled him "England's number one".

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: World Football (2.45am)
"I read my Fiver whilst sitting in an internet cafe and have done since September," writes Guy Broster.

Sky Sports 2: Futbol Mundial (5.30pm)
"At £3 an hour (or 75p for the 15 minutes it takes me to read the Fiver) and a £1 cup of coffee, I am putting £8.75 back into the economy every week."

Live Second Division Football - Reading v Wigan (7pm, 12midnight SS1, 4am SS1)
"That works out at around £210 to take OFF your Totaliser."

Sports Centre Football Hour (10pm, 1am)
Gah! That's no way to end the week! Surely PD Flint can do better: "I work in arts funding in the north-west. Reading the Fiver, double-checking content on other sites and forwarding snippets must take 30 minutes a day."

Hold The Back Page (11pm)
"I reckon I've cost the charity I work for at least two grand, depriving several starving artists of a square meal."

ONsport 1: Big Cup Football (from 7.10pm)
"Am I evil?"

Radio 5 Live: Sport on 5 with Ian Payne (7pm)
You won't catch us making any moral judgements, PD. We're just concerned with the damage we're doing to the economy. Sadly, it's been a pitiful day for the Fiver Scam Totaliser, thanks mainly to that meddling Broster bloke, so the total has only crept up to £67,644.95. Not that we're worried. Don't ask us why, but we've got a funny feeling everything's going to go ballistic next week. Keep 'em coming to the.boss@theguardian.com and let's wait for this stack to blow.
fields.bodyText: BALLS TO BIGOTS Bigots; you can't beat them, but you can ignore them. Well, you can beat them as well, repeatedly in the face with a heavy plank of decorative hardwood, but no liberal tea-time take on the world of football worth its salt would suggest doing that. Much better to follow the example of Neil Lennon, who today decided to play on for Northern Ireland despite being abused by oafs during the recent friendly against Norway, just because he plays for Celtic. "Following lengthy consideration, I have decided that I wish to continue to play at international level with Northern Ireland," Lennon told his club's official website this morning. "The level of support I have received from all sections of the community has been overwhelming and very touching and has played a major part in my decision," he went on, extremely reasonably when you think about it. Lennon, who "urged" supporters to come together and support the team in their upcoming World Cup qualifier with the Czech Republic, explained why his decision took so long. "The decision I have made was not taken lightly as I felt it was important to consider the feelings of my family and friends as they had been through a very traumatic experience," he said. "Obviously I hope that they and myself do not have to suffer under these circumstances again." The Fiver hopes Lennon's gracious statement will bring an end to this nasty episode, and that the only suffering experienced at Windsor Park from now on will be by fans watching their team go down by the usual three-goal margin. SIT DOWN FOR YOUR RIGHTS One of the keys to being a successful manager - as anyone who has ever devoured Moses on Management: 50 Leadership Lessons from the Greatest Manager of All Time will tell you - is to buffer the bad news with some good. You don't say: "Sorry folks, but we've got another 39 years of this wilderness malarkey to go!" Instead, you sheepishly hula-hoop around the impending doom (loss of job as prophet, lack of stone tablet, etc.) while stressing the good ("Look everybody, more unleavened bread!"). And before you know it, everybody has gone home happy. The Imperial Lord Ferg, being a successful manager, knows this. Which is why he spent the day warning Manchester United fans not to stand in seating areas at Old Trafford, while dropping subtle hints that he was on their side in the if-fans-stand-the-ground-could-be-closed debate. "The club has shown great vision in building a stadium which holds 67,000 and if it comes to a situation where this has to be reduced, this would affect the team," he thundered. "We're talking about a loss of seats if this threat is carried out and the fans have to pay heed to this." A loss of seats! Perish the thought! But just as the Fiver was wondering whether Ferg could be a stooge of Trafford councillor Barry Brotherton, the man with the power to close Old Trafford, Ferg's management skills began to show. "It would be great in the future if we could have standing areas and I think I speak for all football fans and all football clubs," he suddenly admitted, causing the Fiver's empathy chakra to tingle warmly. "As a club we would welcome this as would every other club and every other fan." Unfortunately, it was at this point that Ferg bottled out completely by admitting: "But I'm sorry, it's unfortunate this law is in place and you have to change the law before you can do anything." Still, as a display of good management practice, his performance can't be beat. QUOTE OF THE DAY "Personally, I think Anne 'The Sphinx' Robinson must be the most repulsive and obnoxious person ever to set foot on earth. She has no redeeming features. She is seriously ugly and if the BBC does as it should and she is sacked, she could start a new career advertising shaving blades for men. She is Darwin's missing link. I call upon the BBC to rid the nation of this ugly, offensive sphinx. If they don't, I will call upon all Welsh people to boycott the BBC, who would then prove themselves to be supporting racism" - Cardiff City chairman Sam Hammam pulls no punches on the club's official homepage. FREE ALAN Winning the Premiership. Playing for England. Encouraging children to fur up their arteries by consuming fat-drenched beef patties. Yes, football hero Alan Shearer's honourable achievements are second to none. His selfless actions haven't gone unnoticed, either, and today he was granted the freedom of his home town - which is Newcastle, fact fans. It's an honour he richly deserves, putting him as it does in the exalted company of Nelson Mandela and Bob Geldof (members of the great Bishop Auckland side of the 50s, so we're told). "Wherever you go in the world and you mention that you're from Newcastle, the name of Alan Shearer is on everyone's lips," began a publicity-hungry councillor with a paunch and a scrapeover (we're guessing). "Alan, as the best-known Geordie," the council apparatchik continued after making sure professional northerner Jimmy Nail was well out of earshot, "I am proud to nominate you as Honorary Freeman of the city of Newcastle-upon-Tyne." After a choral recital of Fog On The Tyne, the newly honoured freeman stepped up to speak. "When I left Blackburn in 1996, I could have gone to some great cities like Turin, Milan, Manchester, Barcelona or London," a grinning (we're guessing again) Shearer said. "But believe me, there's no place like home. I am hugely proud to be a freeman of this great city." We're sure the city of Newcastle thinks you're special too, Alan, otherwise they wouldn't have singled you out for this award. Singled you out along with agriculture minister Nick Brown, Lord Glenamara and a Tyneside computer software company, that is. THE RUMOUR MILL Spurs striker Sergei Rebrov will be a transfer target for AC Milan this summer if Fatih Terim takes over, and Oliver Bierhoff could be heading in the opposite direction, claims Planet Football. Everton left-back Michael Ball will join Manchester United for £10m "in the next few days", according to Football 365. Teamtalk claims that Parma and five other top Serie A sides are tracking Newcastle winger Nolberto Solano. Barcelona and Real Madrid are hoping to lure Juan Sebastian Veron away from Lazio. NEWS IN BRIEF Tottenham are set to open talks with Darren Anderton over an extension to his contract. Director of Football David Pleat has confirmed that the club will begin discussing new terms with the England midfielder within the next fortnight. Aston Villa manager John Gregory has leapt to the defence of goalkeeper David James and labelled him "England's number one". TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO ITV: World Football (2.45am) "I read my Fiver whilst sitting in an internet cafe and have done since September," writes Guy Broster. Sky Sports 2: Futbol Mundial (5.30pm) "At £3 an hour (or 75p for the 15 minutes it takes me to read the Fiver) and a £1 cup of coffee, I am putting £8.75 back into the economy every week." Live Second Division Football - Reading v Wigan (7pm, 12midnight SS1, 4am SS1) "That works out at around £210 to take OFF your Totaliser." Sports Centre Football Hour (10pm, 1am) Gah! That's no way to end the week! Surely PD Flint can do better: "I work in arts funding in the north-west. Reading the Fiver, double-checking content on other sites and forwarding snippets must take 30 minutes a day." Hold The Back Page (11pm) "I reckon I've cost the charity I work for at least two grand, depriving several starving artists of a square meal." ONsport 1: Big Cup Football (from 7.10pm) "Am I evil?" Radio 5 Live: Sport on 5 with Ian Payne (7pm) You won't catch us making any moral judgements, PD. We're just concerned with the damage we're doing to the economy. Sadly, it's been a pitiful day for the Fiver Scam Totaliser, thanks mainly to that meddling Broster bloke, so the total has only crept up to £67,644.95. Not that we're worried. Don't ask us why, but we've got a funny feeling everything's going to go ballistic next week. Keep 'em coming to the.boss@theguardian.com and let's wait for this stack to blow.

webTitle: Belgium's far right party in Holocaust controversy

fields.headline: Belgium's far right party in Holocaust controversy
fields.standfirst: Belgium's anti-immigration Vlaams Blok party was supposed to be the far right's Trojan horse into European politics. But controversial statements on the Holocaust have done long-term damage, writes Andrew Osborn in Brussels
fields.trailText: Belgium's anti-immigration Vlaams Blok party was supposed to be the far right's Trojan horse into European politics. But controversial statements on the Holocaust have done long-term damage, writes Andrew Osborn in Brussels.
fields.body:
Its success at the ballot box has consistently wrong-footed critics and given hope to far right parties across Europe. But the Vlaams Blok (VB) has now lost control of its own extremist elements and outrageous talk from its own vice president has shattered its carefully constructed respectable image.

It was only in October of last year that the VB saw its share of the vote in Antwerp, Belgium's second city, rise to 33%. The overtly anti-semitic party consistently captured over a fifth of the vote in Flanders and pollsters predicted it could become the biggest party in the entire region next time round.

But a controversial TV interview given by its vice president and ideologue-in-chief Roeland Raes has rocked the nation and may have dealt a mortal blow to its voracious electoral ambition.

Raes, 67, committed the cardinal sin of any far right party: he said what he really thought in public on the Holocaust. In an interview on Dutch TV he cast doubt on the scale and the extent of the Holocaust to a degree which now leaves him open to prosecution for historical revisionism.

Asked by the presenter if he doubted whether the gas chambers had really existed on a grand scale, Raes replied: "Yes I dare to doubt that. I think that what we've been given to believe on certain points has been very exaggerated.

"The persecution and the deportation of the Jews did take place in a systematic way. But whether it was planned that everyone was going to die - well that's another question."

When asked if he was willing to accept that 6.5m Jews had been murdered by the Nazis during the second world war he was equally sceptical. "Of course it does seem that a lot of serious things did take place; with the Jews, with the gypsies and also with homosexuals. But to come up with an exact figure - well that's a completely different question."

He then went on to enrage Belgium's large Jewish community by casting doubt on the authenticity of Anne Frank's diaries, the Jewish schoolgirl who hid from the Nazis in wartime Amsterdam.

His party, which has desperately tried to keep these kind of views among its own members, scrambled to distance itself from Raes whose ill-judged words sparked a wave of hostile editorials and claims that the real nature of the Vlaams Blok had been revealed.

"A mask falls and the Vlaams Blok grimaces," exclaimed daily La Libre Belgique. The VB, which favours the forced repatriation of all non-European foreigners back to their country of origin, did not know what had hit it.

Its efforts to win a veneer of respectability had been ripped to shreds in an instant. Raes was forced to resign from his senior post in the party but vowed to "continue to work in and for the party". He was also later forced to step down as a Belgian senator and relinquish his post as a member of the governing board of Ghent University.

The Blok's leadership, shaken by Raes' interview, is now plunged into crisis. At a hastily convened emergency meeting to discuss his comments it quickly announced that it "distanced itself totally" from Raes.

VB's president Frank Vanhecke told daily Le Soir that "Blok's representatives must devote themselves to the problems of today and not play at being amateur historians."

Its problems could, however, be just beginning for Belgium's Centre for Equal Opportunity. The Struggle Against Racism is now considering whether to lodge an official complaint which would see Raes prosecuted under a 1995 law which declares that any "denial, playing down, justification or approval of the genocide committed by the German national socialist regime during the second world war" is illegal.

Marc Swyngedouw, a political scientist at Brussel's Flemish University, estimates that Raes' words will cost the party dear. "Every reference to Nazism costs it votes. Every time Raes speaks out he puts his foot in his mouth. It's as simple as that and it's disastrous for the Vlaams Blok.

"It was the expression of a tendency in the heart of the party which has always existed. One group has never hidden its nostalgia for Nazi German authoritarianism."

Belgium has the highest number of immigrants per head in the European Union and the VB has been adept at stirring up racial intolerance as a result. During the second world war sections of the Flemish community also collaborated with the Nazis.

Raes has a long history of close involvement with the far right in Europe and was for many years responsible for the Belgian distribution of a magazine called De Schakel which was edited in Argentina by former members of the Flemish SS.
