fields.headline: Labour's Mr Nice
fields.trailText: March 9: The MP for Islington south is one of Labour's most intelligent and least headline-obsessed ministers, writes Andrew Roth.
fields.body:
One of Labour's most intelligent and least headline-obsessed ministers, Chris Smith, minister of culture since the start of the 1997 parliament, can seldom be faulted when making decisions on his own.

But he has made less of a mark than was once expected.

This can be attributed to pressure from the Treasury and other cabinet colleagues.

His most notable decision came long before he took high office when, at a meeting in Rugby in 1984, he announced: "My name is Chris Smith, I'm the Labour MP for Islington South and I'm gay," to a five-minute standing ovation.

He later said: "More is achieved for the sense of self worth of lesbians and gays in society by one person who comes out voluntarily than by 100 who are forced out."

Because he does not like to land unnecessary partisan blows, he has no mass political fan club.

However, he is widely admired outside Labour as a modernising, caring Christian socialist.

A keen mountaineer, he was the first MP to conquer all 277 of the 3,000ft Munro mountains in Scotland; a success that encapsulates both his gentleness and his rigour.

Still, Mr Smith can be battered about more than some cabinet ministers because he is in neither the Gordon Brown nor the Tony Blair camp.

He fell out with the chancellor when serving as social security spokesman in opposition, and relations with Number 10 have deteriorated since the Camelot "fat cats" debacle.

As a result, he often cannot secure extra Treasury funds for his pet causes - such as free museum access - or get the job he desires, probably in a high-spending department.

Born to a civil servant and a teacher in Barnet in 1951, Mr Smith went from George Watson's college, Edinburgh, to Pembroke College, Cambridge, where he gained a BA with first class honours and a PhD in Coleridge and Wordsworth ballads.

Like countless others who later entered the Commons, he became president of the Cambridge Union and was chairman of the Fabians.

At Cambridge, he also struck up a friendship with John Smith, leader of the Labour party from 1992 until his death in 1994.

Mr Smith earned his living initially as development secretary at the Shaftesbury society, which provided sheltered housing for the elderly and disabled.

He had a turbulent initiation into politics after being elected as an Islington councillor in 1978, losing his post as chief whip when rightwing Labour councillors defected to the SDP.

He won his local seat, Islington South, in 1983, narrowly defeating SDP defector George Cunningham.

In 1987, he held on to the seat by another tiny margin and must have been relieved in 1992, when his majority soared above 10,000 and remained the same in 1997.

In parliament, Mr Smith rose through the ranks, shining as shadow chief secretary to the Treasury before 1992 and damaging the Tories as shadow health secretary before 1997.

He had good cause to expect to take on that job after New Labour's election triumph but, instead, was handed unexpectedly the task of reforming the then Department of National Heritage.

Since 1997 Mr Smith's local council has gone Lib Dem but there seems no reason why his seat should do so.

Less certain is his ministerial future.

After four quietly successful years at the Department of Culture, where he avoided becoming tainted with the calamity of the Millennium Dome (he opposed it), Mr Smith has neither fallen apart nor laid siege to the high offices of state.

The prime minister may leave him in place for now, an easy sacrificial victim should a cabinet vacancy be required urgently in the years ahead.

Quotes
Independent on Sunday: "Nobody doubts Chris Smith's intellectual prowess; but some wonder whether he is just too nice to stand up to the party's vested interests and suspect he lacks the killer instinct."

Chris Smith: "My name is Chris Smith, I'm the Labour MP for Islington South and I'm gay."

fields.headline: Corrie scores for ITV2
fields.trailText:
4.15pm: ITV2 pulled in its highest-ever ratings figures with a premiere of Coronation Street, writes Claire Cozens.
Mar 8: Bragg hails Corrie as 'people's art form'
Nov 20: Coronation Street to premiere on ITV2
fields.body:
ITV2 pulled in nearly half-a-million viewers, its highest-ever ratings figures, for a first-run episode of Coronation Street on Wednesday night.

The Wednesday night episode of the soap was premiered on ITV2 to make way for ITV's live coverage of the Champions League match between Manchester United and Panathinaikos.

The half-hour broadcast attracted 457,400 viewers.

The figures mean that ITV2 was the sixth most popular station across the country for from 7.30-8pm.

The ITV showing of Coronation Street, shown at 9.45pm, attracted 9.8m viewers.

It is the fifth time viewers have been able to see Coronation Street on ITV2 before it appeared on the main channel, all on nights when ITV was showing live Champions League matches.

ITV2 will be premiering further editions of the soap on Champions League nights in April and May.

Related stories

fields.headline: Missed chances to tackle the conundrum that is Collymore
fields.trailText: When I heard on Wednesday that Stan Collymore had retired, I couldn't help thinking of what might have been. And, when I look at someone like David Platt, the waste seems even greater.
fields.body:
When I heard on Wednesday that Stan Collymore had retired, I couldn't help thinking of what might have been. His career was a terrible waste of talent and 10 years ago I was close to getting the chance to set him on his way.

When I was in charge of Sheffield Wednesday in 1990-91 we had agreed to take him on a week's trial from Stafford Rangers. He had been recommended by a friend as big, raw talent and I wanted to see what he could do. But before we had a chance to look at him, Stafford's manager informed Steve Coppell at Crystal Palace that Stan might be going to Hillsborough and Palace signed him for £100,000.

Because Stan was not someone we had been knocking doors down for, I brushed it aside as one of those things. But I did try to buy Stan for Aston Villa from Southend a few years later. Barry Fry was trying to get me to take him and I offered £1m. Barry wanted more but I wasn't prepared to go higher because in Dalian Atkinson we had a lad at the club who was similar. Stan ended up going to Nottingham Forest for £2m.

He did well there and I understand from talking to people like Steve Stone that he was hungry then. He was making his way, was on decent but not vast money and was trying to become the star. But once he went to Liverpool and got the status and big wages he didn't seem to want to put his back into it.

It's a shame because, if Stan had 25% of Dean Saunders' application and love of the game, he might have become the best centre-forward England have had since Geoff Hurst. His ability was fantastic and, when I look at someone like David Platt, the waste seems even greater.

David was the opposite of Stan. I had him as a teenager at Manchester United and he was a long way short of the young strikers such as Mark Hughes and Norman Whiteside. But I told Crewe's manager Dario Gradi to take him because he was an honest lad who might have a chance of coming back. David worked his socks off, applied himself and became England captain and a good goalscorer who never let anyone down.

Stan, on the other hand, let everyone down since the Liverpool period, including himself. I can't think of anyone who has had such massive money paid for him, been given such great opportunities and given so little back.

People often mark Rodney Marsh, Alan Hudson and Stan Bowles as under-achievers. Maybe they didn't get the bags of caps they should have but they all did their clubs proud whenever they pulled the shirt on. Dalian Atkinson may not have fulfilled his potential but he did well for me and never got loaded up with money or had vast amounts paid for him. He was a good lad but lacked the mental strength.

A player I get a real sense of "if only" about is Matt le Tissier, though he's achieved a lot more than Collymore. He's one of the biggest talents I've seen and I would have loved to have worked with him. At Aston Villa we tried very hard to get him. People have said Matt didn't have the drive but he had the ability to become the man England could have built a team round through the 90s. If he had gone to Manchester United when Eric Cantona went there, that could have been the catalyst but you were never sure whether he had the mental strength.

As I understand it, Collymore almost ended up at Old Trafford. I think he was ahead of Andy Cole in the pecking order of strikers Sir Alex Ferguson wanted in 1994-95. But apparently, when Alex was trying to buy him, Forest's manager Frank Clark was off with flu and Alex, unable to get hold of him, decided to take Cole straight away. That might have been lucky: if Collymore had gone to Old Trafford it could have been a marriage made in hell.

I know Stan had his illness but he messed too many people about. I remember from speaking with Roy Evans that he was supposed to move into the Liverpool area but never did and would miss training sessions. And I know senior players at the Villa were very disappointed when, out of the blue, he moved out of the dressing room at training and was changing with the young lads.

There were stories that he would be surly and skipped training at the slightest excuse. There were suggestions, too, at Anfield and Villa that he might have a bad influence on the younger lads.

Whether we've seen the last of Stan on a football pitch I'm not sure. I wouldn't be over surprised if he's just used retirement as a get-out-of-jail card at Oviedo because he doesn't fancy it. Yes, he's unlikely to find a club in England but with Stanley Victor Collymore you never know.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

Because Stan was not someone we had been knocking doors down for, I brushed it aside as one of those things. But I did try to buy Stan for Aston Villa from Southend a few years later. Barry Fry was trying to get me to take him and I offered £1m. Barry wanted more but I wasn't prepared to go higher because in Dalian Atkinson we had a lad at the club who was similar. Stan ended up going to Nottingham Forest for £2m. He did well there and I understand from talking to people like Steve Stone that he was hungry then. He was making his way, was on decent but not vast money and was trying to become the star. But once he went to Liverpool and got the status and big wages he didn't seem to want to put his back into it. It's a shame because, if Stan had 25% of Dean Saunders' application and love of the game, he might have become the best centre-forward England have had since Geoff Hurst. His ability was fantastic and, when I look at someone like David Platt, the waste seems even greater. David was the opposite of Stan. I had him as a teenager at Manchester United and he was a long way short of the young strikers such as Mark Hughes and Norman Whiteside. But I told Crewe's manager Dario Gradi to take him because he was an honest lad who might have a chance of coming back. David worked his socks off, applied himself and became England captain and a good goalscorer who never let anyone down. Stan, on the other hand, let everyone down since the Liverpool period, including himself. I can't think of anyone who has had such massive money paid for him, been given such great opportunities and given so little back. People often mark Rodney Marsh, Alan Hudson and Stan Bowles as under-achievers. Maybe they didn't get the bags of caps they should have but they all did their clubs proud whenever they pulled the shirt on. Dalian Atkinson may not have fulfilled his potential but he did well for me and never got loaded up with money or had vast amounts paid for him. He was a good lad but lacked the mental strength. A player I get a real sense of "if only" about is Matt le Tissier, though he's achieved a lot more than Collymore. He's one of the biggest talents I've seen and I would have loved to have worked with him. At Aston Villa we tried very hard to get him. People have said Matt didn't have the drive but he had the ability to become the man England could have built a team round through the 90s. If he had gone to Manchester United when Eric Cantona went there, that could have been the catalyst but you were never sure whether he had the mental strength. As I understand it, Collymore almost ended up at Old Trafford. I think he was ahead of Andy Cole in the pecking order of strikers Sir Alex Ferguson wanted in 1994-95. But apparently, when Alex was trying to buy him, Forest's manager Frank Clark was off with flu and Alex, unable to get hold of him, decided to take Cole straight away. That might have been lucky: if Collymore had gone to Old Trafford it could have been a marriage made in hell. I know Stan had his illness but he messed too many people about. I remember from speaking with Roy Evans that he was supposed to move into the Liverpool area but never did and would miss training sessions. And I know senior players at the Villa were very disappointed when, out of the blue, he moved out of the dressing room at training and was changing with the young lads. There were stories that he would be surly and skipped training at the slightest excuse. There were suggestions, too, at Anfield and Villa that he might have a bad influence on the younger lads. Whether we've seen the last of Stan on a football pitch I'm not sure. I wouldn't be over surprised if he's just used retirement as a get-out-of-jail card at Oviedo because he doesn't fancy it. Yes, he's unlikely to find a club in England but with Stanley Victor Collymore you never know.  You've read the piece, now have your say. webTitle: The Inside: (she goes to the parties so you don't have to).

fields.headline: The Insider
fields.standfirst: (she goes to the parties so you don't have to)
fields.trailText: (she goes to the parties so you don't have to).
fields.body:
In Milan, most foreign of the fashion destinations (no one really speaks English, there are never any taxis), the Brits always stick together. When Romeo Gigli invited everyone to dine at his huge apartment, a huddle of London's fashionistas formed around the buffet table, piling their plates with massive balls of buffalo mozzarella. Hungry after a hard day on the front row, they restocked their plates again and again, not knowing that what was on offer was merely the antipasto. When they realised their food faux pas, they just about managed the soup (carrot, served in a carved-out crusty bap) and pasta, but hid around the corner on Gigli's impressive leather poufs when it came to desert - a selection of cakes so big they had their own annexe.

The next night, with no major parties to attend, word went out to regroup in the Principe hotel bar. What started as a few glasses of kir royale turned into a drinks bill equivalent in cost to a Fendi fur. At the evening's high point (approx 1am), it was as if Sam Taylor Wood had been commissioned to photograph a tableau of everyone who wanted to be fabulous, as people from Gucci, McQueen, Armani and Prada gassed with every UK stylist and writer worth their salt. When the bar shut, the crowd dispersed, maybe first to crash UltraOzbek's impromptu party, then on to the room of Dazed and Confused editor Jefferson Hack. He has become quite a celebrity since he started dating Kate Moss, so everyone wanted to know, was she there? Was she modelling? The answers were obvious: no and no.

webTitle: Shot fired at Israel's new defence minister

fields.headline: Shot fired at Israel's new defence minister
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israel's new defence minister came under fire from Palestinian snipers today during a tour of Israeli positions in the Gaza Strip, witnesses said.
fields.body:
Israel's new defence minister came under fire from Palestinian snipers today during a tour of Israeli positions in the Gaza Strip, witnesses said.

Binyamin Ben-Eliezer, a retired general, was visiting troops in the Gaza Strip on his third day in office and was on the rooftop of a military base when a shot rang out and a bullet whistled overhead.

He was not wearing a protective vest or helmet, contrary to standing orders, Israeli reporters accompanying the minister said.

Security agents pushed Mr Ben-Eliezer back from the edge of the roof and urged him to put on a protective vest and helmet, but he refused, the Israeli reporters said.

The army's chief of staff, lieutenant general Shaul Mofaz and other officers hustled the minister downstairs. As he walked to his car protected by a wall of agents, another shot flew past, but nobody was hit

The minister had been visiting the army's divisional headquarters at Gush Katif, an Israeli settlement bloc, and the army's Gaza Strip commander, brigadier general Yair Naveh, was showing Mr Ben-Eliezer positions in the nearby Palestinian city of Khan Yunis at the time of the incident.

Mr Ben-Eliezer is a former commander of Israeli forces in the West Bank. During a visit to the West Bank earlier today, he said Israel is not targeting the Palestinian civilian population and that the new government of Ariel Sharon will try to bring the Palestinians back to the negotiating table. Meanwhile, in one of his first acts as the Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon sent a note to longtime enemy Yasser Arafat, the Palestinian leader, saying he hoped to establish "personal contact in the near future".

Mr Sharon did not demand that Palestinian attacks on Israelis cease before such a meeting take place. However, Mr Sharon has said formal negotiations can only begin once all violence stops.

Also today on the southern West Bank, a Palestinian man was shot and wounded by Jewish settlers, Palestinian security officials said. A Palestinian witness said the man was shot when he approached a settlement in the area.

fields.headline: Foot and mouth: record increases
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth crisis
fields.trailText: A record daily increase of foot and mouth outbreaks were confirmed today amid warnings of a "second wave" of the disease.
fields.body:
A record daily increase of foot and mouth outbreaks were confirmed today amid warnings of a "second wave" of the disease.

By lunchtime, 16 more cases had been confirmed, taking the total number of outbreaks to 122. Somerset recorded its first outbreak, at a farm near Axbridge, and there were further cases in several other counties.

The increases underscored the comments yesterday of the chief veterinary officer, Jim Scudamore, that there was no end in sight to the crisis which is thought to have cost the economy £1bn so far.

Mr Scudamore could not immediately give locations of the new outbreaks but said the main problem areas were still Cumbria, Dumfries, Devon and Wales. Outbreaks found in a new county are being given top priority.

He said of the new wave of outbreaks: "A lot of cases are coming in now and there's obviously disease in cattle."

A total of 73,000 animals have been slaughtered and 27,000 are awaiting slaughter.

When pressed on whether the disease was contained, Mr Scudamore said that there were no cases in which they could not account for how the area was infected.

But he added that if a new case was found and a link could not be established: "Then we have a clear problem."

Mr Scudamore also said that the disease was threatening the lambing season, warning that the "type O" strain of the virus was especially deadly to lambs.

Already there have been four or five cases of farms experiencing high lamb mortality. Currently 713 farms are subject to movement restrictions on animals, while 141 are under investigation by the Ministry of Agriculture.

Mr Scudamore explained that the current crisis posed logistical problems. He said in the 1967 outbreaks many of the cases were on small farms but now huge numbers of cattle were present on the infected farms.

"You can imagine the large problem we have in terms of moving animals and destruction," he said. "It is an enormous problem that takes huge resources. We are dealing with huge farms with a lot of animals so we have huge problems with disposal of carcasses."

One of the new confirmed outbreaks is in the parish of Shebbear, Devon and will force the slaughter of 300 sheep and 300 cattle. The total number of confirmed outbreaks in Devon is now 19.

This morning the Scottish executive confirmed Scotland's 13th outbreak at Kirtle Vale farm near Gretna in Dumfries and Galloway. Also included within the 10 new cases is a sheep farm in Arthuret, Cumbria.

The latest case in Wales has been found in sheep and goats at the Tawny Owl Animal Park, which is near another confirmed case in Powys.

fields.headline: Mandelson cleared over passports affair
fields.standfirst:
 Vaz also exonerated
 Mandelson hails 'vindication'
 PM rules out return to cabinet
 Lib Dem MP unsatisfied

Full text of Mandelson's statement today
fields.trailText:
 Vaz also exonerated
 Mandelson hails 'vindication'
 PM rules out return to cabinet
 Lib Dem MP unsatisfied
Special report: Peter Mandelson
fields.body:
The former Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson and the Europe minister, Keith Vaz, were today cleared of any improper conduct over the Hinduja passport affair by the Hammond inquiry into the case.

Sir Anthony Hammond ruled that it was "likely" that Mr Mandelson telephoned immigration minister Mike O'Brien personally about Srichand Hinduja's bid for naturalisation, the crucial alleged call that eventually led to Mr Mandelson's resignation from the government in January.

But Sir Anthony adds: "Mr Mandelson's belief that he had not had a telephone conversation with Mr O'Brien was honestly held."

The inquiry's main conclusion stated: "No improper pressure was brought to bear by any minister in respect of these applications."

And, the report says, "there is no evidence" of any connection between Mr Mandelson's contacts with the brothers over sponsorship of the Millennium Dome and their efforts to obtain naturalisation.

Speaking outside his Hartlepool home, Mr Mandelson hailed the report by Sir Anthony, a leading QC, as a vindication of his behaviour. "I am grateful to Sir Anthony for clearing my name and restoring my reputation."

He added: "Sir Anthony's report makes clear that I did not lie, I did not mislead, and I did not deceive."

Mr Mandelson said he regretted that there had been a "muddle" in Whitehall, which had led to his resignation. But confirming that he intended to continue as an MP and focus on his Hartlepool constituents rather than attempting to return to the government, he added: "I feel I can now draw a line underneath these events."

Speaking in Scotland, the prime minister, Tony Blair, said: "Peter has made it clear, and I have also made it clear, that there is no question of him coming back into government."

He added: "I've said all the way through that I think what is important is that the key allegation has been investigated thoroughly and has been found to be false.

Mr Blair said that he believed Mr Mandelson was a man of great ability. And he added: "I said to people right at the beginning that this was a tragic case, and I said I believed Peter would be cleared of any impropriety. And I am very pleased for his sake he has been and I hope he will be able to get on with rebuilding his life."

But with Mr Mandelson's reputation cleared by the report there are bound to be questions over why a minister who had done nothing wrong and was one of Mr Blair's closest allies, was forced to quit.

Norman Baker, the Liberal Democrat MP whose investigations triggered the inquiry, said many questions remained unanswered. He said: "We need to examine the ministerial code to see what improvements can be made."

As the affair broke, Mr Mandelson maintained he had no personal involvement in Srichand's case, a line that was repeated to MPs by the culture secretary, Chris Smith. Mr Straw then reminded Mr Mandelson of the phone call, and also told Mr Blair he had done so.

An early morning meeting in Mr Blair's Downing Street flat on January 24, attended by the cabinet secretary, Sir Richard Wilson, and the lord chancellor, Lord Irvine, appears to have sealed Mr Mandelson's fate.

Mr Mandelson offered his resignation later that day, accepting he should have made clear the phone call had taken place.

The Hammond inquiry, set up by Mr Blair , found that intelligence material about the wealthy Hinduja brothers - linked to an arms bribes scandal in India - was not passed to the home office.

And Sir Anthony says record keeping in ministers' private offices was "unsatisfactory" and needed shaking up, as does the procedure for monitoring telephone calls.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, promised to act on Sir Anthony's recommendations and said the affair had been "a personal tragedy" for his highly respected "colleague and friend".

Despite Mr Mandelson's comment that he did "not desire a return to government", bookmakers William Hill responded to the Hammond report by cutting the odds on him being re-appointed to the cabinet within five years from 7/1 to 5/1.

webTitle: A role model for parental leave

fields.headline: A role model for parental leave
fields.standfirst: If the chancellor really wanted to improve maternity - and paternity - leave he need only look at the deal enjoyed by one of his parliamentary colleagues, says university lecturer and new dad Sanjiv Sachdev
fields.trailText: If the chancellor really wanted to improve maternity - and paternity - leave he need only look at the deal enjoyed by one of his parliamentary colleagues, says university lecturer and new dad Sanjiv Sachdev.
fields.body:
Measures to help families were at the forefront of Wednesday's Budget. Both the length of maternity leave and level of maternity pay were significantly improved. Paid paternity leave will be introduced. These measures are much needed. When a baby is born, dual income households often become sole income ones, at a time when household spending soars. And the new rights and benefits implicitly recognise that there are some things more fundamental to society than the market.

The renowned social policy expert, Richard Titmuss, argued that the key measure of a society's level of civilisation was how it treated its children. UK child poverty levels are, by EU standards, a disgrace - according to the most recent figures (1998/9), some 4.5m children in the UK live in poverty. There is evidence that the death rate of babies in the lowest incomes areas is 70% higher than in the most affluent ones. Unfortunately, the new scheme still falls well short of what is possible, desirable and, indeed, of what government ministers enjoy.

Yvette Cooper, the health minister, was recently widely praised for intending to take up her full entitlement to maternity leave (currently 18 weeks - it will rise to 26). The fact that this is a news story is yet more evidence of the poor balance between work and life in Britain. Good luck to her - the cares and stresses of parenthood are enormous. (I became a dad two-and-a-half weeks ago and my life has never been more tiring, demanding or sleep deprived).

However, financially, it is much easier for Yvette Cooper to take 18 weeks' maternity leave than it is for most public sector workers. This is because the maternity scheme ministers have is one of the best in Britain, a model for other employers. Deriving from a civil service scheme, she will receive her full pay (£76,000 per annum) during these 18 weeks.

Sadly, other public sector workers are less fortunate. The midwives, paediatricians, health visitors, hospital administrators and cleaners helping the health minister during her pregnancy have much less favourable entitlements. The national NHS maternity scheme accords staff almost full pay for the first eight weeks and nearly half pay for the remaining 10 weeks. Many NHS trusts improve upon this scheme but none is as good as that available to ministers.

I must admit to a vested interest here. My partner works in local government with children with special needs. She gets the legal minimum - six weeks at 90% full pay and then just £60 a week for the next three months. Our lives would be much easier if she had the same entitlement as a minister. I could then afford to take up my legal right to parental leave. This is currently unpaid and, according to government estimates, a mere 2% of eligible men take up parental leave, while a third of women workers do so.

Most parents do not take it up because they cannot afford to do so. We must welcome, then, the chancellor's announcement that paid paternity leave will be introduced for the first time. However, it is likely that few fathers will be able to take up their new, two-week entitlement because the level (£100 a week) is so modest. If you work for 40 hours and are only paid at the new minimum wage level of £4.20, you will still earn £168 (albeit before deductions) - higher than the new paternity (and maternity) pay.

It is no accident that most public sector workers don't enjoy the levels of leave available to ministers, but an outcome of public policy. The state, as employer, can set standards, especially for the workers it employs. If the government wished to give other public service workers the entitlements it gives to ministers, it could do so. It has decided not to. So, while the government's measures should be welcomed, only when the entitlements for other public service workers match ministerial entitlements will my welcome be wholehearted.

 Sanjiv Sachdev is senior lecturer at Kingston University

fields.headline: Linda Grant in running for Jewish literary award
fields.trailText: This year's shortlists have been announced for Britain's major literary award for books of Jewish interest, The Jewish Quarterly-Wingate Literary Prizes. Now in their 25th year, the awards were set up to recognise books that bring Jewish themes to a wider reading public.
fields.body:
This year's shortlists have been announced for Britain's major literary award for books of Jewish interest, The Jewish Quarterly-Wingate Literary Prizes. Now in their 25th year, the awards were set up to recognise books that bring Jewish themes to a wider reading public.

The fiction shortlist is led by Linda Grant's Orange Prize-winning novel, When I Lived In Modern Times, and Lawrence Norfolk's melding of classical myth and the Holocaust, In the Shape of a Boar. Elisabeth Russell Taylor's collection of short stories and Mona Yahia's debut novel also made the list.

In the running for the non-fiction award are Michael Billig's study of Jews in popular music, rabbi Hugo Gryn's harrowing autobiography, Louise London's study of the British response to Nazi persecution and Mark Roseman's story of his relationship with a Holocaust survivor.

The judging panel is chaired by Rabbi Julia Neuberger, and the two overall winners will each receive £4,000, with £300 awarded to the runners-up. Former winners include Amos Oz, Conor Cruise O'Brien and Chaim Herzog.

The winners will be announced on April 30.

Fiction shortlist

When I Lived in Modern Times by Linda Grant
Grant explores national and personal identity in the middle of the last century, as a young Jewish hairdresser moves to Tel Aviv and becomes caught up in terrorism.

In the Shape of the Boar by Lawrence Norfolk
A dense, difficult novel opening in pre-history and closing in the near-past. Norfolk weaves themes of flight, genocide and betrayal set against the darkest events of the 20th century and the mythical world of classical heroes.

Will Dolores Come to Tea by Elisabeth Russell Taylor
The second short-story collection from Taylor, who has been compared to Jane Austen and Roald Dahl, examines cruelty and intimacy in contemporary life.

When the Grey Beetles Took Over Baghdad by Mona Yahia
Debut novel focusing on the vulnerable Jewish community in 1960s Baghdad; the adolescent heroine observes the rise of the Ba'ath party and its reign of terror, wondering if this means an end to 3,000 years of Jewish presence in Iraq.

Non-fiction shortlist

Rock'n'Roll Jews by Michael Billig
From Doc Pomus to Lou Reed and Bob Dylan, Billig examines the central part Jews have played in the history of rock'n'roll.

Chasing Shadows by Hugo Gryn and Naomi Gryn
Distinguished rabbi and broadcaster Hugo Gryn's autobiography examines first his childhood in Czechoslovakia and then his family's deportation to Auschwitz.

Whitehall and the Jews 1933-1948 by Louise London
A comprehensive study of the British response to Nazi treatment of the Jews, revealing the doubt and disagreements behind British immigration policy towards refugee Jews.

The Past in Hiding by Mark Roseman
Roseman interviewed Holocaust survivor Marianne Ellenbogen about her experiences, and after her death in 1996 found himself with access to her plentiful diaries and letters. This is both of a memoir of an ordinary woman in extraordinary times and an investigation into memory.

fields.headline: What the regions are saying
fields.trailText:
Regional development agencies
Vincent Watts, national chairman of the Regional Development Agencies, who also chairs of East of England Development Agency, welcomed the government's approach to setting targets for performance and said he looked forward to negotiating specific regional targets.
fields.body:
Regional development agencies
Vincent Watts, national chairman of the Regional Development Agencies, who also chairs of East of England Development Agency, welcomed the government's approach to setting targets for performance and said he looked forward to negotiating specific regional targets.

Resources to help the regional chambers scrutinise the work of the RDAs and the regional economic strategies were also helpful, he said. "It is important to emphasise that improved accountability is mutual between RDAs, which set the priorities of the regional economic strategies with partners, and the many partners involved in delivering the strategies."

National Housing Federation
Aaron Cahill, regeneration policy officer at the National Housing Federation, said: "The extra flexibility for RDA is to be welcomed, but there is a concern that the RDA will go for the prestige projects at the expense of some of the smaller but possibly more effective neighbourhood renewal projects."

British Urban Regeneration Association
John Walker, chief executive of the British Urban Regeneration Association, said: "Giving the RDAs more flexibility is very important - the whole essence of what they are trying to do requires greater freedom, but it's a pity they didn't introduce it sooner."

Centre for Local Economic Strategies
Tim Chamberlain, assistant director of the Centre for Local Economic Strategies, said: "There has been a lot of uncertainty about what would replace SRB, so this ending that uncertainty will be a help."

webTitle: Au revoir to France's far right

fields.headline: Au revoir to France's far right
fields.standfirst: The French National Front is preparing for political oblivion with this Sunday's election. But extremism is not yet extinct, warns Jon Henley
fields.trailText: The French National Front is preparing for political oblivion with this Sunday's election. But extremism is not yet extinct, warns Jon Henley in Paris.
fields.body:
No matter who emerges victorious from France's local elections on Sunday, the vote looks set to mark the long-overdue demise as a credible political force of a movement that, only three years ago, was a serious candidate for national power: the far right.

Before a single vote is even cast, Jean-Marie Le Pen's racist National Front has already lost its symbolic home of Dreux, the town that gave the party, then 10 years old, its first taste of electoral success in 1983. Now the Front is too weak even to field a list there.

In its southern strongholds, the far right will be lucky to hold on to even two of the four towns it captured to such consternation in 1995 and 1997 - Marignane, Orange, Toulon and Vitrolles. And almost everywhere, the extremists have had trouble meeting the requirement that parties must put forward as many men candidates as women.

As recently as 1997, the National Front won very nearly 16% of the vote in regional council elections. It held the balance of power in five of the country's 22 regions, and caused all kinds of havoc to the mainstream right by cutting shoddy secret deals with rebel Gaullist and UDF politicians eager to cling on to power.

At that stage, large numbers of journalists - this one included - were writing doom-laden analyses arguing that the Front had redrawn the map of French politics, leaving the traditional right in tatters and ensuring itself a major role in the horse trading that would inevitably follow the 2002 parliamentary elections.

On the ground, in the towns where it held sway, the Front was withdrawing leftist and ethnic publications from public libraries, renaming streets after eminent fascists, cancelling grants to gay film festivals, halting support for multiracial creches, and even offering a "baby-subsidy" to European-only couples.

Its stated policies, besides wanting to repatriate millions of immigrants, included giving native-born French priority in jobs, education and benefits. It was a thoroughly nasty movement, and just three years ago it could claim, with some justification, to have become a "party of government".

Then, the following year, the National Front split. Fed up with the embarrassing excesses of the hoary old paratrooper Le Pen, who was found guilty of assaulting a women Socialist party rival during the 1997 general election campaign and who liked to quip that the gas chambers were "a detail of history", the young and ambitious Bruno Megret founded the breakaway National Republican Movement.

Mr Megret may have seemed more reasonable. Educated at the elite Ecole Polytechnique, with an MSc from the University of Berkeley in California, he was the polar opposite of the party's president and founder. Smooth, colourless and a consummate tactician, he had orchestrated the Front's increasingly successful campaigns since 1988.

His racist credentials, however, were impeccable: he it was who codified the Front's "national preference" policy, in a 50-point list that drew heavily on the repulsive anti-Jewish laws of France's wartime Vichy regime.

When, with the support of many of the Front's leading lights, he launched his breakaway National Movement in late 1998, it seemed more than possible that it would rapidly sink the mother party and, with the altogether more acceptable Mr Megret at the helm, become an even more potent extremist force than the Front.

The reborn far right, Mr Megret declared, would not lose itself in in-fighting, self-congratulation and empty gestures of protest.

It would pursue its true agenda: to "reclaim France's sovereignty and defend its identity, send immigrants home, establish state authority, repress crime and delinquency, promote traditional family values, and restore the pride of every French man and woman in the fact that they were born French".

Fortunately for France, Le Pen - who liked to describe his rebel lieutenant as a "petty, undersized psychopath with Napoleonic delusions of grandeur" -- fought back, in court and on the ground. The two parties embarked on a vicious and mutually destructive power struggle, turning their unique talent for hatred on each other.

The French electorate, some 30% of whom had at some stage voted far right over the previous decade, did not like it.

Very soon after the split, opinion polls were registering the combined vote of the rival factions as almost half that of the former National Front. The European elections the following year were a severe setback.

Even then, France's far right could have come back. Given a good deep recession, a resulting rise in anti-foreigner sentiment as unemployment rose, a few worrying crime statistics, the extremists could have prospered. Instead, the economy boomed, unemployment fell steadily, and a manifestly, joyously multiracial French football team won the World Cup and Euro 2000.

The mainstream left headed by the Socialist prime minister, Lionel Jospin, looks set to make some stunning gains in this and Sunday's elections, helped in part by the sleaze scandals besetting the traditional right.

The two warring parties of the far right, on the other hand, look set to lose their deposit in most of the towns in which they have managed to come up with complete lists (in some, they have been reduced to fielding candidates without their permission, triggering half a dozen court cases).

But for nearly two decades, rightwing extremism held a place very close to centre-stage in French politics. It has, however, left its mark, particularly on the destabilised and identity-less republican right. And sadly, there is nothing to say it won't be back.

fields.headline: Mandelson muddle fuels conspiracy theories
fields.standfirst:
The revelations in the Hammond report about Jack Straw's role in the cash-for-passports affair do nothing to quash theories that he is Mandelson's chief rival to be next foreign secretary, says political editor Michael White

Special report: Peter Mandelson
fields.trailText: The revelations in the Hammond report about Jack Straw's role in the cash-for-passports affair do nothing to quash theories that he is Mandelson's chief rival to be next foreign secretary, says political editor Michael White.
fields.body:
When Peter Mandelson's lawyer, Jonathan Caplan, protested yesterday that his client would have a good legal case for suing the government for constructive dismissal, he had clearly had time to read the Hammond report in full.

It was a fair point. Sir Anthony Hammond concluded that Mr Mandelson - "consistent and frank" - had not lied about his recollections of the phone call he made (or didn't) to Mike O'Brien, the immigration minister in 1998. He also reported that no impropriety took place with regard to either the Hinduja brothers' £1 million donation to the Greenwich Dome - or the phone call (or not) about the prospects for SP Hinduja getting his British passport.

So why was the Northern Ireland secretary hurriedly forced to resign from Tony Blair's cabinet for the second time? That, too, is a good question, so good that neither the prime minister nor his press office was prepared to answer it yesterday.

Instead they praised him as a man of ability who had done nothing wrong and must now be allowed to rebuild his life and career, not least as the Labour MP for Hartlepool, they added. It was said with every appearance of sorrow - the word tragedy was used - but the underlying implication was brutal: no way back for Peter, the man who, as much as anyone, put Blair where he is today.

In fact, the Hammond report is not so blandly evasive as the first glance suggests. It is true, as the No 10 press office stresses, that he was asked to inquire into the allegations ("tantamount to corruption" said Mr Blair) that the Dome link amounted to cash-for-passports.

But he does raise awkward questions over what ministers and officials did both in 1998 - when both Dome and passport were at issue - and in the weeks, days and hours leading up to Mandelson's dismissal ("resignation" is a euphemism) on January 24 2001.

"Muddle" is the kindest word deployed by Sir Wally - as his cricketing colleagues call him - as he accepts that everyone had acted honourably. Yet it is more complicated than that. The report accepts that Mr Mandelson "probably" did talk to Mr O'Brien about SP Hinduja's passport hopes, but says that does not amount to making "representations" on his behalf. Less charitable readers might assume that any phone call from such a source was a formidable "representation", no matter how little was said.

Surprisingly, he also sets out a letter Mr Mandelson, by now the rehabilitated Ulster secretary, sent to Jack Straw, about the third Hinduja brother, Prakash, in May 2000. He wanted - and got - a British passport too. No "representation", Sir Wally again decided. Yet he also reports irregularities in the normal procedures which govern passport decisions. The brothers had been rejected in 1998, partly because of the "good character" question (the Bofers bribery scandal in their native India), partly because they did not spend enough time in Britain.

In 1998, SP Hinduja was specifically in breach of an "unwaivable requirement" - to have been in Britain five years to the day before his application. But he got the passport. Luckily, busy officials had also forgotten to check with the foreign office's South Asia desk if there had been developments in the Bofers investigation: there had.

There are other intriguing strands. One official in Mr O'Brien's office claimed that Mr Mandelson regarded his chat with her boss as "private", a claim with sinister overtones which was emphatically denied by Mandelson staff.

One the other side of the muddle, Mr Mandelson was led to believe by both Mr O'Brien and Alastair Campbell, the No 10 press spokesman, when the trio spoke on a "conference call" on January 22, that there was documentary proof that the fateful call took place.

There wasn't as it turned out and, in any case, Mr Mandelson's belief on that point is challenged by the other two. It turned out to be crucial. Mr Campbell believed as a result that Mr Mandelson accepted that the call did take place and sought no further proof. Mr Mandelson assumed that proof existed.

So they all drifted closer to the edge - and he fell over. By the time the cabinet secretary, Sir Richard Wilson, had given Mr Blair his own summary (Annexe P in the report) several bits of muddle had conspired to make the prime minister assume his old chum was covering something up - as he had in not revealing his £374,000 home loan in 1998.

Sir Richard's memo is revealing in that it acknowledges a "slippery slope" - passports for help with the Dome - but backs the view that a phone call does not constitute supporting a passport application or making "representations".

"Not a shred of evidence of impropriety," Sir Richard told the PM who nonetheless got rid of Mr Mandelson within 12 hours. Curious or what? But so is the role of Jack Straw, the home secretary, whose past as a have-a-go-hero, tackling muggers in his constituency, is here relived in the role of Mandelson-tackler.

At several crucial moments Mr Straw's intervention ensured that Mr Blair and Mr Campbell were left in no doubt that the O'Brien phone calls took place and that he - Mr Straw - had recently reminded Mr Mandelson of the fact, not once but twice.

All in all a field day for conspiracy theorists who will see Mr Straw as Mr Mandelson's chief rival to be the next foreign secretary. Mr Blair wants to put it all aside and move on to the election campaign. He will be lucky.

fields.bodyText: When Peter Mandelson's lawyer, Jonathan Caplan, protested yesterday that his client would have a good legal case for suing the government for constructive dismissal, he had clearly had time to read the Hammond report in full. It was a fair point. Sir Anthony Hammond concluded that Mr Mandelson - "consistent and frank" - had not lied about his recollections of the phone call he made (or didn't) to Mike O'Brien, the immigration minister in 1998. He also reported that no impropriety took place with regard to either the Hinduja brothers' £1 million donation to the Greenwich Dome - or the phone call (or not) about the prospects for SP Hinduja getting his British passport. So why was the Northern Ireland secretary hurriedly forced to resign from Tony Blair's cabinet for the second time? That, too, is a good question, so good that neither the prime minister nor his press office was prepared to answer it yesterday. Instead they praised him as a man of ability who had done nothing wrong and must now be allowed to rebuild his life and career, not least as the Labour MP for Hartlepool, they added. It was said with every appearance of sorrow - the word tragedy was used - but the underlying implication was brutal: no way back for Peter, the man who, as much as anyone, put Blair where he is today. In fact, the Hammond report is not so blandly evasive as the first glance suggests. It is true, as the No 10 press office stresses, that he was asked to inquire into the allegations ("tantamount to corruption" said Mr Blair) that the Dome link amounted to cash-for-passports. But he does raise awkward questions over what ministers and officials did both in 1998 - when both Dome and passport were at issue - and in the weeks, days and hours leading up to Mandelson's dismissal ("resignation" is a euphemism) on January 24 2001. "Muddle" is the kindest word deployed by Sir Wally - as his cricketing colleagues call him - as he accepts that everyone had acted honourably. Yet it is more complicated than that. The report accepts that Mr Mandelson "probably" did talk to Mr O'Brien about SP Hinduja's passport hopes, but says that does not amount to making "representations" on his behalf. Less charitable readers might assume that any phone call from such a source was a formidable "representation", no matter how little was said. Surprisingly, he also sets out a letter Mr Mandelson, by now the rehabilitated Ulster secretary, sent to Jack Straw, about the third Hinduja brother, Prakash, in May 2000. He wanted - and got - a British passport too. No "representation", Sir Wally again decided. Yet he also reports irregularities in the normal procedures which govern passport decisions. The brothers had been rejected in 1998, partly because of the "good character" question (the Bofers bribery scandal in their native India), partly because they did not spend enough time in Britain. In 1998, SP Hinduja was specifically in breach of an "unwaivable requirement" - to have been in Britain five years to the day before his application. But he got the passport. Luckily, busy officials had also forgotten to check with the foreign office's South Asia desk if there had been developments in the Bofers investigation: there had. There are other intriguing strands. One official in Mr O'Brien's office claimed that Mr Mandelson regarded his chat with her boss as "private", a claim with sinister overtones which was emphatically denied by Mandelson staff. One the other side of the muddle, Mr Mandelson was led to believe by both Mr O'Brien and Alastair Campbell, the No 10 press spokesman, when the trio spoke on a "conference call" on January 22, that there was documentary proof that the fateful call took place. There wasn't as it turned out and, in any case, Mr Mandelson's belief on that point is challenged by the other two. It turned out to be crucial. Mr Campbell believed as a result that Mr Mandelson accepted that the call did take place and sought no further proof. Mr Mandelson assumed that proof existed. So they all drifted closer to the edge - and he fell over. By the time the cabinet secretary, Sir Richard Wilson, had given Mr Blair his own summary (Annexe P in the report) several bits of muddle had conspired to make the prime minister assume his old chum was covering something up - as he had in not revealing his £374,000 home loan in 1998. Sir Richard's memo is revealing in that it acknowledges a "slippery slope" - passports for help with the Dome - but backs the view that a phone call does not constitute supporting a passport application or making "representations". "Not a shred of evidence of impropriety," Sir Richard told the PM who nonetheless got rid of Mr Mandelson within 12 hours. Curious or what? But so is the role of Jack Straw, the home secretary, whose past as a have-a-go-hero, tackling muggers in his constituency, is here relived in the role of Mandelson-tackler. At several crucial moments Mr Straw's intervention ensured that Mr Blair and Mr Campbell were left in no doubt that the O'Brien phone calls took place and that he - Mr Straw - had recently reminded Mr Mandelson of the fact, not once but twice. All in all a field day for conspiracy theorists who will see Mr Straw as Mr Mandelson's chief rival to be the next foreign secretary. Mr Blair wants to put it all aside and move on to the election campaign. He will be lucky. fields.headline: The Hammond report in brief
fields.standfirst: Summary of conclusions from the Hammond Inquiry report
fields.trailText: Summary of conclusions from the Hammond Inquiry report
fields.body:
· The applications for naturalisation of Mr GP Hinduja and Mr SP Hinduja were handled properly and within established criteria. Certain aspects of the latter case should have been pursued more vigorously
· No improper pressure was brought to bear by any Minister in respect of these applications
· The enquiries made on behalf of Mr Prakash Hinduja were handled properly by all concerned
· Mr Keith Vaz made representations on behalf of both Mr SP and Mr GP Hinduja, but these were in the context of many other immigration and nationality cases in which he made representations. There is no evidence of any improper relationship between him and the brothers
· Mr Mandelson or his officials made or passed on enquiries to the Home Office on behalf of Mr SP Hinduja and Mr Prakash Hinduja. It is not possible to reach firm conclusions about the exact circumstances in which the contacts took place in relation to Mr SP Hinduja, but it is likely that Mr Mandelson spoke directly to Mr O'Brien
· Mr Mandelson's belief that he had not had a telephone conversation with Mr O'Brien was honestly held. Mr Mandelson did not make representations on behalf of either Mr SP or Mr Prakash Hinduja
· There is no evidence of any improper relationship between him and the Hindujas or of any connection between his contacts between them over the sponsorship of the Dome and their efforts to obtain naturalisation
· There was intelligence material about the Hinduja brothers, but this was not drawn to the attention of the Home Office and it, probably, would not have affected the outcome of the naturalisation applications if it had been
· In some respects, the processing of the naturalisation applications by the Home Office could have been improved, but systems are now in place which address these issues
· Record keeping in the private offices involved in the matters under Review was, in some respects, unsatisfactory and there is a need to address this issue and that of the monitoring of telephone calls.

webTitle: Questions left unanswered by the Hammond Inquiry

fields.headline: Questions left unanswered by the Hammond Inquiry
fields.standfirst:
Mr Mandelson quoted from the Hammond report several times in his doorstep statement in Hartlepool this morning. These are those quotes in context with analysis

The Hammond Inquiry: full text
fields.trailText: Passport application
fields.body:
Passport application

What the report said: "Mr Mandelson and Mr O'Brien behaved perfectly properly in the way in which they dealt with and processed Mr SP Hinduja's query about a possible change in the nationality rules."

This undoubtedly clears Peter Mandelson of the greatest cloud hanging over his name, that he interfered unecessarily in a passport application that did not concern him or come from his constituents.

Sir Anthony reports: "Mr Mandelson did not try to influence Mr O'Brien or his officials at any point and did not make representations on behalf of Mr Hinduja's application."

Again, this explicit rebuttal of the charge that the Northern Ireland secretary intervened in the passport process removes the taint of undue influence on a minister.

The dome

What the report said: "Ministers generally and Mr Mandelson, in particular, acted correctly."

This is a less than ringing endorsement of the role of Peter Mandelson when he was unofficial "dome minister".

Indeed, Sir Anthony goes on to say: "I have found no evidence either that the Hindujas sought to link these [sponsorship] discussions to their desire to obtain citizenship."

What Mandelson doesn't mention: Whitehall watchers are well aware that "finding no evidence" is not quite the same as the event not actually happening.

Also, Sir Anthony reveals that Mr Mandelson saw classified MI6 material on the controversial brothers before proceeding with their sponsorship of a dome zone, but adds "I find no grounds to criticize him on that score."

The Observer

What the report said: "I do not believe that Mr Mandelson was seeking to be evasive" [in his answer to the newspaper's enquiry on a written answer to Liberal Democrat MP Norman Baker, which sparked Mr Mandelson's downfall.

What Mandelson doesn't mention: Sir Anthony says: "It is not difficult to see how the Observer article, combined with Mr Mandelson's omission to mention the conversation with Mr Straw, may have given the impression that he had not given an honest account of his role."

Most significantly, Sir Anthony adds: "I have been unable to come to any definite conclusion about the suggestion that Mr Mandelson wanted his contact with Mr O'Brien kept private."

This does little to help Peter Mandelson's personal reputation for spin and evasion.

Conclusions

What the report said: "I do not believe that Mr Mandelson has tried to deceive anyone during the course of these events.

"Throughout his evidence to me, Mr Mandelson has been consistent and frank" and "[there is] no reason to doubt Mr Mandelson's honesty throughout the period."

What Mandelson doesn't mention: Sir Anthony makes a great deal of play of the fact that "record keeping in the private matters under review was unsatisfactory and there is a need to address this issue and that of the monitoring of telephonecalls."

Since nearly all Sir Anthony's conclusions are based on the available evidence, plus interviews with the main players, this seems to point to a verdict closer the Scottish legal system's "Not proven", rather than a resounding "Not guilty."

fields.headline: Report gives Mandelson no way back
fields.standfirst: The Hammond Inquiry: full text
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson has lost the battle to win his way back into the government despite today's Home Office report into the Hinduja passport affair, which will acquit him of lying to Downing Street about his role.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson has lost the battle to win his way back into the government despite today's Home Office report into the Hinduja passport affair, which will acquit him of lying to Downing Street about his role.

As Sir Anthony Hammond's report was received by No 10 - ready for publication at 9.30 this morning - sources made clear that Tony Blair will not give the man who was his closest political intimate a third chance in government.

"It's harsh, but it's inevitable. Peter is different," one senior insider warned as the Mandelson camp predicted that the Hammond report will contain nothing that justifies the sudden dismissal of the then Northern Ireland secretary on January 24.

Mr Mandelson, who will spend today in his Hartlepool constituency, is pessimistic that the report will be strong enough to persuade the Blair camp to admit publicly that they panicked and were wrong to demand his resignation.

Mr Mandelson will make a short statement today, but it is not clear what his next move can be. No 10 will argue that the wider background - including his resignation over the £374,000 home loan in 1998 - was crucial to Mr Blair's decision andbelieves the controversy will quickly fade.

Mr Mandelson's best hope is that Mr Blair will be willing to restate that he is a man of integrity, an endorsement he badly needs if he is to continue as a significant player in public life. The prime minister's aides have warned him he will be too damaged if he admits a fundamental error of judgment so close to the likely May 3 election.

Instead, Mr Blair will today use a speech in Inverness to try to move the agenda towards the big economic picture of the Britain voters want to see.

Insiders on both sides of the passport dispute last night played down speculation that the prime minister will be exposed to implicit criticism for discounting advice from the intelligence service, MI6, on the character of the Hindujas, controversial Indian millionaires engulfed in an arms-dealing controversy in Delhi.

Tory ex-ministers say Sir Anthony will show how MI6 would have steered Labour away from accepting their £1m gift to the Millennium Dome's faith zone in 1998, shortly before S J Hinduja finally got his British passport.

One Downing Street source said: "That is the single issue we are most worried about." As minister for the dome in June 1998, Mr Mandelson courted the Hindujas and also made inquiries through his private office about S J's chances of obtaining a passport, either indirectly through officials or in a brief talk with Mike O'Brien, then immigration minister.

At that stage he did not know about MI6's doubts about the Hindujas, though he was briefed in October when he entered the cabinet as trade secretary. Though it enhanced his caution, the report will say, it was not enough to pull out of the faith zone deal.

Sir Anthony will say the crucial phone call over the passport probably took place as Mr O'Brien recalls, but will not accuse Mr Mandelson of lying about it, as Jack Straw, the home secretary, later suggested on TV.

The Hammond report, drawn up after interviews with most of the key players - notably the cabinet secretary, Sir Richard Wilson - will not pass judgment on whether or not Mr Blair was right to force Mr Mandelson's resignation.

One Mandelson supporter predicted: "It's going to be like a piece of modern art; it says whatever the person who is viewing it brings to it." But he added: "If Blair knew then what he will know from the report, would he still ask Peter to resign? The answer must be no."

fields.headline: Nike creates brand tsars
fields.trailText: 1.45pm: Nike has created two brand tsars to oversee every aspect of the sportswear giant's marketing, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
Nike has created two brand tsars to oversee every aspect of the sportswear giant's marketing.

Two of the company's most senior executives, vice-president of Nike USA Charles Denson and vice-president of global footwear Mark Parker, have been appointed to the newly created position of president of the Nike brand.

The pair are Nike veterans, having both worked for the company for 22 years.

Mr Parker, 45, will take responsibility for all global product and brand management activities.

Nike's global marketing, sports marketing, research, design innovation and product creation for footwear, apparel and equipment fall under his remit.

He has moved through the ranks of Nike from footwear designer in 1979 to vice-president of research, design and development and then vice-president of consumer product marketing from 1993 to 1998.

Mr Denson, 44, will take responsibility for Nike's four regional operations and the brand aspects of the company's operations, including finance, human resources, IT, legal and strategic planning.

Denson's various roles within Nike have included vice-president of Nike Europe and vice president of US sales. He began his career at Nike in 1979 as assistant manager at one of Nike's original retail stores in SE Portland.

The regional vice-presidents of the US, Europe/middle east/Africa, the Americas and Asia-Pacific and global sales will report to Mr Denson. A replacement for him as head of the US region will be announced shortly.

"The appointment of Mark and Charlie as presidents of the Nike brand will focus significant creative and general management talent on the largest portion of our business that continues to have a great opportunity for growth," said Nike chairman, chief executive and president Philip Knight.

fields.headline: Bel Littlejohn
fields.standfirst: Guardian columnist and zeitgeist chronicler whose mould-breaking career blazed a trail through the British media
fields.trailText: Guardian columnist and zeitgeist chronicler whose mould-breaking career blazed a trail through the British media
fields.body:
Bel Littlejohn, who has died suddenly, was a lodestar of the zeitgeist, and the Guardian's most remarkable columnist. But although she shot suddenly to prominence with the 1995 emergence of her weekly articles, she already had a multifaceted career behind her, as well as a fluctuating number of husbands.

Bel's personal history was - like the zeitgeist itself perhaps - shot through with ambiguity. She wrote harrowingly of her mother's anguished death from secondary smoking and her father's murder at the hands of a racist. But on another occasion she mentioned in withering terms "a mum and dad still living a typically bourgeois existence dividing their time between Cromer and a timeshare in Provence."

It was held in media circles that her true father was the vociferous Sun journalist Richard Littlejohn, while her mother was that 60s writer Bel Mooney. Wallace Arnold, veteran opinion-former on the Independent on Sunday sometimes claimed: "I taught her everything she knows." But it was generally agreed that the most profound influence on the development of Bel's own imitable prose style was that of her godfather, the parodist Craig Brown.

At the time of her death, Bel was living in north London with her man and her two children, Marley and Bella. She had formerly held the post of youth and spiritual adviser to the new Millennium Dome (an episode of public service about which she was typically reticent in later months, although it was she in fact, who coined the innovative term Millennium Dome Experience in the project's early days).

She was visiting professor of media studies at the University of Oxbridge (formerly Thameside Polytechnic), where her course on Diana studies was mould-breaking. Her intimacy with the Princess of Wales also provided inspiration for the visual artist in Bel. Her installations - also mould-breaking - included the notorious Death of A Princess, (naked in an oxygen mask, and beside her a surgeon giving a stark, despairing thumbs-down). In her own words: "Shocking, yes. But death is shocking." She was twice shortlisted for the Turner Prize for her exhibitions, I Want To Die Now, Alone and Mouldy, Hating Everyone, Always And Forever (1993) and I Wish I Could Disappear Now And Forever Into The Ground, Buried And Forgotten (1996).

Bel also published her mould-breaking Weep No More, Brave Llama, (Bodyshop Press, £17.95) in early 1995. In some ways, that book must be seen as her homage to the artless vegetarian days of the 60s, for she subsequently omitted the title from her Who's Who entry, and in her first Guardian column demonstrated a new maturity:

"Along with Tony and Gordon," she wrote, "I want the workers in industry to realise that the way ahead is an economy which rightly cherishes enterprise and initiative not through the hopelessly outdated and irrelevant clause four, but through fruitful cooperation with management. What were once but the dreams of yesteryear are now, with Tony and Gordon and me and hundreds of ordinary people, soon to become glorious reality. Oz lives!"

She was a true professional. Only twice in more than 300 weekly columns did her copy prove unusable: once when she developed something of a crush on Jonathan Aitken and accused the Guardian, her employers, of "persecuting the poor, dear, misunderstood man", and once, towards the end, when she pitched into fellow columnist Polly Toynbee, dedicated enemy of the late Auberon Waugh. What lay behind this unsisterly spat was suspected by some to be a covetous wish on Bel's own part to inherit 'Bron's' vacant column at the Daily Telegraph. Yes, faults, she had a few. But death was unhappily to deprive her of the fruits of her late-flowering ambition.

Bel Littlejohn, columnist and zeitgeistist, born May 3 1995; died March 8 2001

fields.headline: Vaz cleared over Hinduja affair
fields.standfirst: The Hammond Inquiry: full text
fields.trailText: No evidence exists of any "improper relationship" between the Europe minister Keith Vaz and the multi-millionaire Hinduja brothers, the Hammond Inquiry announced today.
fields.body:
No evidence exists of any "improper relationship" between the Europe minister Keith Vaz and the multi-millionaire Hinduja brothers, the Hammond Inquiry announced today.

The Inquiry report concludes that Mr Vaz made representations on behalf of Srichand and Gopichand Hinduja, but said they were in the context of many other immigration and nationality cases in which he made representations.

Mr Vaz has consistently said he acted as a prominent member of the Asian community and insisted he did nothing improper in asking the Home Office when Mr Hinduja's application was likely to be decided.

Sir Anthony Hammond's report says Mr Vaz "categorically denied" that he had discussed the brothers' possible extradition to India over the Bofors scandal at any meeting with them.

He also denies passing secrets to them and said he would have referred them to the Foreign Office if they had raised the issue.

The report says there is no evidence that Mr Vaz had written to the prime minister or Peter Mandelson about the brothers' applications for naturalisation.

It says the MP made inquiries on behalf of both brothers, particularly Gopichand Hinduja. "It is true that Mr Vaz was probably more vigorous in his representative role than most of the other people who made representations.

"But I believe that it is legitimate to view Mr Vaz's role in the context of his unique position in the Asian community," the report says.

"I have been able to find nothing improper in his relations with the Home Office over these matters."

Sir Anthony said the Home Office official to which Mr Vaz had written and spoken to about the case had not felt he was put under "improper pressure".

fields.standfirst:
The Hinduja family responded to the findings of the Hammond Inquiry with a statement

Special report: Peter Mandelson
fields.trailText: The Hinduja family said: "We note with satisfaction that the Hammond Report confirms what we  have maintained throughout, namely that;
fields.body:
The Hinduja family said: "We note with satisfaction that the Hammond Report confirms what we have maintained throughout, namely that;

"The applications for naturalisation of Mr GP Hinduja and Mr SP Hinduja were handled properly and within established criteria.

"There is no evidence of any improper relationship between Mr Peter Mandelson and the Hindujas or of any connection between his contacts between them over the sponsorship of the dome and their efforts to obtain naturalisation.

"There is no evidence of any improper relationship between Mr Keith Vaz and the Hindujas.

"We welcome the thorough manner in which this matter has been investigated and trust that its conclusions will serve to put an end to this matter."

fields.headline: Flextech axes entertainment channel
fields.trailText: 1pm: Flextech has closed down entertainment-based TV channel SceneOne and laid off staff, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Flextech has closed down its entertainment-based TV channel, SceneOne, and laid off a handful of staff.

SceneOne, which was developed into a 24-hour TV channel on Telewest Digital in June 2000, will now only exist as an interactive channel and website.

SceneOne programming will be used on Flextech's remaining channels such as Bravo, Trouble, Living and Challenge.

Sources close to the decision said the move came about because of problems securing carriage on Sky Digital compounded by low audience figures.

Mark Bradford, general manager at SceneOne, denied there had been a problem expanding onto Sky.

"We conducted a review of SceneOne and decided to reposition it as a T-commerce [shopping through TV] hub, rather than pursue a dedicated TV channel strategy for it," he said.

SceneOne will now be developed into an interactive TV product that will sit behind Flextech's TV channels.

Viewers will be able to click away from the TV programming and go to an interactive area where they can view entertainment information such as concert and film guides, and go on to buy products.

Mr Bradford said the move made more commercial sense.

"This gives SceneOne access to 20m viewers a month rather than just 400,000. The key thing is to access big audiences in the broadcast stream," he said.

fields.headline: BoS to resume Abbey talks
fields.trailText: Bank of Scotland appeared ready to resume merger talks with Abbey National last night, encouraged by the authorities' concerns about the "substantial lessening of competition" which might arise from the competing bid by Lloyds TSB.
fields.body:
Bank of Scotland appeared ready to resume merger talks with Abbey National last night, encouraged by the authorities' concerns about the "substantial lessening of competition" which might arise from the competing bid by Lloyds TSB.

Releasing further information about its recommendation that Lloyds TSB's £19bn offer for Abbey should be referred for a full scale competition investigation, the office of fair trading said it was worried about the "elimination of one of the most significant branch-based competitors to the largest four banks".

These "big four" - Lloyds TSB, Royal Bank of Scotland, Barclays and HSBC - had 74.5% of the branch network in 1999, the OFT said, up from 72.6% in 1995.

The OFT said the attempt by Lloyds to take over Abbey - which called off its merger talks with BoS last week - would also "increase the concentration" in the market for current accounts, where Lloyds TSB is already the largest provider.

The OFT's advice to refer the bid to the competition commission was followed by trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers. The commission has until mid-June to submit a report to Mr Byers.

The OFT said yesterday that it regarded Abbey as a "potential competitor" in the small business banking arena because of its ambition to raise its market share from 1% to 5%. It highlighted the importance of its branch network in achieving this ambition.

Lloyds would close 600 branches two years after taking over Abbey, the OFT said.

BoS said it always regarded the Lloyds bid for Abbey as anticompetitive. "We believe in the strength of our commercial case for a merger with Abbey, but obviously you can not merge with a partner that is unwilling to proceed. We would have created a 'fifth force' that would make a significant contribution in challenging the position of the big four."

fields.headline: Lennon vows to play on
fields.trailText: Celtic midfielder Neil Lennon has vowed to continue playing for Northern Ireland despite suffering sectarian abuse from a small minority of supporters in a recent friendly.
fields.body:
Celtic midfielder Neil Lennon has vowed to continue playing for Northern Ireland despite suffering sectarian abuse from a small minority of supporters in a recent friendly.

Lennon was jeered by a small section of the crowd during the friendly against Norway at Windsor Park last week.

"Following lengthy consideration, I have decided that I wish to continue to play at international level with Northern Ireland," Lennon told the club's official website.

"The level of support I have received from all sections of the community has been overwhelming and very touching and has played a major part in my decision."

Lennon admitted that he had taken his time over the decision for the sake of his family and friends.

But he is confident that Northern Ireland supporters will get behind him and the team for the game against the Czech Republic in a fortnight.

"The decision I have made was not taken lightly as I felt it was important to consider the feelings of my family and friends as they had been through a very traumatic experience.

"Obviously I hope that they and myself do not have to suffer under these circumstances again.

"I am proud to be a Celtic player and I am enjoying my time at the club very much.

"I hope that in the future I will be given the opportunity, as a Celtic player, to also enjoy my international career.

"I would urge all Northern Ireland supporters to come and give the team their full support for our forthcoming match against the Czech Republic."

"The decision I have made was not taken lightly as I felt it was important to consider the feelings of my family and friends as they had been through a very traumatic experience. "Obviously I hope that they and myself do not have to suffer under these circumstances again. "I am proud to be a Celtic player and I am enjoying my time at the club very much. "I hope that in the future I will be given the opportunity, as a Celtic player, to also enjoy my international career. "I would urge all Northern Ireland supporters to come and give the team their full support for our forthcoming match against the Czech Republic."
