webTitle: Bush shows cold shoulder across the Pacific

fields.headline: Bush shows a cold shoulder in place of Clinton's hands across the Pacific
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: President George Bush has made it clear that he is not interested in continuing the Clinton administration's policy of cautious detente with North Korea.
fields.body:
President George Bush has made it clear that he is not interested in continuing the Clinton administration's policy of cautious detente with North Korea.

The change comes as China says it is increasing its defence spending because it believes that the Washington is hardening its stance in favour of Taiwan.

Mr Bush made his position known during talks at the White House on Wednesday with the president of South Korea, Kim Dae-jung, who favours detente and hoped to win Mr Bush's backing for his "sunshine policy" towards the communist regime in the north.

But Mr Bush told Mr Kim that he had no plans to resume discussing missiles with North Korea in the foreseeable future.

This marks a sharp change from Mr Clinton's two-year effort to head off a threatened military build-up in the north and work towards the restoration of normal relations between Washington and Pyongyang.

Mr Bush's stance has stirred speculation in Washington that he wants to freeze out North Korea to justify his government's planned national missile defence (NMD) shield.

The justification offered for NMD in 1999 was that the US faced a threat from North Korea's missile programme.

As well as delivering a serious blow to Mr Kim's efforts to negotiate a broad peace between the two Koreas, Mr Bush appeared to put him at odds with his own secretary of state, Colin Powell, who said on Tuesday that he hoped "to pick up where President Clinton and his administration left off".

But Mr Powell emerged from the Bush-Kim meeting calling Pyongyang "a threat" whose intentions nobody should be naive about.

The president's uncompromising position towards North Korea is a sign that the hardliners around him - including on this issue the national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice - have gained the upper hand in policy-making towards the region.

In a speech last year Ms Rice called North Korea "the road kill of history".

She was behind the Bush administration's recent decision to reintroduce the term "rogue states", which the Clinton administration dropped in its final year.

Before Mr Kim arrived in Washington his advisers argued that North Korea might retreat to its earlier isolationist positions if it concluded that the Bush administration was dropping the policy of engagement.

Mr Clinton had hoped to make a landmark visit to Pyongyang at the end of his presidency to meet the northern leader, Kim Jong-il.

Last week he said he would almost certainly have made this visit had it not been for the 36-day dispute over the outcome of the presidential election.

After meeting Kim Dae-jong this week, Mr Bush said he was "concerned about the fact that the North Koreans are shipping arms around the world".

"We want to make sure that their ability to develop and spread weapons of mass destruction was in fact stopped and that we could verify that in fact they had stopped it," he said.

"We're not certain as to whether or not they're keeping all terms of all agreements."

There is one agreement between the US and North Korea there is one agreement, the 1994 accord which ended Pyongyang's processing of plutonium at a suspected nuclear weapons plant.

US officials told the New York Times yesterday that there was no evidence that North Korea was violating the terms of this agreement.

Washington's harder stance against North Korea became apparent just after China announced this week that it would increase its defence spending by 17.7% to cope with what it described as "drastic changes" in the global military balance.

In a speech on Tuesday, the finance minister, Xiang Huaicheng, unveiled plans for China's biggest increase in military spending in real terms for 20 years.

He said this was "to meet the drastic changes in the military situation around the world and prepare for defence and combat given the conditions of modern technology, especially high technology."

China's military spending has been growing for several years; last year's announced increase was more than 12%.

Officially, the lastest rise will would make the country's total defence budget $17.2bn (£11.5bn) next year, compared with Mr Bush's requested Pentagon budget for 2002 of $310bn. But experts believe that China keeps most of its military spending secret, and that the real figure is more like $70bn-$80bn.

Whatever the realities of the spending, this week's Beijing announcement serves to pass the message that China believes it must prepare for a coming conflict with the US over Taiwan, whose independent status many in the administration wish to protect with a sea and space based missile shield.

webTitle: In brief: Eddie Murphy believes in Shrek

fields.headline: Eddie Murphy believes in Shrek
fields.standfirst: Plus: Tiger leaps into film production; cast list for Matrix sequels continues to grow; Tilda Swinton joins Hollywood's finest for Spike Jonze
fields.trailText: Plus: Tiger leaps into film production; cast list for Matrix sequels continues to grow; Tilda Swinton joins Hollywood's finest for Spike Jonze
fields.body:
 According to ananova, Eddie Murphy has recorded a version of the classic Monkees song I'm a Believer as part of the soundtrack to the film Shrek. Murphy provides the voice of a donkey for the animated film, to be released in the UK in June, which also stars Mike Myers and Cameron Diaz.

 Tiger Aspect Pictures has unveiled a new raft of films following the success of Billy Elliot, Kevin and Perry Go Large and Bean. After scoring three hits out of three, the film arm of the well known television production company is keen to develop more projects. According to Screen Daily, Steve Bendelack of The League of Gentleman is now on board to direct a "darkly funny road movie" called Driving Big Davie, while Tiger is also developing a family-oriented story and a sci-fi horror title, Cyclops. Other projects include The Suitcase Kid, based on a book by children's writer Jacqueline Wilson, and Plastic Paddy, a romantic comedy. Tiger is also set to collaborate with Film Four on horror title The Visitor.

 Harold Perrineau (last seen as a drag queen in Woman on Top) and martial arts expert Daniel Bernhardt are the latest actors to join the cast of the next two instalments of the Matrix. The Hollywood Reporter says that the nature of their involvement is being kept under wraps, but it is known that Bernhardt will play bad-guy agent Johnson.

 British actress Tilda Swinton has been added to the cast of Adaptation. According to the Hollywood Reporter, Swinton will play a studio executive who hires a sexually frustrated screenwriter to script a big-screen adaptation of a novel. Nicolas Cage and Meryl Streep head the cast of the film, which is to be directed by Being John Malkovich's Spike Jonze.

 More news about Adaptation.

fields.headline: Anti-obesity drug available on NHS
fields.trailText: The controversial anti-obesity drug Orlistat should be prescribed on the NHS, a government body ruled today.
fields.body:
The controversial anti-obesity drug Orlistat should be prescribed on the NHS, a government body ruled today.

However, patients in England and Wales will only receive the drug if they fulfil criteria laid down by the National Institute for Clinical Excellence (Nice).

Adults must have lost at 2.5kg by dieting and exercise in the month prior to receiving the first prescription of Orlistat, which is traded under the name Xenical.

They must also have a body mass index (their weight in kg divided by their height in metres squared) of at least 28 and have another serious illness such as diabetes or high blood pressure, or have a BMI of 30 with no other associated illnesses.

Nice estimate that the recommendations will mean 11,000 more people in England and Wales will be prescribed the drug at a cost to the NHS of £12m a year.

Professor Peter Littlejohns, clinical director of Nice, said: "Today's guidance is another example of how Nice can help doctors and patients be clear about the value and appropriate use of a new medicine.

"Obesity has a major impact on a person's physical, social and emotional wellbeing and future health.

"Doctors and patients need to work together to manage this condition and today's guidance provides advice on the contribution which Orlistat can make."

The drug is the first anti-obesity treatment that does not work by suppressing appetite. Instead it works in the gut by impairing the digestion of fats and stopping their passage into the bloodstream.

The capsules are taken three times a day with meals and clinical trials have shown it to be highly effective in helping people lose weight.

One in five adults in the UK are classed as obese and 30,000 people die prematurely every year partly as a result of chronic weight problems.

fields.headline: Peak Practice enjoys good health in new timeslot
fields.trailText: 1pm TV overnights: ITV's decision to move Peak Practice to Thursday appeared to have paid off last night, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
ITV's decision to move Peak Practice to a new Thursday evening slot appeared to have paid off last night, with the syrupy medical drama helping the channel to a peaktime victory over BBC1.

The long-running series proved a popular alternative to a diet of football on BBC1, where the evening schedule comprised a two-hour broadcast of Liverpool's quarter-final Uefa Cup match against Porto.

Peak Practice's ratings reached 7.8m, 400,000 more than in its previous Tuesday evening slot, helped by a lead-in from Who Wants to be a Millionaire?.

The ever-popular quiz show attracted over 10m viewers to give it a 42% share, according to unofficial overnight figures.

By contrast the BBC's Match of the Day, shown between 8pm and 9pm, brought in just 6.4m viewers to give it an average share of 27%.

The lead-in from Peak Practice also helped ITV's Ten O'Clock News attract more than 1m more viewers than the BBC's version.

Elsewhere, the viewers who tuned in to the return of Crossroads at the beginning of the week appear to be drifting away.

The lunchtime broadcast brought in 1.5m viewers, down from 1.7m on Wednesday while the early evening showing attracted 2.5m viewers, down from 2.8m.

BBC2, forced to find a last-minute replacement for its planned broadcast from the cancelled Crufts dog show, nevertheless turned in a respectable performance. Ray Mears' World of Survival attracted 2m viewers between 8pm and 8.30pm.

fields.headline: C4 and Emap shelve teen portal
fields.trailText: 12.30pm: C4 and Emap have put the brakes on a joint venture set up to launch a teen portal, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Channel 4 and Emap have put the brakes on a joint venture originally set up to launch a teen portal earlier this year.

But the venture, called Project Slam, has been shelved and bosses have gone back to the drawing board after admitting their ideas were not good enough.

They said the project would still continue but it was unlikely anything would be launched before the end of the summer.

Initial plans put forward by the team have been rejected by both Channel 4 and Emap, despite being nine months since the venture was first set up.

But Emap Digital chief operating officer Luke Alvarez said the project would still go ahead.

"We have a number of ideas in test and we are anxiously awaiting the results of those," he said.

"Once we have an idea that we like, we'll target launch for some time this summer.

"The trick with Slam is to find a competitive concept that works for both boys and girls."

The decision to rethink the project follows a sharp decline in the fortunes of teenage websites which has seen the closure of both Procter & Gamble's Swizzle and Unilever's Wowgo.

webTitle: Tourists breathe new life into Barnsley

fields.headline: Tourists breathe new life into Barnsley
fields.standfirst: Paul Humphries on how  visitors are flocking to South Yorkshire to fill an economic hole left by the demise of  the old king, coal
fields.trailText: Paul Humphries on how Barnsley has successfully turned to tourism to fill a hole left in the local economy by the demise of the town's coal industry.
fields.body:
Think of coal and you think of Barnsley: all pithead gear and muck heaps. It is a story that was for so long associated with the South Yorkshire town that at times it took on mythical proportions.

It was never a myth, but now it is just a memory. Apart from Arthur Scargill and a handful of officials in the old NUM offices, there are few traces of an industry that for more than 100 years provided a living and, in many cases, an early death to the people of Barnsley.

The muck heaps and the pithead buildings of the numerous collieries that surrounded the town have long since gone, the sites now lush green and landscaped. The only evidence of mining is the winding wheel and pithead gear of Yorkshire Main colliery, sited near the town's football ground, and left as a memory of when coal was king in Barnsley.

It was when the local authority was faced with mass redundancies from the pits, and a future as black as the coal it was famous for, that the council adopted a strategy that had many in Barnsley fearing someone in the council chamber had lost their marbles: Barnsley was going to sell itself as a tourist attraction.

Ann Untisz, principal development and promotions manager with Barnsley metropolitan borough council (BMBC), admits that some people found the idea of Barnsley turning itself into a tourist centre hard to swallow - and some still do. "But those that still find it hard to believe are not equipped with the facts," she says.

And those facts are very impressive. Research shows that 1,600 full-time jobs are linked to Barnsley's tourism industry and when part-time and seasonal workers are taken into account that rises to 2,200. The local economy benefits to the tune of a staggering £63m annually, provided by nearly 300,000 overnight visitors and two million day visitors. Not bad for a strategy that originally brought a few belly laughs in Barnsley.

Understandably, selling the town has not been easy. Other former heavy industrial towns that looked to tourism as a regeneration strategy had their history to fall back on. Wigan, for example, exploited its former industries of cotton and coal and the site of its famous pier. But Barnsley only had coal and the National Mining Museum was already earmarked for Wakefield. To have any chance of succeeding, it had to cast off its traditional image of flat caps and whippets and brass bands and bitter.

The local authority was not slow to realise that it needed the local business community on board. It set up a tourist forum which now takes the lead and numbers over 100 members, with only three representatives from the local authority. "That was how we wanted it to go," says Ann Untisz. "The local business community needed to be spearheading the campaign with our administrative and financial back-up and that's the secret of its success."

John Wigfield, a local hotelier, is chair of the tourist forum. He says: "We realised that tourists don't just sit on a beach, so we all came together and discovered what each of us had to offer. With the local authority we promoted the positive side of coming to Barnsley and we marketed it both here and abroad. It has been a phenomenal success."

Individually, the attractions in Barnsley may not make headline news, but put together as a package they have been a success story. Nothing is left out: the surprisingly vibrant night life of Barnsley, the wild moorland of the Pennines to the west of the town, historic houses, an ideal base from which to visit the shopping centres of Leeds and Sheffield's Meadowhall, everything that had a positive side has been marketed.

"Even Grimethorpe, where Brassed Off was filmed, gets tourists visiting it," says Mr Wigfield. "We even have businessmen and women who stay overnight for the first time and return later for a weekend with their families. Who would have thought that of Barnsley? Last year an Australian couple wanted to flee the pandemonium of the Sydney Olympics. Where did they come? Barnsley of course."

"It's not been easy," says Ann Untisz, "but we hope we are an example to other towns hit by traditional industries going to the wall. There is life after death and that lifeline can, surprisingly enough, be tourism. They should try it."

Other former heavy industrial towns that looked to tourism as a regeneration strategy had their history to fall back on. Wigan, for example, exploited its former industries of cotton and coal and the site of its famous pier. But Barnsley only had coal and the National Mining Museum was already earmarked for Wakefield. To have any chance of succeeding, it had to cast off its traditional image of flat caps and whippets and brass bands and bitter. The local authority was not slow to realise that it needed the local business community on board. It set up a tourist forum which now takes the lead and numbers over 100 members, with only three representatives from the local authority. "That was how we wanted it to go," says Ann Untisz. "The local business community needed to be spearheading the campaign with our administrative and financial back-up and that's the secret of its success." John Wigfield, a local hotelier, is chair of the tourist forum. He says: "We realised that tourists don't just sit on a beach, so we all came together and discovered what each of us had to offer. With the local authority we promoted the positive side of coming to Barnsley and we marketed it both here and abroad. It has been a phenomenal success." Individually, the attractions in Barnsley may not make headline news, but put together as a package they have been a success story. Nothing is left out: the surprisingly vibrant night life of Barnsley, the wild moorland of the Pennines to the west of the town, historic houses, an ideal base from which to visit the shopping centres of Leeds and Sheffield's Meadowhall, everything that had a positive side has been marketed. "Even Grimethorpe, where Brassed Off was filmed, gets tourists visiting it," says Mr Wigfield. "We even have businessmen and women who stay overnight for the first time and return later for a weekend with their families. Who would have thought that of Barnsley? Last year an Australian couple wanted to flee the pandemonium of the Sydney Olympics. Where did they come? Barnsley of course." "It's not been easy," says Ann Untisz, "but we hope we are an example to other towns hit by traditional industries going to the wall. There is life after death and that lifeline can, surprisingly enough, be tourism. They should try it."

webTitle: Ang Lee plans Crouching Tiger prequel

fields.headline: Ang Lee plans Crouching Tiger prequel
fields.trailText: After the huge success of the martial arts romance, Ang Lee is to make a follow-up which will focus on the high-kicking warriors played by Michelle Yeoh and Chow Yun-Fat
fields.body:
Ang Lee, director of the record breaking Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, has announced that he is working on a follow-up.

Following the success of the movie, the most profitable non-English language film ever, Lee has revealed that Crouching Tiger 2 will focus on the high-kicking warriors played by Chow Yun-Fat and Michelle Yeoh in the original. According to Page Six.com, the film will be a prequel to the ten-time Oscar nominee.

"It would be very expensive, everybody's going to charge me five times as much," said Lee. "We got all the equipment for half price. When we went on location, they thought we were a TV crew. That's not going to happen again."

Yeoh, recently honoured at the annual ShoWest convention in Las Vegas as international star of the year, said it was the emotional impact of the film which explained its success. "Crouching Tiger shows that it doesn't matter what the period is, it doesn't matter what the language is, as long as it reaches out to people, it will be successful."

Lee has two other projects to complete before he can think about shooting the prequel. One is a feature film version of the Incredible Hulk (see earlier story), while the other is a biopic of Harry Houdini.

 For more on Michelle Yeoh.

 For more on Chow Yun-Fat.

fields.headline: BMP bags £11m UKTV advertising account
fields.trailText: 12.15pm: UKTV has hired BMP DDB to handle its £11m account for UK Gold, UK Gold 2, UK Drama, UK Horizon and UK Style. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
UKTV has hired BMP DDB to handle its £11m advertising account for UK Gold, UK Gold 2, UK Drama, UK Horizon and UK Style.

BMP pitched against Banks Hoggins O'Shea/FCB and Duckworth Finn for the business, a joint venture between the BBC and Flextech.

"BMP understood our brand and had an immediate grasp of our needs," said UKTV marketing director Julia Weston.

"They have a clear understanding of our target market and our desire to build the brand beyond television."

Jorian Murray, client services director at BMP, added: "We are delighted to have the opportunity to work with the UKTV team.

"There was a clear meeting of minds during the strategic pitch process and we're looking forward to producing some truly outstanding creative work."

fields.headline: Britain told to take a breather
fields.standfirst: Talk about it
fields.trailText:
11.30am: The government is launching a £4m campaign to encourage Britons to take holidays, reports Claire Cozens.
Talk about it
fields.body:
The government will today launch a £4m advertising campaign to persuade Britons to work less hard.

The campaign, which breaks on national TV tonight, aims to let people know they are entitled to at least four weeks holiday a year - and to persuade them to take it.

It follows research that shows while Britain is the one of hardest-working nations in Europe, it is also one of the least productive.

Anecdotal evidence suggests the longer holidays taken by our European counterparts make them more productive rather than less.

"The government believes people are entitled to enjoy decent minimum standards at work," said trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers.

"We all know how much better we feel after some time off. Holidays work.

"It is important that both employees and employers are aware of the right to claim paid annual leave.

"Alongside measures such as the national minimum wage, the right to four weeks paid holiday will ensure that workers get the decent conditions of employment they are entitled to," he said.

The advertising, created by Ogilvy & Mather, takes a humorous look at the benefits of taking a break by showing how inspired people are when they return from holiday.

One advert shows a barber sculpting a surfer out of someone's hair, while another shows a supermarket shelf stacker building a version of the Eiffel Tower out of baked beans.

Adverts will appear on TV, radio and in newspapers for the rest of the month in a bid to raise awareness among workers as well as employers.

fields.headline: Rupert Murdoch
fields.standfirst: An online guide to Rupert Murdoch, who celebrates his 70th birthday this weekend
fields.trailText: An online guide to Rupert Murdoch, who celebrates his 70th birthday this weekend.
fields.body:
1.Many happy returns will be flowing in the Murdoch household this weekend as its head celebrates his 70th birthday.

2. Which house, however, remains uncertain. Perhaps he and wife Wendy Deng will mark the occasion in New York's SoHo - a former artists' district now home to the world's biggest media mogul.

3. In a long and varied life, he has achieved a near dominance of the Australian press, kick started the Times-led evacuation of Fleet Street and appeared in The Simpsons (which he owns.)

4. Rupert is at the centre of the three generations of Murdochs in the media business. Son Lachlan and daughter Elisabeth have both been brought up in the family firm.

5. His father, Sir Keith made his name reporting from Gallipoli and in later years owned the Adelaide News when it was the town's sleepy second paper.

6. Murdoch the younger took it over in 1952 and used the paper as a springboard for interests in books (HarperCollins), television (Sky, Fox), newspapers (New York Post, the Times) and film (20th Century Fox).

7. Many dislike him. He alienated Manchester United supporters when he tried to buy their club. Others simply believe he has too much power.

8. Want to be like him? Well, Rupert has plenty of words of wisdom for aspiring media moguls with an eye to the future.

9. Don't be a traditional conservative. Instead, start off by putting topless models in a daily paper (the Sun) and then fall over backwards to help the communist regime in China.

10. Follow this up by creating a "respectable" image. Admire the Australian university named after great uncle Walter and finally secure immortality with a chair in your own image at Oxford. Happy birthday, Rupert.

webTitle: Full text of Peter Mandelson's statement

fields.headline: Mandelson: 'I do not desire a return to government'
fields.standfirst:
Statement from Peter Mandelson MP today on the results of the inquiry by Sir Anthony Hammond into the Hinduja passports affair

The Hammond Inquiry: full text
fields.trailText: I am grateful to Sir Anthony Hammond for this thorough and comprehensive report which requires careful and considered reading. I have read it with a great sense of gratitude and considerable relief.
fields.body:
I am grateful to Sir Anthony Hammond for this thorough and comprehensive report which requires careful and considered reading. I have read it with a great sense of gratitude and considerable relief.

These are Sir Anthony's key findings in relation to my actions:

In respect of the passport application, Sir Anthony found:

 that "Mr Mandelson behaved perfectly properly"
 that "Mr Mandelson did not try to influence Mr O'Brien or his officials at any point and did not make representations on behalf of Mr Hinduja's application"

In respect of sponsorship of the Dome, Sir Anthony found:

 that "Ministers generally and Mr Mandelson, in particular, acted correctly"

In respect of briefing the Observer newspaper, Sir Anthony states:

 that "I do not believe Mr Mandelson was seeking to be evasive"

In respect of the whole chain of events, Sir Anthony found:

 that "I do not believe that Mr Mandelson has tried to deceive anyone during the course of these events"
 that "Throughout his evidence to me, Mr Mandelson has been consistent and frank"

He found:

 that there was "no reason to doubt Mr Mandelson's honesty throughout this period"

In sum, Sir Anthony's report establishes that I did not lie; that I did not deceive; that I did not set out to mislead.

I am grateful to Sir Anthony for clearing my name and restoring my reputation.

This was indeed a muddle rather than a misrepresentation and I would like to say how much I regret the part I played in creating this muddle.

I feel I can now draw a line under these events. I intend to concentrate on winning back the full trust of my Hartlepool constituents and serving in Parliament for another term. For reasons I hope people will understand, I do not desire a return to government. There are more ways to serve New Labour and to fulfil our ambitions for the country and that is what I intend to do.

webTitle: US cools on Nato role as conflict flares

fields.headline: US cools on Nato role as conflict flares
fields.standfirst:
Serb forces allowed into buffer zone between Kosovo and Macedonia after Albanian extremists launch attacks

Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText:
Serb forces allowed into buffer zone between Kosovo and Macedonia after Albanian extremists launch attacks.
Special report: Kosovo
fields.byline: Richard Norton-Taylor  and  Martin Kettle  in Washington
fields.body:
Nato yesterday agreed to allow Serb forces into the buffer zone between Kosovo and Macedonia amid alarm in the west about the activities of Albanian extremists threatening to engulf the Balkans in a new crisis.

Growing tension in the region, notably along the border with Macedonia, overcame American reluctance to allow the Serbs to enter part of the three-mile deep "ground safety zone" along the border with Kosovo, European diplomats said.

In Washington, fresh doubts emerged about the long-term commitment of the Bush administration to Nato's peacekeeping efforts in the Balkans. At a press conference with Nato secretary general Lord Robertson, the Pentagon secretary Donald Rumsfeld notably adopted a more cautious tone on US commitments in the Balkans than recent remarks by the secretary of state, Colin Powell.

In contrast to Mr Powell, who told Nato ministers two weeks ago that the US and its European allies "went in together and we'll come out together", Mr Rumsfeld said Nato faced "a difficult job" in the Balkans and refused several invitations by journalists to commit the US to "stay the course" in Kosovo.

There was a marked contrast between his downbeat comments and those of Lord Robertson, who called Nato's Kosovo peacekeeping role "a commitment we intend to see through".

Access to a narrow strip of land - where Serbia meets Macedonia and Kosovo - has been restricted to Serb paramilitary and border guard units armed only with light weapons. Talks are continuing between Nato and Yugoslavia about a phased reduction of the zone which was imposed by Nato at the end of the Kosovo war in 1999.

Over the past few days, ethnic Albanian insurgents have killed three Yugoslav officers in the Presevo Valley in Serbia and three Macedonian soldiers. They have used the zone to smuggle arms and men.

Macedonian troops and ethnic Albanian guerrillas clashed for two days this week in the Macedonian village of Tanusevci, just across the border from Kosovo, and on Wednesday, American peacekeepers in Kosovo were engaged in a firefight with gun men in the adjoining village of Mijak on the Kosovo side of the border.

Macedonian troops yesterday drove Albanian gunmen from their stronghold on the border with Kosovo, the defence ministry said. American troops in the area confirmed that the insurgents had fled, taking weapons with them.

The fighting started before dawn near Tanusevci when about 50 Albanian guerrillas attacked Macedonian troops, unleashing horses ahead of them to check for mines, defence ministry spokesman, Blagoja Markovci said.

Lord Robertson said the alliance "is determined that those extremist elements seeking to sow instability or to advance their political agenda by violent means will be stopped, whether in southern Serbia, Macedonia or within Kosovo."

Yugoslav president Vojislav Kostunica yesterday accepted the Nato plan to allow Serb forces into parts of the buffer zone. At his monthly press conference, he also delivered a bitter attack on Nato, saying its peacekeeping force in the Serbian province of Kosovo had produced "disastrous" results.

He accused K-For of failing to disarm ethnic Albanian guerrillas and of "stimulating instead of curbing" aspirations of a Greater Albania because it was too concerned about protecting its own troops rather than local people.

"Is Nato a military or a humanitarian organisation? What's the reason for its presence there?" he asked.

The Macedonian foreign minister, Srgjan Kerim, will attend a special meeting of the North Atlantic Council, Nato's policy-making body, in Brussels today.

Macedonia, whose population is about 30% Albanian, has called for the creation of a Nato-patrolled "ground safety zone" along its border with Kosovo to cut off supplies to the Albanian rebels.

Mr Kostunica also said he was optimistic that Yugoslavia would meet a US deadline to start co-operating with the UN war crimes tribunal, which wants to try his predecessor Slobodan Milosevic.

The US Congress has set a March 31 deadline for cooperation or its aid allocation will be frozen and Washington will oppose badly needed loans from international financial institutions.

fields.bylineHtml: Richard Norton-Taylor and Martin Kettle in Washington

fields.headline: Storm warning over nothing
fields.standfirst: Weather forecasters predicted a violent snow storm that never arrived in the north-east of America after a state of emergency was declared, writes Martin Kettle
fields.trailText: Weather forecasters predicted a violent snow storm that never arrived in the north-east of America after a state of emergency was declared, writes Martin Kettle from Washington.
fields.body:
Exactly a week ago today, those of us who live in the main cities of the north-eastern United States got a nasty shock. By Sunday, the local TV news reported, we would be hit by a winter storm the like of which few could remember.

It would be nasty. It would be brutish. And it would be long. The storm would continue for 48 hours. We should expect two feet of snow, and perhaps more.

At times such as this, the US weather forecasting culture goes into a full battle mode that has to be seen to be believed.

Rapidly changing multicoloured graphics ripple across the screen. Emergency messages interrupt your favourite sitcom. And the normal repertoire of weather speak mutates into a new and more apocalyptic vocabulary that is felt to be appropriate at such moments.

Storms don't approach in the United States, they barrel in. In American winters, snow doesn't fall, it dumps. Here, winds cease to blow and start instead to churn. Meanwhile, Americans don't prepare, they hunker down.

Boy, do they hunker. From the first moment that what inevitably was quickly dubbed "the perfect storm" appeared on the multicoloured radar, the local TV stations and the 24-hour cable networks dispatched reporters to stand in front of prominent local landmarks to describe the frenetic preparations that we were all enjoined to undertake.

The weekend supermarket shopping chores instantly became panic buying. At checkout counters huge lines grew up of people wheeling trolleys full of bottled water, gallons of milk, every kind of processed bread, batteries galore and enough food to feed large parts of Africa for several weeks. As ever, when the snow threatens, there was not a snow shovel to be found in shops up and down the Atlantic coast.

The snow was scheduled to arrive on Sunday evening, and on Sunday morning I watched as reporters from the Weather Channel positioned themselves in places like Times Square and the Washington Mall to look out for the first flurries. The reporters were always clad in kit that most of us would find excessive in Antarctica, hunched dramatically over their microphones.

In the background, doubtless to the mirth of the camera crews, guys in sweatshirts and jeans stood looking casually into shop windows and, on one occasion, even started to play a game of touch football. Didn't these people have any idea what was going on?

As it turned out, of course, they knew better than the forecasters. In Washington, at some point on Sunday night, it began to rain. The following morning, for about an hour, there was a flurry of snow on the wind. But it didn't settle. By lunchtime, the sun was actually shining from a clear blue sky.

But that hadn't stopped the airlines from cancelling flights, leaving bemused travellers standing in largely empty concourses watching the drizzle outside that had brought the nation to a halt. Schools across the north-east stayed closed.

Mayor Giuliani told New Yorkers not to clutter the streets by coming to work. In New Jersey they declared a state of emergency and then, rather ruefully, had second thoughts.

It has to be admitted, of course, that in some parts of the north-east, there was indeed a lot of rather unpleasant wet snow for a night or two. Somewhere on the Massachusetts coast there was some nasty flooding of a limited kind as the sea rose for a while. But for most of us the perfect storm turned out to be singularly imperfect. An awful lot of people had an awful lot of milk to get through before it went off.

These false alarms are one of the regular collective dramas of modern American life, and inevitably one wonders why everyone goes on participating in them when they must know, not very deep down, that the air of crisis is mostly unnecessary and excessive.

Part of the explanation, without question, is the influence of 24-hour news television, which treats these events with such earnestness that one feels under an obligation to swallow one's scepticism. When you keep on hearing the man on CNN telling you that it isn't snowing in Philadelphia, though it just might do so any moment, you eventually submit, and you nip out for an extra few gallons of milk, just in order not to embarrass him.

But there's also something magnificently, absurdly metaphorical about it too. Britain may have weather, but Americans have climate. It's them against the elements, proving to the world that the American dream is undaunted and that the Star Spangled Banner still waves through dawn's early light, and the disappointingly brief snow flurries.

The American faced with a winter storm watch is a bit like an American confronted with the prospect that North Korea might launch an intercontinental ballistic missile at Honolulu. Rationally, you know it isn't really going to happen.

If it is, then there's probably not a lot you can do about it anyway. It will either hit or it won't. But they both provide an opportunity for an act of conspicuous collective defiance before we all retreat in doors to watch the world end on primetime in our sitting rooms.

Or - as it turned out once again this week - not.

fields.bodyText: Exactly a week ago today, those of us who live in the main cities of the north-eastern United States got a nasty shock. By Sunday, the local TV news reported, we would be hit by a winter storm the like of which few could remember. It would be nasty. It would be brutish. And it would be long. The storm would continue for 48 hours. We should expect two feet of snow, and perhaps more. At times such as this, the US weather forecasting culture goes into a full battle mode that has to be seen to be believed. Rapidly changing multicoloured graphics ripple across the screen. Emergency messages interrupt your favourite sitcom. And the normal repertoire of weather speak mutates into a new and more apocalyptic vocabulary that is felt to be appropriate at such moments. Storms don't approach in the United States, they barrel in. In American winters, snow doesn't fall, it dumps. Here, winds cease to blow and start instead to churn. Meanwhile, Americans don't prepare, they hunker down. Boy, do they hunker. From the first moment that what inevitably was quickly dubbed "the perfect storm" appeared on the multicoloured radar, the local TV stations and the 24-hour cable networks dispatched reporters to stand in front of prominent local landmarks to describe the frenetic preparations that we were all enjoined to undertake. The weekend supermarket shopping chores instantly became panic buying. At checkout counters huge lines grew up of people wheeling trolleys full of bottled water, gallons of milk, every kind of processed bread, batteries galore and enough food to feed large parts of Africa for several weeks. As ever, when the snow threatens, there was not a snow shovel to be found in shops up and down the Atlantic coast. The snow was scheduled to arrive on Sunday evening, and on Sunday morning I watched as reporters from the Weather Channel positioned themselves in places like Times Square and the Washington Mall to look out for the first flurries. The reporters were always clad in kit that most of us would find excessive in Antarctica, hunched dramatically over their microphones. In the background, doubtless to the mirth of the camera crews, guys in sweatshirts and jeans stood looking casually into shop windows and, on one occasion, even started to play a game of touch football. Didn't these people have any idea what was going on? As it turned out, of course, they knew better than the forecasters. In Washington, at some point on Sunday night, it began to rain. The following morning, for about an hour, there was a flurry of snow on the wind. But it didn't settle. By lunchtime, the sun was actually shining from a clear blue sky. But that hadn't stopped the airlines from cancelling flights, leaving bemused travellers standing in largely empty concourses watching the drizzle outside that had brought the nation to a halt. Schools across the north-east stayed closed. Mayor Giuliani told New Yorkers not to clutter the streets by coming to work. In New Jersey they declared a state of emergency and then, rather ruefully, had second thoughts. Somewhere on the Massachusetts coast there was some nasty flooding of a limited kind as the sea rose for a while. But for most of us the perfect storm turned out to be singularly imperfect. An awful lot of people had an awful lot of milk to get through before it went off. When you keep on hearing the man on CNN telling you that it isn't snowing in Philadelphia, though it just might do so any moment, you eventually submit, and you nip out for an extra few gallons of milk, just in order not to embarrass him. webTitle: Rebels vanish as troops close in

fields.headline: Rebels vanish as troops close in
fields.standfirst: Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: The last remaining Albanian guerrillas left their Tanusevci camp by mule and car before dawn yesterday. Three guards using nightsights said they saw the sky light up with tracer bullets as the rebels withdrew from the camp, in sight of Macedonian army forward positions. Mortar fire could be heard several miles away.
fields.byline: Nicholas Wood  in Tanusevci and  Rory Carroll  in Debelde
fields.body:
The last remaining Albanian guerrillas left their Tanusevci camp by mule and car before dawn yesterday. Three guards using nightsights said they saw the sky light up with tracer bullets as the rebels withdrew from the camp, in sight of Macedonian army forward positions. Mortar fire could be heard several miles away.

The signs of a hasty retreat by the rebel group, known as the National Liberation Army, could be seen in the 30 or so houses that served as the guerrilla base. Green coats and rations were dumped on the ground next to trenches. In a former school a significant stockpile of weapons was left behind, including anti-tank mines, rocket launchers, mortars and dozens of boxes of ammunition. There was also a television camera and tripod, "confiscated" from a Macedonian television crew last month.

The sole remaining inhabitant of the village, a 74-year-old man, claimed to know very little about his erstwhile neighbours. "I believe there were some people up on top of the hill, but I never went out to have a look at them," Sy Rrustemi said. I've no idea why they were fighting."

US troops based in Kosovo yesterday moved in to take control of this key ethnic Albanian guerrilla stronghold on the boundary with Macedonia when 300 heavily armed troops from a US airborne battalion, backed up by helicopter gunships, started the operation early in the morning only to find the camp deserted.

At least 300 soldiers, including a detachment of Poles and Ukrainians, saturated the village of Mijak on Wednesday after four armed men were spotted leaving a house. Americans fired after the men waved their guns, injuring two and precipitating a siege of the house which was being used as a barracks.

Reinforcements sealed off the ridge, which overlooks forested valleys, as negotiators asked the rebels to surrender. They refused and a decision was taken to allow them to leave. "We estimate there were between 20 and 40 of them," said Major Jim Marshall, a US army spokesman. Major Marshall said the objective of ensuring a safe and secure environment had been realised and confirmed that the insurgents had nowhere to go but Macedonia.

US soldiers interviewed at the nearby village of Debelde appeared mortified. "You could say it's embarrassing," one corporal said. "I mean, they were trapped. We could have at least arrested them." A captain blushed when pressed on the issue. "We do what we are told to do. Or not to do, as in this case."

Nearby settlements were bemused by the ensuing blitz of Black Hawk helicopters and armoured vehicles that clattered over the ridges. Stunted oak trees, until recently covered in snow, have sprouted tiny leaves - a sign that spring, the real fighting season, is on its way, according to one shepherd.

"This means the Americans are still our friends doesn't it?" saidanother. He had been told that his heroes, K-For, who expelled Serb forces in 1999, had now turned against Albanian extremists. "That is crazy. The Americans are our allies and they understand that it is the Macedonians causing the problems."

The decision to deploy the US army in the region follows seven weeks of repeated clashes between the NLA and Macedonian forces in which five people have died, including three Macedonian soldiers killed last Sunday.

On Tuesday, a forward party of US special forces said they were fired on by the rebel group and responded, injuring at least two people.

"We've been very deliberate about this operation," General Kenneth Quinlan, the commander of US soldiers in Kosovo, said. "We've been in this area for a full 48 hours, clearly these guerrillas knew K-For was here."

While the success of the operation may help to repair K-For's relations with the Macedonians, it was also marked with controversy: the Nato-led peacekeeping force denied it had crossed into the country to undertake the task as Macedonia is outside K-For's area of operations.

Speaking outside the village school, which has signs written clearly in Macedonian, Gen Quinlan stressed: "No actually we're in Kosovo right now, we are of course coordinating the operation with the Macedonians."

Only a week ago, the head of the UN mission in Kosovo said there was no evidence to say that guerrillas were being supported from with in the province. Gen Quinlan himself seemed somewhat confused. "Who's right I don't know, the boundary agreement between the Yugoslavs and the Macedonians was only recently certified and I don't even have the decisions," he said.

Sniper fire

Advisers to the Macedonian president, Boris Trajkovski, said they hoped to send Macedonian soldiers into the village in the next few days. Skopje blamed rebels based in Tanusevci for a landmine attack on a military convoy that killed two Macedonian soldiers on Sunday. A third soldier was killed by sniper close to the nearby village of Mali Malina.

Nato had been under significant pressure to clamp down on the National Liberation Army, which it now admits was operating from within Kosovo.

But any hopethat Wednesday's operation would cripple the movement may be premature. Senior figures within the group say they have merely moved their headquarters to Mali Malina.

fields.headline: The guzzler
fields.standfirst: The taste test | Cheapskate | Quick bites
fields.trailText: The taste test | Cheapskate | Quick bites
fields.body:
The taste test: milk chocolate

Brand: El Rey Caoba
Price: £1.29/80g
What it's like: Class act from Venezuela; very refined; very civilised; slightly spicy.
How it rates: *****

Brand: Green & Black Organic
Price: £1.35/100g
What it's like: Chocolate depth-charge; packs real oomph; hint of cinnamon; potent stuff
How it rates: *****

Brand M&S Extra Fine Swiss
Price: £2.29/400g
What it's like: A bit sticky, but respectable chocolate hit at the end
How it rates: ***

Brand: Somerfield
Price: £0.83/200g
What it's like: Nice, middle of the road, middle class, middleweight number
How it rates: ***

Brand: Waitrose Continental
Price: £0.79/100g
What it's like: Very spicy; too sweet for its own good (or mine)
How it rates: ***

Cheapskate...Where to eat out for under £15

Carmela's, 28 George Street, Nailsworth, Gloucestershire. Tel: 01453 834802

Nailsworth is something of a gourmet focal point, what with a top class fishmongers and delicatessen, two decent butchers, an organic greengrocer and Carmela's. There are two Carmela's really, both warm and cosy - lunchtime Carmela's, which is a Cheapskate classic; and the evening Carmela's, which is a bit fancier but doesn't quite skate in on price.

But the cooking has the same vigour and colour and generous approach to portion control. There's a bit of the chicken liver pate and avocado and prawns variety (very superior versions, it has to be said), but inspiration comes from all over - meze, charcuterie, big gloopy salads, chicken stuffed with three cheeses & tarragon, mackerel with red onion marmalade, veggie options and top of the range chips. Superior cooking and a tasty wine list.

Quick bites ... Where to eat out in 15 minutes

HK House,12a Russell Street, Stroud, Gloucestershire. Tel: 01453 768833

Stroud is not what you might call a cosmopolitan centre, so it isn't the first place you'd think of looking for a nifty Chinese restaurant. But HK House is nifty, thrifty and really rather nice - none of your flock wall paper lark here. Clean lines, white walls, slatted banquettes and sassy lighting, it's modern metro classic. And the food's not bad either. Very old favourites, certainly: sesame prawns on toast, Peking duck, natch, kung po chilli, chicken/duck/beef/pork chow mein etc. But for a true quick bite there are noodle dishes of the chow mein variety, and shredded roast duck with rice and iceberg lettuce. The cooking is fresh and dependable. Vegetarian menu. Good value wines and charming service. It's not exactly revolutionary, but it's a great leap for Gloucestershire.

fields.trailText: Everton left-back Michael Ball will join Manchester United for £10m "in the next few days", according to Football 365.
fields.body:
Everton left-back Michael Ball will join Manchester United for £10m "in the next few days", according to Football 365.

Newcastle are lining up a £2m move for Hassan Kachloul, reports the Mirror.

Teamtalk claims that Parma and five other top Serie A sides are tracking Newcastle winger Nolberto Solano.

John Gregory is hoping to sign Morocco centre-back Rachid Neqrouz, according to the Daily Mail. The 28-year-old Bari player becomes a free agent at the end of the season, but Aston Villa have held talks with his agent in the hope of signing him before the transfer deadline.

Fatih Terim is likely to be named as AC Milan's coach for next season within a few days, reports onefootball.com. The website claims the deal was done after Terim backed down on his demand to bring seven backroom staff to the San Siro.

Slovakian striker Szilard Nemeth says he expects to complete a £2m summer switch to Sunderland after talks with Peter Reid, reports Teamtalk. "As far as I'm concerned, it's going well," the Inter Bratislava star told Teamtalk. "But with transfers, it's always a matter of reaching agreement and it doesn't always come easily."

Danish international midfielder Brian Steen Nielsen has rejected a loan move to Rangers, reports Planet Football.

webTitle: Style: The new Britalians. Jess Cartner-Morley on Luella Bartley.

fields.headline: The new Britalians
fields.standfirst: Luella Bartley was a London journalist. Now she's Milan fashion's hottest thing, says  Jess Cartner-Morley
fields.trailText: Luella Bartley was a London journalist. Now she's Milan fashion's hottest thing, says Jess Cartner-Morley.
fields.body:
There is a corner of Milan that is, currently, very English. Behind the fashionably matt silver gates of the new Bottega Veneta headquarters is a designer's dream space: light-filled workrooms, a catwalk theatre, coffee bar serving espresso in tiny egg yolk-yellow cups. The Bottega Veneta company, flying high on the back of British creative team Giles Deacon and Katie Grand, allowed an independent British designer, 27-year-old Luella Bartley, who happens to be Grand's ex-flatmate, to stage her Luella show there. Happily, the Moltedo family, owners of Bottega Veneta, don't seem to mind that their beautiful space has been overrun by "mad, English, scruffy teenagerey people", as Bartley puts it.

Bartley is, by her own admission, one of the scruffy people. She is also officially the hottest thing in fashion right now, bouncing from relative obscurity last year to closing Milan fashion week on Tuesday. Sipping espresso in jeans, flat boots and loose sweater, there's no denying that by Milan standards she looks unkempt, but it is evident she shares with her fashionable friends a semi-ironic love of luxury labels: the strap of a Prada camisole peeks from beneath her sweater, her plastic ponytail bobbles are Louis Vuitton. She is Nordic pale with salty blonde hair, invisible lashes and eyes the blue of Evian bottle tops.

Bartley has shot to fame as, in the words of American Harper's Bazaar, the "leader of the pack" of London's "junior style mafia". She is constantly described as "very London", though she is no more sure than anyone else what this might mean. "I couldn't say, it's just that London Chick label. In London you've got the best art, the best gigs. I get so much out of being in London that my stuff is bound to look quite London." Comparisons are made with Stella McCartney, who held the London Chick title before her, but Bartley's style is harder.

It is less than 10 years since Bartley moved to London to train at St Martins, and her first crack at designing was not a success. "I got incredibly intimidated by the place. Unless you're very artsy and conceptual, they're not interested. Try to make a nice frock and they're not having it, they want some madness going on. It's great if you're that kind of gay male designer, but if you're not . . . "

She changed to the fashion journalism course, took a work placement at the Evening Standard, landed a job and never went back. But after four years at the paper and two at Vogue, Bartley wanted a change. She turned to freelance journalism before deciding to become a designer a couple of years ago, "one drunken evening".

The journalistic background has made a difference. "A designer from a design background would start with a fabric or a colour, while I see the cat walk report in my head and work down from there. I see the whole image before I see the buttons. I put together an outfit for the catwalk in the same way I'd put together an outfit in the morning. That sounds a bit boring, doesn't it? But I wouldn't design something I wouldn't wear. All I really want to do is design jeans."

Through her link with Grand, who collaborates on Luella, Bartley had already used Bottega Veneta bags and shoes in her shows. The company are "really, really cool. Mrs Moltedo just said one day: 'Why don't you come and show in our space in Milan?' "

The Italian connection has proved lucrative. "The orders have been ridiculous. I'm getting single orders for £70,000 rather than my whole season's orders being £70,000."

Moving this season's show to Milan was a smart move. It has enabled her to escape the spectre of her inevitable replacement as London's hottest new thing: the London fashion world's attention span is nonexistent and there is no doubt that sooner or later another designer will be crowned The New Luella Bartley. "I don't think about that too much because it scares me. A lot of people thought this move [to Milan] was arrogant, but it's good to move on from London before they can get bored of you."

The autumn/winter 2001 collection, Looking Hard in the Yard - "I do like my titles, that's a journalistic thing, I guess" - is a "rude boy skinhead" look, with a bit of Buffalo thrown in. "It feels right because it's really hard, quite aggressive, quite graphic."

She bounces around the rails, showing me her favourite pieces: a denim mini with a double waistband, a Fred Perry-style top in cashmere, a tight black leather blouson jacket, "like hard skinhead girls used to wear". And, of course, some "fantastic" tight jeans.

The road from kooky young thing to established designer is perilous, but Bartley is in a good position to negotiate it. For now, her aim is "to be able to pay myself and not go under", but there are also vague plans to turn her London studio into a shop and to expand the accessories line begun this week with the catwalk debut of the Luella bag. Eventually, she would like to do "sunglasses and stuff. I mean, why not? It would be a laugh."

The journalistic background has made a difference. "A designer from a design background would start with a fabric or a colour, while I see the cat walk report in my head and work down from there. I see the whole image before I see the buttons. I put together an outfit for the catwalk in the same way I'd put together an outfit in the morning. That sounds a bit boring, doesn't it? But I wouldn't design something I wouldn't wear. All I really want to do is design jeans." Through her link with Grand, who collaborates on Luella, Bartley had already used Bottega Veneta bags and shoes in her shows. The company are "really, really cool. Mrs Moltedo just said one day: 'Why don't you come and show in our space in Milan?' " The Italian connection has proved lucrative. "The orders have been ridiculous. I'm getting single orders for £70,000 rather than my whole season's orders being £70,000." Moving this season's show to Milan was a smart move. It has enabled her to escape the spectre of her inevitable replacement as London's hottest new thing: the London fashion world's attention span is nonexistent and there is no doubt that sooner or later another designer will be crowned The New Luella Bartley. "I don't think about that too much because it scares me. A lot of people thought this move [to Milan] was arrogant, but it's good to move on from London before they can get bored of you." The autumn/winter 2001 collection, Looking Hard in the Yard - "I do like my titles, that's a journalistic thing, I guess" - is a "rude boy skinhead" look, with a bit of Buffalo thrown in. "It feels right because it's really hard, quite aggressive, quite graphic." She bounces around the rails, showing me her favourite pieces: a denim mini with a double waistband, a Fred Perry-style top in cashmere, a tight black leather blouson jacket, "like hard skinhead girls used to wear". And, of course, some "fantastic" tight jeans. The road from kooky young thing to established designer is perilous, but Bartley is in a good position to negotiate it. For now, her aim is "to be able to pay myself and not go under", but there are also vague plans to turn her London studio into a shop and to expand the accessories line begun this week with the catwalk debut of the Luella bag. Eventually, she would like to do "sunglasses and stuff. I mean, why not? It would be a laugh."

fields.headline: Oversubscribed
fields.standfirst: Spring's best buys
fields.trailText: Spring's best buys
fields.body: Since you can get Prada sandals a third cheaper in Milan than in the UK, shopping here is as important as the shows. Miuccia's multiple stores (there seems to be a Prada or a Miu Miu on every street corner) were everyone's first destination, with many making a beeline for the black-and-white striped sweaters, schoolgirl skirts and cone-heeled shoes that were criticised when they appeared on the catwalk six months ago. Callaghan was nearly cleared out, so eager were women to get hold of anything Nicholas Ghesquiere had designed for his last collection at the house, and at Marni's new store, fans of the folksy label were after the cute pumps in grey and purple. All these are tried and trusted labels - biggest revelation was Bally, the newly-regenerated label most famous for its shoes, but now doing a nifty line in clothes and luggage. Best bag was the shopper with abstract B print, in shades of brown or blue. To sound in the know, get the pronunciation right. It's not Bally to rhyme with alley - think baaaaarley .

fields.headline: Overexposed
fields.standfirst: The Davy Crockett hat
fields.trailText: The Davy Crockett hat.
fields.body: It's the endless show dilemma: you're watching clothes that won't be in the stores for six months, but you want the look now. What can you do? Copy the styling. In Milan, one unfortunate trend was the arrival of the Davy Crockett hat, which sat looking out of place on the girls at Prada. But what Miuccia says goes, so when Anna Molinari fastened her model's hair with real raccoon tails, some found the look too hard to resist, ran backstage and whipped the fur snippets out of the stylists' hands. The next lunchtime, as the audience waited for the Dolce & Gabbana show to start, the game was to spot those who had sneaked away with the tails. But when the show started, the back row was laughing on the other side of its face, as there was yet another Davy Crockett. It seems it's a trend that won't go away, but maybe if everyone can adopt it now, rather than next season, we can get it over and done with before it causes too much offence?

fields.headline: The Watcher
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Keanu is just so dull that his MO could be that he kidnaps women and then just bores them to death by emoting in front of them, or by doing his scenes from Much Ado About Nothing.
fields.body:
Keanu: Portrait of a Serial Killer has an unappealing ring to it. Yet this is what we're being presented with here. Hannibal Lecter gets a personality transplant from Johnny Mnemonic. This is a film whose release date was delayed from last week because it would have clashed with The Gift. That film, like The Watcher, has Keanu Reeves in an unwonted, indeed unwanted bad-guy role. The distributor evidently felt that two films in one week with Keanu as sinister psycho villain is too much. Actually one film in one week like this is too much. Or one lifetime.

Short of getting Angela Lansbury or Rodney Dangerfield or Lassie for the part, the miscasting could not be more complete. Keanu is profoundly wrong as a serial killer. The business of gloating over the serial killer kit (rope, chisel, etc), creeping into the defenceless woman's apartment, taunting the cop from the untraceable payphone - Keanu is not cut out for any of it, and the part pitilessly exposes his weaknesses: the reticence and ingenuousness that charmed in Speed and The Matrix are here just ugly and boring.

Anyway: Keanu is Griffin, the standard-issue serial killer who moves to Chicago from his LA hunting ground to torment James Spader, the cop who used to be on his case, until a mysterious, traumatic foul-up caused him to quit on a disability pension. Spader himself is supposed to be a mess: always falling asleep on his couch, developing a little light stubble, gobbling loads of pills and even injecting himself in the stomach - which gives him a nasty, livid bruise.

He goes for sessions with caring-yet-fanciable therapist Marisa Tomei and blubbers how it was his job to protect women from the killer and asks Marisa if she'd trust him if it were her daughter Keanu was threatening. "Yes, yes!" says Marisa passionately. "Yes, I would!" - thus taking professional supportiveness substantially beyond the call of duty. (Did she understand the question?)

But James gets his act together when Keanu starts whacking babes again: he sets out to get his man. Keanu is just so dull that his MO could be that he kidnaps women and then just bores them to death by emoting in front of them, or by doing his scenes from Much Ado About Nothing.

First-time director Joe Charbanic has obviously developed a taste for repeat-pattern atrocities. His next project is a series of videos for Keanu's band Dogstar.

fields.headline: Best in Show
fields.standfirst:
The dog-show mockumentary from the one-time Spinal
Tap guitarist is a genuine delight, says Peter
Bradshaw
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: The dogs themselves, as the film goes on, seem to be possessed of their own distinctively Keaton-ish flair for deadpan silent comedy.
fields.body:
That maestro of the Great American Mockumentary, Christopher Guest (Nigel Tufnel in This is Spinal Tap), has done it again. This is a little gem of a comedy, a film candidly and professionally structured around the business of getting real laughs with real gags. Using the genre's now richly matured techniques - talking-head interviews interspersed with pseudo- vérité footage of the principals - director and co-writer Guest tells the story of the "Mayflower Dog Show", following the fraught lives of the key competitors and their tremulous, talented pooches.

There's nerdy Gerry, played by Guest's script collaborator Eugene Levy with his lovely little Norwich terrier, Winky. Gerry has a particular cross to bear in the form of his delectable wife Cookie, a bottle blonde played with gusto by Catherine O'Hara, a bit frowzy, a touch blowsy, and alarmingly liable to be hailed at any time by one of her many thousands of ex-boyfriends.

Parker Posey and Michael Hitchcock play a couple of disagreeable yuppies, yammering and snapping at each other like frazzled mutts; they are stewarding the doggie stardom of their bitch Beatrice, with whom they are attending couples-plus-pet counselling sessions because of the issues Beatrice has after accidentally witnessing her owners experimenting with the "Congress of the Cow" position learned from the Kama Sutra.

Sherri Ann (Jennifer Coolidge) is the woman of a certain age who has become vastly rich through marrying an ancient squillionaire and now has the leisure and resources to indulge a passion for her grotesquely shaved and bouffant poodle, called Rhapsody In White, a passion she is cultivating in parallel to her tendresse for Rhapsody's female handler, Christy.

Then there is Harlan, played by Guest himself, and his magnificent bloodhound Hubert. Guest gives Harlan a down-home country accent from North Carolina, a world away from the Swingin'-Larndarn vowels of Spinal Tap's axeman Nigel Tufnel. (Although Harlan's slightly intense explanation of Hubert's telepathic powers is very reminiscent of Nige telling Rob Reiner not to look directly at his most prized guitar.)

Guest's Tap band-mate Michael McKean also makes an appearance as Stefan, the plump and beaming gay hairdresser partner of Scott, co-owner of a fluffily minute shih-tzu called Miss Agnes. John Michael Higgins plays this camper-than-camp part with what is effectively one long, delicious aria of fluttering queeniness, his every word a sulphuric bon mot of scorn for his competitors. (When he sees Christy shepherding Rhapsody around the stage, he snaps: "Look at her. She looks like a cocktail waitress on an oil rig.")

The universe that all these various people inhabit is very different from the wholesome rustic world of Robin Page and One Man and His Dog. The pecking order is entirely reversed: it's One Dog and His Uptight Minder-Person-Cum-Publicity-Agent. The atmosphere generated in the show-arena is weirdly like Vulgaria in Chitty Chitty Bang Bang - because it has no children. Instead, the dogs are the kids, a blatantly dysfunctional aspect of the event signalled by the fact that all the childless entrants refer to themselves, in the dogs' presence, as "mommy" and "daddy".

Comics like Chris Rock have used the dog as a jokey comic symbol for virility and penis size, and there is something of this droll sleight-of-hand in the fact that wimpy Gerry has the little terrier and tough old Harlan has the great lumbering, slobbering bloodhound. But basically the dogs symbolise their owners' abnegation of their sexual identities in favour of a very weird dual-eunuch parental relationship to their adored canines.

The main event itself is an uproarious finale to the picture, featuring a sublimely funny cameo from Fred Willard as Buck Laughlin, the announcer commentating on the action for local TV, insisting on using baseball metaphors from start to finish, and demonstrating a blithe ignorance of everything to do with pedigree dogs: "A miniature breed? How exactly do they miniaturise the little fellers?"

As in Spinal Tap, Guest demonstrates that in his own unshowy way, he is a very accomplished comic actor, never more so than in the heartbreakingly earnest way he jogs around the arena with Hubert when asked to perform a circuit by the judge - his jacket and shirt jiggling in time to the great loose folds of Hubert's glossy coat. The dogs themselves, as the film goes on, seem to be possessed of their own distinctively Keaton-ish flair for deadpan silent comedy.

They say the owner comes to look like his dog; this is a mockumentary which comes to resemble a sleek fox terrier, a nimble, agile little film: quick-witted, intelligent, responsive to the director's whistles and beckonings. Wherever the film's collar is, it deserves to have a large rosette pinned on it.

fields.headline: Born Romantic
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Occasionally, Kane's script swings along; but more often it clunks. The whole thing looks like a two-hour pilot for a Sunday night TV series in the Cold Feet slot.
fields.body:
Writer-director David Kane's chirpy, big-hearted comedy is a well-intentioned affair that I wanted to like. But it proved disappointing at the London Film Festival in November and, sadly, a second viewing can't shift that initial impression.

It is a film stuffed with award-winning British actors; some of them come and go in the blink of an eye. The formidably talented Jessica Stevenson, for example, has about one and a half lines. The same goes for a quite a few others.

It is set mostly in a salsa club, a convenient venue for lonely twenty and thirtysomethings to have zany meetings and mishaps and to fall in and out of love. Jane Horrocks is a tough single gal who will shag anything with a pulse. The reason? She's unhappy. The man who jilted her years ago, played by David Morrissey, comes crawling back into her life. Uptight posh bird Olivia Williams is propositioned by Sinatra obsessive and would-be Rat Packer Craig Ferguson. The lonely aspirational singles are ferried back to their homes by mini-cab drivers, one notably played by Ian Hart, a garrulous and faintly malign figure in tinted glasses, diverting his fellow drivers in the caff with his dodgy excursions into sexual politics.

Occasionally, Kane's script swings along; but more often it clunks. The whole thing looks like a two-hour pilot for a Sunday night TV series in the Cold Feet slot, in which some characters would grow on you - and some not. Its London locations, photographed by Robert Alazraki, are used with some of the same acuity and realism that Michael Winterbottom displayed in Wonderland. But, unfortunately, the comedy in the language and elaborate situations just seems forced.

fields.headline: Child heart tragedy fears
fields.trailText: A tragedy like that at the Bristol royal infirmary could happen again because there is still no satisfactory national record of the children who survive and those who die during and after heart surgery in Britain, a leading child heart specialist said yesterday.
fields.body:
A tragedy like that at the Bristol royal infirmary could happen again because there is still no satisfactory national record of the children who survive and those who die during and after heart surgery in Britain, a leading child heart specialist said yesterday.

The warning came from Stewart Hunter, consultant in paediatric cardiology at Freeman hospital, Newcastle upon Tyne, on the publication of a review he carried out with two others into heart surgery in Magdi Yacoub's famous unit at Harefield hospital.

Dr Hunter, together with statistician David Spiegelhalter and heart surgeon Leslie Hamilton, were asked to review the death rates at Harefield following allegations during the Bristol public inquiry that they were too high. Their report reveals that between 1984 and 1999 there were occasions when the mortality rate in what was "a small unit, chronically understaffed and underfunded" rose above average, but that Professor Yacoub and colleagues quickly identified the reason and improved their methods.

They describe Harefield as under pressure and yet taking some of the most difficult child heart cases because of Prof Yacoub's skill and refusal to turn anyone away. Yet Prof Yacoub and colleagues soon noticed if there was a problem. One rise in death rates occurred when two junior surgeons started carrying out a particular heart operation, so it was decided Prof Yacoub alone should do it.

It is a very different picture from the scenario at Bristol, where surgeons James Wisheart and Janardan Dhasmana failed to recognise that they were not performing as well as surgeons in other hospitals - even when other doctors raised it with them - and that too many of the babies in their care were dying. Both were disciplined by the General Medical Council.

Even now, six years after the Bristol scandal broke, there is no comprehensive and accurate database for surgeons to compare their results with the averages in the country. Prof Yacoub's unit recognised the occasional rise in death rates and took action to bring them down, but doctors in larger units where a rise in mortality might not be so obvious might fail to realise that too many children are dying.

"Producing this review actually proved to be an extremely difficult exercise because the two currently available national sources on clinical out comes - the Hospital Episode Statistics and the Cardiac Surgical Register - were found to be inadequate in providing accurate, verified comparative data which was understandable and usable."

He added: "This represents a serious gap in the system and means that the public might not be properly safeguarded against a repeat of a similar situation to that which arose at the Bristol royal infirmary."

Dr Hunter said he wanted to see the Department of Health invest some of the money being "lavishly" promised for the NHS into a reliable system of national and local record-keeping.

Mark Taylor, chief executive of the Royal Brompton and Harefield NHS trust, said it was "pleased to see that the evidence which suggested Harefield was a poor centre for paediatric cardiac surgery has not been borne out".

fields.headline: Peter Mandelson and the Hindujas
fields.standfirst:
Peter Mandelson, who resigned from the cabinet five weeks ago, has been cleared of wrongdoing in a report by Sir Anthony Hammond, published this morning. But questions still remain about the former Northern Ireland secretary's dealings with the wealthy Hinduja brothers, and Downing Street has made it clear that he will not return to government. Derek Brown and Julian Glover explain

Special report: Peter Mandelson
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson, who resigned from the cabinet five weeks ago, has been cleared of wrongdoing in a report by Sir Anthony Hammond, published this morning. But questions still remain about the former Northern Ireland secretary's dealings with the wealthy Hinduja brothers, and Downing Street has made it clear that he will not return to government. Derek Brown and Julian Glover explain
fields.body:
What does the Hammond report say?
The former treasury solicitor says he has no reason to doubt Mr Mandelson's honesty, and that he did not lie to Downing Street.

What was he supposed to have done?
While he was minister in charge of the Millennium Dome, Srichand Hinduja donated £1m to the so-called faith zone. Subsequently he applied for, and was granted with unusual speed, a British passport. So did his brother Gopichand. Mandelson was accused of lobbying the home office on behalf of the Hindujas, but insists he only made a telephone call to a junior minister to ask how the applications were proceeding.

Why did a simple phone call cause such a stink?
Because Mandelson did not clearly explain it, either to culture secretary Chris Smith (who had to answer a parliamentary question on the subject) or to the prime minister's office. The latter omission greatly irked Alistair Campbell, the Number Ten mouthpiece, who was obliged to make an embarrassing admission that he had wrongly briefed lobby correspondents.

Does the Hammond report mean that Mandelson will get a third go in the cabinet?
Absolutely not. After being forced to resign twice - the first time after the revelation that he had taken an undeclared £374,000 home loan from a cabinet colleague - there will be no third time lucky for Mandelson. fields.headline: 20,000 vote in interactive Budget poll
fields.trailText: 10.30am: Over 20,000 viewers voted in Sky News's first interactive vote for Gordon Brown's Budget, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Over 20,000 viewers voted in Sky News's first interactive vote for Gordon Brown's Budget on Wednesday.

In a new development that Sky is touting as a revolution for democracy, viewers of Sky News were able to use their TV handsets to register their approval or disapproval of Mr Brown's policies.

In the first hour after the chancellor delivered his Budget statement, 8,500 viewers registered their response to the question, "How was the Budget for you?".

Sky claims 41% of people said they were "very dissatisfied" with the Budget, while only 21% were "very satisfied".

The Budget also saw the first public outing of the Sky News Worm(Witness Opinion Response Monitor), Sky News's answer to the BBC's election swingometer.

The Worm charted viewer responses to the statement in real-time, and registered a sudden dip every time Mr Brown mentioned the word "prudence".

The Sky News Active vote is the brainchild of former Sky News deputy Jim Rudder, who was seconded last year to a new department to focus on interactive developments.
