fields.headline: Canal Plus braced for clear-out
fields.trailText: 10.30am: The future of French pay-TV station Canal Plus is again in doubt, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
The future of French pay-TV station Canal Plus is again in doubt as parent company Vivendi Universal prepares to unveil its maiden results.

Vivendi is expected to reveal today that subscriber growth has stagnated at Canal Plus, which will increase speculation of a management clear-out at the company.

Vivendi boss Jean-Marie Messier has been dogged by rumours of a deteriorating relationship with Canal counterpart Pierre Lescure, who runs a company which has yet to turn a profit.

It is reported that Canal expects 30,000 new subscribers this year, against 43,000 last year and 110,000 in 1999.

The latest figures would take the company's total customer base to 4.65m, but the slowdown in growth hints at saturation in the client base.

Analysts will also be concerned that higher operating costs will deepen net losses from £248m in 1999 to £261m last year.

A Canal Plus spokesman could not confirm if the reports were accurate.

The Canal Plus results will increase market doubts about the world's second largest media company, which was formed last year by the £50bn merger of French group Vivendi and Canadian corporation Seagram, owner of Universal Music and Universal Studios.

Investors want to see detailed plans for delivering Vivendi's impressive content portfolio, which centre on its Vizzavi mobile internet venture with Vodafone.

However, the roll-out of the portal has been hampered by the slow take-up of Wap phones and delays in launching next-generation handsets.

A more worrying gap in Vivendi's distribution system is the lack of a strategic partnership with an internet service provider, following its decision to exit AOL France.

Answering these doubts is of more importance to investors than the figures, which are expected to show pre-tax profits of £1.1bn.

Analysts say the results will be boosted by an exceptional year for Universal Music and Universal Studios which is unlikely to be repeated.

fields.headline: Broadcast
fields.standfirst: Publication date: March 8
fields.trailText: March 8: Channel 5 is moving its main evening news programme to 5.30pm from the start of the forthcoming general election campaign.
fields.body:
Channel 5 will shift its main evening news programme to 5.30pm from the start of the forthcoming general election campaign, even though the Independent Television Commission has yet permit a permanent move.

Slam.com, the planned teen portal from Emap Digital and Channel 4, has been shelved.

Peter Curtis, head of acquisitions at HIT Entertainment, has quit the company along with creative director Kate Fawkes.

Channel 5 has won the British terrestrial television first-run rights the multi-Oscar nominated film Gladiator after a "keenly contested" battle with rival broadcasters.

Granada has restructured its children's department following its takeover of United Productions' children's assets. It has rebranded the division Granada Kids.

fields.headline: Sharon tightens grip on Palestine
fields.standfirst: Ariel Sharon has spent his first full day in office as the prime minister of Israel. His leadership of the conflict-stricken country augurs a new period of  security for Israelis, but at the expense of the Palestinians, writes Suzanne Goldenberg
fields.trailText: Ariel Sharon has spent his first day in office as the prime minister of Israel. His leadership of the conflict-stricken country augurs a new period of security for Israelis, but at the expense of the Palestinians, writes Suzanne Goldenberg.
fields.body:
A month after his landslide election victory the hardliner, Ariel Sharon, spent his first full day as prime minister yesterday, and Israelis are now watching to see if the ageing warrior can banish their anxieties about security.

The election of Mr Sharon represents a dramatic shrinking of hopes. Gone is the vision of a brave new Middle East, with Israel at peace with all its neighbours. Instead, the people of the Jewish state would settle for a containment of the five-month uprising, and a guarantee that Palestinian militants will no longer be able to slip across from the West Bank to plant bombs in Israeli cities.

One of the proposed solutions now making the rounds is "separation": the notion that Israel can simply seal off the stony hills of the West Bank behind concrete barricades and waterless moats. While that would permanently deprive 2 million Palestinians of the jobs in Israel that were an economic lifeline before the uprising, Israelis could blithely go about their business.

Some 79 per cent of Israelis now support unilateral separation from the Palestinians, according to an opinion poll published today in Yediot Ahronoth, the largest circulation Hebrew newspaper.

The debate has been sharpened by new threats from the armed wing of the Islamist militant group, Hamas, to launch 10 suicide missions within the borders of the Jewish state to mark Mr Sharon's installation as prime minister on Wednesday.

Border police officials are expected to present Mr Sharon with a plan to hermetically seal off the West Bank - much like the Gaza Strip has been contained behind barbed wire - within days.

But even security officials doubt that they can make citizens feel completely safe, and that "separation" remains an unrealistic fantasy. "The new government will not have a rabbit in its hat to eradicate terror," a senior security official told the Yediot Ahronoth.

This week, Israeli troops dug a moat around Bir Zeit University in Ramallah, the largest Palestinian educational institution in the West Bank, and a centre for activism. The trench has also cut off water and power lines to 65,000 villagers. A similar trench, two metres deep and 1.5 metres wide, was dug around Jericho, preventing even pedestrians from leaving the desert town.

Israeli security forces have also accelerated measures to seal off a 40-mile swathe of the West Bank, from the northern town of Mei Ami to Latrun near Jerusalem, behind watchtowers, and electronic fences. The focus of the operation is Netanya, which has been targeted by Hamas bombers twice during the uprising. The coastal town lies only seven miles from the West Bank town of Tulkaram.

Security officials say it will cost an initial £17 million to lay down concrete and metal barriers across link roads between the West Bank and Israel. On the few designated roads that remain open, the security forces will set up checkpoints akin to border crossings and monitor traffic with motion-sensitive cameras and watch towers.

They could seal off the entire "seam" between the West Bank and Israel within the year.

Meanwhile, security adviser Hagai Herzl this week proposed that any Palestinian who wanted to work in Israel be required to offer his home as collateral in case he is linked to any future bombing. But security officials admit even such Cold War measures cannot make Israel free of Palestinians. For all their fears about the enemy within, the Israeli economy can not function without cheap Palestinian labour.

With the going rate for Palestinian workers just a third of the daily wages, Israelis pay to import labourers from Romania and Thailand. Despite a security ban, Jewish restaurant owners and contractors have continued to take on staff from the West Bank throughout the uprising.

Israeli security officials believe some 20,000 labourers cross into Israel each day to work illegally on building sites and in restaurants. One such labourer was beaten unconscious in Netanya this week in the wake of the suicide bombing attack, drawing attention to the continued flouting of security regulations by Israeli employers.

Even strict vetting of the trickle of approved workers is no guarantee. Last month, a Palestinian bus driver, who had passed rigorous security checks only days before, ploughed into a crowd at Azur junction in central Israel, killing seven soldiers, and a woman civilian.

The driver had been on medication for depression for two years. Such fears are central in the minds of Israelis this weekend, which marks the Jewish festival of Purim, an occasion that has often been marred by violence. Security forces have drafted in 1,000 extra troops to guard shopping malls and other public places, and several towns have cancelled holiday celebrations.

"We are stepping up security this weekend," Israel's police chief, Shlomo Aharonisky, told Israel radio. "But no matter what we do, it is impossible to prevent a terrorist from carrying out a terrorist attack."

fields.headline: Care home girls 'sent into prostitution'
fields.trailText: More than 40 girls, some as young as 14, have gone missing from care homes in the last five years and been transported to Italy to work as child prostitutes, police fear.
fields.byline: Jeevan Vasagar  and Philip Willan  in Rome
fields.body:
More than 40 girls, some as young as 14, have gone missing from care homes in the last five years and been transported to Italy to work as child prostitutes, police fear.

The teenagers had been flown into Gatwick from West African countries by human traffickers who use Britain as a transit point into Europe.

The girls' original documentation was destroyed by the traffickers, who told them to apply for political asylum on arrival, detectives believe.

They were told to claim they were from Sierra Leone, riven by civil war, and not from Nigeria, and also to lie about their age so they were taken into care homes.

Traffickers take samples of hair from the girls and warn them that these will be used to carry out voodoo punishments on them or their families if they disobey orders.

The girls have gone on to abscond from the care homes and are believed to have been transported to countries, including Italy and Holland, where they are told they will find work as hairdressers or shop assistants. Instead, they are forced into prostitution.

Britain is being used as a staging post because the Italian authorities have become alert to direct flights from West Africa.

However, travellers from other EU countries are subject to far less scrutiny.

Sources said one suspected trafficker, a Dutch national of Nigerian origin, was arrested at Dover with a girl from a West Sussex care home in his care last March, but the only charge that could be brought against him was for allegedly handling stolen credit cards.

Detective Sergeant Andy Cummins of Sussex police said: "The girls are afraid of the men and well drilled in their stories. There is a loophole in the legislation in that there is no specific offence of human trafficking. To prove kidnapping, you need to show the person has gone against their will."

Police first established a link with the Italian sex trade after one girl escaped and contacted West Sussex social services in December 1999. The girl, whose Roman Catholic beliefs meant she was not afraid of the voodoo threats, was interviewed by detectives but was unable to provide the information needed for a prosecution.

"She did not know who any of the men were. She did not know England and could not describe what route she had taken."

Police in Turin said yester day they had found Nigerian prostitutes carrying British passports, but were not aware of any girls who had absconded from Britain.

Charity workers say that around 40% of Italy's prostitutes come from Nigeria and there are 2,500 West African prostitutes working on the streets of Turin every day.

"Turin is the Italian capital of Nigerian prostitution," said Mirta Da Pra, the head of a project on prostitution and human smuggling run by the charitable organisation Gruppo Abele.

Nigerian women began arriving in Italy to work as prostitutes in 1988 and today share the market with women from eastern Europe. Their increasing dominance of the market followed the withdrawal of many Italian women in the wake of Aids.

Ms Da Pra said: "They come here to escape from a disastrous social and economic situation in Nigeria, where women have a very low status - they are not even allowed to have their own money - and no prospects."

The prostitution rings are run by Nigerian madams, often ex-prostitutes themselves, who will buy women for between £5,000 and £7,000 from the "sponsor" who facilitated the girls' entry to Italy.

Men play a minor role in the organisation, acting as drivers, collecting money and occasionally imposing discipline through physical force.

"Almost everything is run by the women," Ms Da Pra said. "They are quite fearsome and perfectly capable of administering a beating."

West Sussex social services have now stepped up security around girls arriving from West Africa.

fields.headline: Human traffic
fields.standfirst: In West Africa, ruthless gangs of traffickers terrify young men and women into fleeing to Britain in search of asylum. From here, they are shipped to Italy and a life of prostitution.  Melanie McFadyean  investigates
fields.trailText: In West Africa, ruthless gangs of traffickers terrify young men and women into fleeing to Britain in search of asylum. From here, they are shipped to Italy and a life of prostitution. Melanie McFadyean investigates.
fields.body:
There is a list in West Sussex social services files of 71 children, mostly from West Africa or China. Their details are listed under the following headings: name, date of birth, arrival date, date went missing. Most were in their mid-teens when they arrived here, alone and seeking asylum. All have disappeared: some within 24 hours, some after a week or two, and a handful after several months. What evidence there is strongly suggests they have been trafficked into prostitution in Italy, where some 6o% of street prostitutes are West African.

"Jane", a 16-year-old Nigerian, is one of only two girls to have surfaced again after vanishing from social services here (the other was found hiding in a church in Italy). Jane sits very still, and seems numb as she recounts her ordeal. Even when she cries, she barely moves.

In Nigeria, thinking she was going to a party, Jane was taken by traffickers to a room where there were human heads on spikes. There she was forced to drink the blood of a dead woman. They then cut her with razor blades in small, neat rows, making her promise with each cut not to tell anyone anything, saying they would know because they had voodoo powers. There was another girl there and they forced them to lick each other's wounds.

The traffickers then instructed her to return, bringing a friend, but she refused and so they sent her threatening messages. She met a man who, feigning sympathy, offered to help her. The cycle had begun. She was introduced to a man who provided her with a ticket and forged passport and told her to memorise a telephone number which she was to ring on arrival in London.

Jane imagined that in London she would go through immigration on her forged passport and find a telephone. She had never been more than a few miles beyond her home before, and didn't know UK currency would be any different to Nigerian naira. She could barely read or write and forgot the telephone number, so when a Gatwick immigration officer asked her where she was going, she said she didn't know. She ended up in the care of West Sussex social services.

But two months after her arrival there, she left, only to be arrested three weeks later at a port. The man she was with had been stopped before in the company of young girls, using the same passport as Jane had on this occasion. He had also been arrested in another European country, where an attempt to prosecute him for human trafficking had failed. Port authorities let the man go (despite a Customs and Special Branch request to the contrary). Jane was put in detention for five months, leading her to the brink of suicide before she was released back into West Sussex's care last summer. The Home Office turned down her asylum claim and she is currently appealing.

Lynne Chitty, a senior asylum team social worker at West Sussex, who is looking after Jane, has heard many similar stories. She was told that a lawyer had come forward, claiming to have been instructed by Jane's father, and insisting that the girl was older than she said. Jane says this is impossible, that she doesn't even know who her father is. Chitty says that solicitors are used unwittingly by third parties to control the young people.

She has watched the tragedy of such cases unfold since the first children disappeared in 1995, and she believes that of the West Sussex list of 71 missing, at least 40 West African girls and 14 West African boys have been trafficked into the sex trade. In January 1998 - by which time 10 children had gone missing - Sussex Police set up Operation Newbridge to gather intelligence on the girls. The boys were not included. A Missing Persons Helpline television programme resulted in a lead from a truck driver who had seen young African girls in lorry parks in Italy.

In January 2000, the national crime squad presented a case against a number of men suspected of trafficking and prostitution, but the crown prosecution service rejected it. Current legislation makes convictions virtually impossible, and the authorities regard the few witnesses who might be prepared to come forward as unreliable because they change their stories. Chitty says they change them because they are too frightened to tell the truth until trust has built up between them and social workers.

Chitty claims she has seen the traffickers: a woman hanging around a safe house who ran when approached by police; four men in a car outside a meeting of these children, who were watching her as she called police on her mobile phone. She and her family have been threatened. Disturbingly, half a dozen of the young people fitting the "profile" are working with the gangs, corrupted by money and power. Chitty knows, and they know she knows.

DI Nigel Kent of the National Crime Squad, which led the failed investigation, thinks some girls know what awaits them here, "believing the UK is the land of milk and honey". Bisi Olateru Olagbegi, a Nigerian lawyer and women's rights activist, says that some see prostitution as an escape from poverty, but don't realise the horror of the conditions in which they will live and work. Nor do they realise that their debt bondage, usually about £38,000 to traffickers, pimps and madams, will tie them down for years. (At Italian rates, a girl would have to suffer 3,000 clients to expunge the debt.) Olagbegi says that rape and even bestiality are used to control the girls.

West Sussex social services has been vigorously proactive in tackling the situation, setting up safe houses, reporting every disappearance, working closely with immigration, police, the Missing Persons Helpline, the Refugee Council and others. Other authorities, notably Kent County Council and Hillingdon, have also lost children. For a few months last year, none left the West Sussex safe houses. But another girl vanished one Sunday lunchtime in October and hasn't been seen since. Chitty, who knew the girl well, and the others in the safe house, insist she would not have gone voluntarily and fear she is in danger.

Chitty continues to report every disappearance and supply police with information, but feels it is futile. Detective Superintendent David Gaylor of Sussex police, who was involved at the start of the investigations, shares her concerns but says the police are not to blame: "We feel neutered and disempowered."

Gaylor says that when the issue was first raised with the Home Office two years ago, officials responded, "in so many words, that it wasn't their problem". Since then, Gaylor says there has been some response from Barbara Roche, the immigration minister , but "there's still a long way to go". He hopes now that there will be European and international liaison to combat the traffickers.

Meanwhile the trafficking continues and Chitty fears that nothing will be done until the tragedy becomes a crisis - until one of those who is missing is found dead. She feels passionately about these young people. "I feel privileged to work with them, I can't believe how brave they are. They arrive here, they don't even know where they are. They deserve to be safe, to be cared for. They are children."

fields.headline: NTL to build on 'seismic' 2000
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: NTL has said 2001 will be a period of 'getting down to business', writes David Teather.
fields.body:
NTL, Britain's largest cable company, said yesterday that 2001 would be a period of "getting down to business", after reporting a pre-tax loss of more than $3bn last year.

Stephen Carter, managing director of NTL in the UK, said 2000 had been "a seismic year" for the company, following the acquisitions of Cable & Wireless Communications and Cablecom in Switzerland plus the launch of digital, broadband and the company's internet service provider.

"We will be digesting the activity of 2000," he said. "We are now a business of scale, with customers and strong products."

The effective closure of the capital markets meant it made sense to focus on the company's existing assets, added chief executive Barclay Knapp. NTL has made 11 acquisitions in the UK in the past 18 months.

The company intends to put particular focus on London where it acquired franchises from Cable & Wireless and where take-up is as low as one in four homes passed by the network.

Mr Carter said NTL had now signed 600,000 homes to its digital television service and has set a target of 1.25m for the end of the year. Average revenue per digital subscriber is £42 against £36 on analogue and the company is planning to push through additional price increases soon.

NTL also expects to have 100,000-plus customers using its broadband service by the end of the year, up from the present 12,800. Revenues for the group during the year doubled to £1.9bn while Ebitda (earnings before interest taxation, depreciation and amortisation) climbed from £130m to £229m.

Around a third of the loss at pre-tax level was attributed to interest payments on NTL's debt of £10bn which is expected to peak at £13bn, Mr Knapp said. With much of the NTL network completed, capital expenditure, which peaked at £1.9bn last year, will fall to £1.3bn this year and £1bn next.

webTitle: Everyone's a winner from script with a happy ending

fields.headline: Everyone's a winner from script with a happy ending
fields.trailText: "If Gordon Brown's Budget was rewritten as a Hollywood movie," said Howard Reed of the Institute for Fiscal Studies yesterday, "it would be called 'no losers' - or perhaps, 'everyone's a winner'."
fields.body:
"If Gordon Brown's Budget was rewritten as a Hollywood movie," said Howard Reed of the Institute for Fiscal Studies yesterday, "it would be called 'no losers' - or perhaps, 'everyone's a winner'."

Weeks ahead of a general election, the chancellor's fifth and final Budget of the parliament followed a familiar pattern of quiet redistribution, with most of the gains concentrated at the bottom end of the income scale.

But with middle England likely to play a crucial part in the outcome of the poll, Mr Brown also made sure that average and higher income groups did not suffer. Unlike some previous Budgets, there were gains for families in every income bracket.

"This Budget goes with the grain of previous Labour party budgets whilst offering something for almost everyone," Mr Reed said.

In its analysis of the distributional impact of the personal tax and benefit changes, the IFS said the biggest gainers in percentage terms are households in the poorest tenth of the population.

They gain on average about 1.6% of disposable income. In cash terms, that is about £1.65 a week. The main drivers are the benefit increases and excise duty changes.

Further up the income distribution scale, the widening of the 10p tax band from £1,520 to £1,880 ensures that basic and higher rate taxpayers also have some extra money in their pockets.

In percentage terms, the richest 10% of the population gains about 0.3% of disposable income - around £2 a week in cash terms.

The IFS has also calculated the effect of the Budget changes on direct and indirect tax by family type. This shows that families with children are the biggest beneficiaries.

They gain from the above-inflation increases in the working families tax credit, the children's credit and the changes to child allowances in income support. As a percentage of disposable income, single parents and non-earning couples with children gain the most. Their incomes rise by about 2% a week on average.

At the opposite end of the age range, pensioners gain little from the tax and benefit changes announced yesterday.

But they will still be better off both this year and in the years to come, thanks to the generous package of measures announced in November's pre-Budget report, including increases in the basic state pension and the minimum income guarantee. Pensioners also benefit from tax allowances rising in line with earnings from 2003 onwards, and the planned introduction of the new pension credit.

The IFS said the overall impact of the Budget on the public finances was to loosen fiscal policy by £4.4bn in the coming financial year, rising to £5.2bn in 2002-03 and £5.8bn in 2003-04.

IFS researcher Carl Emmerson said the tax cuts and spending increases announced by the chancellor had been made possible by higher than expected tax revenue - especially income tax - combined with lower than expected spending on social security and debt interest, and underspending of departmental programmes.

However, he questioned the chancellor's claim to have upped spending increases to 3.7% a year over the next three years from 3.4% previously, saying that the only reason spending was growing faster was that it was starting from a lower base.

webTitle: Portillo fails to make his 69p-a-week jibe stick

fields.headline: Portillo fails to make his 69p-a-week jibe stick
fields.standfirst: Brown leaves little room for Tory manoeuvres
fields.trailText: The Tories yesterday struggled to neutralise the electoral popularity of Gordon Brown's fifth Budget by claiming that the chancellor's package gives voters a mere 69p a week in tax cuts - and does not even deliver the extra spending he promises on key public services.
fields.body:
The Tories yesterday struggled to neutralise the electoral popularity of Gordon Brown's fifth Budget by claiming that the chancellor's package gives voters a mere 69p a week in tax cuts - and does not even deliver the extra spending he promises on key public services.

In a day of skirmishing that all but confirmed a May 3 election date, Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor, clashed with Treasury ministers over his own insistence that he can match Labour's most important spending commitments and cut taxes by £8bn.

With Tony Blair putting the finishing touches to his own speech - to party activists in Scotland tonight - claiming that Labour is now the "natural party of economic competence" - Mr Portillo faced Labour charges that his own spending strategy will force him to cut Mr Brown's plans by £11bn by 2003-4.

Mr Portillo's counter-offensive included "six tax rises Gordon brushed over". They included increases on company cars, corporation tax and national insurance contributions, the latter costing 2.5m people on more than £28,500 up to £2.90 a week.

All the taxes Mr Portillo singled out were in the pipeline from previous Brown policies but come into force in the weeks ahead. In a press conference yesterday, as instant polls showed the chancellor's package has won early voter approval, he coupled them with an insistence that taxes have risen overall by £28bn since 1997.

In response, chief Treasury secretary Andrew Smith claimed Mr Portillo had conceded that by the 2003-4 spending round, a Hague government would be spending £11bn less than Labour plans to.

Mr Smith said the Budget red book showed Labour planning to increase spending by 3.7% a year over the next three years; £74bn a year by 2003-4.

At a press conference, marking out Labour's economic attack for the election, his cabinet colleague, social security secretary Alistair Darling, repeatedly challenged Mr Portillo to say whether he would stick by his commitment to increase spending by only 2.25% over three years in line with the so-called trend rate of growth in the economy.

Mr Darling said the only spending principle enunciated by Mr Portillo was that he would not allow spending to rise faster than the rate of growth in the economy. "When he is pressed he says he will match us, but then he insists he will stick to 2.25%. He either has a rule or he doesn't."

Mr Darling said the government had increased the percentage rise in spending because the base from which it was starting in the coming financial year was lower than had been envisaged at the time of the spending review last summer. He said spending levels were lower than expected due to savings on social security and debt interest payments.

Labour also acknowledged that departmental spending was £1bn lower in 2000-01 than envisaged in the pre-Budget report. Mr Darling said this money would be carried over.

Mr Portillo's office insisted Labour's Budget did not increase spending on health, education and crime by £2.3bn over the next three years. The total increase in spending announced in the Budget in the third year was only £825m, the Conservatives claimed.

Mr Blair will praise his chancellor and heir apparent today, and say the Budget is the latest evidence that the government is successfully pursuing policies that deliver economic efficiency and social justice. Nobody should underestimate the significance of being more trusted on the economy than the Conservatives, he will argue. "It is a historic first term prize that allows us to fight for the right to deliver a radical, second term agenda."

Labour's "unfinished business" is the creation of a Britain in which everyone has the chance to fulfil their potential, and every region shares in rising prosperity, the prime minister will say.

The Budget was one of a strong, confident chancellor in a strong, confident government, focusing on the long term and investing in the future against an economic backdrop.

All, Mr Blair will say, are the result of tough choices - standing in stark contrast to the Tory years of boom and bust. But the prime minister's mantra will also be heard: "We were warriors against complacency in 1997, and we must renew the war on complacency now. We take no vote for granted."

webTitle: Future Network courts buyers for top title

fields.headline: Future Network courts buyers for top title
fields.trailText: The troubled magazine publishing group is understood to have attracted several potential buyers for Business 2.0, reports David Teather.
fields.body:
All may be collapsing in the internet world but interest in the print title which has charted the fortunes of the e-economy is still keen.

Future Network, the troubled magazine publishing group, is understood to have attracted several potential buyers of Business 2.0, its flagship title effectively put on the market as part of a wider review.

The magazine has been a phenomenal success in the US and Time, Condé Nast, Ziff Davis Media and Gruner & Jahr have all been named as potential bidders.

Investment bank Morgan Stanley Dean Witter was last month mandated to assess the alternatives for Business 2.0. The title is understood to have made revenues of £40m last year in the US - although advertising volumes for Business 2.0 are likely to be far lower this year.

It launched in Britain last May where sales are at 50,000. Analysts said the title could be valued at up to £100m, two-thirds of Future's market capitalisation.

At the same time last month, Future embarked on a cost cutting exercise involving the loss of 350 jobs and the closure of 20 magazine titles.

Media analysts are also expecting some management change as the result of the collapse in Future's share price over the past year.

Future insiders concede that Business 2.0 may have outgrown the company which specialises in magazines for the computer games industry.

fields.headline: Music Choice doubles revenues
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Music Choice Europe, the radio group which has BSkyB as its largest shareholder, has doubled its revenues, writes David Teather.
fields.body:
Music Choice Europe, the radio group which has BSkyB as its largest shareholder, yesterday said it had doubled revenues last year to £5.2m on the back of the growth in digital television.

The company broadcasts 46 genre-based radio stations over digital TV networks and is included in the basic Sky package.

Revenues are from fees paid by the broadcasters to carry the service. But from the end of the month the company is developing a second revenue stream with the launch of an interactive service on the TV screen when a radio station is playing.

It will carry advertising and allow listeners to click through for more detailed information on the advertisements or the artist playing. The service already features the name and track being played on screen and the aim is also to allow subscribers to buy the compact disc using their remote control.

"Research tells us that people look at the screen to see who is playing and those are eyeballs we can use by delivering an on screen enhanced TV service," said Music Choice chief executive Simon Bazalgette.

The company also announced a deal with the nightclub Ministry of Sound to provide programming for one of its dance stations.

Losses before tax for the year narrowed slightly from £12.6m to £11m.

webTitle: Hard-pressed doctors set for election confrontation

fields.headline: Hard-pressed doctors set for election confrontation
fields.trailText: The British Medical Association (BMA) is gearing up for confrontation with health ministers during the election campaign by producing a patients' dossier, showing the suffering caused when doctors in the hard-pressed NHS are forced to cut corners.
fields.body:
The British Medical Association (BMA) is gearing up for confrontation with health ministers during the election campaign by producing a patients' dossier, showing the suffering caused when doctors in the hard-pressed NHS are forced to cut corners.

Doctors' leaders will say they are not taking sides but their intervention is likely to help William Hague's attempt to undermine the credibility of NHS reforms - regarded by Labour strategists as one of their strongest electoral suits.

The plan emerged yesterday after the BMA council on Wednesday decided patients were being "short-changed" by excessive workload. "Patients in both primary and hospital care get too little time with their doctors. The inexorable rise in workload and the constant flow of new government initiatives and targets have created a very real tide of anger and demoralisation amongst senior hospital doctors and GPs," the BMA said.

John Chisholm, chairman of its GP committee, said: "We will not name individual patients or doctors to protect their anonymity, but we will provide evidence of what it is really like in the NHS."

Dr Chisholm said he was writing to the UK's 36,000 GPs urging them to lobby MPs and parliamentary candidates and contact newspapers, television and radio on workloads and recruitment issues.

The average GP was giving 10,000 consultations a year - 50% more than when the NHS was founded in 1948. That cut the average length of a consultation to eight minutes or less.

"This is unfair to patients. It does not give the space they need for reassurance and discussion of the treatments they need, or advice on how to live with chronic illness. For doctors all the pleasure of medicine is destroyed by the conveyor belt pace... The result is work related stress and disaffection," he said.

The government was planning to appoint an extra 2,000 GPs in England by 2004, but this was less than a fifth of the 10,330 needed to provide a satisfactory service.

"We are way behind even the government's ridiculously low targets for GP recruitment. The government must take some urgent and immediate steps to boost morale, providing pensions incentives to keep older doctors in the workforce and offering hope to new doctors that general practice will be an attractive career where they can serve the community without destroying their own health or disappearing under a mountain of paperwork," he said.

Derek Machin, deputy chairman of the consultants' committee, said pressure from the government to reduce hospital waiting lists was forcing doctors to prioritise the wrong patients. Ministers were promising to appoint 7,500 more consultants by 2004, but this was raising patients' expectations without yet reducing the burden on doctors.

"For hospital consultants, the crunch issue really is workload. For too long, consultants have tried to reconcile two contradictory imperatives. We try to fast track patients through the system, squeezing extra appointments into out-patient clinics, discharging patients at lightning speed and putting quantity ahead of quality. That increases the risk of accident and error," he said.

Plans to intervene in the election came as the BMA moved closer to settling a long-running argument with the general medical council on streamlining disciplinary procedures.

Dr Bogle said both sides would support a small GMC executive that could speed up decisions and a larger council of about 50 medical and lay representatives that could discuss policy. There was disagreement about which body should have the more statutory powers.

fields.headline: Identica takes on 'upmarket sex toys'
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The marketing consultancy has been hired to create a new luxury brand - providing upmarket 'sex accessories' for women. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Identica, the marketing consultancy whose clients include Vodafone and NatWest, has been hired to create a new luxury brand - providing upmarket "sex accessories" for women.

Lilestone, a company set up by two former City financiers earlier this year, aims to tap into a gap in the market for lingerie, sex toys and contraceptives for the more discerning customer.

The new company, a sort of Anne Summers for the Marie Claire-reading classes, will have a flagship store in London's Notting Hill as well as a website and catalogue operation.

Identica has been charged with coming up with a name, corporate identity and packaging for the brand, which is scheduled to launch in September.

"We believe that changing attitudes to female sexuality, due to heightened media coverage and the removal of social taboos surrounding female sexual fulfilment, means there's a marketplace for high quality sexy luxury goods for women," said Lilestone founder Charlotte Semler.

"We are developing a brand which will be targeted to reflect the lifestyle aspirations of an upmarket, sophisticated target audience."

Lilestone was formed last year with backing of over £1m and is seeking a listing on Ofex, where it hopes to raise a further £1.5m.

fields.headline: Newton named Sun showbiz editor
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The Sun's Los Angeles correspondent Victoria Newton is being promoted to showbusiness editor, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The Sun's Los Angeles correspondent Victoria Newton is being promoted to showbusiness editor as the paper overhauls its showbusiness desk.

Ms Newton has been reporting from LA for the past two years, where she made her name breaking the story of Catherine Zeta Jones's pregnancy by Fatal Attraction star Michael Douglas.

More recently, she has filed a string of stories on the marriage break-up of Tom Cruise and Nicole Kidman.

Ms Newton's appointment comes shortly after deputy showbusiness editor Emma Jones was poached by Emap's Smash Hits.

Ms Newton will report to the Sun's assistant editor, showbusiness, Dominic Mohan, who will continue to oversee the showbusiness pages.

Nicole Lampert has become deputy editor of the Sun's showbusiness column, Bizarre.

fields.headline: Basking in the Sun
fields.standfirst:
With its usual comical brass neck, Murdoch's tabloid tells its readers to vote the way they already plan to

Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText:
Polly Toynbee: With its usual comical brass neck, Murdoch's tabloid tells its readers to vote the way they already plan to.
Special report: election countdown
fields.body:
"It's in the bag, Tony. You might as well call election now", was the Sun's headline yesterday. Its front page proclaimed: "Blair gets our support for a second term." On and on rolled the eulogy. (They do nothing by halves). "Yesterday's budget was an astounding achievement."

This conversion was no surprise. The Sun always rises to embrace power. Bullies the world over have just one rule - always join the winning side, don't be seen dead with the losers. This is another tombstone representing the collapse of the right. After two elections supporting Labour, the Sun can never again be the cornerstone of the old Conservative party. It recognises there is nothing there - no party (average age 66), no policies, no personalities, no purpose, no project. A very dead parrot, the final end of the Thatcher era. The nostrums and the diktats of her days were nowhere to be found in the Budget speech, finally purged and not before time. Labour has nothing left to fear from the past, no excuse now for future pusillanimity.

Gallantly, the Sun tried hard to support William Hague but the faltering relationship is over, leaving an anguished Tory camp yesterday. The Sun front page Dear John letter had all the classic pathos of the but-let's-always-stay-friends, adding insult to injury. "Truth is: the Tories are quite simply not ready. We respect William Hague... We gave him a chance. But, truly, we cannot endorse a Hague-Portillo team up against Blair-Brown. Who could? ... New Labour is not perfect. There is much to be done. And we will want results, Tony. We will demand them... But Blair has done enough to win our backing."

Oh, good. Phew! That's it then. The election must be in the bag because the Sun says so and it will be "the Sun wot won it" yet again. They always do. The sheer brass neck, the conviction that they do actually run the country is comical, almost endearing in its illusion: it is one of their very few sincerely held beliefs. When journalists start believing they control the events they report, they have always lost the plot. Everyone sniggers. This portentous self-importance is just another common journalistic delusion of grandeur: given a platform and a bunch of students, journalists swashbuckle with the doughty sword of truth, boasting of the mighty brought low by fearless investigation, toiling in the dustbins of politics. However, most British journalists work for Murdoch, Black and Rothermere, for whom truth-seeking does not comes first. Frivolity and showmanship are rarely mentioned in earnest seminars. Nor the louche sneer and jeer that is the lingua franca. Nor the sheer joy of bullying anyone famous, kicking heads in for the hell of it. Power indeed.

But psephologist Professor John Curtice takes a dusty view of the power of the press over voters in elections. Minimal, his research suggests. For all the bombast of newspaper opinionising, during the last election all that happened during the campaign was a 4% swing away from Labour to the Lib Dems, not advocated by any newspaper. Well, he says, at the margins the newspapers do bring in some voters. The Sun's switch to Labour at least stopped them recruiting Tories, but brought in no extra. A third of voters read no newspaper at all. Over the four years between elections, a third of readers swap papers, shifting cavalierly to a political opposite. The consumers of this declining industry are fickle and volatile. "For marketing purposes, the Sun needed to keep up with its readers."

Other suspicions lurk. Murdoch gives nothing for nothing. What's he after? It requires nothing so vulgar as a deal or even a word spoken - but the communications white paper's crucial section on media ownership is "out for consultation" until after the election. ON-digital is taking BSkyB to the Office of Fair Trading for abusing its monopoly control over sport and movies - the drivers of the digital future that can drive others out of business. Murdoch continues to lobby for the BBC to become a tiny public service broadcaster, its money dispersed among all broadcasters willing to do a bit of public service too. Murdoch has no views, only business interests that require him to be in arm-twisting reach of governments everywhere.

However, venality apart, if the Sun is interesting, it is as a weather vane, acutely attuned to popular mood. On Wednesday it took a new astonishing line. It lambasted Hague's infamous "Let me take you to a foreign country" speech. The Sun leader said: "Hague risked being called an extremist by banging on about immigration. This was imprudent... If an asylum seeker and his family is prepared to risk their lives to come here - might they not work hard? We're just asking - particularly as we need immigrants to boost our workforce... If they want to work, they should be allowed to stay. And Blair should be more prepared to argue that case." Hague's speech "left a nasty taste in the mouth".

Perplexed cynics point out that Rupert Murdoch's new wife is a thirty-something who was born in China. Another interpretation might be that at last the multiculturalism of Britain, its diversity and plurality, has become so embedded in the national psyche, soap operas and comedy shows, that the Sun must follow.

Inside Downing Street the Daily Mail used to be the bellwether. Its daily menu of anti-government stories - most of them breathtaking invention and distortion - frightened the life out of their pollster Philip Gould, who warned that private polling shows asylum seekers are a major concern to his focus groups.

The Mail continues to belabour asylum seekers, but the Mail is in another business altogether from the Sun. Its arrogance is to believe that it is now Her Majesty's true opposition, there being no other. What it sells is a delusion of another kind. It offers a make-believe world where readers can amusingly delude themselves briefly. Come with the Mail and you enter a faraway country that is forever 1955, Noddy on the bookshelf, a comfy place where Mr and Mrs England with Janet and John would live happy ever after if it weren't for the scary gollywogs in the wood: a never ending tale of right v wrong.

There are signs at last that the government is growing braver about the press. They can ignore both the Sun's boastful blandishments and the Mail's brickbats. There can rarely have been a lower moment in any leader's career than the craven anti-European article Tony Blair wrote in the Sun just before the last election, the quid pro quo for its support. There is no need to heed any of that any more.

But there will be a need for bravery when it comes to facing the full blast of a 70% eurosceptic press in the euro referendum. Newspapers may not do much to change party allegiance, but Harvard research has shown how right across Europe a eurosceptic press has influenced opinion against the euro. The government has to win by sheer force of argument, but it will be a frightening and final "who governs" showdown with the press.

However, venality apart, if the Sun is interesting, it is as a weather vane, acutely attuned to popular mood. On Wednesday it took a new astonishing line. It lambasted Hague's infamous "Let me take you to a foreign country" speech. The Sun leader said: "Hague risked being called an extremist by banging on about immigration. This was imprudent... If an asylum seeker and his family is prepared to risk their lives to come here - might they not work hard? We're just asking - particularly as we need immigrants to boost our workforce... If they want to work, they should be allowed to stay. And Blair should be more prepared to argue that case." Hague's speech "left a nasty taste in the mouth". Perplexed cynics point out that Rupert Murdoch's new wife is a thirty-something who was born in China. Another interpretation might be that at last the multiculturalism of Britain, its diversity and plurality, has become so embedded in the national psyche, soap operas and comedy shows, that the Sun must follow. Inside Downing Street the Daily Mail used to be the bellwether. Its daily menu of anti-government stories - most of them breathtaking invention and distortion - frightened the life out of their pollster Philip Gould, who warned that private polling shows asylum seekers are a major concern to his focus groups. The Mail continues to belabour asylum seekers, but the Mail is in another business altogether from the Sun. Its arrogance is to believe that it is now Her Majesty's true opposition, there being no other. What it sells is a delusion of another kind. It offers a make-believe world where readers can amusingly delude themselves briefly. Come with the Mail and you enter a faraway country that is forever 1955, Noddy on the bookshelf, a comfy place where Mr and Mrs England with Janet and John would live happy ever after if it weren't for the scary gollywogs in the wood: a never ending tale of right v wrong. There are signs at last that the government is growing braver about the press. They can ignore both the Sun's boastful blandishments and the Mail's brickbats. There can rarely have been a lower moment in any leader's career than the craven anti-European article Tony Blair wrote in the Sun just before the last election, the quid pro quo for its support. There is no need to heed any of that any more. But there will be a need for bravery when it comes to facing the full blast of a 70% eurosceptic press in the euro referendum. Newspapers may not do much to change party allegiance, but Harvard research has shown how right across Europe a eurosceptic press has influenced opinion against the euro. The government has to win by sheer force of argument, but it will be a frightening and final "who governs" showdown with the press. polly.toynbee@theguardian.com

webTitle: Theatres get biggest ever cash injection

fields.headline: Theatres get biggest ever cash injection
fields.standfirst: Arts Council payout means big winners but anger elsewhere
fields.trailText: Arts Council payout means big winners but anger elsewhere.
fields.body:
English theatre was given the biggest cash injection in its history yesterday and was warned that the public will expect nothing short of a renaissance in live drama in return.

The Arts Council chairman, Gerry Robinson, challenged companies which he admitted had been brought to their knees by decades of under- funding to "get out there and deliver, inspire and entertain", as he unveiled the first tranche of a rescue package that will pump an extra £70m into the industry over three years.

More than 190 theatres and touring companies will see substantial rises in their budgets from spring 2002, with some having their funding tripled and even quadrupled. The luckiest few, which include the Chichester Festival Theatre and South Asian Theatre Development, will receive five times as much in grants as they do now.

Mr Robinson claimed there was a "new generation of talented people ready to emerge" whose ambitions had been thwarted. "Now they have the money and it is time for theatre to deliver."

The big winners were spread fairly evenly across the country, from Live Theatre in Newcastle to the Plymouth Theatre Royal, with those seen as innovators particularly rewarded.

But not of all those theatres that seemed to have done well were celebrating. Edward Hall at the Watermill near Newbury, said he was "disgusted" by the extra £30,000 it had got to help bring on new directors like him, which the arts council had billed as a 131% rise.

"Are they serious? - £30,000 would give underpaid staff here an extra £11.50 a week [if it were to be used for wages]. I am disgusted."

Mr Robinson, who put the unprecedented package together with the culture secretary, Chris Smith, in the wake of the Boyden report, which warned of a catastrophic decline in regional theatre, said he was determined the money should go straight towards improving the work on the stage.

And he heralded an end to the "tick-box culture" under which companies were forced to jump through bureaucratic funding hoops. "I hate the bureaucracy that surrounds arts funding. The other side of the coin is that when it doesn't work we are going to say, 'Hey, we thought we were going to get this for our money'."

Mr Robinson admitted that when he took on the arts council job, he had assumed many of theatre's problems were down to inefficiency. "However, you only have to look at the figures to be disabused of that notion. We are talking about chronic underfunding here, and it was only because the people involved were so committed that magical work has been done."

But with three regional theatres not getting a penny extra, and another, the Theatre Royal in York, facing a cut in real terms, not everyone was jubilant.

The future looks bleak for the Swan Theatre in Worcester, but the Croydon Warehouse - a springboard for new writers - is in most immediate danger of closure. As well as missing out on any extra cash from the review, it faces losing its £60,000 grant from the London arts board next year.

However, there was better news for the third of the threatened theatres, the Gateway in Chester, which had also missed out on the windfall. In a surprise move, North West Arts announced yesterday that it would increase its funding by 63% over the next three years if the project became a mixed-use arts centre.

Kim Evans, the arts council's executive director of arts, said the fact that four companies had not benefited out of more than 190 had to be seen in context. "Let's be clear, this is a great day for the theatre."

webTitle: New film documents Elvis's legendary Vegas performances

fields.headline: They just can't help believing
fields.standfirst: He shivered, shook, kissed 100 swooning girls, then karate-kicked his way through Suspicious Minds... at last, a film has been released that does justice to Elvis's legendary Vegas performances.  Will Hodgkinson asks the fans for their verdicts
fields.trailText: He shivered, shook, kissed 100 swooning girls, then karate-kicked his way through Suspicious Minds... at last, a film has been released that does justice to Elvis's legendary Vegas performances. Will Hodgkinson asks the fans for their verdicts
fields.body:
By 1968, Elvis Presley's career was at an all-time low. The combined effect of the mid-60s British invasion led by the Beatles and the Rolling Stones, and the revolution in American music spearheaded by the Beach Boys, the Doors and Janis Joplin, ensured that the King's slick black quiff and curling upper lip had become as corny as communist paranoia and ice-cream sodas. Having spent most of the decade forsaking stage and studio for the cheap sets of one Hollywood B-movie after another, Elvis was, at the tender age of 33, all washed up.

Help came in the form of a young NBC television producer, Steve Binder. Binder put Elvis back on the map with a vérité-style documentary, featuring a stripped-down performance that cured Elvis of his stage fright and, by giving him contemporary material and a sharp, leather-clad image, made him relevant again. Elvis responded to the show's success by telling his manager, the notorious Colonel Parker: "I've got to get back in front of the public. I've got to get out on the road again!"

The colonel responded by showcasing his boy at Las Vegas, home of ageing crooners, gambling grannies and traditional entertainment in all its stagnant forms. Elvis had played Vegas once before - in 1956 he had bombed in front of an audience shocked by his then controversial stage show - and he hated the idea of going back. But Parker was enticed by the thought of a residency at the world's largest and most lavish hotel, the 1,500-room International, and signed his boy to play two months a year for five years.

That's the Way It Is, the concert film of Elvis's 1970 performances at the Hotel International, documents the beginning of the Vegas period that lasted up until Elvis's death, and shows how, despite his misgivings, he rose to the occasion magnificently. Starved to perfection and knocking them dead in a white jumpsuit, Elvis shivered and shook before a 35-piece orchestra, two vocal groups and a soprano; kissed 100 swooning girls; karate-kicked his way through Suspicious Minds; and generally gave the performance of a lifetime. This despite the fact that That's the Way It Is was made in the same year that, doped up to his eyeballs, Elvis visited President Nixon to demand that he be appointed special agent for the Bureau of Narcotics and Dangerous Drugs. He still appears as a regular guy, joking around in rehearsals, admitting to stage fright, and giving the people what they want.

A new edit of the film forsakes the fan and bell-boy interviews of old for pure, undiluted Elvis. For those who still live and breathe the King, this is the definitive version.

Sid Shaw, proprietor of Elvisly Yours

The first film wasn't punchy enough, there wasn't enough Elvis and it lost its momentum. This is pure Elvis. It shows the warmth of the man, the personality, the humour, the amazing talent. He puts on his glasses back to front, he falls off his chair... it must have been a real fun experience to rehearse with Elvis because he just wanted to have a good time, entertain people, and make them forget their worries.

This version of the film has been around for 17 years, but because the people who own Graceland are so litigious it has been denied to the general public. Finally they have come to their senses, and I think it'll be the resurrection of Elvis. You come out of this film feeling that you've been entertained, and that's what Elvis did. You could listen to Heartbreak Hotel or Jailhouse Rock 1,000 times and they're still fresh. When you listen to a Spice Girls song, after half a dozen hearings you want to bang your head against a wall - but Elvis had something therapeutic in his voice. A lot of handicapped people love Elvis Presley. It's almost like a religious phenomenon, and it's so sad that all these years he hasn't been promoted.

This is his year: 2001 was his theme tune. If you add together the year he died, the month he died, and the day he died, it comes to 2001, which is quite uncanny. People always write about the drugs and the hamburgers, but it's the music that will be remembered in the 25th century. OK, he had his personal problems, but he was a great entertainer, the world's best. He had some kind of aura. His voice had matured by the 1970s; like good wine it got better and better. The guy sold a billion records. No one will ever get near that. No one.

Shaun Blacker, Essential Elvis magazine

The new version is better because it's got more of Elvis in rehearsal - you see more of the man himself. I think the early Vegas years were his best time, as he was at his peak. He had had enough of the films, he wanted to get back onstage, and this was filmed during the first few dates in Vegas. OK, later on he wasn't so fit, but in 1970 he was 100%, and he was enjoying it. I don't think Elvis really enjoyed his life from the 1960s onwards - I think he was a simple person who wanted to do some thing special, and after he achieved that he was always harking back to his roots. Everyone knows about the drug situation, and that was part of the problem.

It's the charisma of the man. When he walked on stage everyone was awestruck. In January, I met Sonny West, Elvis's bodyguard, and he said that he was a real friend. When you see Elvis in the film joking around, that's exactly the way he was: relaxed, doing his music, just a bloke like you or me who happened to be very talented. But a lot of people were frightened of him too, and he had too many yes-men around him. He needed people to tell him where he was going wrong, which was what Sonny and Red West did, and Elvis fired them. He had a low opinion of himself at the time, he didn't think the public thought highly of him. He thought he'd been away too long to go back to the stage, and making this film helped him a lot.

Alice Castle, producer of a 15-part series on Elvis for BBC World Service

I like this version of the film firstly because it starts with the date of the first rehearsal, August 7 1970, which was the day I was born, and secondly because it sums up that whole age of the Vegas gang of Sammy Davis Jr and George Hamilton, and the Memphis Mafia [the group of friends and cronies who went everywhere with Elvis]. There's a moment when he's rehearsing and Colonel Parker calls him a "big-ass". It shows there was tension between them, and you remember that the reason why Elvis made all of those awful films was to support Colonel Parker's gambling habit.

It's easy for us, 30 years on, to look at this film as a showcase for a great entertainer, but that's part of the myth. He was kitsch at the time - I remember my parents saying that anyone who had any taste in music thought Elvis was naff in the early 1970s - but if you speak to the hardcore fans they say this was his greatest moment; maybe because he was essentially a performance artist who didn't write his own material, and this was his biggest performance. If you saw this film on a huge screen, in a drive-in with massive speakers on either side, it would be the closest you'd get to seeing Elvis live. But what's been included are all of the most famous 1950s songs, and anyone who knows a lot about Elvis may be disappointed because their personal favourites aren't there.

Elvis impersonator Di and her Elvis-loving manager Shirley

Shirley: We got to the last couple of numbers and I realised I was starting to cry. Something said to me: what the hell - or who - put this man on earth? I looked over at Di and she was crying as well. Then you realise: this man invented rock'n'roll.

Di: These days people think Elvis was fat for the whole of the Vegas period, when in reality he was only fat for the last six months of his life. These people just see rhinestones, fat and burgers, but for those who were there when it was happening, it was just phenomenal. That was my first vision of Elvis - when I was nine I saw a picture of him in a white jumpsuit, looking like he did on That's the Way It Is. He made a huge, instant impact on my life. I was only nine. What's that all about?

Shirley: What's the space between the first single and this film? Fourteen years. Only maybe David Bowie has maintained that impact. Fourteen years and he's still this rock'n'roll star who has this amazing effect on people.

Di: It's an indefinable energy. Elvis wanted to be an angel, which is why he had the cape and the jumpsuit, and he knew he had something special, and that's why he could be something bigger than himself. Watching that energy on screen tonight made me feel so humble.

Shirley: He was really slim then, too.

Di: It's a shame they took off I Just Can't Help Believing. I remember every time it came on Top of the Pops I used to tape it off the telly with my little tape recorder. Ever since then I've wanted to be an Elvis impersonator but never thought I could because I'm not a man. His energies go right down the middle - he's very feminine with his clothes and his pretty face, but very masculine with his moves.

Shirley: With Di, we're re-glorifying that image by making Elvis beautiful again. He was a very beautiful man. He was the king of rock'n'roll.

Mark Carter, long-term Elvis fan

When I was 14 I went on a family holiday to Los Angeles. We drove to Las Vegas to see Elvis in one of the concerts that was recorded for That's the Way It Is, but when we stopped for breakfast we met a couple who told us that you had to queue all day for tickets. I was up for it, but my dad said, "Fuck it, we won't bother." The next time we went to Las Vegas, he died. I've seen That's the Way It Is three times since then.

The Vegas years are the best because when Elvis was young and pretty, what he did was rather shallow like all pop music. When he was older, you could see his life was telling on him and his music had more depth. Elvis wasn't particularly political, but when he did protest songs like In the Ghetto and If I Can Dream, he put so much emotion into them that they're more powerful than anything Dylan did. By the time That's the Way It Is came out he was such a huge icon, it would have been hard for the audience to believe that they were seeing him in the flesh. He was a part of history. Unfortunately, by that time he had been so humoured by everyone around him, he wasn't attached to the ground in any way. It was perfectly feasible for him to think he should set up a meeting with President Nixon to become a narcotics agent and wander around the White House with a gun in his pocket. Especially when he was high on speed.

Elvis: That's the Way It Is is released next Friday. The single Suspicious Minds and the album The Live Greatest Hits (both RCA) are released on March 26.

Elvis wasn't particularly political, but when he did protest songs like In the Ghetto and If I Can Dream, he put so much emotion into them that they're more powerful than anything Dylan did. By the time That's the Way It Is came out he was such a huge icon, it would have been hard for the audience to believe that they were seeing him in the flesh. He was a part of history. Unfortunately, by that time he had been so humoured by everyone around him, he wasn't attached to the ground in any way. It was perfectly feasible for him to think he should set up a meeting with President Nixon to become a narcotics agent and wander around the White House with a gun in his pocket. Especially when he was high on speed. Elvis: That's the Way It Is is released next Friday. The single Suspicious Minds and the album The Live Greatest Hits (both RCA) are released on March 26.

webTitle: Heist nets Eta 1.6 tonnes of explosives

fields.headline: Heist nets Eta 1.6 tonnes of explosives
fields.standfirst: Special report: violence in Spain
fields.trailText: A spectacular theft of explosives by presumed members of the Basque group Eta at a warehouse near the French town of Grenoble yesterday raised fears of new bombings across Spain.
fields.body:
A spectacular theft of explosives by presumed members of the Basque group Eta at a warehouse near the French town of Grenoble yesterday raised fears of new bombings across Spain.

French police said there were eight suspected Eta gunmen involved. Seven escaped, but police said they had under arrest one who had earlier held five people, including a small child, captive at the home of a warehouse guard while the gang loaded 1.6 tonnes of explosives on lorries.

The unidentified suspect was captured at a police checkpoint in Annonay, 50 miles away, early yesterday morning, according to anti- terrorist police, who said he was driving a stolen car and carrying a loaded 9mm pistol and false identity papers.

Despite the many checkpoints set up on routes south to the Basque country, there was no sign yesterday of the two lorry loads of explosives, 20,000 detonators and fuses.

The early morning raid began when the gunmen burst into a security guard's house at Verey, on the outskirts of Grenoble. His family and friends were forced to the ground and held at gunpoint by two gang members while the guard was taken to the explosives warehouse and forced to open the gates.

Two hours later, after the explosives had been driven away, the hostages were freed.

Nicole Destenave, one of the captives, said the raiders were polite and well behaved. "They kept their masks on all the time. They spoke Spanish and were very polite. They were considerate as well, because they asked us several times if we wanted a drink or needed to go to the bathroom," she said.

In a single operation, Eta is believed to have dramatically increased its capacity to carry out attacks.

The separatist group snatched eight tonnes of explosives in a combined raid with a French Breton separatist group in Plevine, western France, in 1999. But much of that haul was discovered by French police before it could be used.

Spain's interior ministry said those explosives had now decayed and become unusable. That might explain why Eta bombs in Seville, Malaga and Madrid have failed to explode in recent months, although the group did successfully explode a car bomb in San Sebastian last month, killing two people.

France historically has been a place of refuge, training and preparation for Eta. Its leaders have always lived and plotted their campaigns in the towns and villages of the Basque region of south-west France - away from the reach of Spain's anti-terrorist police.

The group currently has one armed unit based in France, which travels across the border to carry out attacks, according to police.

A few weeks ago French police in the southern region of Les Landes discovered a training ground where Eta members had been learning to use grenade launchers, and Eta's principal military leader, Juan Carlos Garcia Gaztelu, was captured in the south-western French town of Anglet two weeks ago.

Eta claims it is fighting for a country of "seven provinces". Three of these - Labourd, Soule and Basse Navarre - are in France. It does not, however, carry out killings on French soil.

ETA also recruits in the French Basque country. One of it most lethal units, which killed 31 adults and five children in the 80s and 90s, was made up entirely of French Basques.

Eta has killed 800 people in 30 years, 26 of whom have died since it called off a 14-month truce in December 1999.

Shortly after breaking the truce the group tried, but failed, to carry out a massive bombing campaign in Madrid. Spanish police uncovered two 900kg bombs in separate vans as they headed for the capital.

Eta now has sufficient explosives to try a similar attack again and police believe they might be used during the campaign for May elections to the regional Basque government.

"This obviously is not good news," said the interior minister, Mariano Rajoy.

fields.headline: Natural porn killers
fields.standfirst: Smut pedlars are bracing themselves for the George Bush crackdown
fields.trailText: Smut pedlars are bracing themselves for the George Bush crackdown
fields.body:
The two most powerful men in the US today are called Bush and Dick. That might sound like good news for the pornography industry. It's not. Pornography is no laughing matter for Prez and Veep. The adult entertainment moguls have been here before - and this time they're ready for the axe's descent.

For US pornographers, the Clinton era represented eight years of expansion. The Justice Department adopted a hands-off role, and having a horny president didn't hurt. Day after day, revelation by revelation, it seemed the US steadily became a dirtier nation.

Porn statistics confirm this. There are now 25,000 adult bookstores in the US; 10,000 new hardcore video titles are released every year, up from 300 in 1980. Last year saw 711m porno rentals and the industry's annual turnover is now close to $10bn a year.

At the same time, we've seen a broadening of the taboos that porn is prepared to break, a massive increase in the explicit depiction of practices guaranteed to offend the likes of the new attorney general, John Ashcroft.

Practices long avoided by pornographers because of their perceived propensity for drawing litigious fire have sneaked into the fringes of porn's mainstream. Go to any conventional bookshop in America and pick up Penthouse. Inside you'll find at least one hardcore photo layout that includes unsimulated fellatio, penetration and that hardcore staple, the "pop-shot".

The Republicans see the White House Clinton vacated as an Augean stable of licentiousness and depravity requiring a Herculean hosing- down (the first thing George Jr did was to remove the Oval Office's carpet). We can now expect Bush to hit history's rewind button, flashing back to Ed Meese's lengthy, expensive Pornography Commission (conducted by men who signed their memos "Yours in Christ"). Meese oversaw widespread busts in the porn community, and Bush Sr's administration managed 30 court actions. Dubya told campaign audiences last year that "porn has no place in a decent society".

No one yet knows what form his hard line will take, but already America's smut pedlars are preparing for a new onslaught. Larry Flynt, the publisher of Hustler and Barely Legal, has issued his video production arm with a 24-point memo on what shouldn't be shown in his video releases. Now off limits are the following: blindfolds, wax-dripping, urinating, sex between black men and white women (though not white men and black women because racism is alive and well in porn), bisexuals, transsexuals, menstruation and, uh-oh, "sex in coffins".

This is not the hillbilly deluxe, first amendment literalist Larry Flynt I remember: the man who jump-started the move toward greater explicitness in 1990s pornography. I was present the day porn's new dawn broke, in 1994. The wheelchair-bound Flynt, who was shot and crippled by a rightwing maniac in 1978, had just recovered from spinal surgery, having spent years waiting for laser procedures.

Now he was well again, ready once more to take up the reins of power at Larry Flynt Publications, which I had just joined as a copy editor (later I wrote the Hustler letters page - my mother was so proud). Staff were called to the conference room, where Larry sat under a gigantic reproduction of his late wife Althea's first and grotesquely explicit Hustler centrefold.

He outlined his grandiose plans for a revitalised Hustler. "I want vaginal penetration!" he croaked weirdly. "I want cum-shots! I want it all! No limits!"

We all thought he was demented, but within months Hustler was featuring everything he'd proposed. Within a year, Penthouse had copied him and soon film-makers followed suit. To everyone's astonishment, not a peep was heard from prosecutors - until now. Flynt, always first into the fray, has become the first, so to speak, to withdraw.

In the 1970s, pornographers considered themselves an extension of counterculture, and porn was often produced under threat of legal action. Sets were busted, performers jailed, production companies harassed. Porn outfits were fly-by-night, one-man operations on the fringes of the law. But now, after the eight-year legal ceasefire, the major companies are million-dollar corporations run by the sons of the original pioneers.

Now that the onslaught is due to recommence, there's no one left with the history, cash and experience to finance expensive legal battles. Even Larry has backed off to await the coming storm. In the 1980s, he spent half his fortune on a legal fight against Rev Jerry Falwell that went to the supreme court and enshrined certain journalistic liberties forever.

Without a comparable champion today, porn will retrench, contract and batten down the hatches for the next four years. The idea of John Ashcroft triumphing is simply too abhorrent for me to contemplate, so I'm rooting for the perverts.
