webTitle: Pawel Pawlikowski, director of The Last Resort

fields.headline: Meet me in Margate
fields.standfirst: Trouble seems to follow Pawel Pawlikowski around. MPs tried to ban his film about the Bosnian war. Then came his documentary about the leader of Russia's far right. So when he turned up in Kent to shoot a feature film about asylum seekers, the mud began to fly.  Fiachra Gibbons on the making of Last Resort
fields.trailText: Trouble seems to follow Pawel Pawlikowski around. MPs tried to ban his film about the Bosnian war. Then came his documentary about the leader of Russia's far right. So when he turned up in Kent to shoot a feature film about asylum seekers, the mud began to fly. Fiachra Gibbons on the making of Last Resort
fields.body:
NEW YORK TIMES

"[Tanya] is stuck, uprooted and friendless, in a place where the bleak tones of sea and sky emphasise the general absence of hope.

The thoughtful stylishness of Mr Pawlikowski's direction... extends to [Tanya] the dignity and compassion that only art can confer."

LOS ANGELES TIMES

"[They end up in] a lonely, isolated tower, surrounded by fences and even barbed wire, located next to a distressed amusement park whose brazen Dreamland Welcomes You sign mocks them with its unconvincing civility... this is the best class of poetic realism, the kind you can believe in without a trace of hesitation."

HOLLYWOOD REPORTER

"The film should help position the award-winning documentarian [Pawlikowski] as a feature writer-director of considerable promise.

[Margate is portrayed as] a bleak holding tank of a failed resort area. Looking out on to a dilapidated amusement park, the area is a virtual prison."

It looks like a dump, that's what it looks like - from "Margate", the closing chapter of Graham Swift's Last Orders.

You have to feel sorry for Margate. There it is, stuck out like an untended boil on the backside of Kent, disowned by its solidly respectable neighbours, Ramsgate and Broadstairs, whose facades seem pulled in a permanent rictus of displeasure and embarrassment at its coarse proletarian pleasures. All through the 1980s, London councils dumped the mad and the bad - their undeserving poor - into the empty bucket-and-spade guesthouses along its broad bay. Even they didn't stay.

To top it all, there is Tracey Emin. "Margate made me what I am," the artist once declared. But she won't be bringing charges. "Because to me, Margate is beautiful, romantic, charismatic, sad, eccentric and screwed-up... You don't lose your virginity there, you have it broken into."

Like its most illustrious daughter, Margate has had to learn to trade on its own tackiness. Buster Bloodvessel, the gargantuan ska singer, opened a hotel near the front called Fatty Towers as a taste-free retreat for lardy lovers. But despite the reinforced beds and the gut-buster breakfasts ("2,000 calories in every bite") it too closed down.

Fatty Towers may end up, like most of the old Regency hotels in the Cliftonville area, providing a home for refugees, though the £20 worth of food vouchers they get each week wouldn't keep its former residents in bubble and squeak.

Close to 3,000 asylum-seekers have been left to stew in one small district of this town of little more than 45,000 people. Such a glaring example of how, in the words of William Hague, England has been turned into a "foreign land" has inevitably attracted Ann Widdecombe as well as the National Front, which has held six rallies in Margate in the past year. Neither Widdecombe nor the Front drew enough supporters to outnumber the police.

For, while the locals may not welcome the influx of refugees, they know that even if the flocks of lonely Afghan and Albanian men who walk the streets were allowed to work, there is none for them here.

"For a place where you come to have fun, we've become a net exporter of misery," says Mike Pearce, the droll editor of the local paper, the Thanet Times. "We're either Dole-on-sea, Poverty-on-sea or Refugees-on-sea. They are always making up some godawful name for Margate." He doesn't mention The Cat-flap at the End of the A28. Or the town's place at the end of Graham Swift's novel Last Orders: it's to Margate that the four middle-aged, pissed-up south London geezers come to scatter the ashes of their old mate, Jack Dodds.

Last winter - a time of year when Margate never looks its best - another bloody foreigner with an unpronounceable name came to Margate. He brought a camera crew with him, and he was making a film about a flaky Russian single mother who had exchanged a crumbling tower block in Moscow for an equally crumbling one overlooking Dreamland, the kind of funfair of which nightmares are made. With a sub-plot that involved cyberporn and pre-teen vodka binges, it was clear that he wasn't making a holiday programme.

Which seemed like a gift for Sandy Ezekiel, Thanet's leading Tory, who has never tired of exposing how the Labour-led council has allowed the town to be overrun by refugees. Was not the film's very name, Last Resort, another nail in Margate's coffin? On Tuesday last week, councillor Ezekiel called for the resignation of the tourism chief, Iris Johnston, for allowing this "derogatory film" to be shot.

One can imagine how much greater his rage would have been if he'd realised the film's maverick director, Pawel Pawlikowski - once a refugee himself - was the same BBC man MPs accused of consorting with enemy during the Bosnian war for making Serbian Epics, a masterly documentary that examined the forces that drive Serb nationalism. Anyone who could persuade the "psychiatrist and poet" Radovan Karadzic to stand on the hills above Sarajevo and read his early verses prophesying the city's destruction as his own artillery blew it to bits must be a secret traitor, some Tory MPs reasoned. Fortunately, attempts to ban Serbian Epics failed - so, for his next film, Pawlikowski took a cruise down the Volga with the extreme Russian nationalist Vladimir Zhirinovsky.

But all Ezekiel had to go on when he launched his attack in the Thanet Times last week was the imagined slight to Margate. "Councillor Johnson was well aware of the film and its content," he protested. "Sources within the council have informed us that she went about assisting the production team with the recruitment of asylum-seekers to act in the film."

This was a serious accusation, as asylum-seekers are forbidden from working. The film, he went on, was "made entirely in her ward and this amounts to gross negligence. It should have been properly vetted. I have called for an inquiry into how this film was ever allowed to be filmed in Margate."

Ezekiel, however, was in for a surprise. For Last Resort is not a self-righteous rant against racism or provincial smallmindedness. It does not, for example, contain a single skinhead or a Dr Martens boot. Nor does it make any bones about the fact that its heroine's claim of political asylum is as bogus as a three-pound note. Instead it is a rather sublime and surprising love story about a twice-married, rather dippy Muscovite called Tanya who, with only a year or two left to trade on her doll-like looks, drags her 10-year-old son to England to throw herself at the mercy of a man with whom she has had a fleeting romance.

Two days before the row broke out in Margate, the director Pawel Pawlikowski was adding a Bafta for the best British newcomer to the Michael Powell award for best British film at Edinburgh, and the international critics' prize at the London Film Festival. Meanwhile, in the US, the film was getting the kind of reviews American indie directors would sell their Latino maids into slavery for. Both the New York Times and Los Angeles Times raved over Pawlikowski's rare knack of combining "realism and warmth", how the film "leaves you with a feeling of having glimpsed something essential about the way the world is now".

Back in Margate, those councillors who had actually seen the film were breathing a sigh of relief. "I am getting sick and tired of councillor Ezekiel's promotion of untruths," councillor Johnston said. "Unlike him, I have had a preview of the film which is a tender, gentle love story. There are some remarkable shots of the seafront which can only re-emphasise what we all know - that we have a stunning bay." Councillors also point out that the name of the resort in the film has been changed to Stonehaven.

Richard Nicholson, the council's Labour leader, and the man behind the plan for a £7m arts centre dedicated to the town's other great artist, JMW Turner, thought it might even enhance Margate's new arty image. "The story centres on the desperation of a young woman with a young son, abandoned when they reach a foreign country. Obviously, the director needed to invoke this feeling of isolation, and by clever use of parts of Margate in the off season was able to portray this to good effect. I do not think this will harm Margate in any way. This film could actually encourage more visitors who will be pleasantly surprised when they arrive to find not only the evocative locations used in the film, but many other fine aspects of Margate and Thanet."

Pawlikowski wasn't confident of a positive local reaction when he started filming. "Back then I called it Russian Lover or something like that. It would have been asking for trouble, just crazy, to put Last Resort on the clapperboard. Many people in Margate were suspicious of us at first and you can't blame them. They thought we had come down to put the boot into them, to take the refugees' side. The locals generally don't like the refugees and they don't want them there - things are tough enough for them. They assume the refugees get all sorts of benefits English people don't get, which is rubbish, of course."

Pawlikowski wanted to create an imaginative landscape in which Tanya (played by the Russian actress Dina Korzun) and her son Artiom (Artiom Strelnikov) felt both lost and trapped in a kind of Stalag Butlin's, fenced in by arbitrary, unexplained rules, barbed wire and bureaucracy, a landscape without cars or other means of escape, where large groups of sad, unshaven men, Kurds and Afghans, wandered aimlessly all day observed by CCTV cameras.

"When I first when down to Margate," he said, "my first contact was with the Roma, the Gypsies, who were the only refugees really who interacted with the locals. Even with them, what struck me was how little their world extended beyond what they called Margatta. They would make epic journeys to a strange place at the far end of their known world called Greyvas End. You don't have to be there long to realise that most of the asylum-seekers are clueless peasants. They are Kurds and Afghans mostly. Some have not even lived in cities before. They are all stunned, many don't move because they don't know what to do. When the local Margate kids go round spitting at them, you can see their shock because they come from cultures were people have manners, where strangers receive hospitality. To me, they looked like they were living inside a Kafka story."

In a typical touch, Pawlikowski cast one of those spitting girls - who could have stepped from the scrawled pages of one of Tracey Emin's lurid teenage diaries - as one of the prepubescent gang who introduce 10-year-old Artiom to the joys of smuggled Belgian vodka and cigarettes, and the first, disturbing stirrings of sex.

In this Kafkaesque Ingerland where caffs sell batter without fish and meat pies without filling, and where you don't get change from your food vouchers, Tanya and Artiom are befriended by Alfie, a skid-row fixer who works on the slot machines down the arcade and who introduces the boy to the rudiments of English ("10 Benson & Hedges, please") and the correct way to mix his chicken tikka.

When he first landed in Margate with his skeleton crew, Pawlikowski had little more than a loose semi-autobiographical story to go on. (He came to Britain from Poland with his family when he was 12). "Initially Alfie [played by Paddy Considine, a former boxer who made a startling screen debut in Shane Meadows's A Room for Romeo Brass] was to be a much more ambiguous, slighty threatened character, but the chemistry with Dina was magical. Paddy is a real phenomenon. We all lived together during the shoot, that is part of my method, so we were able to improvise scenes and come up with new ideas in the evening and over dinner. I am an insomniac, too, so I just kept writing all night sometimes. That is the way I like to work."

Like its director, Last Resort is a very peculiar animal. It mixes gritty realism with a very un-British dreamlike quality which transcends the grimness of its setting. The handheld, documentary sequences of refugees huddled in shuffling queues for a solitary phonebox or the interior fug of greasy spoons are cut with beautiful, lingering wide-angle landscapes to create the eerie perspective of people who spend their days peering out uncomprehendingly at the strange country beyond their windows.

"I'm interested in the forgotten places, the dumping grounds," says Pawlikowski, " the places we have taken out of our mental picture. I want people to see images of lives that will catch them off balance."

Surprises is what Pawlikowski is all about. He really surprised the BBC with his last project, Twockers. They commissioned him to go off and make a documentary in Halifax and he returned with a haunting TV film about a boy burglar who befriends a pregnant teenager, a kind of hyper-dysfunctional Kes crossed with the Lord of the Rings. It may sound unutterably depressing - three tabloid "Rat Boys" sitting on a settee above a sink estate discussing in their own skroaty slang what old dear to do over next - but it wasn't. Even the break-ins looked balletic. "The kids we found and improvised with knew what they were doing," he says.

The only tragic thing about this beautifully-crafted gem was that it could never have been made by a British director. Pawlikowski makes no bones about his belief that, with a few notable exceptions, British film-making sucks. "I see all these guys running around that are all technique. They have nothing to say and the stupid thing is that they are not even curious and they don't care. They make films the way you and I go to the supermarket, picking this image and that style off the shelves. Everything is either plot, plot, plot or style, style, style and when they try to do something that reflects life or tells a story it turns into some awful issue-based thing. It is really frustrating when you want to see something original, something different. Most of the really interesting film-makers in this country are over 50."

Pawlikowski has a great Polish love for argument, for taking extreme positions that can't possible be held and clinging on for the hell of it. "My big problem is that I'm really a feudalist - the world and film-making would be a lot simpler if it was feudal."

His recipe is simple. "You have to be a conman to make really good films today," he says. "You have to work inside the system but against it. Take the money and run." He has huckstered the BBC into backing his pet projects for the past 10 years. "It's got harder, but as long as I kept winning prizes they let me get away with it." With Dostoevsky's Travels, he spun a hilarious and fantastical documentary around the writer Fyodor's great grandson Dimitri, a St Petersburg tram driver, whom he found struggling to break free of the clutches of an overbearing vegetarian German baroness who had held him prisoner in her schloss in Schleswig- Holstein: "I rang [the novelist] Nigel Williams, who was editing Bookmark at the time and said, 'I got this great idea, Nigel, send me some money immediately, I'll explain later.' Every wino in Russia can seemingly quote from its exhaustive menu of cocktails in which eau de Cologne, French polish, and deodorant are among the more favoured ingredients.

Pawlikowski's career hasn't been all Felixes, Emmys and Prix Italias, however. For four years the BBC's obsession with voyeurism and fly-on-the-wall documentaries left him out in the cold. Then his one brush with the lilliputian world of British star power produced what Pawlikowski calls "my near nemesis", the low-budget BBC and Russian co-production, The Stringer, where Anna Friel took top billing ahead of some of Andrei Tarkovsky's greatest actors. If Twockers and Last Resort were his time in purgatory to pay for the £1.4m he blew on The Stringer, he has used it to hone one of the most distinctive styles of British film-making.

"You have got to go against the grain to stand any chance of making anything that will pass the test of time. When we went to Bosnia to shoot Serbian Epics, we must have been the only crew there who didn't shoot a single frame of fighting. That was a perverse thing to do, but the film we made has not aged like so much else that tried to catch the rage of the moment."

Now that the world has completely lost interest in Bosnia, he has followed that logic to the letter by returning to Sarajevo. "It has turned into this weird protectorate. It's crazy. I have this great idea..."

At the Thanet Times, Mike Pearce revels in a similar contrarianism. He wistfully regrets that the furore over Last Resort has run out of steam so quickly. "I had thought there might be more in it," he says, though he is proud of how Margate has stood aloof from the racist excesses of Dover, where the local paper described asylum-seekers as "human sewage".

Thanet Film Club are planning to show it in nearby Broadstairs, he tells me, but not until the autumn. "Films like Last Resort don't normally make it to Margate," says Mike, "I'm sure it is great, but it's not my thing. I'm more a tits and bums man myself."

Last Resort opens at selected cinemas from next Friday.
fields.bodyText: NEW YORK TIMES "[Tanya] is stuck, uprooted and friendless, in a place where the bleak tones of sea and sky emphasise the general absence of hope. The thoughtful stylishness of Mr Pawlikowski's direction... extends to [Tanya] the dignity and compassion that only art can confer." LOS ANGELES TIMES "[They end up in] a lonely, isolated tower, surrounded by fences and even barbed wire, located next to a distressed amusement park whose brazen Dreamland Welcomes You sign mocks them with its unconvincing civility... this is the best class of poetic realism, the kind you can believe in without a trace of hesitation." HOLLYWOOD REPORTER "The film should help position the award-winning documentarian [Pawlikowski] as a feature writer-director of considerable promise. [Margate is portrayed as] a bleak holding tank of a failed resort area. Looking out on to a dilapidated amusement park, the area is a virtual prison." It looks like a dump, that's what it looks like - from "Margate", the closing chapter of Graham Swift's Last Orders. You have to feel sorry for Margate. There it is, stuck out like an untended boil on the backside of Kent, disowned by its solidly respectable neighbours, Ramsgate and Broadstairs, whose facades seem pulled in a permanent rictus of displeasure and embarrassment at its coarse proletarian pleasures. All through the 1980s, London councils dumped the mad and the bad - their undeserving poor - into the empty bucket-and-spade guesthouses along its broad bay. Even they didn't stay. To top it all, there is Tracey Emin. "Margate made me what I am," the artist once declared. But she won't be bringing charges. "Because to me, Margate is beautiful, romantic, charismatic, sad, eccentric and screwed-up... You don't lose your virginity there, you have it broken into." Like its most illustrious daughter, Margate has had to learn to trade on its own tackiness. Buster Bloodvessel, the gargantuan ska singer, opened a hotel near the front called Fatty Towers as a taste-free retreat for lardy lovers. But despite the reinforced beds and the gut-buster breakfasts ("2,000 calories in every bite") it too closed down. Fatty Towers may end up, like most of the old Regency hotels in the Cliftonville area, providing a home for refugees, though the £20 worth of food vouchers they get each week wouldn't keep its former residents in bubble and squeak. Close to 3,000 asylum-seekers have been left to stew in one small district of this town of little more than 45,000 people. Such a glaring example of how, in the words of William Hague, England has been turned into a "foreign land" has inevitably attracted Ann Widdecombe as well as the National Front, which has held six rallies in Margate in the past year. Neither Widdecombe nor the Front drew enough supporters to outnumber the police. For, while the locals may not welcome the influx of refugees, they know that even if the flocks of lonely Afghan and Albanian men who walk the streets were allowed to work, there is none for them here. "For a place where you come to have fun, we've become a net exporter of misery," says Mike Pearce, the droll editor of the local paper, the Thanet Times. "We're either Dole-on-sea, Poverty-on-sea or Refugees-on-sea. They are always making up some godawful name for Margate." He doesn't mention The Cat-flap at the End of the A28. Or the town's place at the end of Graham Swift's novel Last Orders: it's to Margate that the four middle-aged, pissed-up south London geezers come to scatter the ashes of their old mate, Jack Dodds. Last winter - a time of year when Margate never looks its best - another bloody foreigner with an unpronounceable name came to Margate. He brought a camera crew with him, and he was making a film about a flaky Russian single mother who had exchanged a crumbling tower block in Moscow for an equally crumbling one overlooking Dreamland, the kind of funfair of which nightmares are made. With a sub-plot that involved cyberporn and pre-teen vodka binges, it was clear that he wasn't making a holiday programme. Which seemed like a gift for Sandy Ezekiel, Thanet's leading Tory, who has never tired of exposing how the Labour-led council has allowed the town to be overrun by refugees. Was not the film's very name, Last Resort, another nail in Margate's coffin? On Tuesday last week, councillor Ezekiel called for the resignation of the tourism chief, Iris Johnston, for allowing this "derogatory film" to be shot. One can imagine how much greater his rage would have been if he'd realised the film's maverick director, Pawel Pawlikowski - once a refugee himself - was the same BBC man MPs accused of consorting with enemy during the Bosnian war for making Serbian Epics, a masterly documentary that examined the forces that drive Serb nationalism. Anyone who could persuade the "psychiatrist and poet" Radovan Karadzic to stand on the hills above Sarajevo and read his early verses prophesying the city's destruction as his own artillery blew it to bits must be a secret traitor, some Tory MPs reasoned. Fortunately, attempts to ban Serbian Epics failed - so, for his next film, Pawlikowski took a cruise down the Volga with the extreme Russian nationalist Vladimir Zhirinovsky. But all Ezekiel had to go on when he launched his attack in the Thanet Times last week was the imagined slight to Margate. "Councillor Johnson was well aware of the film and its content," he protested. "Sources within the council have informed us that she went about assisting the production team with the recruitment of asylum-seekers to act in the film." This was a serious accusation, as asylum-seekers are forbidden from working. The film, he went on, was "made entirely in her ward and this amounts to gross negligence. It should have been properly vetted. I have called for an inquiry into how this film was ever allowed to be filmed in Margate." Ezekiel, however, was in for a surprise. For Last Resort is not a self-righteous rant against racism or provincial smallmindedness. It does not, for example, contain a single skinhead or a Dr Martens boot. Nor does it make any bones about the fact that its heroine's claim of political asylum is as bogus as a three-pound note. Instead it is a rather sublime and surprising love story about a twice-married, rather dippy Muscovite called Tanya who, with only a year or two left to trade on her doll-like looks, drags her 10-year-old son to England to throw herself at the mercy of a man with whom she has had a fleeting romance. Two days before the row broke out in Margate, the director Pawel Pawlikowski was adding a Bafta for the best British newcomer to the Michael Powell award for best British film at Edinburgh, and the international critics' prize at the London Film Festival. Meanwhile, in the US, the film was getting the kind of reviews American indie directors would sell their Latino maids into slavery for. Both the New York Times and Los Angeles Times raved over Pawlikowski's rare knack of combining "realism and warmth", how the film "leaves you with a feeling of having glimpsed something essential about the way the world is now". Back in Margate, those councillors who had actually seen the film were breathing a sigh of relief. "I am getting sick and tired of councillor Ezekiel's promotion of untruths," councillor Johnston said. "Unlike him, I have had a preview of the film which is a tender, gentle love story. There are some remarkable shots of the seafront which can only re-emphasise what we all know - that we have a stunning bay." Councillors also point out that the name of the resort in the film has been changed to Stonehaven. Richard Nicholson, the council's Labour leader, and the man behind the plan for a £7m arts centre dedicated to the town's other great artist, JMW Turner, thought it might even enhance Margate's new arty image. "The story centres on the desperation of a young woman with a young son, abandoned when they reach a foreign country. Obviously, the director needed to invoke this feeling of isolation, and by clever use of parts of Margate in the off season was able to portray this to good effect. I do not think this will harm Margate in any way. This film could actually encourage more visitors who will be pleasantly surprised when they arrive to find not only the evocative locations used in the film, but many other fine aspects of Margate and Thanet." Pawlikowski wasn't confident of a positive local reaction when he started filming. "Back then I called it Russian Lover or something like that. It would have been asking for trouble, just crazy, to put Last Resort on the clapperboard. Many people in Margate were suspicious of us at first and you can't blame them. They thought we had come down to put the boot into them, to take the refugees' side. The locals generally don't like the refugees and they don't want them there - things are tough enough for them. They assume the refugees get all sorts of benefits English people don't get, which is rubbish, of course." Pawlikowski wanted to create an imaginative landscape in which Tanya (played by the Russian actress Dina Korzun) and her son Artiom (Artiom Strelnikov) felt both lost and trapped in a kind of Stalag Butlin's, fenced in by arbitrary, unexplained rules, barbed wire and bureaucracy, a landscape without cars or other means of escape, where large groups of sad, unshaven men, Kurds and Afghans, wandered aimlessly all day observed by CCTV cameras. "When I first when down to Margate," he said, "my first contact was with the Roma, the Gypsies, who were the only refugees really who interacted with the locals. Even with them, what struck me was how little their world extended beyond what they called Margatta. They would make epic journeys to a strange place at the far end of their known world called Greyvas End. You don't have to be there long to realise that most of the asylum-seekers are clueless peasants. They are Kurds and Afghans mostly. Some have not even lived in cities before. They are all stunned, many don't move because they don't know what to do. When the local Margate kids go round spitting at them, you can see their shock because they come from cultures were people have manners, where strangers receive hospitality. To me, they looked like they were living inside a Kafka story." In a typical touch, Pawlikowski cast one of those spitting girls - who could have stepped from the scrawled pages of one of Tracey Emin's lurid teenage diaries - as one of the prepubescent gang who introduce 10-year-old Artiom to the joys of smuggled Belgian vodka and cigarettes, and the first, disturbing stirrings of sex. In this Kafkaesque Ingerland where caffs sell batter without fish and meat pies without filling, and where you don't get change from your food vouchers, Tanya and Artiom are befriended by Alfie, a skid-row fixer who works on the slot machines down the arcade and who introduces the boy to the rudiments of English ("10 Benson & Hedges, please") and the correct way to mix his chicken tikka. When he first landed in Margate with his skeleton crew, Pawlikowski had little more than a loose semi-autobiographical story to go on. (He came to Britain from Poland with his family when he was 12). "Initially Alfie [played by Paddy Considine, a former boxer who made a startling screen debut in Shane Meadows's A Room for Romeo Brass] was to be a much more ambiguous, slighty threatened character, but the chemistry with Dina was magical. Paddy is a real phenomenon. We all lived together during the shoot, that is part of my method, so we were able to improvise scenes and come up with new ideas in the evening and over dinner. I am an insomniac, too, so I just kept writing all night sometimes. That is the way I like to work." Like its director, Last Resort is a very peculiar animal. It mixes gritty realism with a very un-British dreamlike quality which transcends the grimness of its setting. The handheld, documentary sequences of refugees huddled in shuffling queues for a solitary phonebox or the interior fug of greasy spoons are cut with beautiful, lingering wide-angle landscapes to create the eerie perspective of people who spend their days peering out uncomprehendingly at the strange country beyond their windows. "I'm interested in the forgotten places, the dumping grounds," says Pawlikowski, " the places we have taken out of our mental picture. I want people to see images of lives that will catch them off balance." Surprises is what Pawlikowski is all about. He really surprised the BBC with his last project, Twockers. They commissioned him to go off and make a documentary in Halifax and he returned with a haunting TV film about a boy burglar who befriends a pregnant teenager, a kind of hyper-dysfunctional Kes crossed with the Lord of the Rings. It may sound unutterably depressing - three tabloid "Rat Boys" sitting on a settee above a sink estate discussing in their own skroaty slang what old dear to do over next - but it wasn't. Even the break-ins looked balletic. "The kids we found and improvised with knew what they were doing," he says. The only tragic thing about this beautifully-crafted gem was that it could never have been made by a British director. Pawlikowski makes no bones about his belief that, with a few notable exceptions, British film-making sucks. "I see all these guys running around that are all technique. They have nothing to say and the stupid thing is that they are not even curious and they don't care. They make films the way you and I go to the supermarket, picking this image and that style off the shelves. Everything is either plot, plot, plot or style, style, style and when they try to do something that reflects life or tells a story it turns into some awful issue-based thing. It is really frustrating when you want to see something original, something different. Most of the really interesting film-makers in this country are over 50." Pawlikowski has a great Polish love for argument, for taking extreme positions that can't possible be held and clinging on for the hell of it. webTitle: When good housekeeping fails to pay off

fields.headline: When good housekeeping fails to pay off
fields.standfirst: Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: Getting nothing extra from the Arts Council is a cruel blow for the Theatre Royal in York, whose staff inevitably feel that they are paying an unfair price for good housekeeping.
fields.body:
Getting nothing extra from the Arts Council is a cruel blow for the Theatre Royal in York, whose staff inevitably feel that they are paying an unfair price for good housekeeping.

Alone of the Yorkshire region's many and thriving theatres, the Royal has worked and saved its way out of deficit, without sacrificing a reputation for original, challenging productions.

Kafka's Dick opens a week today with Matthew Kelly in the cast, and Hull Truck's first production for children, Big Trouble in the Little Bedroom, arrives in the summer. Elizabeth Jones, the executive director who turned the red to black but is now leaving in frustration at the endless funding hide-and-seek, cannot help but gnash the teeth she has gritted during her 10 years in charge.

"I'm obviously very disappointed that there's no extra money from this pot," she said, a reaction given vim by the theatre's record of helping itself. Yorkshire Arts, the Arts Council's local filter body, denies any element of punishing the virtuous, but the Royal has shown only too well how to stand on its own two feet.

Ms Jones said: "We found the money ourselves to appoint an education outreach officer, and that revived a theatre-in-education programme which lapsed when the theatre nearly closed 10 years ago. Yes, it's modest by the standards of big regional theatres, but it's very successful and popular."

Recent work includes a new mystery play written as well as performed by local schools, and the Royal has also found funding for building improvements and redecoration. Meanwhile, the staging of Kate Atkinson's Behind the Scenes at the Museum, set in York, won national critical approval for the main house.

The budget cut in real terms does not, however, mean anything remotely approaching closure, says Ms Jones, who is furious that the Royal has been included in lists of the doomed.

"There is no question, even remotely, of shutting down," she added. "There is no threat of any kind to our core funding. What we are doing now is picking ourselves up and applying, as ever, for something else under a different grants programme."

fields.headline: Lake's success wins generous reward
fields.standfirst: Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: A grant rise of over 230% has taken the north's newest theatre to heights almost as giddy as the neighbouring Lake District fells - a natural barrier theatre-goers of Cumbria have happily ignored.
fields.body:
A grant rise of over 230% has taken the north's newest theatre to heights almost as giddy as the neighbouring Lake District fells - a natural barrier theatre-goers of Cumbria have happily ignored.

In less than two years, the Theatre by the Lake in Keswick has gone from a summer-only rep whose customers were 75% tourists to a year-round theatre overwhelmingly patronised by locals.

"As centres go in Cumbria, we are fairly central," said the theatre's executive director, Patric Gilchrist, who described the regional response as "simply fantastic". That is the key reason for the Arts Council's generosity, which ups the theatre's annual grant from £113,000 this year to £333,000 in April 2003.

The extra money will allow the 20 staff and resident company to build dramatically on enterprising origins. Keswick's original theatre was the post-war touring Century Theatre's famous Blue Box, a convoy of ex-army lorries bolted together to form a prefab.

Uncomfortable stints in the stalls finally galvanised local people to raise £6.25m for a new building, opened in August 1999. The Lake's productions have been suitably original since.

Mr Gilchrist and artistic director Ian Forrest will use the extra money to broaden the repertoire. The expansion of the theatre has been paralleled by educational work in Cumbria's scattered communities; extra funding will add to that, and also allow some risk-taking commissioning of new work.

webTitle: Wahid's whirlwind visit to Borneo fails to mollify his critics

fields.headline: Wahid's whirlwind visit to Borneo fails to mollify his critics
fields.standfirst: Special report: Indonesia and East Timor
fields.trailText: The Indonesian president, Abdurrahman Wahid, returned from a two-week overseas tour yesterday and within hours flew to the scene of brutal ethnic cleansing to try to silence calls for his resignation and stave off impeachment proceedings.
fields.body:
The Indonesian president, Abdurrahman Wahid, returned from a two-week overseas tour yesterday and within hours flew to the scene of brutal ethnic cleansing to try to silence calls for his resignation and stave off impeachment proceedings.

But his whirlwind visit to Central Kalimantan on Borneo, where indigenous Dayaks have killed at least 470 migrants from Madura in the past three weeks and driven out tens of thousand, failed to placate his growing army of critics.

Amien Rais, the upper house speaker and a vociferous opponent of Mr Wahid, said that all the main parties had now agreed to send him a second letter of censure: the final warning under the Indonesian constitution before formal impeachment.

Impeachment is supposed to take at least three months. But with Mr Wahid still defiant and Indonesia's economic, social and political woes growing daily, more and more politicians are willing to bypass the constitution and accelerate the handover of power to Vice-President Megawati Sukarnoputri.

During Mr Wahid's absence she appeared noticeably more presidential.

Mr Wahid's half-hour tour of the riot-torn town of Sampit and meetings in the provincial capital, Palangkaraya, were designed to dispel the allegation that he is indifferent to people's suffering. The allegation was prompted by his insistence on leaving the country after the crisis erupted and his refusal to return early when the scale of the slaughter became clear.

His promises of money to rebuild settlements and improve educational opportunities for locals seemed to have little impact on the hundreds of Dayaks who were prevented from airing their grievances at any of the president's appointments. Within minutes of his leaving Palangkaraya the police fire at hundreds of stone-throwing protesters, seriously injuring at least three.

"The bottom line is that Gus Dur [Mr Wahid's nickname] just does not care," a presidential palace insider said."We've seen it time and again. He's cocooned in his own little world and is not going to change."

Mr Wahid demonstrated his stubbornness on the flight back to Indonesia on Wednesday night. "Whatever happens, I must remain president," he told reporters, adding that he feared several regions would secede if he stepped down before his term ends in 2004.

Such intransigence and refusal to absorb criticism prompted Mr Rais to call for the president to be removed from office as soon as possible.

In the past fortnight Mr Rais has organised several meetings involving the six major political parties - including, most significantly, Ms Megawati's Indonesian Democratic Party of Struggle (PDIP) - at which he claims it was agreed to proceed with impeachment.

If this loose and unlikely coalition of nationalist and Islamic parties holds together, then Mr Wahid has little chance of survival, because his National Awakening party controls just 10% of the legislature.

Mr Rais conceded that there was no constitutional basis to hasten the special parliamentary impeachment session.

Others are not so sure. Pramono Anung, a senior PDIP members who is close to Ms Megawati, said: "The situation is getting so out of control so quickly that now we might have to ignore the constitution for the sake of the nation.

Besides failing to address crises such as Kalimantan, Mr Wahid has failed to end the sectarian conflict in the Moluccas and appease separatists in Irian Jaya and Aceh.

Speculation is growing that Ms Megawati and others will encourage Mr Wahid, who has suffered several strokes, to resign on health grounds as a face-saving solution.

webTitle: Mugabe will chase me off if I meddle, Mbeki insists

fields.headline: Mugabe will chase me off if I meddle, Mbeki insists
fields.standfirst: Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: President Thabo Mbeki has dismissed calls for sanctions against Zimbabwe for its illegal land seizures and rising political oppression with a warning that the economic collapse of South Africa's neighbour could backfire on the entire region.
fields.body:
President Thabo Mbeki has dismissed calls for sanctions against Zimbabwe for its illegal land seizures and rising political oppression with a warning that the economic collapse of South Africa's neighbour could backfire on the entire region.

He defended his widely criticised policy of "good neighbourliness" towards Zimbabwe's government in an interview with an Afrikaans news- paper, Beeld, by saying he was in no position to order Mr Mugabe around.

But the impression that Pretoria is not only unwilling to criticise Mr Mugabe but has become an apologist for the regime has been reinforced by the South African justice minister, who said he did not believe Zimbabwe's judges were under attack from their government.

Mr Mbeki told Beeld that the pleas for sanctions by the South African opposition and European politicians such as Britain's shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude, were futile.

"In instituting sanctions, life in Zimbabwe would come to a standstill," he said.

"And then what? It's easy for people in Europe to issue statements, but they don't inherit the consequences. Zimbabweans would cross our borders and come to us. We share one fate in this region."

The land and political crisis shrunk Zimbabwe's economy by 6% last year, has cost tens of thousands of jobs, devalued the national currency and sent foreign investors fleeing. South Africa is afraid that if the crisis deepens much more, hundreds of thousands of Zimbabweans will head south, worsening the country's rampant and sometimes violent xenophobia.

Last week Mr Mbeki announced that, under pressure from the senior executives of some of the world's top companies, he would meet Mr Mugabe to express "very serious concern" at the events in Zimbabwe.

But this week, while he said he was exerting some pressure on Mr Mugabe to adhere to the legal redistribution of land and to end the violence, he made it clear that he would only go so far.

"We cannot have a situation where Thabo Mbeki goes and tells President Mugabe what to do. He would chase me off," he said. "Some commentators act as if Zimbabwe is a province of South Africa. Zimbabwe is a sovereign country."

There is more at stake for Mr Mbeki than the fate of Zimbabwe. Mr Mugabe is a key player in the Congo war and Mr Mbeki sees no point in isolating him when progress is finally being made to end the destabilising conflict.

Mr Mbeki's critics say his government is being an apologist for an increasingly repressive regime. On Tuesday the justice minister, Penuell Maduna, said he was "satisfied" by assurances from his Zimbabwean counterpart that there had been no threats against judges who had ruled against Mr Mugabe's government, even though there is ample evidence to the contrary.

The Zimbabwean justice minister, Patrick Chinamasa, himself warned three supreme court judges that they might come to harm if they did not resign. A leader of the "war veterans" occupying white-owned farms threatened the chief justice, Anthony Gubbay, to his face. A few hours later Mr Gubbay agreed to retire early.

Mr Maduna defended the Zimbabwean government by saying that if the chief justice was threatened he should lay a charge with the police, even though the police have repeatedly defied court orders to clear the war veterans from farms.

webTitle: Leader: Two into one won't go

fields.headline: Two into one won't go
fields.standfirst: But in this case, may have to be made to
fields.trailText: Caesar's wife, ie Cherie Booth, is a highly regarded barrister who has no need of Caesar's patronage to make a good living. Yet she, along with her fellow lawyers with the title QC, enjoys precisely that.
fields.body:
Caesar's wife, ie Cherie Booth, is a highly regarded barrister who has no need of Caesar's patronage to make a good living. Yet she, along with her fellow lawyers with the title QC, enjoys precisely that. The state gives this select band a handle that boosts their earnings - and does it pretty mysteriously too. That, as lawyers might say, is prima facie anti-competitive. Having got their kite mark, QCs could - you might think - be safely be approached by clients who will know quality by the initials. But no, the bar council insists the public has its hand held by another kind of lawyer whose skills are hardly different - the solicitor.

As set out in the office of fair trading's new report, the list of offences by the legal profession(s) against fair dealing with the public is so long that you wonder, not for the first time, whether the disproportionate presence of lawyers in successive cabinets has served the common interest. John Vickers, the OFT director general, does, it is true, sometimes sound a bit too much like an economics professor (which he used to be). There are vital social functions performed by the professions; as entities within civil society, self-interested or not, they do act as buttresses against the overmighty state and their codes of honour often challenge the mindless market. But all Mr Vickers is asking for in his lucid report are good reasons for the variety of professional practices that do restrain trade. He rarely finds them.

The law is his prime target, though architects and accountants do not escape his simple questions about professionals' failure to advertise their fees. As for the gentle folk in wigs, the OFT confirms how successful they have been, Labour's recent legislation on access to justice notwithstanding, in sustaining the status quo in courts and companies. Ms Booth and fellows are still trailed by "juniors": twice the fee, far from twice the legal fire power. Very few solicitors get anywhere near the higher courts; but they in turn have clung tenaciously to conveyancing and stopped banks and insurance companies doing wills.

Margaret Thatcher failed to abolish the "dual structure" of the law. Mr Vickers says he will do it by stealth as he liberalises restrictive rules for both lots. Stealth is something Labour has been good at. Jack Straw, so vociferous the other day about his fellow barristers, should now start preparing to muster Caesar for a long haul.

webTitle: Leader: How green is our Blair?

fields.headline: How green is our Blair?
fields.standfirst:
A hero on Tuesday. But after fuel tax cuts ...

Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: Rarely can a prime minister's reputation have risen so fast and fallen so soon. On Tuesday Tony Blair was the hero of the green lobby; on Wednesday he had become a duplicitous villain. On Tuesday he spoke with real passion about the threat of global warming and the importance of the Kyoto international climate treaty.
fields.body:
Rarely can a prime minister's reputation have risen so fast and fallen so soon. On Tuesday Tony Blair was the hero of the green lobby; on Wednesday he had become a duplicitous villain. On Tuesday he spoke with real passion about the threat of global warming and the importance of the Kyoto international climate treaty. He promised to put Britain on a fast track into the global "green industrial revolution" and held out the prospect of world leadership in addressing environmental issues.

With some justification, the green lobby had been awaiting this speech - only the second by Mr Blair on green issues in four years, with the last just four months ago - with a certain scepticism. But even they received it enthusiastically. Friends of the Earth described it as his "strongest" ever; Greenpeace saw it as the first indication that the prime minister was "genuinely and personally committed to the fight against climate change"; and the Worldwide Fund for Nature thought it was "a turning point".

One day later the claws were out. On Tuesday Mr Blair had announced £100m of new money to be invested in renewable energy - wind, solar and wave energy -because green technologies were on the verge of becoming the next wave in the knowledge economy revolution. On Wednesday Gordon Brown unveiled a pre-election budget which gave 17 times as much to road users - some £1.7bn in cuts to fuel and road vehicle taxes. Drowned by the cheers of AA and RAC members, the green lobby pointed to the blatant contrast between the chancellor's measures and the principles which the prime minister had enunciated just 24 hours earlier.

Road transport is already the fastest growing source of CO2 emissions, the main climate changing gas. The green lobby pointed to an inevitable rise in car use with the cut in fuel prices. True, some of the £1.7bn is there to encourage smaller cars and cleaner fuels, which shows ministers are trying. But they are not trying hard enough. Independent research has shown just how effective higher fuel prices can be in cutting road traffic. In Tuesday's Guardian, the chairman of the commission for integrated transport, David Begg, set out the findings of new research on last year's road traffic patterns: a 0.3% increase, one of the lowest recorded in modern times. Historical patterns suggested last year's GDP growth of 3% should have produced a 3.8% rise in road traffic. Clearly, last autumn's brief fuel shortage would have had some impact, but the research suggested the major cause was the 8% hike in fuel prices.

On Tuesday the prime minister was unequivocal about the threat posed by climate change: desertification doubling, increased flooding, soil erosion, decreased crop yields, increased risk of epidemics, further plant and wildlife species made extinct. There were two reasons why leadership was needed: first, the damage caused by failing to treat the environment with care; second "mutual responsibility". Britain's task was to argue the case of the environment at every level of society - "and to match actions with the words".

In his October speech, the prime minister spoke about the difficulties of politics, of the need "to woo the electorate as well as to lead them". At least that was honest. This week's passionate oration - when he knew what was to follow the next day - will have only bred further disillusion and cynicism about modern politics. This was a week when rather than talk about hard choices in politics, Mr Blair should have just gone ahead and made them.

fields.headline: The finger of fate
fields.standfirst: Or how nemesis turned redeemer
fields.trailText: The last English sporting figure to speak about karma landed himself in terrible trouble. Glenn Hoddle foolishly mused on the cycle of fortune and nature - suggesting that the disabled were paying the penalty for misdeeds in a previous life - and ended up forfeiting his job as manager of the English football team.
fields.body:
The last English sporting figure to speak about karma landed himself in terrible trouble. Glenn Hoddle foolishly mused on the cycle of fortune and nature - suggesting that the disabled were paying the penalty for misdeeds in a previous life - and ended up forfeiting his job as manager of the English football team. So do not expect too much karmic talk from Nasser Hussain - even if, on this occasion, he might just have a point.

For England's cricket captain has seen for himself the curiously cyclical form fate so often takes. Last year he was the victim of an appallingly bad umpiring decision while on tour in South Africa. During the Cape Town test the Sri Lankan official BC Cooray - known in the game as Hip, Hip - was officiating when Mr Hussain struck the ball directly with the face of the bat. Bafflingly, he declared him out: leg before wicket. The ruling was so unjust that it seemed to have had a painful effect on the skipper's form. After Cape Town, Mr Hussain de scended into a desperate run drought, barely able to score more than single figures. Fortune was never on his side: he even lost 11 of the last 12 tosses.

Yesterday the captain's luck changed. He scored a century, helped in that effort by two wildly wrong decisions from the umpire. He was caught twice - unmistakably - yet the man in the white coat refused to lift his finger. Who was that man? Why, it was BC Cooray.

Mr Hussain will now be cheering Hip, Hip's name every time he walks from the pavilion. In one of fate's typically witty jokes, the captain's nemesis has become his redeemer. Perhaps now he will subscribe to the view this newspaper has held on the matter of umpirical judgement ever since the great stand-off between Mike Gatting and Pakistani officialdom back in 1987. Our view can be summarised easily. When bad decisions go against England, that is wholly unacceptable. When they go in our favour - that's great.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In some editions of the Guide, March 3, we gave details of the current exhibition, Tutankhamun and the Treasures of the Pharaohs, at The Dome, Doncaster (March 6 to April 1), but mistakenly said that admission was free. It is £6 for adults, £4 for children, £18 for a family ticket (2 + 2), £5 for concessions and £3 for people in school parties. Sorry for getting it wrong.
fields.body:
In some editions of the Guide, March 3, we gave details of the current exhibition, Tutankhamun and the Treasures of the Pharaohs, at The Dome, Doncaster (March 6 to April 1), but mistakenly said that admission was free. It is £6 for adults, £4 for children, £18 for a family ticket (2 + 2), £5 for concessions and £3 for people in school parties. Sorry for getting it wrong.

In our report of the tennis tournament, the Sybase Open, page 12, March 5, we said that Marat Safin had won no events since his victory in the US Open six months ago. In fact, he won a tournament in Tashkent, remained unbeaten in St Petersburg and finished the year by claiming the title of the Masters Series event in Paris. In 2000 he won seven titles - more than any other player.

In a report headed Back impresarios, theatre chief urges, page 6, March 2, we said: "The Swan theatre in Worcester ... gets little or no help from its local council." Worcester city council have asked us to point out that they have an observer on the Swan board and provide funds of £157,000 a year.

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. webTitle: Letters: Where the Budget fell short

fields.headline: Where the Budget fell short
fields.trailText: Five million adults and 2m children live in households where no one is in work. But if they wanted to know how much better off as a result of this "family-friendly" Budget, they would have read your supplement (March 8) in vain.

But if they wanted to know how much better off as a result of this "family-friendly" Budget, they would have read your supplement (March 8) in vain. The harsh fact is that families suffering from unemployment (or "workless households" as they now are) are barely any better off. Working families will gain by up to £36 per week, but many unemployed families - too poor to benefit from any of the panoply of tax credits now on offer - will gain by a meagre £1.50. Gordon Brown continues to focus his generosity on working families, whilst offering only crumbs and ever greater moral pressure on those who are unable (or in the case of many single parents) unwilling to find work.

The latest turn of the thumbscrew is to require all single parents, including those with children under five, to attend "back to work" interviews. Yet the government's repeated claims that there are now 1m job vacancies to match the headline fig ure of 1m unemployed still ring hollow in many parts of the country. Not to mention the fact that one in five jobs advertised in Job Centres in Greater Manchester are so part time (ie less than 16 hours a week) that they fail to qualify for working families tax credit or any of the other "welfare to work" benefits. Niall Cooper
National coordinator, Church Action on Poverty
churchaction@cwcom.net

 I and my fellow claimants of job seekers' allowance don't appear to benefit from the Budget, but I don't mind. I would gladly give £5 a week from my munificent £52 a week benefit, if it meant the Tories not regaining power. P Day
Doncaster

 This government can be accused of many things, but joined-up policy making is still not one of them. The £1.7bn handout to the road lobby will severely dent the impact of the £1bn provided for urban regeneration and offset tax changes aimed at those on low incomes. The government's own research shows that one in five urban dwellings are in poor environments, compared with just 4% of suburban or rural dwellings. Towns and cities are much more likely to have problems with poor air quality, heavy traffic and street parking nuisance.

So the chancellor reduces the price of owning and using a car. The result will be a continuing rise in long-distance car commuting and urban traffic levels. The consequent noise, fumes and danger will undermine efforts to breathe new life into towns and cities. They will also disproportionately affect those on low incomes, who are more likely to live on or near busy roads. Ben Plowden The Pedestrians' Association
info@pedestrians.org.uk

 The Budget has almost no impact on the growing number of single households. And as your summary shows, nobody else seems to be conscious of their concerns either - high mortgages, high debt and poor provision of housing. But the fast rate of growth of single households means that ignoring their voice before an election could be foolhardy. Ann Fine
London

 How kind of Gordon Brown to "want to make it easier for mothers to make the choice to stay at home after their child is born and for much longer than previously". Better still, in the 21st century, to encourage fathers to "make the choice" to do their share of childcare and of shouldering the financial burden. Giving the option to transfer the increased maternity pay and maternity leave to fathers would be a start. Judith Sawyer
Bromley, Kent

 In a "Budget for families", I am left wondering what value this government places on education. Many families are in the same position as me, supporting our children through university and all we have to look forward to is an annual increase in tutition fees and our children being burdened by heavy debts. Perhaps I should just be grateful there will be no increase in spirit prices and drink myself into oblivion. Jan Clark
South Ferriby, Lincs

 Brown's "Budget for the poor" has been welcomed by nearly all commentators - who are naturally middle-class. Let them try living, as a single pensioner must, on £72.50 a week. But wait! How many single pensioners actually receive this? If their national insurance contributions, from 1978, have fallen short of the maximum, their pension can be dramatically reduced. I receive only £60 a week, and I can't apply for the minimum income guarantee because my savings are a little above the qualifying amount. Naomi Elias
Chesham, Bucks

 Absent from your coverage was any mention of the rise in defence expenditure, which has leapt from £21bn to £24bn, an increase of over 11%, the first big increase in defence spending for years. Richard Byrne
Ilford, Essex

 Well done on your comprehensive supplement. But I fear a readership apparently not thought capable of visualising socio-economic groups without the help of photographs of TV soap characters can hardly be expected to grasp the complexities of the latest Brown Budget. Brendan Coffey
London

fields.headline: Pigeons and a duck
fields.trailText: Perhaps Ken Livingstone could purchase the Sky Mirror sculpture from Nottingham Playhouse (Letters, March 8) and site it on Nelson's column?
fields.body:
Perhaps Ken Livingstone could purchase the Sky Mirror sculpture from Nottingham Playhouse (Letters, March 8) and site it on Nelson's column? It might be a more humane way of getting rid of the pigeons than starving them to death. Tessa Hartog
Cardiff

 Instead of trying to avoid the problems caused by the focused sunlight, why not enlist the co-operation of solar energy technologists to exploit the heat, given that renewable energy research is starved of funds? We experimented with a 1m reflector in Namibia; the result was spectacular. Roger Lowery
Ware, Herts

 Commodus was not a "cowardly custard" (Catherine Bennett, March 8) or any other kind of dessert. As emperor he would often fight in the arena for fun (I didn't say he wasn't a bit bonkers) and was undefeated in gladiatorial combat. He met his end (much to everyone's relief) by being murdered in the bath, which may be a cowardly way to be killed but is not a coward's death. Dr Ian Lane
Belfast

 In Stoke-on-Trent, men affectionately refer to their wives and girlfriends as "ma lady" (Letters, March 8), whereas in nearby Leek, men and women both refer to sweethearts as "little duck". I think it's utterly charming. I'd far rather be a duck or a lady than a tart or a bitch. Laura Marcus
Leek, Staffs

 Perhaps Vivien Bailey (Letters, March 8) will nevertheless allow me, a proud Welshman, to call Anne Robinson a bitch. Jeffrey Williams-Jones
Bodorgan, Ynys Mon

 Ever been to Wales? Ever heard the "jokes" about the English? 'Nuff said! Margaret Williams London

webTitle: Letters: Military's contempt of war crimes court

fields.headline: Military's contempt of war crimes court
fields.trailText: The reported opposition by British military commanders to the reach of the international criminal court should not stop parliament passing legislation (Forces fear war crimes, March 7) to ratify the statute.
fields.body:
The reported opposition by British military commanders to the reach of the international criminal court should not stop parliament passing legislation (Forces fear war crimes, March 7) to ratify the statute. Neither the bill nor the statute outlaw "wrong rules of engagement". They outlaw "genocide, crimes against humanity and war crimes". These crimes, many of which draw from international law, are defined exhaustively in the statute.

If British commanders engage in these crimes they would, and should, be brought to justice (but first in national courts: the international criminal court intervenes only where the national courts are unable or unwilling to investigate and prosecute a crime). The statute is the product of years of negotiation between human rights organisations and governments worldwide for an effective international system of investigation, prosecution and trial to deal with the most heinous crimes committed by individuals. No armed forces should escape responsibility for such crimes.
Dermot Feenan
University of Ulster
d.feenan@ulst.ac.uk

 Your report paints a picture that is not matched with the reality of the bill being debated in the Lords. The bill reflects the broad principles of international humanitarian law as set out, for example, in the Geneva conventions of 1949 and their 1977 additional protocols. In addition, members of the armed forces are already subject to English law wherever they are serving.

The court is unlike any previous war crimes tribunal, where alleged war criminals have had to be surrendered to the tribunal. It is hard to imagine British commanders wanting to breach existing international law and, if it is alleged that they have done so, not to want to be tried by a court based on UK law. Moreover, the more states that fol low the UK's action, the less likely it will be an alleged war criminal will escape trial.
Prof Peter Rowe
Lancaster University
p.rowe1@Lancaster.ac.uk

 As a retired military lawyer, it seems to me that an important element is missing from the debate. When carrying out attacks on military objectives, we are already under a treaty obligation not to cause disproportionate incidental loss and damage to the civilian population. The Geneva conventions have been put to the test recently. I am not aware we had any difficulties complying with our treaty obligations during the Gulf conflict of 1991 or the Kosovo conflict of 1999. The prosecutor at the Yugoslav tribunal in the Hague examined some of the incidents that arose during the Nato air campaign and decided that there should be no prosecutions.
Tony Rogers
Shepperton, Middx
apyr@ukQnljnc.co.uk

webTitle: Letters: Asians kick around ideas about football

fields.headline: Asians kick around a few ideas about football
fields.trailText: I commend Geoffrey Wheatcroft for his article on the often patronising comments against Asians in football (This misguided campaign for Asians to play football, March 8).
fields.body:
I commend Geoffrey Wheatcroft for his article on the often patronising comments against Asians in football (This misguided campaign for Asians to play football, March 8). Making allowances for a player because you want to boast that you are the first to scoop the accolade of "finding" the first Asian star should be strongly discouraged.

That said, everyone does need a hero. When Ian Wright signed for Arsenal in 1991, the visible increase in black supporters at the club was extraordinary. Those who supported Arsenal anyway loved him for his ability and passion, but he also brought in legions of fans who loved him because he was brash and arrogant, rude and in your face - and black. Many young south Asians are waiting for that figure, but most of us are prepared to wait for the star rather than an understudy pushed from the wings by a greedy impresario. There are many talented players of south Asian origin at a host of clubs, such as Leeds, Arsenal, Derby, Newcastle, West Ham and Brentford. If they are good enough to be a premiership player they will get their dues.
Saptarshi Ray
London sap@snooplife.co.uk

 It's true that Asians are intimidated by terrace culture, but their absence from the game is also due to their attitude to it. Football's a proletarian sport and Asians (particularly Indians) don't by and large see themselves as proles.

Our parents arrived here hard-wired for embourgeoisement; their concerns being home ownership, saving capital and higher education for their children. The idea of our spending endless hours playing football, rather than doing something constructive, was anathema to them, though it's a prerequisite to becoming even a mediocre semi-professional talent.

Though I watch the game, I'm pleased my generation isn't in that working-class trap, vying for a handful of sporting careers seen as the only route to affluence. And I'm depressed by the mass still enthralled by the bread-and-circuses spectacle of football, who ignore the wider issues affecting their lives.
Nirpal Dhaliwal
London

 How dare Geoffrey Wheatcroft assume that, because I was born in the East End of London not India, to call myself "Asian" or "Indian" would be "repellent cant"? His assertion that it is not due to racism but for historical and cultural reasons that there are no Asian players in the Premiership is itself racist.

How does he account for Vaduka, Kewell and Bosnich? I don't recall Australia winning many World Cups. His final paragraph gives away its inherent racism. He wants many more Asians to play cricket so that England may unearth a great spinner. Of course Asians, being puny or timid, wouldn't make great fast bowlers. Just look at Imran Khan, Wasim Akram and Waqar Younis.
Rakesh Patel
London

fields.headline: BATM resolves supplier dispute
fields.trailText: BATM, the Israeli telecoms equipment maker, yesterday delivered better than expected results and said that a dispute with an important supplier had been amicably resolved.
fields.body:
BATM, the Israeli telecoms equipment maker, yesterday delivered better than expected results and said that a dispute with an important supplier had been amicably resolved.

Shares in BATM, which fell by 50% in December when it warned on profits, climbed 16% to 116p. Despite the rally, the shares are still well below the highs of more than 700p that they touched last year at the height of the dot.com boom.

Chairman Peter Sheldon said: "Market conditions are generally not good at the moment but we're particularly well placed to succeed even in difficult circumstances, and we believe we will do better this year than we did last year."

Mr Sheldon claimed that BATM's growing customer base should insulate it from any slowdown in demand from big telecoms firms and enable it to report revenue growth of around 35% in 2001.

Pre-tax profits for the year to December came in marginally above analysts revised expectations at $22.2m. Revenues came in at $91.9m with both increases largely due to the integration of last year's acquisition of Telco Systems.

BATM's December profits warning was blamed on the inability of a key supplier to deliver optical transceivers to a contracted deadline. "We now love each other again," said chief executive Zvi Marom.

He said that with more than $60m of cash in the bank BATM was in a position to buy firms offering technologies complementary to its own.

fields.headline: Poll challenger rattles Ugandan president
fields.standfirst:
After 15 years of virtually uncontested rule, one of the west's preferred African leaders faces growing opposition

Today's favourites can be tomorrow's despots
fields.trailText: After 15 years of virtually uncontested rule, one of the west's preferred African leaders faces growing opposition.
fields.body:
On the night before President Yoweri Museveni addressed a rally in the northern Ugandan town of Gulu, his supporters took to the streets and covered up the campaign posters of his opponent Kizza Besigye. By the time Mr Museveni entered the town there were only new, yellow posters bearing his smiling image.

Mr Museveni, who has ruled Uganda for 15 years, is convinced that he will win Monday's presidential election. Confident in a grey suit, he told the Guardian he would secure 80% of the vote.

Even his most loyal supporters, however, admit that this is unlikely. For the first time in his rule he is facing a genuine challenger.

Mr Museveni came to power in 1986 after fighting a five-year guerrilla war. Under his leadership the amount of poverty has fallen by 21%, primary school enrolment has doubled and human rights have improved.

He continues to receive western support, despite his reluctance to return the country to pluralist democracy. Instead, he heads the Movement system, which he describes as a broad-based form of democracy and his critics call a one-party state.

Mr Museveni, 56, is being challenged by an insider with impeccable references.

Dr Besigye, 44, is a quiet, serious man from the president's region of western Uganda.

He is standing as a reformist, sharing credit for the Movement's successes while distancing himself from its failures.

He argues that the president has veered away from the spirit of the Movement, and his regime has become corrupt, militaristic, sectarian and undemocratic.

"I do not know whether the traits we are opposing today were within him all along, or whether they are new developments. All we know is Museveni is definitely a very faint, if not unrecognisable, shadow of what he used to be," Dr Besigye said.

Dr Besigye's candidature has angered Mr Museveni, who describes his former doctor as "a traitor to the Movement".

The accusation of treachery does not surprise Dr Besigye. "Museveni believes he is the Movement," he said. "This has been an attitude we find difficult to get along with because loyalty means loyalty to a principle not a man."

Dr Besigye has found support among reformists, who until now had no voice.

He has strengthened his position by allying himself with multipartyists and the ex-convict and former mayor of Kampala Nasser Sebaggala, who has a large following in central Uganda. Their common ground is a desire to oust Mr Museveni.

The close content has led to an aggressive campaign. The police have recorded more than 100 cases of election-related crime. Most are minor, such as defacing posters. Some are serious: kidnap and murder.

Mr Sebaggala and an opposition MP have been charged with incitement to violence, after reportedly urging a crowd to machete foreigners who try to vote.

Mr Museveni has also been accused of harassing his opponents. "His team have approached everyone on our task force," Dr Besigye said.

"Museveni has met some and promised positions in government and money if they leave us. Once they decline, the intimidation begins."

The tension has been heightened by administrative problems, including a reduction in the time the elecoral register is put on display ofrom 21 days to three.

This is bound to cause problems, since the electoral commission had already admitted that there were 2m more people on the original rolls than citizens of eligible voting age.

The opinion polls consistently put Mr Museveni ahead, but only with 50% to 54%, far less than he secured in 1996.

His critics hope that a smaller margin of victory could shock him into finally listening to his opponent's grievances.

But Mr Museveni has already made it clear that he will never offer Dr Besigye a job in his government.

"I'm glad he said that," Dr Besigye commented.

"Because I don't think any one of us would ever consider joining him."
