He argues that the president has veered away from the spirit of the Movement, and his regime has become corrupt, militaristic, sectarian and undemocratic. "I do not know whether the traits we are opposing today were within him all along, or whether they are new developments. All we know is Museveni is definitely a very faint, if not unrecognisable, shadow of what he used to be," Dr Besigye said. Dr Besigye's candidature has angered Mr Museveni, who describes his former doctor as "a traitor to the Movement". The accusation of treachery does not surprise Dr Besigye. "Museveni believes he is the Movement," he said. "This has been an attitude we find difficult to get along with because loyalty means loyalty to a principle not a man." Dr Besigye has found support among reformists, who until now had no voice. He has strengthened his position by allying himself with multipartyists and the ex-convict and former mayor of Kampala Nasser Sebaggala, who has a large following in central Uganda. Their common ground is a desire to oust Mr Museveni. The close content has led to an aggressive campaign. The police have recorded more than 100 cases of election-related crime. Most are minor, such as defacing posters. Some are serious: kidnap and murder. Mr Sebaggala and an opposition MP have been charged with incitement to violence, after reportedly urging a crowd to machete foreigners who try to vote. Mr Museveni has also been accused of harassing his opponents. "His team have approached everyone on our task force," Dr Besigye said. "Museveni has met some and promised positions in government and money if they leave us. Once they decline, the intimidation begins." The tension has been heightened by administrative problems, including a reduction in the time the elecoral register is put on display ofrom 21 days to three. This is bound to cause problems, since the electoral commission had already admitted that there were 2m more people on the original rolls than citizens of eligible voting age. The opinion polls consistently put Mr Museveni ahead, but only with 50% to 54%, far less than he secured in 1996. His critics hope that a smaller margin of victory could shock him into finally listening to his opponent's grievances. But Mr Museveni has already made it clear that he will never offer Dr Besigye a job in his government. "I'm glad he said that," Dr Besigye commented. "Because I don't think any one of us would ever consider joining him."

webTitle: Today's favourites can be tomorrow's despots

fields.headline: Today's favourites can be tomorrow's despots
fields.standfirst: Poll challenger rattles Ugandan president
fields.trailText: The outcome of the Ugandan election is not in doubt. President Yoweri Museveni will win handsomely, aided by some 2.5m "ghost voters" on the electoral roll - more than 20% of the total - and the fact that the army has been called out to supervise the poll.
fields.body:
The outcome of the Ugandan election is not in doubt. President Yoweri Museveni will win handsomely, aided by some 2.5m "ghost voters" on the electoral roll - more than 20% of the total - and the fact that the army has been called out to supervise the poll.

Mr Museveni did not need to rig the election. His record is good enough to deliver a majority of votes. Ugandans have enjoyed more stability and prosperity under the last 15 years of Mr Museveni's "no party democracy" than under the previous regimes of Milton Obote and Idi Amin.

International aid donors, led by Britain, have rewarded Mr Museveni's market oriented economic policies and his commitment to universal primary education and overcoming Aids.

But Mr Museveni is a military commander of autocratic leaning who routinely vows to "crush" his opponents. Over the years his cronies have grown fabulously rich on the pickings of "privatisation" and, more recently, the mineral wealth of neighbouring Democratic Republic of Congo, where many army battalions are stationed.

The president was taking no risks. In the 1996 elections he faced no serious challenges: his opponent, Paulo Ssemogerere, was easily branded a relic of the discredited factional politics of Uganda's disastrous past.

This time around, however, Mr Museveni faces credible opposition from within his National Resistance Movement. The challenger is Dr Kizza Besigye, a comrade in arms from the days of the guerrilla struggle, and his former physician and minister.

Dr Besigye does not dispute Mr Museveni's successes, but calls for reform. The government, he says, has grown corrupt, and has launched expensive foreign adventures that bring no benefits to ordinary Ugandans.

Mr Museveni's response to this challenge has been intimidation and outright violence. Ugandans were stunned by the arrest and detention of the youth coordinator for the Besigye campaign, Major Okwir Rabwoni. After a four-hour standoff at Entebbe airport on February 20, a company of military police seized the MP by force, threw him on to a pickup truck and took him to military intelligence headquarters for interrogation.

Major Rabwoni fled the country a few days later. On March 3, the president ordered the army to "ensure order" in the elections. The same day, troops opened fire on an opposition rally in Rukengeri, forcing Dr Besigye himself to run for his life. At least one person was killed.

The question is not who will win, but, what does this deeply flawed election mean for Uganda? Consider the warning signals for conflict that are already flashing. First, many Ugandans will deny that the elections represent the real choice of the country. Second, both the Movement and the army are divided - and Uganda's soldiers are among the most politicised in Africa.

Prominent Besigye supporters include several with unhealthy records who have even recently come perilously close to inciting xenophobic violence. Mr Museveni's generals have made implicit threats, saying that weapons are still there for ruling the country should the election not go according to plan. There are enough angry and bitter people to react to any call to insurrection.

Up to now the international community has been conspicuously silent. Mr Museveni has been the favoured African leader of both Whitehall and Washington, and has been given carte blanche in domestic affairs. A few human rights irregularities have been considered a small price to pay for stability.

But today's favourites can easily become tomorrow's erratic despots: consider the fall from grace of President Mugabe of Zimbabwe. Similarly, lessons from across the world show that early warning signs of conflict are ignored at our peril. Discreet but firm diplomatic intervention at an early stage can prevent the kind of crisis that has engulfed Sierra Leone.

Mr Museveni will emerge from the elections weakened and damaged. His post- electoral challenge will be to unite his country and embark upon a real process of democratisation.

Alex de Waal is director of Justice Africa

fields.headline: Dame Ninette de Valois
fields.standfirst: Irish-born dancer and choreographer who devoted her life to the creation of British national ballet in the 20th century
fields.trailText: Irish-born dancer and choreographer who devoted her life to the creation of British national ballet in the 20th century.
fields.body:
On July 13 1996, just before the Royal Ballet School's annual matinée at Covent Garden was about to begin, applause suddenly erupted from one side of the auditorium. "It must be Madam," said those of us who could not see her, and everyone spontaneously rose to applaud the fragile, white-haired figure who had been wheeled to her place at the side of the stalls circle.

Madam it was. Dame Ninette de Valois, who has died aged 102, had made it, as she had made it almost every year, to see the student dancers who would carry forward the work she had started so many years ago - the tiny enterprise that was to grow into the whole edifice of the Royal Ballet and its school.

Earlier that year, on February 20, she had made it to Covent Garden for the 50th anniversary of the reopening of the Royal Opera House in 1946 with her company's production of The Sleeping Beauty. And she had come on stage for a standing ovation, led by the Queen from the royal box.

She was also at Sadler's Wells that year for the final gala there, before the demolition of the theatre where her company had started. Far from being sentimental or nostalgic, Dame Ninette, although she never ceased to recognise the vital part which that theatre, thanks to Lilian Baylis, had played in the foundation of British ballet, knew it was time for rebuilding and lent her blessing to the enterprise. She had also travelled on a special train, at the age of 92, to celebrate the relocation of the then Sadler's Wells Royal Ballet to Birmingham when it was time for that company to move on and become the Birmingham Royal Ballet of today. She took a great interest in the reopening of the Sadler's Wells Theatre in October 1998, and of the Royal Opera House in November 1999.

Characteristically, she spent her 100th birthday at White Lodge in Richmond Park, the junior school of the Royal Ballet, still mentally alert to all that was going on and applauding, as always, the young dancers of the future. For, as she once wrote, "The work has not been thought out just for the present but for those days, months and years that go to make up the future. In brief there has been planted for you a true heritage. It is your duty to protect this gift - and see that it lives and expands." The gift, of course, was the Royal Ballet.

The Royal Ballet was Dame Ninette de Valois's ballet, the Royal Ballet School her school. So she regarded them; and no one disagreed. Without her the 20th-century history of ballet in these islands would have been entirely different. Dame Ninette made British ballet. She had lieutenants, of course, but the generalship was hers, and she alone, in the formative years, was irreplaceable.

Latterly she could not scrutinise, all the time, the working of both London and Birmingham companies and the school; but her occasional visitations, her questions and whiplash criticism never ceased to matter greatly. She always aroused awe in those, especially the women, who worked under her. To the last it was Madam's approval that blessed, and her disapproval that damned, a budding project.

At any time in her long career, "indomitable" was one of the right adjectives for her, especially in the last decades of her life, when she refused to give in to the arthritis and other ailments that increasingly afflicted her. She was constantly in demand and was obdurately conscientious in meeting that demand.

Hindsight may tell us now that in the 1920s Britain was, at last, due for its turn as a centre of ballet. The Diaghilev company, known in London since 1911, had made a particularly big impression here. So had Pavlova. British dancers - Sokolova, Markova, Dolin, De Valois herself - were beginning to be noticeable among Diaghilev's exalted Russians. But this was also a time when the French title worn by Diaghilev's organisation, Les Ballets Russes, was a pertinent reminder that these exiled Russians had made their artistic home in France, where the tradition of ballet long outdated even the Russian one.

It would have been a rare prophet who, at that time, could tell that an enduring consequence of this gorgeous Franco-Russian marriage would be the determination of a young, rather solitary Irish dancer that such delights should be made possible in Britain too.

De Valois was born Edris Stannus at Baltiboys, a country house some two miles from the village of Blessington in County Wicklow, and always insisted, like WB Yeats, with whom she worked, "I am of Ireland." Irish she was, by birth and temperament, but it was to England - like the Polish Marie Rambert - that she gave her life. Her first dance was an authentic Irish jig, taught to her by the family cook, Kate, to perform on the stone floor of the kitchen at Baltiboys. Did that jig, which she "adored", instil in her the passionate understanding of native dances of the British Isles that she was, much later, to introduce with such sensible determination to the curriculum of the Royal Ballet School?

By the age of 11, the family had moved to London and she learned "fancy dancing" from the fashionable Mrs Wordsworth, and then more professional exercises at the Lila Field Academy. Halfway through her 14th year she was on tour with the "Wonder Children" from that academy, had learned the Dying Swan from having seen Pavlova, and claimed to have danced it - sometimes with encore - "on the end of every pier in England".

But she realised that more serious training in classical ballet was necessary and went to Edouard Espinosa for classes. She became principal dancer in pantomimes at the Lyceum and in opera ballets at Covent Garden; took classes alongside Diaghilev's dancers in London with Maestro Cecchetti; and became friends with Lydia Lopokova and Léonide Massine, with whose small company, in 1921, she had her first taste of working with Russians.

Already moves were afoot to establish a British national ballet and De Valois, with her usual good sense and foresight, realised that the only way to learn how to run a ballet repertory company was to join one. She went straight for the best and joined, unconditionally as a member of the corps de ballet, Diaghilev's company. She was there from 1923 to 1925, and returned briefly in 1926. She danced and created solo roles in ballets by Massine and Nijinska; she learned about company procedure, choreography and, from her studies with Cecchetti and Nicholas Legat, the classic, academic dance.

In 1926 she opened her own school, grandly called the Academy of Choreographic Art, and that same year had her now celebrated interview with Lilian Baylis of the Old Vic. Baylis "liked her face", liked her long-term plans for the establishment of a school and company - and the fact that she was not asking for any money. She offered work with her actors and singers at the Vic - "£l a week, dear, for the teaching, £2 for arranging a short dance per show" - and a carrot. She was planning to rebuild the derelict Sadler's Wells Theatre, which would offer space for an embryonic ballet company. De Valois accepted her terms and never wavered in her gratitude for the faith Baylis had in her and for the support she gave.

In the years of waiting for the reopening of Sadler's Wells, De Valois busied herself not only with her school but in working with Yeats at the Abbey Theatre, Dublin, and with Terence Gray at the Festival Theatre, Cambridge. She was also creating her first choreographies, so that when the time came to close her school and move it into Sadler's Wells she had a nucleus of small ballets on which to build. With but one or two performances a week, and very few dancers, she had little else on which to build. But she had the immense good fortune of securing, right from the start, the services of Constant Lambert as musical director and, as invaluable guests, Markova and Dolin. It was Dolin's performance as Satan in Job and Markova's Giselle that really launched the company.

In 1935, when Markova left, De Valois dared, very riskily as it seemed, to make a ballerina of the adolescent Margot Fonteyn. She introduced the great classics, one by one, into the repertory and, there being no more adequate choreographer immediately in sight, she set about supplementing the classics with a British repertory.

Of her own choreography she was the toughest of critics, yet she was responsible for making much of that early repertory very British in character. She drew on artists such as Blake, Hogarth and Rowlandson for inspiration and decor, and British compositions old and new, guided by Lambert, for music. Once Frederick Ashton joined her in 1935 as chief choreographer, she was content to delegate much of the choreographic task to him, and in all the postwar years made only one ballet for her company, the unmemorable Don Quixote - to the Roberto Gerhard score. Yet three of her principal prewar works have lived on: Job - made for the Camargo Society, that curtain-raiser to the Vic-Wells company - The Rake's Progress and Checkmate. They have lived because they are well-constructed and distinctively British items in an increasingly Catholic repertory.

From 1931 until her retirement from the directorship in 1963, Madam's biography is that of her company, although she allowed, in her enchanting autobiography Come Dance With Me (1957), "a glimpse of the private side of someone's public life". It seems in retrospect a story of regally calm progress, but it had its challenges and its crises. Until 1939 there was the formidable rivalry of De Basil's and later Massine's big touring organisations, which had inherited so much of Diaghilev's repertory and talent and came, every summer, to the big theatres of the West End, reducing the enterprise at Sadler's Wells to pygmy size. Yet, even before the war scattered them, these Ballet Russe companies were disintegrating. They had no homes; no Diaghilevs to bind them.

During the war the Sadler's Wells company became homeless - and was nearly stranded in Holland by the German invasion. Temporary residence was found at the New (now Albery) Theatre; nationwide touring became necessary; the loss of male dancers to the armed forces was, somehow, surmounted. The momentous step of accepting the invitation to reopen the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, implying recognition of national status, followed in 1946. Perhaps the company was not quite ready. But largely through the new, sumptuous staging of The Sleeping Beauty (supervised by De Valois), it quickly acquired the strength to fit a bigger role. Then came the first visit to the United States in 1949; again a risk, again a triumph.

By 1956, the infant Vic-Wells Ballet had gained its Royal Charter - through a brilliantly argued submission written by De Valois - which safely united both companies and their schools under their Royal name. The Royal Ballet had become a setter of international standards, a provider of dancers, choreographers and ballet masters for all save the eastern bloc. And even in that world it proved its quality on its first visit to Moscow and Leningrad in 1961.

Meanwhile, the school had expanded into a full-time educational establishment, and when Madam retired from the company in 1963, it was to the school that she devoted her scarcely abated energy.

In addition to her work building a national ballet, Dame Ninette lived a happy parallel life as the wife of Dr AB Connell, whom she married in 1935 (he died in 1987). It was an exemplary union of volatility and calm. While Dr Connell practised at Sunningdale, she was known locally simply as "the doctor's wife", for she was as efficient and charming in running a household (she was an excellent cook) and in dealing with telephone messages for the doctor as she was in running her company.

She was made a Dame of the British Empire in 1957 and a Companion of Honour in 1982, and was awarded the ultimate honour, the Order of Merit, in 1992, receiving in the same year the special award of the Society of West End Theatres for her lifetime's achievement. In addition, there were innumerable honorary degrees and decorations, accepted not so much for herself as in recognition of "the company".

Lilian Baylis was not alone in "liking her face". When young she was very pretty and a piquant, accomplished dancer. Her eyes were large and her facial bone structure was fine; she had the sort of young good looks that age enhanced.

Her manner was unobtrusive to the point of shyness and her conversation was a voluble flurry. She had many advisers, to none of whom she seemed to listen; her views were always strong, sometimes ruthless and, from day to day, self-contradictory. She had a persuasive charm that was almost irresistible and very seldom resisted. It was totally unforced, full of fun and humour.

Her great strength lay in her integrity, her complete lack of interest in getting rich - she never did - or in acquiring glory for herself. In her final years, past achievements mattered less and less to her; she looked urgently, impatiently, to the future, concerned only with what "her" ballet was going to become. Her colleagues, her dancers - her children, as they could not help regarding themselves - loved her, especially towards the end when she needed them most. They knew that without her they, the two companies, the school, the whole of British ballet with its reputation built over half a century, would not be here.

On her 100th birthday at White Lodge she was surrounded by the children she loved, especially the small boys. It was a beautiful day and she turned to one of her former colleagues, looked up at the sky and said: "I don't see how anything up there can be as beautiful as this."

Ninette de Valois (Edris Stannus), ballerina, choreographer, ballet company director and teacher, born June 6 1898; died March 8 2001

The late James Monahan (the Guardian's former ballet critic, James Kennedy) took charge of the Royal Ballet School at the end of a long career in journalism and at the BBC World Service. He died in 1985.

Until 1939 there was the formidable rivalry of De Basil's and later Massine's big touring organisations, which had inherited so much of Diaghilev's repertory and talent and came, every summer, to the big theatres of the West End, reducing the enterprise at Sadler's Wells to pygmy size. Yet, even before the war scattered them, these Ballet Russe companies were disintegrating. They had no homes; no Diaghilevs to bind them. During the war the Sadler's Wells company became homeless - and was nearly stranded in Holland by the German invasion. Temporary residence was found at the New (now Albery) Theatre; nationwide touring became necessary; the loss of male dancers to the armed forces was, somehow, surmounted. The momentous step of accepting the invitation to reopen the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, implying recognition of national status, followed in 1946. Perhaps the company was not quite ready. But largely through the new, sumptuous staging of The Sleeping Beauty (supervised by De Valois), it quickly acquired the strength to fit a bigger role. Then came the first visit to the United States in 1949; again a risk, again a triumph. By 1956, the infant Vic-Wells Ballet had gained its Royal Charter - through a brilliantly argued submission written by De Valois - which safely united both companies and their schools under their Royal name. The Royal Ballet had become a setter of international standards, a provider of dancers, choreographers and ballet masters for all save the eastern bloc. And even in that world it proved its quality on its first visit to Moscow and Leningrad in 1961. Meanwhile, the school had expanded into a full-time educational establishment, and when Madam retired from the company in 1963, it was to the school that she devoted her scarcely abated energy. In addition to her work building a national ballet, Dame Ninette lived a happy parallel life as the wife of Dr AB Connell, whom she married in 1935 (he died in 1987). It was an exemplary union of volatility and calm. While Dr Connell practised at Sunningdale, she was known locally simply as "the doctor's wife", for she was as efficient and charming in running a household (she was an excellent cook) and in dealing with telephone messages for the doctor as she was in running her company. She was made a Dame of the British Empire in 1957 and a Companion of Honour in 1982, and was awarded the ultimate honour, the Order of Merit, in 1992, receiving in the same year the special award of the Society of West End Theatres for her lifetime's achievement. In addition, there were innumerable honorary degrees and decorations, accepted not so much for herself as in recognition of "the company". Lilian Baylis was not alone in "liking her face". When young she was very pretty and a piquant, accomplished dancer. Her eyes were large and her facial bone structure was fine; she had the sort of young good looks that age enhanced. Her manner was unobtrusive to the point of shyness and her conversation was a voluble flurry. She had many advisers, to none of whom she seemed to listen; her views were always strong, sometimes ruthless and, from day to day, self-contradictory. She had a persuasive charm that was almost irresistible and very seldom resisted. It was totally unforced, full of fun and humour. Her great strength lay in her integrity, her complete lack of interest in getting rich - she never did - or in acquiring glory for herself. In her final years, past achievements mattered less and less to her; she looked urgently, impatiently, to the future, concerned only with what "her" ballet was going to become. Her colleagues, her dancers - her children, as they could not help regarding themselves - loved her, especially towards the end when she needed them most. They knew that without her they, the two companies, the school, the whole of British ballet with its reputation built over half a century, would not be here. On her 100th birthday at White Lodge she was surrounded by the children she loved, especially the small boys. It was a beautiful day and she turned to one of her former colleagues, looked up at the sky and said: "I don't see how anything up there can be as beautiful as this." He died in 1985.

fields.headline: Sex traffic is Europe's shame
fields.standfirst: Discrimination at work and in education, violence at home, a rampant slave trade: the struggle for rights continues
fields.trailText: Discrimination at work and in education, violence at home, a rampant slave trade: the struggle for rights continues.
fields.body:
European governments are doing far too little to protect the tens of thousands of women who are unwittingly sold into sexual slavery every year and forced to work in brothels from Amsterdam to London, the European commission warned yesterday.

In an outspoken "open article" on the subject, the its social affairs commissioner, Anna Diamantopoulou, suggested that a plethora of words and policy announcements on the subject had not ended or even dented "the nightmare" of trafficking in woman.

"What is the meaning of a statistical victory or the successful implementation of equality policy when phenomena such as trafficking in women still exist in civilised Europe?" she asked on International Women's Day.

"The nightmare is upon us. It is circulating on our roads, it is in our neighbourhoods, it is encircling us and it is a stain on our culture. It is not hidden or latent - it does not tiptoe about in the dark," she said.

"We see it in the plate-glass windows of Antwerp and Hamburg; it inundates the centres and pavements of Amsterdam, Paris, Athens and Rome; it is a product for sale in the markets of London and Madrid."

Not nearly enough was being done by governments to clamp down on the traffickers or to identify and help the victims of "this modern day slave trade", she added.

"A shame on our civilisation, because all of us are in some way responsible.

"We are talking about societies that foster discrimination, poverty and prejudice, about customers - 'consumers' who have put their humanity in their wallets.

"Politicians who refuse to strike the evil at its roots. Citizens whose disapproval merely takes the form of ethical or aesthetic revulsion at a phenomenon which does not concern them - unless it knocks at their door."

Her aides confirmed that there was growing frustration in Brussels that policies designed to tackle the problem were not achieving their aims, because governments had not bothered to put in place the necessary social infrastructure to look after victims.

The EC has repeatedly told member states to closely monitor the working conditions of au-pairs and women who work in bars, massage parlours and sex shows.

It has also suggested that the police, social services and health authorities should collaborate to identify and help those being held against their will.

"As far as the commission is aware, no follow-up has been made by the member states of these recommendations, although they have certain means to exert control over employers," the commission said.

A special meeting was held yesterday at the European parliament to raise awareness of the issue but it failed to produce concrete proposals.

The EC says 120,000 women and children are trafficked into western Europe every year, many of whom are bought and sold into forced prostitution, beaten, imprisoned, raped and sometimes killed.

Most of them come from eastern Europe or the former Soviet Union, and the CIA estimates that traffickers can earn $250,000 a woman. The most popular countries for finding them are Russia, Ukraine, Poland and the Czech Republic. Three-quarters of the women are under 25 and many are teenagers.

Traffickers use marriage and employment agencies and other front companies to smuggle the women into the EU after advertising in the local press for dancers, waitresses and club hostesses.

The EU will shortly produce a proposal that will allow victims of the trade the right to claim temporary asylum if they agree to give evidence against traffickers.

Women's charities maintain that the residency rights should be permanent.

webTitle: Intifada adds pressure to Palestinian families

fields.headline: Perilous time in Palestinian families as siege adds pressure to old injustices
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The upheavals caused by the the intifada in the West Bank and Gaza have put an intolerable pressure on many Palestinian families, and women's groups believe that domestic violence is rising.
fields.body:
The upheavals caused by the the intifada in the West Bank and Gaza have put an intolerable pressure on many Palestinian families, and women's groups believe that domestic violence is rising.

"[It] has affected people mentally and emotionally," said Falak Khayyat, director of the Family Defence Society, which defied age-old traditions of burying such issues deep within the family to found the first shelter for battered Palestinian women in the West Bank city of Nablus.

Calls to the society's advice line, which does not dare to advertise the refuge overtly, had doubled in recent months, she said.

"We used to open our hotline until 2.30pm. Now we are open until midnight."

In a heavily guarded villa on the slopes overlooking the town sit two women who managed to escape to this sanctuary in the hope of salvaging something of their lives.

For nearly 40 years Fatima put up with an alcoholic husband who knocked out her front teeth; then she left him.

Mariam ran away from her home in Gaza when her pregnancy began to show. For her it was a matter of survival: unmarried mothers have been put to death to cleanse what their relatives see as the family's honour.

"I was confused and depressed and tired. I could not think," she said, cuddling her month-old baby son in the shelter's living room. "Now I am happy."

The Israeli siege of Palestinian areas prevents more than 100,000 day labourers going to their jobs in Israel. Unemployment in the West Bank and Gaza is 38% and a third of Palestinians have dropped below the poverty line, living on less than £1.38 a day.

The blockade, which has added to family tension, also prevents women in danger escaping. Ms Khayyat said she knew of at least nine women currently in need of shelter who had no way of reaching Nablus.

Meanwhile the shelter is facing its own economic crisis. Funding from Oxfam Quebec and Oxfam Ireland will run out in a few days.

The Palestinian Authority, which was paying some of the staff, has its own financial crisis. Some donors, including the European Union, are balking at handing more cash to a corrupt and incompetently run administration. Others are giving higher priority to programmes such as food aid for beleaguered Palestinian areas.

The authority, which is struggling to pay its police force and civil servants, has no incentive to defy traditionalists by punishing domestic violence.

"This is a superb time to kill a woman if you feel like killing her, because the police keep saying that now is not the time to look into this," said Nadera Shalhoub-Kevorkian of the Hebrew University in Jerusalem, a criminologist who helped to train the shelter's staff.

All these factors threaten the future of the shelter, whose very existence is an exercise in courage.

In Palestinian society the notion of a shelter beyond the reach of a woman's relatives is taboo, and the Nablus refuge is largely kept secret for fear of it causing a social backlash.

An earlier attempt to set up a women's refuge in Ramallah failed after city elders branded it a whorehouse. A similar refuge in Jordan is also kept secret.

In the face of such resistance, taking in an unmarried mother such as Mariam could prove explosive - particularly in a conservative city like Nablus.

In the course of her research, Dr Shalhoub-Kevorkian has uncovered 234 suspicious deaths in the West Bank alone between 1996 and 1998. She believes that they were "honour killings", the name given in the Arab world to the murder of young women who offend social norms. The killers are often close male relatives of their victim.

In the police ledgers such deaths are not seen as murder. They are referred to obliquely as deaths due to "fate and destiny".

"This is how the authorities nullify abuses," Dr Shalhoub-Kevorkian said.

Such killings are only the most dramatic outward manifestation of how deep and powerful are the social forces that keep women trapped in dangerous situations.

In Fatima's case, family life was cursed soon after her marriage at the age of 14 to a cousin.

"I used to pray to god everyday that I would die. Ever since I got married, I wanted to leave, but then I had a daughter," she said.

Nine children later she fled from her village near Jerusalem after her husband burned down the family home, and broke her arm.

It took Ms Khayyat four years of stubbornly lobbying Yasser Arafat and his social affairs minister, Umm Jihad, to win support for the Nablus shelter, and she has been careful to get the active support of the city's most prominent male citizens on board: the local governor, Muslim sheikhs, and a Christian priest are on its advisory board.

The shelter took in its first woman in August. Since then there have never been more than four women at a time in the villa, which is protected by barbed wire, an electric gate and television monitors.

Prospective inmates were carefully screened, Ms Khayyat said, and the staff on the hotline explored less drastic ways of resolving family disputes. That, she admitted, could close off the option of a speedy escape from a dangerous situation, but the centre had little choice.

"In our society," she said, "a mistake could destroy the whole family".

fields.headline: Enterprise crude output cut
fields.trailText: Enterprise Oil, the UK's biggest independent exploration company, yesterday reported record profits of £1bn but disappointed the City by admitting crude output would fall this year.
fields.body:
Enterprise Oil, the UK's biggest independent exploration company, yesterday reported record profits of £1bn but disappointed the City by admitting crude output would fall this year.

Its shares fell 5% in early trading after Enterprise explained that technical problems in the North Sea would reduce production from 280,000 to 250,000 barrels a day.

The fall in production was particularly unwelcome because the group increased its output last year by over 30% as four new fields were brought on stream. The problems overshadowed what chief executive Pierre Jungels decribed as "stirring results" for the 12 months to 31 December when pre-tax profits hit £1bn, compared with £289.2m for the previous year.

Profits after tax rose from £177.2m to £488.8m while turnover was up from £850m to £1.8m, boosted by higher crude prices.

Mr Jungels claims that Enterprise obtains the highest profits per barrel - £5.30 net after tax - in the industry. Unlike the big oil groups it does not have refineries and retail divisions which dilute strong crude prices but also act as a bolster when oil markets fall.

Enterprise raised the dividend from 7.3p to 8.0p and said it would start buying back its own shares from Monday.

It would not say how much it plans to spend, but has permission to buy back up to 10% of its shares. Analysts predicted Enterprise could spend between £50m and £200m.

Temporary shutdowns on North Sea fields such as Banff and a reduction on estimated reserves on the Garden Banks 161 field in the US Gulf would hinder production.

But Enterprise said it was making good progress with new fields such as Corrib in Ireland. New facilities will be producing an extra 150,000 barrels a day within four years. Enterprise shares ended the day down 18p at 617p.

webTitle: GKN issues profit warning after big fall in US orders

fields.headline: GKN issues profit warning after big fall in US orders
fields.trailText: GKN, Britain's biggest engineering group, yesterday issued a profits warning as big US motor manufacturers cut their orders by 30%.
fields.body:
GKN, Britain's biggest engineering group, yesterday issued a profits warning as big US motor manufacturers cut their orders by 30%.

Nearly £600m was wiped off the share price despite the company reporting a rise in annual pre-tax profits from £513m to £528m.

Chief executive Sir CK Chow said there would be a "significant" impact from the cut in demand for automotive demand, and pointed to a downturn in orders for tractor parts due to the BSE and the foot and mouth crisis in Europe.

He believed the position would stabilise in the second half of the year, but investors remained wary.

GKN was not willing to quantify the effects of the slowdown in the US car parts business but experts predicted they would blast a £50m hole in the group's sales figures.

Vehicle production in North America overall is down 20%, but the big three domestic companies - Ford, General Motors and Chrsyler - are cutting stocks by 30%.

GKN's Sinter Metals business, which supplies these groups, is most affected, although its Automatic Driveline business has a wider customer base.

Mr Chow said the European car market showed no sign of a slowdown, and Britain may even improve due to investments by Honda and Nissan.

A slowing US economy is also reducing orders from the e-commerce and retail sectors for GKN's Interlake business, which builds conveyor belt and storage systems.

Some market watchers thought the heavy shares sell-off inappropriate. Charles Burrows, an analyst with HSBC, believed it had been "overdone". The shares ended the day at 740p down 70p.

GKN increased operating profits from £558m to £593m, while sales rose from £4.6bn to £5bn. A final dividend of 12.9p was recommended, compared to 11.7p last time.

Despite the downturn in the tail end of the year, the automotive parts business grew 12%. The industrial services division, which takes in Chep pallets and Cleanaway waste management services, performed strongly.

The division is in a state of flux because of plans by GKN to merge it with Brambles Industries of Australia, a complex plan to execute with dual listing in London and Sydney. There has been speculation that Mr Chow is leaving GKN to head up the new group but he declined to comment yesterday.

webTitle: Song in your heart is written in your genes

fields.headline: Song in your heart is written in your genes
fields.trailText: Karaoke kings and queens are born, not made, according to a study of the musical ability of twins.
fields.body:
Karaoke kings and queens are born, not made, according to a study of the musical ability of twins.

A team from the National Institute on Deafness in the US and St Thomas's hospital in London studied 284 pairs of female twins and found that the ability to tell the wrong notes in a familiar tune was inherited.

The researchers, who report in the journal Science today, played the women a medley of 26 familiar songs - including Silent Night and God Save the Queen - some of which contained altered notes. Identical twins, who have identical genes and upbringings, tended to get the same scores. Non-identical twins, with similar backgrounds but different genes, had different results.

The researchers wanted to find out whether the capacity to carry a tune was linked to hearing ability. The results were surprising. Some partially deaf people turned out to be good at pitch recognition. But there were people with good hearing who simply failed to recognise wrong notes. And it became clear that listening to Mozart in the nursery could not improve a child's musical ability. Up to 80% of it was inherited.

Tim Spector, from St Thomas's, said: "This is important because the general perception is that if you come from a musical family you are likely to have better abilities because of your exposure to large amounts of music. It's one I had as well."

webTitle: BA snaps up British Regional for £78m

fields.headline: BA snaps up British Regional for £78m
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: British Airways yesterday bolstered its position in a home market under assault from European carriers with an agreed offer to buy British Regional Air Lines (Bral) for £78m.
fields.body:
British Airways yesterday bolstered its position in a home market under assault from European carriers with an agreed offer to buy British Regional Air Lines (Bral) for £78m.

The deal will bring a £20m windfall to Sir Michael Bishop, chairman of BA rival British Midland. Sir Michael owns a 26% stake in Bral and has already taken out £30m on its flotation in 1998.

BA, Europe's largest airline, will merge Bral's 50 aircraft and 1,468 employees with its UK subsidiary Brymon Airways, which has 22 aircraft and 778 staff.

BA said this would produce savings and synergies but no job losses or reductions in services are anticipated. BA recently announced plans to cut 1,000 jobs and halve the number of flights from Gatwick in an attempt to cut costs.

Bral already operates under BA colours as a franchisee but until now has been able to make its own commercial decisions and choose its own schedules. "Combining these regional specialists will allow us to capitalise on their strengths and ensure we remain competitive in this sector of the market."

The 120p-per-share cash offer for Bral has been unanimously recommended by Bral's board but must first receive the approval of the office of fair trading. BA said it was confident this would be complete within seven days and any concerns addressed.

In September BA called off its own merger with KLM after running into serious opposition from regulators, particularly in the US. Had it gone ahead it would have created the third largest carrier in the world behind United Airlines and American Airlines.

BA shares rose 3p to 365p, while Bral finished 1p higher at 118.5p.

fields.headline: Stamps with silver lining
fields.trailText: The first heat sensitive stamps are being released to celebrate Britain's weather. The cloud design on the new range of stamps will change from a grey to blue if it is rubbed.
fields.body:
The first heat sensitive stamps are being released to celebrate Britain's weather. The cloud design on the new range of stamps will change from a grey to blue if it is rubbed.

The range of weather stamps will be released on March 13 to mark the 150th anniversary of weather maps going on sale.

Thermochromic ink enables the cloud on the stamp to change from a dark and gloomy grey to sky blue when touched.

Mark Thomson, managing director of Royal Mail stamps and collectables, said: "We feel the stamps capture the wide range of weather conditions in Britain

"Each stamp is a segment of one complete image - bringing all four together creates the dial of a barometer."

fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
 And so to the last of our Turncoat of Turncoats, Kim Howells, and a rightward journey of quite dazzling pluck. The most radical force in Welsh NUM pickets of the early 80s, who can forget his letter to Scargill which ended "Remember that you always have our full support"? Who but Kim himself, who later bayed for Arthur's arrest on trumped up embezzlement charges. His stripes earned as Kinnock's trusty adviser, a further turn was necessary after John Smith's purge left him isolated on the backbenches. How welcome then the advent of Mr Tony Blair and friends. Whether awestruck by Kim's chameleon credentials, or simply anxious to offload a dirty job, in 1996 High Command set him perhaps the ultimate Turncoat labour. And with what bravery Kim duly proclaimed that the epithet "socialist" should be phased out, as the party no longer needed "an ideological Holy Grail". With Commie Kim earning his pieces of silver today as the DTI's competition minister - the wit of it! - even Mr Tony has been known to remark that he can run away a bit with his capitalist dreams. And with Diary pundit Steptoe offering 9-2, might he not run away with a Turncoat?

 In similar vein, we turn to Clydesdale MP Jimmy Hood, who proclaimed to the Commons in 1991: "Open cast mining is a disastrous development." Odd then, that until yesterday Jimmy should keep mum on the planned Bright Cross open cast mine site that has so incensed his constituents. Now it seems a little local trouble has forced him to break his silence. "I have never been in discussion with Scottish Coal regarding Bright Cross," he protested this week, "and I have never been involved in the planning process." No, Jimmy, but you do take £7,500 a year from them - and you a former NUM official to boot. You come too late to edge countrymen Gus Macdonald and Robin Cook out of the Turncoat field, but we shall watch your progress with interest.

 Thanks to our old friend Jonathan Aitken's daughter Alexandra for her piece in this month's Tatler, in which she displays a firm grasp of the situation in which the family Aitken find themselves. "Forced out of our home by our father's creditors," she begins, "I survive on a diet of socialising with supercons." Constructing an underworld with all the authenticity of a Guy Ritchie film, Alexandra even takes the time to explain the esoteric delights of Cockney rhyming slang, Dad being "fluent" in that quaint tongue these days. "I now know that £1,000 is the amount of moolah a top con might pay for a sex session with a top 'Tom', or prostitute," she trills, "although I am informed that these East End ladies of the night usually get paid in stolen goods." Remarkable. Although how much earlier would she have come to this knowledge, had her father's case not collapsed before the four witnesses willing to testify to his pimping had a chance to take the stand. Still, a splendid read, to which we will return next week.

 An intriguing email arrives. "Can you guess who?" it teases. "Seven have been arrested for fraud, 29 accused of spousal abuse, 19 of writing bad cheques, 117 have bankrupted at least two businesses, three have been arrested for assault, 71 cannot get a credit card due to bad credit, 14 have been arrested on drug-related charges, eight have been arrested for shop-lifting, 21 are current defendants in lawsuits, 84 were stopped for drunk driving." They are, of course, the 535 members who make up the US Congress. Marvellous.

 Meanwhile, can you guess who was fooled into thinking that www.whitehouse.org, with its picture of George Bush Snr where little Dubya's should be, was the official White House website? Yes, it was the Diary You Can Sometimes Trust, and we had better leave it at that.

webTitle: My week: Jon Brotherton, BBC cameraman.

fields.headline: My week: Jon Brotherton
fields.standfirst: Butterflies and the bomb
fields.trailText: Butterflies and the bomb.
fields.body:
Jon Brotherton, 40, BBC cameraman.

I do a four-day on, four-day off shift and my week started last Friday with a live piece from the tropical butterfly house at Syon Park, Middlesex, for the One O'Clock News. The day ended with a trip to Waterloo station following the discovery of refugees hiding under a Eurostar train.

On Saturday I was on the 3.30pm-1am shift at Television Centre in west London, and it was very quiet. Just before midnight I was thinking about seeing if I could get away an hour early. I was on my way to talk to Laurie Margolis, the duty news editor, when the evacuation was sounded. Laurie said: "Just go and get a camera and let's see if we can see something."

We ran out of the main gate and got shouted at by the police, who had cordoned off the street, to get back inside. Laurie and I headed for the multi-storey car park next door, which coincidentally happened to be just behind the police cordon. I took the shots from its fire escape.

It wasn't until the bomb disposal robot approached the taxi that we actually knew which vehicle was the suspect one. The streets were completely clear but at one point someone came out of Television Centre and the police yelled at them to get clear.

When the bomb exploded at 12.30am my reaction was one of surprise more than fear. I didn't think that the explosion would be big enough to do me harm where I was, although the size of the fireball and the pressure of the blast were quite tremendous. It was much later that I realised that if we hadn't been evacuated people could have been injured. The seat that I had sat in earlier is now part of the bomb-damaged area.

Once the fire around the taxi had died down we suddenly thought, "Right, we've got this blast on tape." We made our way back, stepping over fragments of the taxi and the robot. A tape of the explosion was finally handed over to the World Service newsroom.

Just before 1am I was dragged into the studios of Radio Five Live to do an interview. Afterwards I told the presenter, Richard Dallyn, that I found the interview more harrowing than watching the bomb go off. I finally got home at midday.

Apart from the bomb, it has been quite a quiet week for me. Most of my time has been spent getting comments from my colleagues, who are, in many ways, slightly jealous that they did not take the shot. I've had messages of congratulations, and lots of people at work have come up to me and shaken me by the hand. On Monday morning I picked up a copy of every published newspaper.

Matthew Keating

webTitle: On the farm: Our diarist grapples with new advice on how to spot foot and mouth.

fields.headline: On the farm
fields.standfirst:
Surveillance of the lambs: our diarist grapples with new advice on how to spot foot and mouth

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Surveillance of the lambs: our diarist grapples with new advice on how to spot foot and mouth.
fields.body:
We picked up new vital information late last night - urgent new advice for flockmasters. The Ministry of Agriculture (Maff) has issued further guidelines on new clinical signs for diagnosis in sheep.

Up until then, we felt we were all fairly on the ball about the difficulties of checking the sheep, as we were already aware of the sheep symptoms, and extremely conscious that they are very hard to spot. But we must now look for new signs, which include ewes aborting their lambs (every farmer's biggest nightmare at this time of the year), and apparently healthy lambs dropping dead for no apparent reason.

Also, rather alarmingly, it states that sometimes as little as 5% of the animals in a flock may show any symptoms. Since we have almost 1,300 head of sheep spread out across the farm, 5% is only 65. But we'll keep looking. We do look at every single animal every day, and we do know which sheep is last to come for food in each group, or notice if any are looking off colour.

We have printed out several copies of the new advice and given one to Graham, who works for us. The biggest problem is that all these "new" symptoms are also indications of other conditions that we expect to find at this time of the year. One or two sheep do often abort their lambs, not necessarily because of a disease, sometimes just as a result of being knocked or bullied at the troughs. There are other diseases, and nasty ones, too, which cause abortion, lameness and a condition called twin-lamb disease, which makes ewes very listless and puts them off their food. If left untreated with this condition the ewes die, which, as any cynical sheep farmer will tell you, is an ovine's greatest wish in life anyway.

Family after family is now caught up in the spreading crisis. The Brough family keep only six hoggs (last year's lambs) a couple of miles from Heddon-on-the-Wall. These half-dozen animals are destined for the freezer. After the Waugh brothers' pig farm at Heddon was confirmed with foot and mouth at the weekend, Ann Brough and her son, David, took every precaution possible around their small holding. While they were busy with this task involving the use of formaldehyde (in place of disinfectant) their dog - a lurcher, named, Mr Jinks - devoured the family's lunchtime roast chicken.

On Monday, one of the hoggs was lame (as sheep frequently are) and a telephone call was made to their own vet. The vet was busy operating and advised the Broughs to ring the ministry. They did, and the farm was duly cordoned off and a sample taken for testing. The following day, relations arrived from the US and were not allowed anywhere near the farm or the family until the final day of their stay, when Ann, under a licence from Maff, was able to break out of confinement to see them.

Needless to say the one lame sheep is fully recovered now and there have been no further signs of disease among the other five sheep. Ann says she has never felt so disconsolate in her life and the whole experience has been very degrading. And I can only guess that when these six hoggs are gone, next year's meat will come from the butcher.

I've wormed the dogs today, and written this up in our animal medicine book. We are members of a farm assurance scheme (Farm Assured British Beef and Lamb, known as FABBL), part of Assured British Meat (ABM). Under this scheme we are registered and checked by an independent inspector to make sure we farm within the strict guidelines. The criteria set by FABBL cover all sorts of aspects: animal management, feeding, housing, handling and veterinary treatment. And this means that Pearl and Tigger (who cuddles up to the Aga all day long) must be included in the records. I wonder how many people realise that their dog is a potential link in the life cycle of a tapeworm? And that all "assured" farmers have such strict rules concerning man's best friend, or in this case the children's best and - owing to foot and mouth - only friends.

Terrible news: the chief veterinary officer has just announced that this outbreak is set to run and run.

 The writer and her husband run a livestock farm near Heddon-on-the-Wall, Northumberland. She is writing a daily diary during the foot and mouth crisis.

webTitle: Private lives: Should I continue living near by ex for the sake of our son?

fields.headline: Private lives
fields.standfirst: Should I continue living near my ex for the sake of our son?
fields.trailText: Should I continue living near my ex for the sake of our son?
fields.body:
Shortly before Christmas, my husband of four years announced, by email, that he intended to leave me. He was working overseas and when he got back, left the family home, with little explanation. I've tried to persuade him to change his mind but there is little chance of this. I live where I do because we moved for my husband's job 18 months ago. My family and all my friends are 500 miles away, but my husband says he wants to spend equal time with our son, who is two. He also has a daughter overseas whom he rarely sees. Do I move to be near my family or stick it out here so my son and his father can have regular contact?

You have done enough

I'm sure you know by now that you are showing a staggering level of tolerance for your husband's behaviour. Communicating news of your separation by email is just the start of a journey on which you seem to be expected to go along, regardless of your feelings. If your account is an accurate description of the situation, there is no other conclusion to reach than that your husband is immature and selfish. I think you have done enough for him now - pick up your life and move to where you will be best supported by people who care for you.

His behaviour is typical of abusive and controlling partners (usually men): for instance, removing partners geographically to a place where they will have little support or using manipulative methods to bring about their isolation. You seem to be torn in a way I recognise - you are a whole human being, now caring full-time for your son, on your own. Whose interest is your husband considering when he attempts to control your movements, even from outside the relationship he has deserted? Does he care about the impact of his actions on you and consequently on the happiness of your child? You do not have to take on any responsibility for the disappointment he may feel about failing in his relationship with his first child - if he is committed to maintaining communication with his son he can move his job and his home to do so - as you did.

Name and address withheld

Follow your instincts

I was in a similar situation as your writer - my marriage broke down, divorce followed and I was in Australia. I had no friends or famiy for support. I felt very lonely and desperately wanted to go home to the UK, but felt I should stay as the three children had a good relationship with their father and saw him fairly regularly.

I wrestled with this dilemma for some months, but matters came to a head when after a weekend visit I asked the children's father when he would be seeing them again. "Oh," he replied, airily. "I'm not sure. I'm going away next weekend, the following weekend I'm on a work-related course and the next week I'm off to the UK for a three-week holiday." (The latter I would have loved but could not afford.)

This reply made my mind up for me. I put the house on the market and bought airline tickets to the UK for myself and the children. While there were short-term unpleasant ramifications, long term, the children and I have been settled and happy near friends and family.

Contact with the children's father has been intermittent over the past 10 years. The children have not seen him for about two years nor heard from him for about six months.

Move closer to support

You, your son and your future security and happiness are the priority. You will need your family for support, childcare and additional emotional security for your son in the future.

I was in exactly the same situation, with two children under seven. Within two years, my husband moved more than 500 miles away. Fortunately, I had already made the decision to move near my family. My daughters have thrived with the love of family members, and the support we've received.

It's a painful time for you now, but in years to come you will know that you made the right decision.

Name and address withheld

Put your needs first

Live where YOU and your son feel most comfortable. If your ex can't be bothered to travel to see his child, you can remind him that there's always email . . .

Name and address withheld

Next week

My relationship with my mother is abysmal and I'm considering severing links. I do not believe she loves me at all. For as long as I can recall she has periodically stopped speaking to me without provocation or explanation. This has often happened at times when I am most vulnerable; during my finals and following my father's death eight years ago. Eventually she comes around, without apology. She presented herself as attentive and doting at my wedding four years ago, despite having shown no interest in the preparations. Then, I decided to withdraw, because I realised that the more I hope for love, the more she disappoints me. However, I contacted her after my son's birth last year and during her three subsequent visits she has made it clear that her interest is focused solely upon him. My husband believes we should not deny her a relationship with our son. Should I continue to put up with such treatment for the sake of my mother's relationship with her grandchild?

webTitle: Worlds apart: Relations between British Jews and Israelis are not as easy as they used to be, says Ned Temko.

fields.headline: Worlds apart
fields.standfirst:
Relations between British Jews and Israelis are not as easy as they used to be. The left and right here are united in despair, says Ned Temko, editor of the Jewish Chronicle

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Relations between British Jews and Israelis are not as easy as they used to be. The left and right here are united in despair, says  Ned Temko, editor of the Jewish Chronicle.
fields.body:
Late last year, when the daily violence in Gaza and the West Bank was still front-page news and the British media almost unanimously held Israel to blame, a businessman and philanthropist, on the right of the political spectrum, took me aside at a communal function and exclaimed: "Israel is in trouble. We in this country must do something to help." Yet precisely what British Jews could or should do, he conceded, he was not quite sure.

He seems more certain now. He and a few like-minded souls have been urging, and helping to organise, holiday-cum-fact-finding visits to Israel, partly as a boost for the country's suddenly struggling tourist industry, and partly as a boost for communal morale. When he reads a particularly one-sided account of how the Israeli-Palestinian peace process so suddenly and utterly collapsed, he sits down and writes a letter to set the record straight. But while he feels better "at least to be doing something", a nagging gloom remains and whether cause or effect, a sense that things in Israel, and between Israel and the roughly 270,000 British Jews, are not as easy as they used to be.

The extraordinary new government of Ariel Sharon is no exception. A few years ago, the very idea of a Sharon government would have been absurd. The Oslo peace process, with all its problems, was taken by most Israelis, and most British Jews, as a fait accompli. There was disagreement over whether it would work, how much land should be swapped for what kind of peace, and whether the left-of-centre Labour Party that started Oslo, or the right-wing Likud, was better suited to deliver on hopes for "peace with security". But Likud meant Binyamin Netanyahu. Sharon was yesterday's man, a figure tainted in many Israeli and diaspora minds by the Lebanese War. And if Sharon had somehow managed to claim the prime minister's job, the political left would have responded, instinctively, with denunciation and despair.

There is despair these days among many British Jews. But it is not neatly limited to the left. Nor, for the most part, is it focused on Sharon. At communal events, around dinner tables, not to mention on the letters pages of the Jewish Chronicle, the old dividing lines between left and right, Labour and Likud, peace versus security, have blurred - replaced by a shared sense that peace, at least of the sort envisaged after Oslo, is, for now, simply impossible.

The shift can be charted, almost month by month, from last summer's abortive attempt at Camp David by Israel's then-prime minister, Ehud Barak, to secure a "final status" peace accord with Yasser Arafat. Days after the summit collapsed, another Jewish community figure, this one squarely on the political left, remarked to me over lunch that "Arafat was right". Yes, Barak had become the first leader in Israeli history to put the issue of Jerusalem on the table. But, if reports were to believed, he had limited himself to suggesting shared control over even the predominantly Arab east of the city. "What do you expect?" he asked. "Why should we assume the Palestinians would settle for that?"

Then came the "new intifada " - initially causing huge confusion, and discord, among British Jews, as well as an unprecedentedly open bout of argument and soul-searching on the Jewish Chronicle's letters pages. Why did Sharon go walkabout on the Temple Mount? Why answer stones with gunfire? And, on the other side: how can Israel talk peace with Arafat when he prefers war? How can his signature be trusted if, when he doesn't get what he wants, he looses the mob, frees Hamas bombers from jail, and cynically cries "Goliath against David" to supine editorial writers the world over?

Yet inexorably, in the months that followed, the spiralling violence, the lynching of two Israeli reservists in Ramallah, and finally the desperate pre-election search by Barak for a way to give Israel's voters a peace agreement - including the further concession on Jerusalem that my left-of-centre luncheon partner had urged - redrew the terms of debate. Arafat really didn't want peace, according to the new consensus. Or if he did, he was much too weak to deliver it. He didn't want Barak, either. By spurning not only the frantic efforts of Israeli negotiators to get an agreement, but also moves for at least a reduction in violence, he cast his vote for Sharon.

A few weeks ago, two British rabbis, advocates of dialogue with the Palestinians before it was fashionable, decided to join a commemoration of Deir Yassin, the Arab village on the outskirts of Jerusalem attacked during the 1948 war by an Irgun-led force, leaving dozens of civilians dead. Rabbis John Rayner and Jeffrey Newman said they felt a "moral imperative" to participate, adding that any hope of a peaceful future for Israelis and Palestinians must surely lie in their facing "the truth about themselves" and learning mutual understanding and respect.

Some of the criticism that greeted their initiative was predictable: a British Likud leader said the rabbis had got their facts wrong, that whatever else Deir Yassin was, it occurred during a war for Israel's very existence, and it was not a premeditated massacre. But a letter in this week's Jewish Chronicle probably better reflects the new mood in British Jewry - and the sense, particularly among many early advocates of Israeli-Arab dialogue, of despair and betrayal. It accepted the rabbis' good faith, professed to understand their motives, but added: "When the time comes when a Palestinian leader expresses the desire to attend a memorial day for any of the innocent victims of Arab aggression, I will be very pleased to accompany them to a future Deir Yassin memorial event."

The older, more familiar political battle lines - in Israel and among Britain's Jews - will surely reappear. Sooner or later, the negotiating process begun in Oslo will resume in earnest; not, necessarily, because either side can summon up enthusiasm for the process, but because there is no alternative. This will mean painful compromise, and difficult choices, for both sides. In Israel's case, it would prove a defining moment for a Sharon "unity government" which includes both Shimon Peres (architect of Oslo) and Rechavam Ze'evi (advocate of the "transfer" of Palestinians outside the confines of the biblical Land of Israel).

But when? The reality, most Israelis and British Jews appear to assume, is that it will not come soon. The immediate challenge for the Sharon government is one which largely unites its 26 cabinet ministers: to find a way, if not to end the now five-month-old intifada , to isolate or live with it. Arafat could not even bring himself to deliver a formulaic expression of regret over the latest suicide-bombing in Israel, mounted during rush-hour near a crowded bus station. He has insisted, meanwhile, that any talks must resume where Barak (humiliated first by Arafat, then by Israeli voters) left off. To some Israelis, and some diaspora Jews in Britain and elsewhere, that path is, even now, worth taking. But their number is fewer than even several weeks ago, and far, far fewer than several months ago.

fields.headline: Human traffic
fields.standfirst:
In West Africa, ruthless gangs of traffickers terrify young men and women into fleeing to Britain in search of asylum. From here, they are shipped to Italy and a life of prostitution. Melanie McFadyean investigates

Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: In West Africa, ruthless gangs of traffickers terrify young men and women into fleeing to Britain in search of asylum. From here, they are shipped to Italy and a life of prostitution.  Melanie McFadyean  investigates.
fields.body:
There is a list in West Sussex social services files of 71 children, mostly from West Africa or China. Their details are listed under the following headings: name, date of birth, arrival date, date went missing. Most were in their mid-teens when they arrived here, alone and seeking asylum. All have disappeared: some within 24 hours, some after a week or two, and a handful after several months. What evidence there is strongly suggests they have been trafficked into prostitution in Italy, where some 6o% of street prostitutes are West African.

"Jane", a 16-year-old Nigerian, is one of only two girls to have surfaced again after vanishing from social services here (the other was found hiding in a church in Italy). Jane sits very still, and seems numb as she recounts her ordeal. Even when she cries, she barely moves.

In Nigeria, thinking she was going to a party, Jane was taken by traffickers to a room where there were human heads on spikes. There she was forced to drink the blood of a dead woman. They then cut her with razor blades in small, neat rows, making her promise with each cut not to tell anyone anything, saying they would know because they had voodoo powers. There was another girl there and they forced them to lick each other's wounds.

The traffickers then instructed her to return, bringing a friend, but she refused and so they sent her threatening messages. She met a man who, feigning sympathy, offered to help her. The cycle had begun. She was introduced to a man who provided her with a ticket and forged passport and told her to memorise a telephone number which she was to ring on arrival in London.

Jane imagined that in London she would go through immigration on her forged passport and find a telephone. She had never been more than a few miles beyond her home before, and didn't know UK currency would be any different to Nigerian naira. She could barely read or write and forgot the telephone number, so when a Gatwick immigration officer asked her where she was going, she said she didn't know. She ended up in the care of West Sussex social services.

But two months after her arrival there, she left, only to be arrested three weeks later at a port. The man she was with had been stopped before in the company of young girls, using the same passport as Jane had on this occasion. He had also been arrested in another European country, where an attempt to prosecute him for human trafficking had failed. Port authorities let the man go (despite a Customs and Special Branch request to the contrary). Jane was put in detention for five months, leading her to the brink of suicide before she was released back into West Sussex's care last summer. The Home Office turned down her asylum claim and she is currently appealing.

Lynne Chitty, a senior asylum team social worker at West Sussex, who is looking after Jane, has heard many similar stories. She was told that a lawyer had come forward, claiming to have been instructed by Jane's father, and insisting that the girl was older than she said. Jane says this is impossible, that she doesn't even know who her father is. Chitty says that solicitors are used unwittingly by third parties to control the young people.

She has watched the tragedy of such cases unfold since the first children disappeared in 1995, and she believes that of the West Sussex list of 71 missing, at least 40 West African girls and 14 West African boys have been trafficked into the sex trade. In January 1998 - by which time 10 children had gone missing - Sussex Police set up Operation Newbridge to gather intelligence on the girls. The boys were not included. A Missing Persons Helpline television programme resulted in a lead from a truck driver who had seen young African girls in lorry parks in Italy.

In January 2000, the national crime squad presented a case against a number of men suspected of trafficking and prostitution, but the crown prosecution service rejected it. Current legislation makes convictions virtually impossible, and the authorities regard the few witnesses who might be prepared to come forward as unreliable because they change their stories. Chitty says they change them because they are too frightened to tell the truth until trust has built up between them and social workers.

Chitty claims she has seen the traffickers: a woman hanging around a safe house who ran when approached by police; four men in a car outside a meeting of these children, who were watching her as she called police on her mobile phone. She and her family have been threatened. Disturbingly, half a dozen of the young people fitting the "profile" are working with the gangs, corrupted by money and power. Chitty knows, and they know she knows.

DI Nigel Kent of the National Crime Squad, which led the failed investigation, thinks some girls know what awaits them here, "believing the UK is the land of milk and honey". Bisi Olateru Olagbegi, a Nigerian lawyer and women's rights activist, says that some see prostitution as an escape from poverty, but don't realise the horror of the conditions in which they will live and work. Nor do they realise that their debt bondage, usually about £38,000 to traffickers, pimps and madams, will tie them down for years. (At Italian rates, a girl would have to suffer 3,000 clients to expunge the debt.) Olagbegi says that rape and even bestiality are used to control the girls.

West Sussex social services has been vigorously proactive in tackling the situation, setting up safe houses, reporting every disappearance, working closely with immigration, police, the Missing Persons Helpline, the Refugee Council and others. Other authorities, notably Kent County Council and Hillingdon, have also lost children. For a few months last year, none left the West Sussex safe houses. But another girl vanished one Sunday lunchtime in October and hasn't been seen since. Chitty, who knew the girl well, and the others in the safe house, insist she would not have gone voluntarily and fear she is in danger.

Chitty continues to report every disappearance and supply police with information, but feels it is futile. Detective Superintendent David Gaylor of Sussex police, who was involved at the start of the investigations, shares her concerns but says the police are not to blame: "We feel neutered and disempowered."

Gaylor says that when the issue was first raised with the Home Office two years ago, officials responded, "in so many words, that it wasn't their problem". Since then, Gaylor says there has been some response from Barbara Roche, the immigration minister , but "there's still a long way to go". He hopes now that there will be European and international liaison to combat the traffickers.

Meanwhile the trafficking continues and Chitty fears that nothing will be done until the tragedy becomes a crisis - until one of those who is missing is found dead. She feels passionately about these young people. "I feel privileged to work with them, I can't believe how brave they are. They arrive here, they don't even know where they are. They deserve to be safe, to be cared for. They are children."

• In tomorrow's Guardian Weekend: Melanie McFadyean hears the stories of other child refugees who have survived hair-raising journeys from countries in turmoil around the world, only to find a very uncertain welcome in the UK.
