Nor do they realise that their debt bondage, usually about £38,000 to traffickers, pimps and madams, will tie them down for years. (At Italian rates, a girl would have to suffer 3,000 clients to expunge the debt.) Olagbegi says that rape and even bestiality are used to control the girls. West Sussex social services has been vigorously proactive in tackling the situation, setting up safe houses, reporting every disappearance, working closely with immigration, police, the Missing Persons Helpline, the Refugee Council and others. Other authorities, notably Kent County Council and Hillingdon, have also lost children. For a few months last year, none left the West Sussex safe houses. But another girl vanished one Sunday lunchtime in October and hasn't been seen since. Chitty, who knew the girl well, and the others in the safe house, insist she would not have gone voluntarily and fear she is in danger. Chitty continues to report every disappearance and supply police with information, but feels it is futile. Detective Superintendent David Gaylor of Sussex police, who was involved at the start of the investigations, shares her concerns but says the police are not to blame: "We feel neutered and disempowered." Gaylor says that when the issue was first raised with the Home Office two years ago, officials responded, "in so many words, that it wasn't their problem". Since then, Gaylor says there has been some response from Barbara Roche, the immigration minister , but "there's still a long way to go". He hopes now that there will be European and international liaison to combat the traffickers. Meanwhile the trafficking continues and Chitty fears that nothing will be done until the tragedy becomes a crisis - until one of those who is missing is found dead. She feels passionately about these young people. "I feel privileged to work with them, I can't believe how brave they are. They arrive here, they don't even know where they are. They deserve to be safe, to be cared for. They are children." • In tomorrow's Guardian Weekend: Melanie McFadyean hears the stories of other child refugees who have survived hair-raising journeys from countries in turmoil around the world, only to find a very uncertain welcome in the UK.

webTitle: Chilean judges reduce charges against Pinochet

fields.headline: Chilean judges reduce charges against Pinochet
fields.standfirst:
Former dictator now accused only of 'covering up' murders

Special report: Pinochet on trial
fields.trailText: Human rights groups responded with outrage to a Chilean court decision yesterday which reduced the charges against the former dictator Augusto Pinochet.
fields.body:
Human rights groups responded with outrage to a Chilean court decision yesterday which reduced the charges against the former dictator Augusto Pinochet.

The 85-year-old general now faces charges of covering up crimes of murder and kidnapping rather than being responsible for them.

"This is an embarrassment," said Vivianna Diaz, president of the Families of the Detained and Disappeared.

Speaking in the supreme court building in Santiago, Ms Diaz denounced what she said were political pressures on the court to save Gen Pinochet from further investigation and a possible trial.

"They are looking for a way to protect him," she said

Carmen Soria, the daughter of the Spanish diplomat Carmelo Soria, who was murdered by Pinochet security forces, was even more blunt.

"This is crazy. If he didn't order it [state-sponsored repression], who did? In my opinion, he was responsible for all the repression.

"He didn't go out and kill people, but was he the intellectual author? Absolutely."

The ruling by a two-to-one majority confirmed that Gen Pinochet remains under investigation and house arrest.

His defence sought to have the investigation closed by arguing that the general could not be directly linked to the thousands of murders carried out during his 1973-1990 rule.

But lower ranking army officials, cashing in what they call their "life insurance" in an attempt to show they were simply loyal soldiers carrying out sordid orders, continue to leak documents to the press that demonstrate Gen Pinochet's direct involvement in everything from drawing up execution lists to the ensuing coverups.

The online Chilean news paper El Mostrador has been rewriting Chilean history recently by publishing a spate of secret decrees and confessions about crimes committed during the Pinochet reign.

The judge investigating Gen Pinochet, Juan Guzman, will now move forward in his effort to to establish his role in the "Caravan of Death" massacres: the organised murder of political prisoners by a special military unit which travelled the length of Chile.

The Caravan of Death is one of more than 200 criminal cases before the courts in which Gen Pinochet is implicated.

The evidence in the case is particularly strong, since former army generals have repeatedly testified that murders committed in their areas of jurisdiction were carried out on the direct orders of Gen Pinochet in Santiago.

Judge Guzman has repeatedly denounced the efforts of the Chilean government to scuttle his investigation. He was sanctioned by the supreme court, which many observers see as a warning to drop the investigation. But in the year since Gen Pinochet returned to Chile after 16 months of house arrest in England, the investigation has slowly progressed.

While human rights activists still see many hurdles in their effort to have Gen Pinochet tried, their anger at the most recent ruling arose from the view that it would delay - not end - the ever more complex effort to prosecute him.

"This is going to be a very interesting year as the judges try to clean up their images - the Chilean public has no faith in them," said Ms Soria, who has fought for more than 10 years to have the case of her father's murder reopened.

Referring to the dozens of top military officials now under investigation, she smiled and said: "I love seeing them nervous."

fields.headline: Number's up for NSB
fields.trailText: The market's ruthless mood was demonstrated by the reaction to year-end numbers from NSB Retail Systems, a specialist software supplier for retailers.
fields.body:
The market's ruthless mood was demonstrated by the reaction to year-end numbers from NSB Retail Systems, a specialist software supplier for retailers.

At first glance the figures looked rather impressive: revenue almost doubled at £41m, operating profits up from £4.6m to £8m and earnings per share ahead by 50% at 2.44p.

But the City was expecting something better, and chief executive Nikki Beckett admitted: "Despite the increase in EPS, these re sults are disappointing and below our expectations. Our 2000 plan always required significant new business in the final two months of the year.

"We did not close all of this business, contributing to both a revenue and profit shortfall." The market shouted its response: the share price dropped from 132p to 84.5p.

As recently as September the stock was trading at 300p, having reached a peak of 340p earlier last year.

fields.headline: Shire clings to roller coaster
fields.trailText: Sometimes the London market gets a little too complicated for those who play it.
fields.body:
Sometimes the London market gets a little too complicated for those who play it.

Take Shire Pharmaceutical, which is in the process of merging with its Canadian rival Biochem Pharma. Its shares have been all over the place over recent days as speculation has swirled that the terms of the all-paper merger will draw all sorts of funny business from bid arbitrageurs and hedge funds.

The assumption is that these professional traders will be shorting Shire on the basis that, since the British company is paying for the Canadian concern in shares, North American investors will not want to be holders of the new stock and will send it back to Britain.

After another volatile session yesterday, the price ended 6p lower at £11.20.

But many in the market do not seem to have noticed that the merger terms include a complex formula designed to stop these sorts of market antics. The terms of the merger will be set with reference to Shire's average share price over 15 trading days, which began on Wednesday, while there is also a so-called "collar" where the stock-swap ratio in the merger is fixed if Shire's shares settle outside a set price band. The effect has been that arbitrageurs can only make money on this deal if Shire's share price moves roughly sideways over the next three weeks.

Close followers of the situation point out that Shire will romp up the Footsie league table when the merger is complete, sparking some heavy buying by index-tracking institutions which will have to take its new, heavier weighting into account.

For the market as a whole yesterday, the focus was distinctly short-term and downbeat. The FTSE 100 index managed to edge up 1.4 points to a 6,003.2 close, but the mood was dictated by situations like GKN, down 70 at 740p after warning that the US slowdown is likely to hit profits, and Abbey National, down 25p to £11.41, as comments from the office of fair trading solidified the view that Lloyds TSB's £19bn bid will be blocked by the competition authorities.

Royal & Sun Alliance took a hard knock, ending the session 22.5p lower at 479p in heavy trade. Dealers blamed disappointing figures from smaller rival Independent Insurance earlier in the week.

With plenty of bad news around, the main index only seemed to be supported by Vodafone, which advanced 4.75p to 207p as a few brokers issued "buy" advice in the wake of a strategy presentation by the world's biggest mobile phone group. In the presentation, chief executive Chris Gent said the company was on track to launch a full commercial service using the GPRS technical standard across Europe by the summer.

There was good news elsewhere among hi-tech related issues. Cable group Telewest, for example, added 9p to 146p after strong results from its rival NTL, which is quoted on the Nasdaq in the US.

But while the likes of Cable & Wireless and ARM Holdings made good progress in the morning, weakness on the Nasdaq later in the wake of the Yahoo! warning undermined their advance. C&W closed 14.5p higher a 752.5p and ARM had managed to add 8.5p to 369p by the close.

Meanwhile, Marconi, which raced ahead to 530p in the morning, subsequently ended the day at 511p, up just 3p on balance.

Lower down the corporate scale, discount stores group TJ Hughes crashed 118p to 202p after warning that it had mis-stated its stock position. Finance director Tony Potter has resigned "with immediate effect".

Plumbing parts group BSS fell 47.5p to 282.5p after news that takeover talks with an unnamed suitor had collapse. It also warned that trading during the second half was lower than expected. At one stage the price hit 257p before a partial recovery.

fields.headline: At this price?  Cordiant
fields.trailText: Cordiant, the advertising and marketing services group which owns the Bates brand, warned yesterday that the accepted forecast of 6% growth in global advertising spend this year was probably "a little high".
fields.body:
Cordiant, the advertising and marketing services group which owns the Bates brand, warned yesterday that the accepted forecast of 6% growth in global advertising spend this year was probably "a little high".

Chief executive Michael Bungey suggested growth was more likely to be 4.5-5%. The fall in dot.com spending, he noted, had been particularly severe, all of which could be considered a little gloomy. Shares in Cordiant, however, added 5p to 289p as the group announced its full-year results.

The company, which demerged from Saatchi & Saatchi three years ago, has been pursuing a target of reducing its reliance on above-the-line advertising spend and increasing its exposure to faster growing, higher margin marketing services such as public relations, direct marketing and sales promotion.

A series of acquisitions means it reached its target of 50% of group revenues from this area by the end of last year. It has now set a new target of two-thirds of total revenues by the end of 2003 coming from other marketing services.

The strategy has meant margins at group level creeping up to 12% against 10% in 1999 and pre-tax profits for the year 79% higher to £57m. Revenues were 54% higher at £513m.

Just 10% of Cordiant's revenues come from above-the-line advertising in the US, which means even if that market, perceived to be the most vulnerable, falls away, the impact should be minimal. The group also, wisely, steered clear of taking dot.com accounts in return for stock so Cordiant's exposure to that burst bubble are also low.

Since splitting with Saatchi's, Cordiant has grown four times in value and moved into the top 10 largest marketing groups in the world.

If nothing else, as Mr Bungey freely admits, it makes a tasty takeover target. Buy.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Ballerina to rest in peace
fields.body:
Ballerina to rest in peace

The ashes of the ballerina Anna Pavlova will stay at Golders Green crematorium in London after Moscow withdrew permission for their return to Russia yesterday.

Valentina Zhilenkova, director of the Anna Pavlova Foundation of Mercy, led a 10-year fight for the return of the ashes, but members of St Petersburg's ballet protested that they should either be left in peace or reburied in her home town, St Petersburg.
Amelia Gentleman, Moscow

Colombia peace talks open

Envoys from 26 nations met with leaders of Colombia's largest guerrilla group yesterday to try to end the 37-year conflict which has claimed 130,000 lives.

The meeting in Los Pozos, a Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia stronghold 430 miles south of Bogota, brought together officials from the UN, Europe and Latin America, but not the US.
AFP, Los Pozos

Islands face economic crisis

The Solomon Islands are weeks away from economic collapse, the governor of the country's central bank, Ric Hou, said yesterday.

The economy has been devastated by a two-year civil war that has claimed dozens of lives and displaced 20,000 of the 300,000 population.
AFP, Auckland

fields.headline: Interest rates stay on hold
fields.trailText: The Bank of England left interest rates on hold at 5.75% yesterday despite the deteriorating outlook for global economic growth.
fields.body:
The Bank of England left interest rates on hold at 5.75% yesterday despite the deteriorating outlook for global economic growth.

Some analysts blamed the decision on the Budget, which cut taxes and increased spending by more than £5bn, at the top end of City expectations.

However, most economists expect the expansionary impact of the Budget to be more than offset by the slowdown in global growth, forcing the Bank's monetary policy committee to cut rates again to boost demand.

Financial markets are pricing in a fall in the Bank's repo rate to about 5.25% over the next six months.

David Page, of Investec, said the MPC had probably been swayed by robust retail sales figures in January.

"Some members of the committee might well like to see another month of data to ensure that this is not the start of a significant upswing in domestic demand," he said.

"With the Budget out of the way, we expect the MPC's concern over the global economy to outweigh its caution over domestic demand pressures."

Since the last meeting, the signals from America have been mixed, with a fall in consumer confidence and a 13% drop in the Nasdaq balanced by improving retail sales, leaving intact the view that the economy will recovery smartly in the second half of the year.

However, Japan, the world's second largest economy, appears to be slipping into recession, triggered by weakening exports and the continued stagnation of domestic demand. Figures published yesterday showed household spending, considered essential for a long-awaited full recovery to take hold, fell 0.5% in January from a year earlier.

Meanwhile shop prices edged up 0.64% during February, mainly due to higher prices for eggs and clothes, according to the British Retail Consortium. The BRC said this was a small increase considering most retailers offered items for sale at discounted prices in January. The MPC could have cut rates without risk of inflation.

webTitle: Awash Hungary fights its worst floods

fields.headline: Awash Hungary fights its worst floods
fields.trailText: "Everyone left here yesterday," Istvan Porgo shouted above the din of a helicopter preparing to take off from the football pitch behind him.
fields.body:
"Everyone left here yesterday," Istvan Porgo shouted above the din of a helicopter preparing to take off from the football pitch behind him.

Nine hundred men, women and children were evacuated from Tiszaszalka on Wednesday, almost the entire population.

The few who remain, backed up by soldiers and rescue workers, are piling earth embankments ever higher against the brown waters of the Tisza river.

The river is more like a sea now, and Tiszaszalka an island. On Tuesday floodwater up to 10 metres deep (32ft) broke through the dykes near the village of Tarpa, 10 miles south-east. The day before, the water breached the defences upstream in Ukraine.

Large tracts of Ukraine, Hungary, and Romania are now under water, prompting the evacuation of more than 60,000 people. Seven people have died in Ukraine.

Although the flood is at a record level, years of preparation and improved cooperation between states has limited the loss of life.

But one problem the rescue workers face is the reluctance of people to leave their homes and animals. In Gulacs, near Tarpa, the Gero family returned home yesterday to rescue their pig, despite a metre of water.

"More should have been done to prevent these floods," Andras Gero said.

Some blame overlogging upstream in Ukraine and Romania, which has removed the trees that normally soak up the melting snow, allowing four days of torrential rain to overwhelm both the natural and man-made defences.

Others blame officials for not spending enough on flood defences, although older Hungarians say the rivers have been over- regulated: they should be allowed to flood wider areas, not channelled between narrow banks.

By last night Tiszaszalka had had three days without rain, but no one dared predict how much melted snow would flow from the Carpathian mountains, whose foothills to the east, rise out of the brown sea.

webTitle: M&S designer range stays on the rails

fields.headline: M&S designer range stays on the rails
fields.trailText: Sales of Marks & Spencer's new designer range, Autograph, have flopped, with womenswear missing targets by more than 20%, the company confirmed yesterday.
fields.body:
Sales of Marks & Spencer's new designer range, Autograph, have flopped, with womenswear missing targets by more than 20%, the company confirmed yesterday.

"We did slightly miss some optimistic targets [last month]," said a spokeswoman for M&S. "Stores have been sent these aspirational targets to help them achieve more. We didn't think they'd actually meet them all."

One store missed its sales goal by 60% while the Marble Arch store in London needed to shift £55,000 of womenswear per week in February to meet its target of £220,000 but in one week netted just £31,000.

The news comes as executives appointed three designers to refit its stores - including 20/20 which revamped Sainsbury stores.

M&S introduced Autograph - a range of clothes by designers including Katharine Hamnett, Betty Jackson and Julien Macdonald - a year ago in an effort to throw off its mundane image and boost sales.

The company denied it was disappointed with the sales performance, saying that Autograph accounted for a "very, very" small percentage of womenswear turnover.

"Overall we are pleased with sales," the spokeswoman said. "Menswear reached its very aspirational target and womenswear is doing pretty well, though it missed the target. This range is only in 25 of our stores; it's a small amount of our business."

M&S shares fell 9.25p to 229.25p.

The news comes as executives appointed three designers to refit its stores - including 20/20 which revamped Sainsbury stores. M&S introduced Autograph - a range of clothes by designers including Katharine Hamnett, Betty Jackson and Julien Macdonald - a year ago in an effort to throw off its mundane image and boost sales. The company denied it was disappointed with the sales performance, saying that Autograph accounted for a "very, very" small percentage of womenswear turnover. "Overall we are pleased with sales," the spokeswoman said. "Menswear reached its very aspirational target and womenswear is doing pretty well, though it missed the target. This range is only in 25 of our stores; it's a small amount of our business." M&S shares fell 9.25p to 229.25p.

webTitle: Russia accused of stalling nuclear cleanup

fields.headline: Russia accused of stalling nuclear cleanup
fields.standfirst:
Frustrated negotiators close to dropping aid offer to clear Barents sea graveyard of rusting submarines
Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: A western plan to spend billions of pounds cleaning up the Russian far north is in danger of collapsing in acrimony after more than two years of difficult negotiations between Russia, the European Union, the US, Norway, and Japan.
fields.body:
A western plan to spend billions of pounds cleaning up the Russian far north is in danger of collapsing in acrimony after more than two years of difficult negotiations between Russia, the European Union, the US, Norway, and Japan.

Governments in the west - especially those in Scandinavia - are frightened by the risks posed by what some have called "the world's biggest nuclear graveyard': the dozens of abandoned submarines with their nuclear reactors littering the Barents sea in the Russian arctic.

Russian and Scandinavian foreign ministers are to meet in the arctic port of Murmansk next week to try to reach an agreement to put billions of pounds in western aid money into what a 10-year project.

But the host of objections raised by the Russians has so exasperated the western negotiators that they are warning that the whole project could be ditched.

The Russian side is worried about preserving military secrecy, has insisted that western companies involved in the work must pay Russian taxes, and has declared that western governments or companies will be liable for any accidents during thework.

"What is the point of getting lots of experts together if they're not going to get anywhere? the EU external affairs commissioner, Chris Patten, commented.

"In some ways the negotiations have slipped backwards. Is it wise to go on with endless meetings that don't go anywhere?"

The Kursk submarine disaster off the coast of Murmansk last summer highlighted the potential for nuclear pollution in the Barents sea. There are estimated to be about 100 Russian submarines rusting abandoned in the fjords of the Kola peninsula, with 300 nuclear reactors and 8,000 nuclear fuel elements.

The Swedes and the Norwegians are trying to inject urgency into the negotiations. Although the western is offering aid money, and much of it would go to western engineering companies contracted to do the work, the Russians have been insisting that those companies would then be liable to Russian taxation and their imported equipment subject to Russian customs duties.

"This is Norwegian taxpayers' money, given as aid. Norwegian politicians won't accept paying [tax] on what is seen as aid to Russia," said Thomas Nielsen, who is monitoring the talks for Bellona, a Norwegian environmental organisation which specialises in arctic nuclear pollution.

A meeting of experts in Moscow last week brought some movement on the taxation wrangle between Moscow and the EU, although sources said the Americans were still refusing to accept the Russian conditions. Russian officials declined to comment on the negotiations.

On the bigger problem of liability and indemnity, western officials are pessimistic about any agreement being reached before a Russia-EU summit in May.

"We want the western companies to enjoy a kind of diplomatic status so they are not terrorised by the Russian tax police and customs," a senior western diplomat in Moscow said.

"You're playing with atoms and people get scared. If something goes wrong, it's expensive. Who is going to pay for the damage? The Russians insist we're liable for any damage we cause. We're telling them they've got a problem with nuclear waste. But we're more concerned about it than they are."

A senior official in Brussels estimated the funds at stake at anywhere between $100m and several billion dollars. The overall cost of the clean-up is reckoned to be $10bn (about £7bn). Some of the biggest names in western nuclear engineering and waste management, such as British Nuclear Fuels, stand to gain from the contracts if the project gets the green light.

The negotiations on the so-called MNEPR (multilateral nuclear environmental programme for Russia) began two years ago.

But while the Russians appear happy to string them out, key western donors are fed up, Mr Nielsen said.

"The Russians are not going to sign the agreement, because they fear losing control of the project," he predicted. "And there is a time limit on the west's willingness to lend its technological help."

European commission officials said that the urgent task was to get the abandoned submarines into shallow water, to reduce the risk of radioactive materials being dispersed into the ocean.

The nuclear fuel and the reactors could then be detached from the vessels and put into storage.

But Russian Baltic and Northern fleet officers were balking at allowing western engineers into areas they regard as top-secret, they said.

"We now have a situation where both sides are aware that if there is no progress, there is a risk of a major collapse," one said.

"There has to be a breakthrough not later than the EU-Russia summit in May," the western diplomat in Moscow said.

"Otherwise one has to question whether it is worthwhile to continue."

Mr Nielsen said that rather than a multilateral agreement, Moscow's negotiators would prefer to deal with one western participant at a time.

Failure to reach a deal could also dash Russia's hope of the EU contributing tens of millions of dollars towards raising the Kursk and its two nuclear reactors from the bed of the Barents sea this summer.

fields.headline: Banks guilty of laundering
fields.trailText: Fifteen British-based banks were yesterday censured by City regulators for flouting anti-money laundering rules after a three-month investigation into 42 accounts linked to former Nigerian president General Sani Abacha.
fields.byline: Jill Treanor and Peter Capella in Geneva
fields.body:
Fifteen British-based banks were yesterday censured by City regulators for flouting anti-money laundering rules after a three-month investigation into 42 accounts linked to former Nigerian president General Sani Abacha.

The City of London police is now expected to open an investigation into how almost £1bn was moved between a total of 23 British-based banks that held accounts for the family of the former president, who died from an overdose of Viagra in 1998.

The investigation by the financial services authority, made public yesterday, followed criticism that money laundering controls failed to prevent as much as £3bn being looted by the former president from his country.

In a strongly worded warning to the City to clean up its act, the FSA said it had found 15 of the 23 banks had "significant" control weaknesses and that seven of these had been set strict deadlines to rectify their proceedings for dealing with suspected money laundering which must be reported to the national criminal intelligence service.

The regulator refused to identify the banks other than to say they included British ones and branches of banks inside and outside the European Union.

Nigerian sources, however, named a number of banks including Barclays, HSBC, NatWest, Royal Bank of Scotland as well as US ones such as Citibank, Merrill Lynch, and First Bank of Boston as having been investigated. This is not to say they were among those censured by the FSA yesterday. Most are thought to concern branches in London, including Golders Green, Knightsbridge and St John's Wood. One branch is understood to be in Leeds.

Phillip Thorpe, managing director of the FSA, said: "The extent of the weakness is frankly disappointing... potential breaches of money laundering regulations also being discussed with the appropriate law enforcement authorities".

A spokesman for the City of London police confirmed the force was reviewing the information. "It is envisaged a police investigation will ensue in due course," the spokesman said yesterday.

The serious fraud office is also continuing to provide information requested by the Swiss authorities, which last year found that $213m of Abacha assets flowed from London to Switzerland.

The Swiss regulator reprimanded six Swiss-based banks and froze assets in Switzerland while a local prosecutor seeks to press money laundering charges and to seize the money. The Nigerians formally asked the Home Office to freeze Abacha-related assets in Britain last June, but it is feared that with the case still under consideration the remaining money may have been removed.

The FSA said that while the turnover on the 42 accounts was $1.3bn for the four years between 1996 and 2000 this did not necessarily mean that it was the proceeds of crime or the total amount of money received into Britain.

It is now thought that about $900m came from Switzerland to British shores during the 1990s, making the two countries a key platform for the rest of the global web of alleged money laundering.

More than 18 months after they started following the paper trail in Switzerland, then spreading out to other countries, the lawyers continue to be astonished by what they find. There is evidence of direct payments from the Central Bank in Nigeria, cash and travellers cheques smuggling, as well as the possible proceeds of corruption. $2.2bn was taken from the Central Bank alone.

webTitle: Arriva looks to rail business for profit

fields.headline: Arriva looks to rail business for profit
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Bus company Arriva - the former Cowie Group - expects its recently acquired rail business to start contributing to profits shortly, after it won two-year extensions to its franchises.
fields.body:
Bus company Arriva - the former Cowie Group - expects its recently acquired rail business to start contributing to profits shortly, after it won two-year extensions to its franchises.

Arriva runs the Northern Spirit and Merseyrail Electrics lines, which lost £23.6m last year, it revealed yesterday. But with the franchise extensions, along with applications to run Trans-Pennine Express, Thameslink and Wales and Borders routes, rail will become increasingly important to the group.

Arriva's operating profits accelerated 5% last year to £97m despite floods, fuel shortages and petrol price rises. But pre-tax profits fell from £198.7m in 1999 to £72.1m. The 1999 figure was boosted by an exceptional profit from the sale of its car leasing business. Chief executive Bob Davies said Arriva's underlying strength had been reflected in its ability to deliver a good set of results in spite of difficult trading conditions.

The company's bus fleets include the No 19, one of Londoners' favourite Routemaster conductor services with open backs.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Vauxhall ends Luton dispute
fields.body:
Vauxhall ends Luton dispute

A dispute over the ending of car production at Vauxhall's Luton plant is over after an agreement with unions, the company said yesterday.

Vauxhall said it was confident there would be no compulsory redundancies over the closure of the car assembly plant.

Workers have staged industrial action in protest against the decision to stop building cars in Luton next spring, with the loss of 2,000 jobs. But Vauxhall said an agreement had been made with the unions which effectively ended the dispute.

SFO inquiry in Guinness trial

The serious fraud office is investigating allegations of corruption involving a juror in the 1986 Guinness illegal share-support trial, the court of appeal was told yesterday.

Lord Justice Judge said some of the issues under investigation might amount to "no more than gossip or hearsay". However, if certain facts were to be established, the allegations would "obviously be of significance", he said.

Jack Lyons, the financier is appealing against his conviction in the Guinness scandal with Ernest Saunders, Gerald Ronson and Anthony Parnes.

Genus fights foot and mouth

Cattle breeding company Genus yesterday announced measures to reduce staff costs in the wake of the current outbreak of foot and mouth disease, which has hit its trading.

The company said now it would put 714 of its staff on short-time working or reduced salary. All executive directors would take a 20% cut in basic salary and all non-executive directors had waived fees for March.

Insurer ditches endowments

Countrywide Assured, the life insurer and estate agency group, yesterday announced it will stop selling endowments from the end of this month. Countrywide was reporting a 26% fall in profits for last year, which it blamed on a combination of reduced sales of these policies.

webTitle: Staff bonuses cut at John Lewis

fields.headline: Staff bonuses cut at John Lewis
fields.standfirst: Retailers feel the pinch as discriminating shoppers show their increasing power
fields.trailText: More than 50,000 John Lewis department store and Waitrose supermarket staff will receive lower annual bonuses this year as a result of a drop in profits.
fields.body:
More than 50,000 John Lewis department store and Waitrose supermarket staff will receive lower annual bonuses this year as a result of a drop in profits.

The John Lewis Partnership, which is owned by its 54,000 staff, predicted that low inflation would make it tough to turn future sales increases into profits. It estimated its profits after the payment of staff bonuses in the year to the end of January at £91.5m, down 23% from last year's £116.9m.

The staff will be paid a 10% bonus, totalling £58.1m, equal to five weeks' pay. Last year they received a bonus of 15%.

Chairman Sir Stuart Hampson said the group was committed to a big programme of capital spending to strengthen the business, and "saw no reason to cut back those plans in the light of these results".

John Lewis has recently opened a new store in Southampton, which it said had produced a powerful performance and is now modernising its Jessops store in Nottingham.

It also bought 11 former Somerfield supermarkets last year to convert to Waitrose outlets and is in the middle of a £100m revamp at its prestige Peter Jones outlet in Sloane Square, which has hit the group's bottom line by £17m.

The group is now planning a major update of its Oxford Street store to provide extra selling space an a "much stronger ground floor" - without the fabrics department.

Sir Stuart said that profits would have been further dented but for a particularly strong second half performance. At the halfway stage profits had been down 43% on the previous year and the partners, he said, "rose splendidly" to the challenge.

Department store sales were up 7.2%. Waitrose sales were up 13%, driven by new store openings, and up 3% excluding new space, despite food price deflation. For the first time the supermarket division brought in more sales than the department stores.

fields.headline: It's always, 'hey, Ferris, love your wife!'
fields.standfirst: Matthew Broderick tells  Michael Ellison about Oscars, Tonys and Sarah Jessica Parker
fields.trailText: Matthew Broderick tells Michael Ellison about Oscars, Tonys and Sarah Jessica Parker
fields.body:
Wherever you look, there is another image of his wife - on television, on bus shelters, on billboards all over town. The unshaven man in the red and white striped shirt and the beige cords indicates the magazine rack on one wall of the bustling French cafe in SoHo, a bowl-sized cafe au lait in front of him, the Bill Laswell remix of Bob Marley's Jammin' in the air.

There she is again on the cover of yet another glossy, Sarah Jessica Parker, the star of Channel 4's Sex and the City, an actor who has entered the bloodstream of popular culture. "People are consistently telling me how much they like my wife. That's my cross to bear. You get, 'Hey, Ferris, I love your wife.' At least they remember something. It's hard to walk around with her."

Broderick, of course, is not exactly an underachiever. At 38, he's won two Tony awards for his work on the New York stage (one before the age of 20) and made 30 movies. Now he's set to star in a new Broadway stage version of the Mel Brooks movie The Producers, which opens next month and looks certain to be a hit, and in the film You Can Count on Me, which has had two Oscar nominations. But who could forget his performance in the title role of Ferris Bueller's Day Off?

That was his defining role in the movies, the 1986 slacker film made before Generation X was allowed out without its mother, and he will never be allowed to forget it. "I've made my peace with him," he says. "I'm not sick of it. If people say something in the street I barely hear it. I suppose I'm abstractly happy, but it was 15 years ago." He would just as soon steer the conversation in the direction of his friend since their schooldays, playwright Kenneth Lonergan - once of the Royal Court in London - who is on the Academy Award shortlist for his screenplay for You Can Count on Me.

Right now, Broderick is scouring a large article about his friend in a New York weekly to see if he is quoted anywhere. He is not. "Don't I count at all?" he asks, employing his best self-deprecating tone. This very night the actor is going to see Lobby Hero, Lonergan's new play. His talk is all Kenny this and Kenny that.

Indeed, had they not been friends, it is unlikely that Broderick would have taken the part of Brian, the smalltown bank manager who is possibly even more officious than he is ambitious, in You Can Count on Me. "I probably would never have heard of it. I think probably it would never have gotten through my agent. I hope it would but they might have sent it to me and I didn't read it. I was doing a play at the time and I might not have wanted to bother.

"Now people tell me, 'You're in my favourite movie of the year.' I never expected that. It's such a small movie. We just hoped it would get in the theatres and get distributed." The film has far surpassed those modest aspirations. As well as the screenplay by Lonergan, who wrote the Robert De Niro/Billy Crystal film Analyze This, Laura Linney's performance has earned her an Oscar nomination for best actress. It tells the story of a wayward brother and a superficially respectable single-mother sister whose respectively impetuous and staid worlds collide in rural America. The movie has a rare grip on reality raised by superb acting.

The perception of those unaware of Broderick's parallel stage career is that he was a brilliant talent who lost his way in movies, only to rally in Election in 1999 as the teacher warring with Reese Witherspoon's precocious schoolgirl. It was as if Ferris Bueller had grown up to be a stolid, middle-class professional.

"It was just a coincidence," he says. "It wasn't a plan. Election, I just loved the script and I loved having the part. Kenny's was just because it was Kenny's. My career's had its ups and downs really, but suddenly I've had a pretty long movie career. A couple of years ago I had a couple that weren't very good." He mentions The Cable Guy, with Jim Carrey, and Inspector Gadget - "which did make $100m, by the way" - but says it's impossible now for him to discern during the production of a movie how it will work out. "You change and people don't want you to change and somehow you have got to bring people along. There aren't that many of us around that came along in the 1980s." It's not as though he was blamed unduly for these flops but, still, he was affected.

"If you think I killed Godzilla it's kind of unfair. It's all right. I don't know what people were hoping for. The Road to Wellville... it had Anthony Hopkins, Bridget Fonda, directed by Alan Parker. I hadn't been doing all that well and I was thrilled to get it and it just didn't work. It was a terrible movie but I don't think it's anyone's fault. There's no way I would have said, 'No thanks, I don't want to do it.' There's a lot of luck involved.

"I really don't know. I mean, when I did Election, from the time I read it I thought it was great, and it was the same at the read-throughs. But I've had that feeling before and the movie comes out and it didn't work at all."

Broderick is still boyish beneath the stubble and the flecks of grey in his hair. He has been almost 20 years in the movie business and has been on the stage even longer. The first Tony was for Brighton Beach Memoirs by Neil Simon, with whom he collaborated frequently. The second, more than 10 years later, was for his musical debut in the Broadway revival of How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying.

He has worked extensively with members of his own family: his first theatre appearance was with his father, James Broderick, who died in 1981 after spending most of his career on the stage; he acted in and directed his mother Patricia's script for Infinity, the biography of the Nobel Prize-winning physicist Richard Feynman; and Sarah Jessica Parker appeared in How to Succeed towards the end of its run.

Broderick and Parker married four years ago. "I imagine we will work together again, but we don't have any plans. It would need to be a genuine project. I'm not totally comfortable using a personal relationship. It bothers me. Sometimes I watch a real couple performing together and it's difficult to believe. I mean, a romantic comedy with my wife about a struggling actor and his director wife, and they live in New York, that would be very uncomfortable. It needs to be something foreign from our lives." Off the top of his head, he suggests they could be the competing leaders of two teams of dogs racing across the north pole.

For now, though, Broderick is committed to six months in The Producers, while Parker will be shooting the third season of Sex and the City. She is the show's executive producer, and has won a best actress Golden Globe for her role as Carrie, whose slender frame and cascading tresses are the definitive emblem of a show that has infiltrated contemporary life to a phenomenal extent.

"Television makes you very famous. It's very strange. I've never been around that before. It can be very isolating and worrying. Disguises? We always fight about that. I'm always, 'Put a hat on.' She says, 'It doesn't do any good.' I'm a big hider." Now, for instance, he is wearing a fetching red woolly number on his head but only, it turns out, because it's cold.

"I've been famous for almost more of my life than I haven't been. It's part of my nature, which is eerie. Luckily, I've never been crazy big, where people can't go out and need bodyguards. It's a complicated thing and I enjoy a lot of it. I could have any table in Chicago (where The Producers had its pre-Broadway run) and people wanted to buy me dinner all the time. No check. fields.headline: The IRA statement
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The leadership of Oglaigh na h-Eireann has received a detailed briefing of the intensive negotiations which have taken place over the last eight weeks. The British government's position shows that it is not prepared to uphold the commitments it made over the last number of years. This is totally unacceptable to the IRA. Despite this the leadership remains committed to the quest for a lasting peace in our country. This will only be achieved if everyone plays their part.
fields.body:
The leadership of Oglaigh na h-Eireann has received a detailed briefing of the intensive negotiations which have taken place over the last eight weeks. The British government's position shows that it is not prepared to uphold the commitments it made over the last number of years. This is totally unacceptable to the IRA. Despite this the leadership remains committed to the quest for a lasting peace in our country. This will only be achieved if everyone plays their part.

In recent years Oglaigh na h-Eireann has engaged in an unprecedented series of substantial and historic initiatives to enhance the peace process, including maintaining cessations over seven years, regular monitoring of arms dumps by international inspectors and a commitment to the creation of a future in which the causes of conflict are resolved by peaceful means.

As an earnest of our commitment, and despite the British government's position, the IRA leadership has decided to enter into further discussions with the IICD. This will be on the basis of the IRA leadership's commitment to resolving the issue as contained in our statement of May 6th 2000 and on no other basis. For this engagement to be successful, the British government must deliver on its obligations. It must return to and deliver on the agreement made with us on May 5th 2000. At that time the two governments in a joint letter and a joint statement set out commitments for the full implementation of the Good Friday Agreement by June 2001.

The British government publicly and privately committed itself to deal with a range of matters including human rights, equality, justice, demilitarisation and policing. The record shows that the IRA have honoured every commitment we have made including the opening of IRA arms dumps to inspections by the agreed International Inspectors, Cyril Ramaphosa and Maarti Ahtisaaroi.

We have done so despite the abuse of the peace process by those who persist with the aim of defeating the IRA and Irish republicanism and the obvious failure of the British government to honour its obligations.

The political responsibility for advancing the current situation rests with the two governments, especially the British government, and the leadership of the political parties.

webTitle: Bullied teacher wins £100,000 for stress caused by workload

fields.headline: Bullied teacher wins £100,000 for stress caused by workload
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: A teacher whose complaints about workload were dismissed by a "brusque, autocratic and bullying" head was yesterday awarded £100,000 in damages.
fields.body:
A teacher whose complaints about workload were dismissed by a "brusque, autocratic and bullying" head was yesterday awarded £100,000 in damages.

Alan Barber, 56, a former head of mathematics at East Bridgwater school in Somerset, retired in March 1997 on medical advice suffering from depression.

In a judgment at Exeter county court, Judge Michael Roach said evidence showed the former headteacher, Margaret Hayward, to have been "brusque, autocratic and bullying in her attitude to staff under her charge".

He ordered the defendant, Somerset county council, to pay damages plus costs and refused leave to appeal.

The council alleged Mr Barber manufactured his illness to win an attractive early retirement package. It was also claimed that a failed relationship might have triggered his depression. Mrs Hayward said Mr Barber was trying to make a bogus claim for early retirement. But the judge said he was "wholly unimpressed" with her claim.

Judge Roach said Mrs Hayward in court "took every opportunity to denigrate the claimant, even to the point of telling me that [Mr Barber] had taken to learning Spanish in 1995 as a forerunner to his eventual move to Spain."

In 1995 the school restructured its staff because of falling pupil numbers. Mr Barber, who had been head of mathematics for 11 years, applied successfully for the new post of "mathematical area of experience co-ordinator" in a smaller department. But he no longer had support from deputies and was, in effect, head of department. He was also made publicity and public relations manager.

Mr Barber developed symptoms of depression in 1995 and in May 1996 he was signed off work for depression brought on by his "unremitting" workload of between 61 and 70 hours a week.

The annual Ofsted inspection also brought extra pressure. Mr Barber's department was criticised by inspectors but the judge accepted Mr Barber's view that this did not trigger his depression.

He returned to work three weeks later and told Mrs Hayward he was not coping with his workload. But she responded by telling him that all staff were under stress. The judge said she should have investigated his problem. In November 1996 Mr Barber stopped work.

Doug McAvoy, general secretary of the National Union of Teachers, said: "If a teacher becomes ill they must be given support and help not treated in a high handed and autocratic manner."

webTitle: Lawyers must stick to trading laws

fields.headline: Lawyers must stick to trading laws
fields.trailText: Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, fired the first shot in a war with lawyers, accountants and architects, by announcing that the professions can no longer be excluded from competition laws.
fields.body:
Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, fired the first shot in a war with lawyers, accountants and architects, by announcing that the professions can no longer be excluded from competition laws.

Mr Byers told the Commons that the government would remove an exemption from the 1998 Competition Act that allows practices such as banning barristers from setting up joint businesses with accountants.

He said he was acting on recommendations set out by the director general of fair trading and would be considering other suggestions set out in a report.

Competition, Mr Byers stressed, was "essential to an efficient economy", boosting innovation, pushing down costs and ensuring a good deal for consumers.

The director general said he believed the exemption, under Schedule 4 of the act, "weak ened the incentive of the professions not to engage in anti-competitive activities".

The removal of the exemption will mean the professions can face the threat of financial penalties and actions for damages.

The report also attacked lawyers' QC system and the lord chancellor's role in it.

webTitle: Flu wonder drug users baffled by inhaler

fields.headline: Flu wonder drug users baffled by inhaler
fields.trailText: The anti-flu drug Relenza is not effective in the very people it is meant to help - the elderly - because they cannot operate the inhaler it comes with, according to research published today.
fields.body:
The anti-flu drug Relenza is not effective in the very people it is meant to help - the elderly - because they cannot operate the inhaler it comes with, according to research published today.

Millions of pounds could be wasted on NHS prescriptions for Relenza which have little effect because the drug is not being administered properly.

When it was launched amid much fanfare in 1999, Relenza was hailed as a certain blockbuster - the first drug to treat influenza effectively. While not a cure, it can reduce the duration of flu by one or two days and lessens the severity of symptoms.

Relenza is expected to cost the NHS £12m a year. The drug, made by GlaxoSmithKline, is inhaled into the lungs as a dry powder, using a device called a Diskhaler, twice a day.

But a study published in the British Medical Journal has found many elderly people cannot manipulate the inhaler.

Researchers tested the Diskhaler and a similar but simpler device called a Turbohaler on 73 patients, aged 71 to 99, in Croydon, south London.

In the first test, more than half (57%) of those using the Turbohaler achieved perfect scores and used the device properly, compared to only a quarter (26%) of those operating the Relenza Diskhaler. A day later, 47% of the Turbohaler users were still able to work their device perfectly, compared to only 13% of those allocated the Diskhaler.

fields.headline: Water war at Mid Kent
fields.standfirst: French keep watching brief on German move
fields.trailText: Water company Mid Kent could find itself at the centre of a takeover battle after a management buy-out team, backed by Germany's WestLB Panmure, launched a £106m offer yesterday.
fields.body:
Water company Mid Kent could find itself at the centre of a takeover battle after a management buy-out team, backed by Germany's WestLB Panmure, launched a £106m offer yesterday.

The bid, worth 605p in cash, is backed by several of Mid Kent's leading shareholders, including Prudential and Axa.

But French group Vivendi, with 23.8% of Mid Kent, has not yet decided how to respond. Analysts believe the company, which owns stakes in several small water businesses, may step in with its own higher offer. Last night Vivendi said "We are watching the situation."

Other water companies have also expressed interest in Mid Kent. Last month the company revealed it had received a number of approaches. Apart from the management offer, there were three other bids. One shareholder, believed to be the Pru, has said it would back any rival offer of more than 635p.

If the WestLB proposal goes ahead, it plans to provide £50m for capital expenditure to help Mid Kent improve its pipes and other infrastructure.

Under the terms of the deal, the German owned bank will hold a 50% stake in Mid Kent, chief executive Keith Tozzi and finance director Robert Atwood 10%, and the rest will go to other managers and employees.

The company has assets of £130m, which prompted some analysts to suggest the management's bid was on the low side, but Andrew Gardner of WestLB said: "There are also liabilities to take into account. It is not as if we are paying £106m for something worth £130m."

He pointed out that Mid Kent's independent directors were backing the bid, and that the offer was 20% higher than Mid Kent's share price the day before it announced the takeover approaches.

Mr Gardner said Mid Kent's 560,000 customers would see an improvement in their supplies, and hinted at cheaper bills in the next few years.

Further down the line, he said Mid Kent may well look at merging with other small water companies such as East Surrey or South East Water.

Last night Mid Kent's shares closed up 8p at 585p.

webTitle: Wall Street Journal catches a chill

fields.headline: Wall Street Journal catches a chill
fields.standfirst:
American media in difficulties

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: It is getting ugly over there. Even newspapers are issuing profits warnings. Earlier this week the New York Times said first-quarter results would fail to meet expectations. Then Knight Ridder said it would be cutting jobs at the San Jose Mercury News, a newspaper smack in the middle of dot.comland. Now, coming on top of a profits warning from the internet's number one brand, Yahoo!, the owner of the mighty Wall Street Journal, Dow Jones, has said its figures will disappoint and that it will be cutting its 8,550-strong workforce.
fields.body:
It is getting ugly over there. Even newspapers are issuing profits warnings. Earlier this week the New York Times said first-quarter results would fail to meet expectations. Then Knight Ridder said it would be cutting jobs at the San Jose Mercury News, a newspaper smack in the middle of dot.comland. Now, coming on top of a profits warning from the internet's number one brand, Yahoo!, the owner of the mighty Wall Street Journal, Dow Jones, has said its figures will disappoint and that it will be cutting its 8,550-strong workforce.

This is no ordinary "failure to meet the market's hyped-expectations". The last time Dow Jones laid off any employees for economic reasons was 1995. On the financial side, the company now expects to report earnings of less than half analysts' predictions and only a quarter of the earnings figure produced a year ago.

The reason is simple: advertising revenues have fallen off a cliff. The Journal has been hit on two fronts, with spending by the hi-tech industry and the financial sector drying up simultaneously. These two areas are reckoned to account for half the Journal's revenue. On top of this, while Dow Jones denies it, analysts suspect the Journal has been guilty of the same sins as Wall Street during the latter part of the current boom, allowing costs to balloon out of control.

Since, on this side of the Atlantic, the publishing/advertising boom has not proved as outlandish as in New York and Silicon Valley, we must assume that the downside here will not be so sheer. But given the speed of contraction in the US, there can be no hope that dynamic parts of the British economy, such as the City of London, will somehow avoid the fallout.

The relatively upbeat comments from Pearson, owner of the Financial Times, at the beginning of the week are beginning to seem very odd. Already in London investment banks are quietly laying off staff as the flow of flotations and other corporate transactions slows to a trickle. Without such business, the big, high spending banks have little to advertise.

Bankers bicker

The office of fair trading saw straight through Lloyds TSB's promise to "co-locate" 600 Abbey National branches two years after taking over the high street bank.

Publishing its reasoning behind its controversial decision to recommend the bid for a full-scale competition investigation, the OFT's analysis avoided such niceties - "in other words 600 branches would close" was its verdict.

While making it clear that its recommendation was based on competitive grounds (not compassionate ones about branch closures and job cuts), the OFT appears to place a great deal of importance on Abbey's network of 750 branches.

John Vickers, the new director-general of fair trading, seems persuaded that knocking out the bank with the sixth largest branch network could cause a "substantial lessening of competition" - not just in current accounts but also in the small-business banking market where close proximity of businesses to branches appears important.

More intriguingly, a paragraph removed from the analysis published yesterday - but printed on the online Quest analysis service run by stockbrokers Collins Stewart - showed that Lloyds offered the OFT concessions to try to get the bid cleared. These were turned down.

It is not unusual to bring out the olive branches during the competition process. But it will be interesting to see what new concessions Lloyds TSB can find in mid-June should the competition commission agree with the OFT analysis.

At this stage, it is difficult to see what else it can plead and promise, other than fierce competition at home and the need for bulk to get deals done in Europe - although Lloyds TSB will also be able to throw some of the OFT's own analysis back at the regulator. Why, for instance, did the putative BoS/Abbey merger, with its 27% slice of current accounts in Scotland, not raise competition concerns?

However the competition commission turns, its decision will arguably carve out the future shape of the banking industry in Britain for years to come. A decision to block the bid would stop any further large scale mergers or takeover involving the big British banks.

It might not, however, stop foreign players, particularly some of the Americans, wading in.

As the competition commission has a remit to consider the "public interest", a wide array of arguments will now be hurriedly prepared by bankers and their lawyers.

With luck, bank customers might even start to a get better deal as the players fight to prove they have their best interests at heart.

fields.headline: Jail show dislodges ITV news
fields.trailText: Television regulators were under fire yesterday for allowing ITV to screen News at Ten only twice a week later this month, and for entertaining a plan by Channel 5 to move its main news out of peak time.
fields.body:
Television regulators were under fire yesterday for allowing ITV to screen News at Ten only twice a week later this month, and for entertaining a plan by Channel 5 to move its main news out of peak time.

The weakness of ITV's News at Ten deal, reached with the independent television commission last year, was exposed when TV schedules were published: the bulletin, normally broadcast at 10pm three times a week, is to make way one night for a prison riot in Bad Girls.

At the same time, Channel 5 confirmed that it was lobbying to move its 6pm bulletin forward by half an hour.

ITV insisted it was not breaking its deal with the ITC, reached last October, when it was agreed that the late news would be usually be shown at 10pm on three nights a week. But the small print says the programme must start at 10pm on an average of three weeknights - ITV will have four bulletins at 10pm next week and two the week after.

Norman Baker, the Liberal Democrats' broadcasting spokesman, attacked the arrangement. "The News at Ten agreement which the ITC reached with ITV was a botched job, although it was better than nothing. But if it is being watered down, that's highly unsatisfactory."

He also attacked Channel 5's plans to move its main evening news bulletin. "There is a real question mark as to whether Channel 5 can be regarded as a public service broadcaster. Moving its news forward removes any fig leaf."

David Liddiment, director of programmes at ITV, said its evening news won high ratings even when it was screened later than 10pm.

ITV pointed out that on Wednesday night, its 10.15pm bulletin won just under 6m viewers - almost 2m more than the BBC's Ten O'Clock News.

The extra delay in the week beginning March 19 is to make way for the first episode of a new series of Bad Girls, which features a jail riot.

An ITC spokesman said: "Their plans to schedule the news on just two days a week would not present a problem because the deal was that they would only be expected to screen the news 'on average' three nights a week."

webTitle: Care home girls being exported as prostitutes

fields.headline: Care home girls being exported as prostitutes
fields.standfirst: Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: More than 40 girls, some as young as 14, have gone missing from care homes in the last five years and been transported to Italy to work as child prostitutes, police fear.
fields.byline: Jeevan Vasagar  and Philip Willan  in Rome
fields.body:
More than 40 girls, some as young as 14, have gone missing from care homes in the last five years and been transported to Italy to work as child prostitutes, police fear.

The teenagers had been flown into Gatwick from West African countries by human traffickers who use Britain as a transit point into Europe.

The girls' original documentation was destroyed by the traffickers, who told them to apply for political asylum on arrival, detectives believe.

They were told to claim they were from Sierra Leone, riven by civil war, and not from Nigeria, and also to lie about their age so they were taken into care homes.

Traffickers take samples of hair from the girls and warn them that these will be used to carry out voodoo punishments on them or their families if they disobey orders.

The girls have gone on to abscond from the care homes and are believed to have been transported to countries, including Italy and Holland, where they are told they will find work as hairdressers or shop assistants. Instead, they are forced into prostitution.

Britain is being used as a staging post because the Italian authorities have become alert to direct flights from West Africa.

However, travellers from other EU countries are subject to far less scrutiny.

Sources said one suspected trafficker, a Dutch national of Nigerian origin, was arrested at Dover with a girl from a West Sussex care home in his care last March, but the only charge that could be brought against him was for allegedly handling stolen credit cards.

Detective Sergeant Andy Cummins of Sussex police said: "The girls are afraid of the men and well drilled in their stories. There is a loophole in the legislation in that there is no specific offence of human trafficking. To prove kidnapping, you need to show the person has gone against their will."

Police first established a link with the Italian sex trade after one girl escaped and contacted West Sussex social services in December 1999. The girl, whose Roman Catholic beliefs meant she was not afraid of the voodoo threats, was interviewed by detectives but was unable to provide the information needed for a prosecution.

"She did not know who any of the men were. She did not know England and could not describe what route she had taken."

Police in Turin said yester day they had found Nigerian prostitutes carrying British passports, but were not aware of any girls who had absconded from Britain.

Charity workers say that around 40% of Italy's prostitutes come from Nigeria and there are 2,500 West African prostitutes working on the streets of Turin every day.

"Turin is the Italian capital of Nigerian prostitution," said Mirta Da Pra, the head of a project on prostitution and human smuggling run by the charitable organisation Gruppo Abele.

Nigerian women began arriving in Italy to work as prostitutes in 1988 and today share the market with women from eastern Europe. Their increasing dominance of the market followed the withdrawal of many Italian women in the wake of Aids.

Ms Da Pra said: "They come here to escape from a disastrous social and economic situation in Nigeria, where women have a very low status - they are not even allowed to have their own money - and no prospects."

The prostitution rings are run by Nigerian madams, often ex-prostitutes themselves, who will buy women for between £5,000 and £7,000 from the "sponsor" who facilitated the girls' entry to Italy.

Men play a minor role in the organisation, acting as drivers, collecting money and occasionally imposing discipline through physical force.

"Almost everything is run by the women," Ms Da Pra said. "They are quite fearsome and perfectly capable of administering a beating."

West Sussex social services have now stepped up security around girls arriving from West Africa.

fields.headline: Snatched children well, says mother
fields.trailText: A young mother who went on the run after snatching her three children from a foster home yesterday contacted social services to say they were safe and well.
fields.body:
A young mother who went on the run after snatching her three children from a foster home yesterday contacted social services to say they were safe and well.

Sarah Barnes, 22, abducted her sleeping daughters and baby son from a house in Thurrock, in Essex, after barging in at 2.30am on Wednesday with another woman and threatening to attack the foster parents if they refused to hand the children over.

A nationwide hunt was immediately launched for Barnes and the children's Turkish father, Murat Budancamanak, by Essex police.

The children were taken into care last December because social workers feared they were "at risk of violence".

Barnes yesterday phoned Thurrock council to reassure staff that Clare, three, Yasmin, two and Murad, five months, were in no danger. A spokeswoman said: "We could hear them in the background. She wouldn't tell us where she was."

Describing the abduction, an Essex police spokesman said the two women burst in when the foster parents answered the door. "They were making all sorts of threats and then wrapped the children in duvets and ran out."

Yesterday, Thurrock council, which has an interim care order for the children, was granted another by a judge at Chelmsford county court demanding that the children be returned. Judge Caroline Ludlow lifted restrictions on publicity in the hope that media coverage would help trace them.

webTitle: Channel 5 lines up Jerry Springer for game show with £1m prize

fields.headline: Channel 5 lines up Jerry Springer for game show with £1m prize
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Express takeover
fields.trailText: Jerry Springer is being lined up to present Britain's second £1m game show, in a deal that will boost his appearances on British TV.
fields.body:
Jerry Springer is being lined up to present Britain's second £1m game show, in a deal that will boost his appearances on British TV.

Channel 5 said that the team-based series, Greed, would feature the best aspects of The Weakest Link and Who Wants to be a Millionaire?

It features groups of five contestants who must work to gether to boost their prize - but individuals are eliminated in a endgame round and may leave with nothing.

Greed boasts the largest prize ever offered by Channel 5. Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? has given away £1m only once since it launched on ITV in 1998.

Channel 5 executives hope Greed will succeed where other shows have failed, and boost the station's ratings performance. Two recent game shows, Jailbreak and The Mole, were heavily promoted but never gained widespread popularity or acclaim. If nothing else, Greed is a blatant attempt to gain the sort of notoriety gained by last year's Naked Jungle, in which presenter Keith Chegwin and contestants appeared nude.

It is also another attempt by Springer to gain a foothold in the British TV industry - his previous efforts have met with mixed success. A British-made chat show, along the lines of the US programmes fronted by David Letterman and Jay Leno, was dropped by ITV but later taken up by Channel 5.

In Greed, groups of contestants are pitted against each other. In each group, a leader is chosen by the speed and accuracy of the answer to the first question. In subsequent questions, the leader must decide whether the group pockets the amassed cash, or gambles it on the next question.

As the money increases, the questions get more complex. Group members cannot confer, and a wrong answer could mean leaving with nothing. "The rewards are high, but the risks are great," Channel 5 said.

A £1m prize will be available for each of the 11 hour-long shows when it launches in the spring.

Channel 5's controller of entertainment, Alan Nixon, said: "This is a really exciting show and underlines our commitment to maintaining and strengthening a diverse and innovative entertainment output." Greed, made by Pearson Television, has been sold to 20 countries in the past year.

 Comic Relief yesterday announced the six celebrities who will be thrown together for a charity version of Big Brother.

Anthea Turner, Vanessa Feltz and Boyzone star Keith Duffy will join Claire Sweeney, who plays Brookside's Lindsey Corkhill, comedian Jack Dee, and former boxing champion Chris Eubank.

Contestants enter the house today for the week-long fundraiser, with the first eviction tomorrow. The housemates receive no fees and money raised from the public voting lines will go to Comic Relief, as will the fee which TV company Endemol would have been given for use of the format.

fields.headline: Royal Ballet founder dies at 102
fields.standfirst: Tributes for Dame Ninette de Valois, regarded as one of the most influential figures in dance in the 20th century
fields.trailText: Tributes for Dame Ninette de Valois, regarded as one of the most influential figures in dance in the 20th century.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
Dame Ninette de Valois, the founder of the Royal Ballet, who is credited as one of the greatest influences in the development of classical dance in the UK, died yesterday at the age of 102.

Sir Anthony Dowell, director of the Royal Ballet, said: "It is hard to imagine a future without Madam."

Madam, her enduring nickname - though the brave called her the Hockey Mistress - was the clue to the ferocity of the tiny woman towards fools, time wasters, and anyone less demanding of perfection in her companies, which included Birmingham Royal Ballet and the Royal Ballet School.

Sir Anthony, who retires this year, was 11 when he met her, on joining the Royal Ballet School. Yesterday, after her death at her home in Barnes, south west London, he said she had been "central to my life".

David Bintley, director of the Birmingham Royal Ballet, said: "Aside from Sergei Diaghilev, I would say she was the most influential figure in dance in the 20th century, not just in Britain but around the world. What people forget about her now is that she was such a modern person: she was a passionate believer in innovation, in using modern music and design, in attaining classical excellence only to build on that to create a British school of dance."

Ian Albery, chief executive of Sadler's Wells, where her first company was based, said she was the founder of British ballet and her death meant the end of an era. "She loved the Wells as her spiritual home. She will be missed by us all."

Dame Ninette's grand adopted title entirely concealed her origins: she was born Edris Stannus, in Wicklow, Ireland, in 1898, child of an army officer and a glass worker. The family moved to England, and within a few years she was on the stage, as one of Lila Field's Wonder Children. She danced Anna Pavlova's Dying Swan, as she recalled, "dying twice nightly on all the coastal piers for my 'death' was always ferociously encored".

In 1923 she made her debut with Diaghilev's troupe in Monte Carlo, and although she could then have gone anywhere in the world, she came back to England, to start a ballet academy. She worked with Lilian Baylis at the Old Vic, and then founded a small ballet company based at Sadler's Wells.

Out of that eventually evolved giants on the international cultural stage, the Royal Ballet, at Covent Garden Opera House, Birmingham Royal Ballet, and the Royal Ballet School.

She was made Dame Commander of the Order of the British Empire in 1951, Companion of Honour in 1981, and in 1992 she was appointed to the Order of Merit, to which only 24 people may belong at one time.

David Bintley was 18, also at the Royal Ballet School, when they first met. He had to count on his fingers yesterday to work out, with astonishment, that she must already have been an old woman of 79.

"She could be absolutely terrifying and I count it as one of the blessings of my life that I never saw that side of her. She took an early shine to me which never wore off. The dragon manner was business. Outside of that she was the most witty, delightful, intelligent and informed of companions."

She had been frail for many years, and became so much weaker three years ago that it was feared she would not reach her centenary. She outlived a parade of brilliant figures who she had discovered and nurtured when they were young and she was already elderly, including Margot Fonteyn.  The ashes of Russian ballerina Anna Pavlova, who died 70 years ago, will not be returned to her homeland, it has emerged. Trustees at the London Cremation Company, which keeps the urn at Golders Green, north London, were told yesterday that Moscow's mayor, Yury Luzhkov, had cancelled the project.

In 1923 she made her debut with Diaghilev's troupe in Monte Carlo, and although she could then have gone anywhere in the world, she came back to England, to start a ballet academy. She worked with Lilian Baylis at the Old Vic, and then founded a small ballet company based at Sadler's Wells. Out of that eventually evolved giants on the international cultural stage, the Royal Ballet, at Covent Garden Opera House, Birmingham Royal Ballet, and the Royal Ballet School. She was made Dame Commander of the Order of the British Empire in 1951, Companion of Honour in 1981, and in 1992 she was appointed to the Order of Merit, to which only 24 people may belong at one time. David Bintley was 18, also at the Royal Ballet School, when they first met. He had to count on his fingers yesterday to work out, with astonishment, that she must already have been an old woman of 79. "She could be absolutely terrifying and I count it as one of the blessings of my life that I never saw that side of her. She took an early shine to me which never wore off. The dragon manner was business. Outside of that she was the most witty, delightful, intelligent and informed of companions." She had been frail for many years, and became so much weaker three years ago that it was feared she would not reach her centenary. She outlived a parade of brilliant figures who she had discovered and nurtured when they were young and she was already elderly, including Margot Fonteyn.  The ashes of Russian ballerina Anna Pavlova, who died 70 years ago, will not be returned to her homeland, it has emerged. Trustees at the London Cremation Company, which keeps the urn at Golders Green, north London, were told yesterday that Moscow's mayor, Yury Luzhkov, had cancelled the project.

fields.headline: Affluence clue to breast cancer
fields.trailText: Eating less and exercising more may protect women from breast cancer, according to research published today.
fields.body:
Eating less and exercising more may protect women from breast cancer, according to research published today.

The study, in this week's British Medical Journal, focuses on the lower levels of breast cancer in the developing world than in affluent countries where food for most is unlimited.

Grazyna Jasienska, assistant professor at the institute of public health at Jagiellonian University in Krakow, Poland, believes there is a link between low food intake and lower levels of the ovarian hormones, oestrogen and progesterone, which are crucial in the development of breast cancer.

She looked at data on the hormone levels of women in Bolivia, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Nepal, Poland and the United States which had been ascertained by saliva samples.

She found that higher concentrations of ovarian progesterone were strongly associated with a higher incidence of breast cancer, from Congo at the bottom of the league to Nepal, Bolivia, Poland and the United States with the highest risk.

She points out that food intake can influence women's reproductive systems - too little food can cause women to stop ovulating. But when women regularly eat a lot, they ovulate more regularly and have high hormone concentrations. She believes women can lower their risk by eating less and taking more exercise.

Cancer charities were cautious over the findings. Tim Key of the Imperial Cancer Research Fund, said: "Obesity increases breast cancer risk among women after the menopause and even moderate levels of physical activity can reduce breast cancer risk.

"However, the strength of the association may not be as great as the authors suggest because other factors probably explain some of the low breast cancer risk in poor countries".

Jackie Graveney of Breakthrough Breast Cancer, said: "The report shows an interesting correlation but also highlights the need for large and high powered clinical trials"
