fields.headline: Woman hit rape victim
fields.trailText: An 18-year-old woman accused of encouraging a gang rape yesterday admitted punching the victim in the face, but told Blackfriars crown court in central London that she would have stopped the attack had she been present.
fields.body:
An 18-year-old woman accused of encouraging a gang rape yesterday admitted punching the victim in the face, but told Blackfriars crown court in central London that she would have stopped the attack had she been present.

Claire Marsh and two youths aged 15 and 16, who cannot be named for legal reasons, have been charged with rape on the grounds that they were party to the assault on the 37-year-old woman although they did not actually have intercourse with her. They deny the charges.

The victim was attacked by the Grand Union canal at Ladbroke Grove, west London, in July 22 last year. Marvin Edwards, 18, and a 15-year-old who cannot be named have admitted rape and will be sentenced later.

Earlier, the victim said she had been pushed into the canal and was punched in the face by Marsh as she crawled out. She said the gang ripped her clothes off and pinned her down while she was raped by two youths. She also said a girl, believed to be Marsh, encouraged her attackers.

Yesterday Marsh insisted she had left the group by the time of the attack. "If I was [there] I would have stopped it because I don't approve of that sort of thing," she said.

She said the woman had appeared to be drunk or on drugs when she approached the group and asked for cannabis. There was a "laughing, joking atmosphere". Marsh searched her pockets.

Asked by Judge Timothy Pontius what she would have done had she found cash or valuables, she replied: "I would have thought about taking it, but I wouldn't have done it because it wouldn't be right."

Marsh, now a bingo caller but was unemployed at the time, said the woman had "held her arms out like a crucifix" and jumped backwards into the canal. When she climbed out she seemed aggressive and lunged forward. "The way I took she was coming towards me to hit me. I actually hit her in the face ... Basically I was defending myself."

The woman fell over and Marsh held her down and asked her what she was playing at. But she said she released her when another member of the group kicked the woman's head. She had then gone to visit a friend.

The case was adjourned until Monday.

webTitle: Radio review: Square pegs in a round hole.

fields.headline: Radio review
fields.standfirst: Square pegs in a round hole
fields.trailText: Thining Allowed | The Archers | It'll Never Last
fields.body:
Laurie Taylor didn't mince his words on Thinking Allowed (Radio 4). "I don't like seeing them wandering around - their clothes, their demeanour, the way they walk even", he fizzed, mentioning his credentials as a social scientist in case we thought he was being flagrantly intolerant. He was, actually, but given his target - golfers - who was going to mind?

Only Will Hutton minded. Despite damning statistics from a Golf Monthly survey (two-thirds of 180 golf clubs surveyed operate a two-tier set of rules based on gender), Hutton extolled "the beauty of the game", its inherent democracy. "Hitting a golf ball straight, true and high is one of the most satisfactory feelings I know", he thrilled.

He didn't stand a chance, what with the silly outfits golfers have to wear, the racism and sexism of the top clubs, and the fact that Taylor was clutching a copy of something called The Global Anti-Golf Manifesto. Hutton gave it his best shot, though, and we know how that pleases him, talking of the need for Etty Kett, as he slowly pronounced it, making him sound like a Yorkshire sub-postmistress.

You get this sort of ding-dong between passionate advocates of television or radio who can't see the allure of the other. This week, though, even the most impartial judge would have to recognise radio's triumph over television (which brought us - Crossroads, again).

Best of all has been The Archers (Radio 4) and its daily reflection of the unfolding foot and mouth crisis, sensitively and quite thrillingly handled. The feeling we get from news bulletins, of a crisis closing in around rural communities, has been weaving into the Ambridge drama just as stealthily. When no television soap even pretends to reflect day-to-day reality, this is to be cherished.

But there were other delights. Alan Whicker presented the second part of It'll Never Last (Radio 2), radio's history of television. Imagine this the other way round - television would give radio only a queasy nostalgia-fest, a Top Ten of Nicey and Smashies. Radio's history of television is a comprehensive seven-hour tribute, decade by decade, linked by Whicker's voice, all gruff like a wily old terrier.

We reached the 50s this week, a period in the history of terrestrial television like the 90s was for satellite and digital. In the 50s, Andy Pandy was a "pioneer", the BBC wouldn't show newsreaders' faces for fear of a cult of personality, and there was an early evening television-free hour, Toddlers' Time, for putting children to bed. It didn't last, of course, that innovative, sweet, golden age of telly, but it's good to have it properly remembered.

webTitle: TV review: Easy as falling off a bike.

fields.headline: Easy as falling off a bike
fields.trailText: As If | Trouble at the Top | Horizon: Children Beyond Control
fields.body:
'Pssst. Take a butcher's at this. Just starting on E4..." is something loads better than the rubbish you're watching at the moment. This is the implication of that faintly gay Irish continuity voice, cooing the not-so-soft sell just before the 49th repeat of Friends on terrestrial.

In order to show you what you're missing in the digital wonderland just yonder, E4's Dawson's Oaks/ Holly Creek cross-breed, As If , has parachuted back onto C4 - to clarify whether young people with pierced tongues and henna tattoos look any different through a digital signal.

Here's the plot: Jamie fancies Nicki, who's going out with Toby; Suzie (token face-metal interest) fancies Jamie, but also fancies Rob, who's going out with Sasha. But the thing about Rob 'n' Sasha, right, is they haven't even done IT yet. No jiggy-jiggy at all (that's penetrative sex, in case you're not familiar with the canon of Craig David).

Jamie is the central character, ie the one allowed to have Dream On-style monologues, and proves, amazingly, even more annoying than the hitherto most repulsive teenager on TV - Screech from Saved By The Bell.

Saved By The Bell is the Platonic ideal to which all teen-drama aspires: plastic, American, deeply shallow, impossibly stupid. In other words, a show with all the basic ingredients for a fine half hour of teen entertainment.

As If scores low in comparison, not least because of some decent acting from Jamie, played by Paul Cheques, who manages to combine all the cool of the Juicy Fruit advert with a touch of the Norman Wisdoms. Mugging for England, I kept half-expecting Jamie to drop the T4 cool-speak ("straight-up, yeah, whatever, innit?") and mount a postbox, shouting "Mr Grimsdale!" from the top of his little unbroken voice.

On BBC2, meanwhile, Gerry Cottle was worried about noodle burns on the carpet. The Chinese circus was coming to town and, predictably, there was going to be Trouble At The Top .

The Chinese hold the world record for balancing girls on a bicycle. It's 16, and not a lot of people know that. In order to break the record, the Chinese circus flew in from Beijing to stay in a grotty caravan near Gerry Cottle's house. After a disastrous opening night at the circus, a post-mortem at Gerry's gaff revealed the problem. Thing is, "we just love entertaining people", said one of Gerry's crew, holding a cheese sandwich. Unfortunately, there were only eight people to entertain that night, and four were looking the wrong way. Just as well really, as the Chinese kept falling off their bikes.

Gerry roped in PR guru Mark Borkowski to drum up business. Mark suggested getting the girls to cycle in formation onto a motorway. Gerry - also eating a sandwich (this one made with that disgusting Clover stuff) opted for some basic photo-op manoeuvres around a wet Trafalgar Square. The Chinese, increasingly nervy, kept falling off their bikes.

Trouble At The Top provided the most poignant portrait of a circus down the pan since Gary Glitter's ill-fated tour of windswept seaside resorts in the early 80s was caught by the BBC for posterity. Watching 16 girls repeatedly falling off their bike reminded me of watching Glitter repeatedly failing to be fired from a canon - a low-point for Gazza, surpassed only by getting caught downloading pictures of little boys.

Horizon: Children Beyond Control (BBC2) appeared to be the work of Chris Morris, as most documentaries appear to be these days. After laughing long and hard at this for about 15 minutes, slowly the mirth began to recede.

Children are getting increasingly violent, apparently, and someone called Doctor Federici has the answer. Parents, he says, need to take control. Namely, by grabbing their offspring firmly in an arm lock and sitting on them until their personalities have been wiped into the shag-pile.

Federici's bonkers theory is that dysfunctional children need to be broken down, a bit like recruits to the SAS. The bewildered faces of kids and parents, twisted on the carpet in combat, suggested that the only beneficiary was the deeply deranged Federici.

Horizon was a sad indication of how estranged many parents now feel from their kids. If they want some respite from the domestic war, I find a session with Postman Pat works wonders.

fields.headline: Radio pick of the day
fields.trailText: The Island Of The Day Before Yesterday | Vital Statistics | Johnny Mathis
fields.body:
Mike Walker's play The Island Of The Day Before Yesterday (2.15pm, Radio 4) offers a nicely sardonic picture of literary scheming. Simone Strachey has always been eclipsed by his war hero father and film star mother. Now, as professor of semiotics at one of Italy's dimmer universities, his ambition is to rival Umberto Eco. When his father dies, Simone hires an ex-librarian to catalogue the family papers, and is offered the chance of some semiotic skulduggery.

On March 10 1801 Britain counted its entire population for the first time. With the approach of next month's census, Vital Statistics (3.45pm, Radio 4) looks back at that original survey. Clergymen and Overseers of the Poor were assigned to carry out the count, but most of their returns were later destroyed. Beyond discovering that the nation had 11 million mainly rural-dwelling inhabitants, we are left with few other findings.

David Jacobs continues his series on singing stars with six programmes about Johnny Mathis (7.0pm, Radio 2). His father, who had had his own musical career in Texas, encouraged young Johnny to develop his talent at school concerts and church choirs. Mathis's voice coach Connie Cox remained a major influence long after her pupil had hit the big time. Mathis recalls how she used to send him detailed comments "as thick as the Old Testament" analysing each new album he released.

webTitle: Satellite, cable and digital pick of the day.

fields.headline: Satellite, cable and digital pick of the day
fields.trailText: Ocean's 11 | The Red Shoes | Singles | In Dreams | Caligula | Live Athletics
fields.body:
Films

Ocean's 11 (Lewis Milestone, 1960) 9.50am, 4pm, Sky Cinema
More evidence of Frank Sinatra's mob connections: he looks a little too natural as crooked Danny Ocean, who assembles a top team of former commando buddies for a New Year's Eve raid on five Las Vegas casinos. Rat-pack cronies Dean Martin, Sammy Davis Jr and Peter Lawford are in the back-slapping, self-indulgent gang, with appearances by Angie Dickinson, Shirley MacLaine, and - the FBI will love this - George Raft. The heist is superbly handled, and some of the shady men-in-black-suits style filtered through to Reservoir Dogs.

The Red Shoes (Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger, 1948) 4.45pm, Carlton Cinema
Moira Shearer as a ballet student driven to suicide by the conflicting demands of her art (personified by Anton Walbrook's autocratic impresario) and love for composer-husband Marius Goring. It's a stunningly beautiful study of the world of ballet, with mesmerising dances and extraordinary, Oscar-winning designs.

Singles (Cameron Crowe, 1992) 9.45pm, Sky Cinema
Another perceptive view of the emotional rollercoaster that is dating from the director of the clever teeny romance, Say Anything. Singles observes chapters in the lives of a group of twenty-somethings living in a Seattle apartment block. It's engagingly played by an ensemble cast including Campbell Scott, Kyra Sedgwick and Bill Pullman, but Bridget Fonda stands out as Janet, who is a little slow to realise that a relationship with a grunge band lead singer (Matt Dillon) is doomed to failure.

In Dreams (Neil Jordan, 1999) 10pm, Sky Premier
Jordan conjures nightmarish imagery reminiscent of his earlier fable Company Of Wolves in this otherwise disappointing thriller about a serial killer lurking in New England. Robert Downey Jr is way over the top as the killer, and looks all the worse pitted against the excellent Annette Bening as the clairvoyant illustrator of children's books who develops a creepy psychological hotline into his disturbed mind.

Caligula (Tinto Brass, 1979) 12.45am, FilmFour
This version of Tinto Brass's infamous view of ancient Rome in flagrante has been snipped to remove much of producer and Penthouse boss Bob Guccione's tacky pornographic additions. What's left is still no classic. Malcolm McDowell as the mad emperor Caligula, Peter O'Toole as Tiberius, Helen Mirren the rampant Caesonia and John Gielgud a noble old senator: all washed their hands of it.
Paul Howlett

Sports

Live Athletics 10am, 1pm, 3.45pm & 6.45pm, British Eurosport
The first day of the World Indoor Championship from Lisbon. There has been some controversy over the format of the event, with Jonathan Edwards complaining that the field events have been neglected in favour of the track. His participation will be all over by lunchtime, with the final of the triple jump one of the first events scheduled.
Simon Burnton

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Thursday date for Selby line
fields.body:
Thursday date for Selby line

Railtrack hopes the line closed by the Selby rail crash in which 10 people died can reopen next Thursday. Emergency services completed their work at Great Heck yesterday, with the removal of the last vehicles and a final search of the site. Engineers estimate it will take a week to restore the track, overhead line and signalling equipment.

L-plate attached to bomb taxi

An L-plate was attached to the taxi which exploded outside BBC TV Centre, west London, last Saturday, anti-terrorist officers said yesterday.

1066 and Battle of Waterloo

Sixty per cent of seven to 16-year-olds were not sure what happened in 1066 with 18% thinking it was the Battle of Waterloo, not the Norman invasion of England, according to a poll for Abbey National. Forty four per cent thought USA stood for Union States of America.

'No baby, no fee' delight for pair

A couple from Penarth near Cardiff have had the first baby under a "no baby, no fee" scheme. Julia and Roy Shelton who paid £10,000 to a reproduction centre in Exeter, Devon, say six-week-old Phoebe was "everything we have ever hoped for."

Drink-drive test of brandy cake

Brigend magistrates yesterday set out to prove the proof of the pudding is in the eating. Andrew Rees, 50, a former policeman of Llampha, South Wales, claimed a cake made with brandy tipped him over the drink-drive limit. Another cake is to be baked with an identical recipe and analysed by forensic scientists.

webTitle: Country Diary: Pine martens on the up.

fields.headline: Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Pine martens on the up
fields.trailText: Pine martens on the up
fields.body:
Tetbury

Beside the monitor on the desk I am looking at an unusual colour photograph, sent to me by a reader living in the Western Highlands, not far from Fort William. It captures a scene, caught from her kitchen window, of a pine marten enjoying the food scraps that she regularly puts out. The large chunk of bread in its mouth stands out against the creature's lustrous chocolate brown fur. These food scraps are clearly appreciated by the pine martens, judging by the increase in the visitor population during the 24 years that she has lived in her home.

Although it is a native mammal, I have yet to see a marten. Rigorous gamekeeping in the late 19th and early 20th centuries reduced numbers to residual populations in remote corners of these islands. So, come the spring and a visit to family in Glasgow, where we may celebrate both the birth of an eighth grandchild and the promotion of Partick Thistle, I hope to go further north and visit Elizabeth's back garden.

A few years ago I spent a cold winter's evening hoping to see the martens on the Crom Estate in County Fermanagh. Even a log baited with raspberry jam failed to tempt them out. I have written here before of the People's Trust for Endangered Species and its proposal to reintroduce pine martens into selected woodlands in southern England. Despite a long period during which they have not been persecuted by gamekeepers, populations have not recovered, and the relict populations south of the Scottish border are essentially located in the Lake District, rural Wales, and Northumberland, where the conditions of minimal disturbance and distance from traffic that they require are replicated.

fields.headline: Child heart tragedy fears
fields.trailText: A tragedy like that at the Bristol royal infirmary could happen again because there is still no satisfactory national record of the children who survive and those who die during and after heart surgery in Britain, a leading child heart specialist said yesterday.
fields.body:
A tragedy like that at the Bristol royal infirmary could happen again because there is still no satisfactory national record of the children who survive and those who die during and after heart surgery in Britain, a leading child heart specialist said yesterday.

The warning came from Stewart Hunter, consultant in paediatric cardiology at Freeman hospital, Newcastle upon Tyne, on the publication of a review he carried out with two others into heart surgery in Magdi Yacoub's famous unit at Harefield hospital.

Dr Hunter, together with statistician David Spiegelhalter and heart surgeon Leslie Hamilton, were asked to review the death rates at Harefield following allegations during the Bristol public in quiry that they were too high. Their report reveals that between 1984 and 1999 there were occasions when the mortality rate in what was "a small unit, chronically understaffed and underfunded" rose above average, but that Professor Yacoub and colleagues quickly identified the reason and improved their methods.

They describe Harefield as under pressure and yet taking some of the most difficult child heart cases because of Prof Yacoub's skill and refusal to turn anyone away. Yet Prof Yacoub and colleagues soon noticed if there was a problem. One rise in death rates occurred when two junior surgeons started carrying out a particular heart operation, so it was decided Prof Yacoub alone should do it.

It is a very different picture from the scenario at Bristol, where surgeons James Wisheart and Janardan Dhasmana failed to recognise that they were not performing as well as surgeons in other hospitals - even when other doctors raised it with them - and that too many of the babies in their care were dying. Both were disciplined by the General Medical Council.

Even now, six years after the Bristol scandal broke, there is no comprehensive and accurate database for surgeons to compare their results with the averages in the country. Prof Yacoub's unit recognised the occasional rise in death rates and took action to bring them down, but doctors in larger units where a rise in mortality might not be so obvious might fail to realise that too many children are dying.

"Producing this review actually proved to be an extremely difficult exercise because the two currently available national sources on clinical out comes - the Hospital Episode Statistics and the Cardiac Surgical Register - were found to be inadequate in providing accurate, verified comparative data which was understandable and usable."

He added: "This represents a serious gap in the system and means that the public might not be properly safeguarded against a repeat of a similar situation to that which arose at the Bristol royal infirmary."

Dr Hunter said he wanted to see the Department of Health invest some of the money being "lavishly" promised for the NHS into a reliable system of national and local record-keeping.

Mark Taylor, chief executive of the Royal Brompton and Harefield NHS trust, said it was "pleased to see that the evidence which suggested Harefield was a poor centre for paediatric cardiac surgery has not been borne out".

fields.headline: Pass notes No 1835
fields.standfirst: Bosco
fields.trailText: Bosco
fields.body:
The latest addition to the Blue Peter team, following in the hallowed pawprints of Goldie the dog and George the tortoise? Do tortoises have paws, by the way? I think they're more stumps than paws. Anyway, we're talking about Bosco, the police dog.

Don't tell me, wonderdog Bosco has rescued a flaxen-haired child from an old mine shaft? No, he has bitten 54 people in four years.

Are you sure they weren't just playful nips? I think they probably required stitches.

Perhaps he just got overexcited? Yes, but it's hardly in the line of duty is it? I mean it's rather like a St Bernard saying: "Sod this rescue lark, I'll just drink the brandy."

Still, 54 people, that's quite an achievement. One of Bosco's many achievements. In fact, he recently won four awards at the Cleveland police dog awards, taking rosettes in the obedience, criminal chase, searching and overall champion categories.

So the people of Middlesbrough must really think he's the dog's . . . My mother is reading this.

I mean, the cat's whiskers. Well, not exactly. Particularly not one Lawrence Agar, who successfully sued for assault, false imprisonment and malicious prosecution.

That's quite impressive for one dog. I don't think Bosco was responsible for the false imprisonment and malicious prosecution bits. Just the frenzied, biting assault.

Mr Agar isn't by any chance a postman, is he? No, he's a 36-year-old telephone engineer.

I see. Just what is it about these fellows in the communications industry that makes them so damned . . . biteable? Perhaps it's the promise of irresistible, bite-sized, meaty chunks encased in marrowbone jelly and enveloped in a tasty blue serge uniform.

Or perhaps he was just following a lead. Oh, please.

I can't help my biting wit. Try. Still, let's just hope Bosco's bite is worse than his bark.

webTitle: Coniston sees Bluebird again after 34 years

fields.headline: Coniston sees Bluebird again after 34 years
fields.standfirst: Divers raise wreckage of speedboat in which Donald Campbell died attempting to break world water speed record
fields.trailText: Divers raise wreckage of speedboat in which Donald Campbell died attempting to break world water speed record.
fields.body:
A silt-covered union flag broke the surface of Coniston Water yesterday, ending the speedboat Bluebird's 34 years under the lake.

At 6am, assisted by divers and buoys, the wrecked boat emerged tailfin first from the lake bed, three decades after it crashed, killing the adventurer Donald Campbell and disappearing into the sand.

Campbell's widow, Tonia Bern-Campbell, and 50 villagers watched as the boat's rear emerged intact. The cockpit, where Campbell had sat when he tried to break the world water speed record in 1967, was completely crushed. Campbell's body was never found and yesterday's wreckage betrayed no trace of his remains.

From 5am 16 divers worked to bring the boat to the surface of the 150ft deep lake in Cumbria. Using buoys and hydraulic lifts, they raised the 30ft aluminium craft while silt dripped away to reveal its preserved paintwork.

Bill Smith, the diving team leader, stood on a side wing of the boat as it was slowly towed to shore. He said: "I think the realisation has yet to dawn. It is beautiful and it is gruesome all at the same time."

Mr Smith said Campbell's widow was "understandably upset". She left the shore and took shelter in a boathouse.

Tony Robinson, who, at 22, was the lake marshal with the grim task of fruitlessly searching for Campbell's body, said the impact of the crash looked worse than he had imagined. He said watching Campbell die had been like a blank. "This morning it all came back again, all those emotions."

Campbell, 45, an insatiable risk-taker who already held world land and water speed records, had attempted to break his water speed record on Coniston Water in the jet-powered Bluebird. His aim, he said, was to prove that "the British, when they make their minds up, can jolly well overcome all obstacles". Campbell took Bluebird up to 297mph but needed to make a return run to meet the 300mph record. As the craft reached its speed it somersaulted and crashed, killing him instantly.

The wreckage was first found by navy divers days after the crash, but Campbell's body was never recovered and attempts to locate the boat again failed. Late last year a team of divers found the wreckage during the filming of a BBC documentary.

Campbell's widow disapproved of bringing Bluebird to the surface, saying it would be like disturbing a grave. But his family eventually agreed to the salvage, fearing publication of the boat's location on the lake-bed would lead amateurs to disturb it. Villagers estimated that 10-12 divers came to the lake every day searching for Bluebird's remains.

The BBC's plans to broadcast the salvage live this Sunday were abandoned after the Ministry of Agriculture feared crowds at the lake could spread foot and mouth disease. But yesterday, beside the themed bars devoted to Campbell, villagers turned out in force and there was muted clapping as the craft emerged.

David Watt, 67, who has lived in Coniston all his life and followed Campbell's trips out on the lake, said: "It is very, very sad. It seems so tragic, so tragic. It is very emotional.

"It was a magical time to watch Bluebird and to hear the roar of the engine echoing around the hills."

Hazel Nicholson, whose husband shot the black and white film footage of the Bluebird crash, said the mood at the salvage was sombre. "Donald Campbell was hugely popular in the village. I wasn't sure whether or not to come today and I have mixed feelings. It is all very sad."

Vicky Stowe, curator of Coniston's Ruskin Museum, which houses a Campbell exhibition, said people in Coniston opposed Bluebird's recovery.

"Some felt it was a grave and should be left sacrosanct. A lot of people knew the whereabouts of Bluebird all the time but they protected it in accordance with what we understood to be the family's wishes. But they have reluctantly come to the conclusion that it had to be raised, or unscrupulous divers could have plundered it."

She said the Coniston museum hoped to display the boat and would seek lottery funding for an extension to house it.

"The feeling is that Coniston has protected Bluebird all these years and would like to continue protecting it and the Campbell legend."

fields.headline: Double discount for petrol buyers
fields.standfirst: Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: Motorists could get a double discount from Wednesday's Budget, with duty on some types of petrol falling by as much as 5p a litre, petrol retailers said yesterday.
fields.body:
Motorists could get a double discount from Wednesday's Budget, with duty on some types of petrol falling by as much as 5p a litre, petrol retailers said yesterday.

The chancellor, Gordon Brown, cut duty on most types of petrol by 2p a litre as part of a package of measures announced last November to appease fuel protesters.

Savings on some kinds of petrol will be greater than the headlines on Budget night. Asda, the supermarket chain, said that lead replacement petrol qualified for duty reductions under two of the chancellor's schemes, one under the unleaded fuel regime and another under the low sulphur regime.

With VAT taken into account, said the chain, the total saving off a litre of the fuel would actually be 4.78p. Asda said it planned to pass the total saving on to motorists from today with a litre of lead replacement petrol falling to 75p.

A spokesman said: "This is an unexpected bonus for motorists and it is only fair that we pass these savings on to them."

Shell said it would be cutting 4.8p off the cost of lead replacement fuel at its forecourts today.

"The chancellor's announcement on fuel duty means that some fuels could qualify for more than one price reduction," a Treasury spokesperson said.

Lead replacement petrol is mainly used by drivers with older cars.

fields.headline: City diary
fields.trailText: • The Treasury's Budget fibs, part one: according to the glossy Budget 2001 - Investing for the Long Term leaflet published by the Treasury to accompany Wednesday's tax fest, the key measures included an extra £1bn for education ... extending the 10p income tax band ... and so on. Until sixth in this list of measures: "an increase in the national minimum wage for workers aged 22 and over to £4.10 an hour". Laudable. Except that the increase in the minimum wage was announced by DTI secretary Stephen Byers on Monday, and has nothing whatever to do with the Budget. Naughty. Still, it's good to see Gordon has decided to gracefully accept the passing years and knocked off using the hair dye, allowing those attractive grey streaks to return.
fields.body:
 The Treasury's Budget fibs, part one: according to the glossy Budget 2001 - Investing for the Long Term leaflet published by the Treasury to accompany Wednesday's tax fest, the key measures included an extra £1bn for education ... extending the 10p income tax band ... and so on. Until sixth in this list of measures: "an increase in the national minimum wage for workers aged 22 and over to £4.10 an hour". Laudable. Except that the increase in the minimum wage was announced by DTI secretary Stephen Byers on Monday, and has nothing whatever to do with the Budget. Naughty. Still, it's good to see Gordon has decided to gracefully accept the passing years and knocked off using the hair dye, allowing those attractive grey streaks to return.

 The great thing about the Budget, of course, is that people think of little else on the day. So what an excellent time to quietly hand out the black bin bags and ask for security passes back, as they did at Credit Suisse First Boston on Wednesday. The word was that it was just part of the 10% staff cuts following the takeover of Donaldson, Lufkin and Jenrette last year, but this time around it was the "rainmaker" investment bankers filling the bin bags.

 We all make mistakes (hello, Pricewaterhouse- Coopers!), although it's always a mild concern when bankers (or accountants) make them. Take this recent press release from Lloyds TSB, offering a new platinum credit card. It boasts up to 56 days interest-free repayment period, and free, 180-day purchase protection. The only problem is, as the press release is dated 30 February 2001, just how do they calculate their calendars at Lloyds? "I'm sorry sir, your card's purchase protection expired on March 32nd?"

 From our Nonsense On Stilts Department (You Couldn't Make It Up sub-section). An email arrives about a function to be held this evening by somebody named The Drum Cafe (which dubs itself "The Premier African Drumming Experience," as if there were any competition in this field). "Essentially we run interactive drum circles as a professional team building event," writes Michelle Carlile. "The experience is uniquely African, but the rhythmic harmony of the drum circle has proved to be incredibly unifying in any culture. Our clients love it, and I'm sure you will." Mmm, no I won't.

 It's so easy to poke fun at economists for pursuing irrelevant and meaningless research with no connection to the real world. So mortar boards off to Warwick University for its study of whether or not money makes people happy. Apparently £1m does (there's a surprise), but the important thing is the calculations: "Assume a reported wellbeing function: r = h(u(y, z, t)) + e, where r is some measure of psychological stress or self-reported number or well-being level (perhaps the integer 4 on a satisfaction scale, or "very happy" on an ordinal happiness scale), u(_) is to be thought of as the person's true wellbeing or utility, h(.) is a continuous non-differentiable function relating actual to reported wellbeing, y is real income, z is a set of demographic and personal characteristics, t is the time period, and e is an error term." Simple, really. And if that doesn't improve your ordinal happiness scale, I don't know what will.

 Today sees the launch of the financial services authority's exciting new yoof soap-style TV project with Channel 4, to teach teenagers about money ("ISAs are well wicked - respect", etc). webTitle: 'Let my people talk to your people'

fields.headline: 'Let my people talk to your people'
fields.trailText: Gucci and LVMH are embroiled in one of the ugliest rows in corporate history - each accusing the other of criminal defamation. The legal wrangle provides an insight into the way share option deals are negotiated.
fields.body:
Gucci and LVMH are embroiled in one of the ugliest rows in corporate history - each accusing the other of criminal defamation. The legal wrangle provides an insight into the way share option deals are negotiated.

LVMH has accused Gucci's chief executive, Domenico de Sole, and chief designer Tom Ford of arranging for themselves multi-million pound sweetheart share deals with LVMH's rival PPR. Mr De Sole was forced to file an affidavit setting out the negotiations that led to 5% of Gucci's share capital being pledged to himself and Mr Ford.

He accused LVMH of harassment and denied there was any agreement between himself, Mr Ford and PPR that they should be given huge rewards for handing control of Gucci to PPR.

Mr Ford's negotiations were handled by his representatives and they were starting from a strong bargaining point. Mr de Sole said as much in the affidavit: "There would be no Gucci as we know it today without Mr Ford's creative talent".

When Gucci took over the YSL ready-to-wear label, Mr Ford's talent were needed there too. "An unprecedented and simultaneous responsibility for . . . two of the world's most recognisable brands," said Mr de Sole, justifying fundamental renegotiation of Mr Ford's rewards.

It took six months to thrash out the Texan designer's deal, worth up to $25m. The first approach from his representatives came in June 1999, three months after the PPR deal, and started with a demand for options over 4m shares. Gucci employedits own consultants to deal with Mr Ford's people and find out how much other fashion "talents" were being paid.

Three months later Mr Ford's people had climbed down a little over his basic salary and performance bonuses - and had been forced to abandon demands for the right for Mr Ford to start his own-name line of luxury products.

Gucci offered options on 3m shares, but a demand for 4m was a "deal-breaker". If Gucci said no, Mr Ford threatened to take his talents elsewhere. He wanted to be paid the same as "many high profile entertainment industry leaders". Gucci's only victory was to have the strike prices of the options reduced and the amount exercisable in the early years halved.

webTitle: The battle for Gucci turns personal

fields.headline: The battle for Gucci turns personal
fields.standfirst: It's a deluxe brief for a host of European lawyers as luxury goods companies battle it out in the courts
fields.trailText: It's a deluxe brief for a host of European lawyers as luxury goods companies battle it out in the courts.
fields.body:
If the prospect of two French billionaires fighting like cat and dog over an Italian handbag company sounds far fetched - think again. The two-year legal battle between Bernard Arnault's LVMH luxury label combine and François Pinault's PPR group over the ownership of Gucci intensified yesterday, when an Amsterdam court ordered an investigation into alleged mismanagement at Gucci. The decision put LVMH ahead on points, but the fight is not over yet.

At first the legal wrangle, which is lining the pockets of European lawyers and financial advisers, was over who should effectively control Gucci. But time has since marched on and LVMH says it does not want Gucci any more. But LVMH does not want PPR to have it either, and if the company's French rivals must have control LVMH want it to cost a fortune.

Now the combatants say it is about principles and about treating shareholders "honourably and fairly". It is about who started the punch-up in the first place - and it is personal.

Aside from the action alleging mismanagement, there are other claims flying around continental courtrooms. PPR is suing LVMH in Paris, accusing Mr Arnault's company of defamation and of dissemination of false information. Gucci, meanwhile, has trotted off to the European competition authorities, claiming that LVMH is not competing fairly.

The figureheads at PPR and LVMH are old rivals, who coexisted quite happily until the battle for Gucci. Mr Arnault was overlord of a worldwide luxury empire without equal, while Mr Pinault stuck largely to retailing, mail order and a range of other business interests. Mr Arnault's stable of deluxe labels includes names such as Givenchy, Krug, Chaumet and Christian Dior perfumes, while Mr Pinault had the Printemps store group and the La Redoute mail order business.

Nevertheless, to the outsider, it seems that whatever Mr Arnault has and does, Mr Pinault wants too, and vice-versa.

The parallels between the two men are uncanny. Mr Pinault has Chateau Latour, Mr Arnault Chateau d'Yquem. The PPR man has Christie's auction house - LVMH has Phillips. Both have Paris stores, huge art collections, Paris mansions, second wives, villas in St Tropez and fortunes estimated just north of £1.2bn.

The lawyers' bills have been mounting since Mr Pinault muscled in on Mr Arnault's plan to take a big stake in Gucci.

In Paris they call it La Guerre des Requins - the war of the sharks. In London it is the battle of the handbags.

The trouble started when LVMH built an unwelcome 34% stake in Gucci. The Italians said the French raiders were trying, without making a full bid, to snaffle control of the group, which had been turned from a bombed out brand to the world's hottest high fashion label through the combined talents of businessman Domenico de Sole and Texan designer Tom Ford.

To thwart LVMH, Gucci issued a vast tranche of shares to an employee stock holding trust to dilute LVMH's stake to 20% and did a white-knight deal with Mr Pinault, handing him a controlling 42% of the company in return for $3bn.

Gucci's de Sole and Ford claimed that this was just what they wanted - the power to build their own stable of luxury brands to compete with LVMH. They have since gone out and bought a host of brands, albeit mostly rather small ones like shoemaker Sergio Rossi and handbag-maker Bottega Veneta. Cheekily they also snapped up the Alexander McQueen fashion label, even though the talented Mr McQueen is head designer at LVMH's own Givenchy fashion house. It also took over the YSL ready-to-wear label, and Mr Ford has moved in to work his Gucci magic.

But LVMH went to the courts in Amsterdam, where Gucci has its main stock market listing, claiming that the new share issue was devised simply to cheat LVMH and that PPR should have been forced to make a full bid, at a premium price, which would have handed LVMH a handy profit on the shares they held.

At first the Dutch courts upheld the PPR-Gucci deal, but the supreme court of the Netherlands ordered a review. LVMH upped the stakes, filing a brief accusing Gucci of secretly granting huge share options, worth millions of dollars and representing 5% of the company's share capital, to Mr Ford and Mr de Sole, to encourage them to do the deal with Mr Pinault. LVMH also reported the allegations to the US Securities and Exchange Commission, where Gucci is also listed.

The Gucci duo insisted the options and the deal with PPR were unnconnected. Mr de Sole described the allegations as "very trashy", but he was forced to file an affidavit with the Amsterdam court setting out the details of the internal negotiations - usually guarded like a state secret - which led to Mr Ford being paid like a pop star with a package worth up to $25m.

Yesterday the battle of the egos moved on again, when the Amsterdam Enterprise court backed LVMH's demands and ordered a full investigation of the PPR deal, saying: "We need to investigate whether or not Gucci harmed the justified interests of its shareholders, one of which is LVMH.

"The PPR deal . . . is justified grounds to doubt good management at Gucci," the verdict said. But it will not look at de Sole and Ford's share options - unless they are found to be material to the decision-making process.

Yesterday LVMH's advisers were cock-a-hoop. "Gucci had no strategic reason to do the deal with PPR", said a spokesman for the luxury empire. "Before PPR emerged they always said they wanted to remain independent. They got $3bn off PPR and still haven't spent it. They've still got $2.5bn in the bank."

LVMH want the court to force PPR to mount a hugely expensive full bid - handing the company a huge profit on its 20% stake - or unravel the bid, leaving Gucci out of pocket by $3bn, although LVMH says it would ensure a new $3bn share issue to enable Gucci to build its own empire, this time open to all Gucci shareholders.

Gucci is playing it cool. "We have nothing to fear or hide from the inquiry", said a spokesman. "In all cases the company and its management have acted entirely properly. We want to put this whole damn matter to rest and we believe the inquiry will leave the deal with PPR intact."

The investigation by three prominent Dutch legal and business figures, who will have access to the minutes of Gucci board meetings, is likely to take up to six months. Another court case will follow to rule on the findings.

But there is always a chance that the two giant egos locked in combat could call off their fight. Last summer they came close to a deal that would have handed $100 a share to LVMH for its 20m shares to call the whole thing off. The deal fell through at the last minute.

As the LVMH spokesman said last night: "We are always open to finding solutions" - so long, we assume, as it punishes Mr Pinault in the pocket.

Related articles

"Let my people talk to your people"

fields.headline: Eurostar asylum seekers flee
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: Three asylum seekers who stowed away under a 180mph Eurostar train to get into Britain are being hunted after they absconded from an immigration reception centre where they were being held.
fields.body:
Three asylum seekers who stowed away under a 180mph Eurostar train to get into Britain are being hunted after they absconded from an immigration reception centre where they were being held.

The men were among nine Romanians who were discovered in a compartment underneath the floor of the Paris to London Waterloo service on March 2 and taken to Oakington reception centre near Cambridge.

When found on the train, one of the men was with his wife and two children, the second with his pregnant wife and their three-year-old child, and the third man with his pregnant fiancee.

A Home Office spokeswoman confirmed three of the nine went missing on Wednesday evening. Police were immediately notified and they and the Immigration Service were liaising on the ongoing investigation, she said.

She added: "It is not a detention centre so it has minimal physical security and is designed to provide a relaxed regime for the women and children and families there."

Jack Straw, the home secretary, said yesterday that the immigrants, who are understood to have scaled a barbed-wire perimeter fence to escape, would be imprisoned when caught.

fields.headline: Japan 'on verge of collapse'
fields.standfirst:
Minister's warning sends chill through world's second biggest economy
Special report: Japan
fields.trailText: Minister's warning sends chill through world's second biggest economy.
fields.body:
Japan's public finances are in danger of collapsing under the weight of the world's biggest national debt, the finance minister, Kiichi Miyazawa, said yesterday in a dire warning about the world's second biggest economy.

"The nation's finances are now abnormal, in a condition that is quite close to collapse," he told the Japanese parliament in an unusually frank appraisal of Japan's fiscal health. "We need fundamental restructuring to rebuild our finances. It will be necessary to introduce measures to reduce debt, as well as dealing with taxes, local government finances and social security."

The doom-laden comments came amid a cluster of gloomy economic data that helped to push the Japanese currency to a 19-month low of more than 120 yen to the dollar.

The comments are a virtual admission that the government's attempt to spend its way out of a 10-year economic slump have failed.

Japan has introduced more than a dozen pump priming packages totalling more than 111 trillion yen (£653bn) since the economic bubble burst at the end of the 1980s, but in the past five years, it has rarely managed to eke out an annual growth rate of even 1%.

The country's addiction to public works has produced a rocketing public debt, which - including central and local governments - is forecast to hit 666 trillion yen (£3.9 trillion), or 128% of national output, by the end of this fiscal year.

Coming from the octogenarian Mr Miyazawa, one of the biggest spending finance ministers in history, and who is usually criticised for the delphic nature of his statements, the warning was a shock to many analysts.

"A national minister saying the country's finances will collapse is akin to a company president saying his company will fail," a Sanwa Bank currency dealer, Mitsuru Sahara, said.

The alarm may have been intended to lower expectations ahead of quarterly gross domestic product data due out on Monday and expected to show that Japan has only just avoided its third recession in five years.

Yesterday, a steep fall in machinery orders intensified concerns that Japan's economy, which is bigger than the rest of Asia combined, is deteriorating faster than expected because of weakening export markets in the US and the prolonged stagnation of domestic demand. The orders, which are seen as an indicator of capital investment, fell 11.8% in January, almost twice as far as analysts had expected.

Separate data on consumption added to the growing fears of deflation that have been expressed by the Bank of Japan. According to the home affairs ministry, average household spending declined by 0.5% in January.

The full economic picture is still far from clear as other figures suggested that corporate investment was up 7.1% in the final three months of last year, while total company pre-tax profits also increased.

Politics may be behind the alarmist comments by the finance minister, who is expected to stand down soon, along with the unpopular prime minister, Yoshiro Mori.

Mr Miyazawa may feel more free to speak his mind in an attempt to influence the direction of the next government's policies and to increase pressure on Mr Mori, who could quit as early as today, to resign.

fields.headline: Thinks... by David Lodge
fields.standfirst:
Secker & Warburg, £16.99
Condensed in the style of the original, with alternating narrators
Buy it at a discount from BOL
fields.trailText: One, two, testing ... I'm recording the thoughts going through my head ... Got a good snog from Marianne ... Better keep the tape hidden from Carrie.
fields.body:
One, two, testing ... I'm recording the thoughts going through my head ... Got a good snog from Marianne ... Better keep the tape hidden from Carrie.

So here I am. Teaching creative writing at Gloucester University. God I feel lonely since Martin died. People are being kind, though, and Ralph and Carrie Messenger seem to have adopted me.

I really fancy Helen Reed. I must read her book and try to manipulate a way of meeting her on campus.

"Hi, I was just passing," said Messenger. "Would you like lunch?"

"So what is Cognitive Science?" asked Helen over a salad.

"It's the study of consciousness. Is it just electrochemical activity in the brain? Can feelings be reduced to hard-wiring? In short, how to give an objective account of a subjective phenomenon."

"Novelists have been doing that for years," replied Helen.

Ralph thought he had manipulated our meeting. Actually, I had been hanging around hoping he would make a move. I thought he might kiss me when he left.

I contemplated giving Helen a kiss, but thought it a bit obvious.

I'm completely thrown. The sex scenes in one of my students' works could only have been written by someone who had been to bed with Martin. "I wasn't the first," she said when I confronted her.

"Will you go to bed with me?" asked Ralph. "No. I don't approve of adultery."

She had left a pair of knickers out accidentally on purpose.

I turned Ralph down, but it was a closer call than he realises. If only I could be sure Carrie wouldn't find out.

Helen keeps a diary. That's interesting.

My God. I bumped into Carrie in Ledbury. She's having an affair with Nick, the interior designer.

"Carrie's gone off to the States as her Dad's ill. Can I come round?" "OK."

fields.headline: World Cup bid was always 'doomed'
fields.trailText: Alec McGivan, who headed England's 2006 World Cup bid, yesterday admitted it was doomed from the start because of Europe's refusal to back it.
fields.body:
Alec McGivan, who headed England's 2006 World Cup bid, yesterday admitted it was doomed from the start because of Europe's refusal to back it. The Football Association, meanwhile, conceded it had been widely viewed as arrogant and insular during the campaign, further damaging England's chances.

McGivan admitted to MPs yesterday that, because Uefa had backed Germany from the outset, an English bid was never going to be successful. Germany eventually won the decision unexpectedly from South Africa.

The bid director's comments confirmed what many said at the time - that without Uefa's support England's £10m bid would prove a waste of time.

Giving evidence to the parliamentary select committee for culture, media and sport which is examining the hosting of international events in Britain, McGivan said the English bid also lacked political awareness and clout.

"Uefa's support for Germany right across the board damaged us enormously. Seven out of eight European delegates voted for Germany. Not to have the backing of your confederation from the start was, looking back, very damaging.

"It was very difficult to do deals, it was all block votes and confederation wheeler-dealing and we were simply squeezed out." McGivan added: "You need political clout and that's a lesson we have learned. We were aware it was a weakness but thought we could overcome it."

In written evidence the FA conceded it was viewed unfavourably by many around the world and seen as out of touch with the global game. "English football ... had adopted an insular attitude," it said, "seen by some Uefa and Fifa members as stand-offish and even arrogant."

The FA chairman Geoff Thompson told MPs there were problems caused by the so-called gentleman's agreement between its former chairman Bert Millichip and Germany. Millichip had allegedly agreed not to bid against Germany in return for the Germans supporting England's bid for Euro 96.

"Clearly there were people in Uefa who felt there was a gentleman's agreement," said Thompson. "There was genuine misunderstanding, something that happened and nobody really knows why."

The former sports minister Tony Banks also told MPs that instead of staging the 2005 World Athletics Championships at a stadium to be built at Picketts Lock, north-east London, he would have preferred to have seen Wembley built with a running track.

Banks said: "It distresses me that we cannot do these things in this country. It all comes back to the culture of 'let's do it on the cheap; let's pass the hat around and see if we can get someone else to pay for it'."

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: La Veuve de Saint-Pierre | The Colour of Paradise | Gossip
fields.trailText: La Veuve de Saint-Pierre | The Colour of Paradise | Gossip
fields.body:
La Veuve de Saint-Pierre
Retail (£14.99) and DVD (£19.99) VCI/Film Four Cert 15

A very classy costume drama from Patrice Leconte with an intriguing plot. A man is found guilty of murder on a small island near Canada in 1850 and sentenced to death. But a guillotine has to be sent from France - a lengthy and difficult journey. In the meantime, the compassionate and progressive wife of the captain in charge finds useful tasks for the convict who becomes a popular and useful member of the community. A wide range of moral dilemmas is expertly juggled in a quiet, undemonstrative way. Juliette Binoche and Daniel Auteuil are the civilised couple caught in a legal double-bind but the noble savage part - a natural for Depardieu - provides a nicely relaxed performance for the Bosnian Serb director Emir Kusturica, whose manic films could hardly be a bigger contrast to the quiet dignity on offer here.

The Colour of Paradise
Retail (£12.99) Optimum Releasing Cert PG

Presumably there must be run-of-the-mill Iranian films but those that make it to the west invariably stick in the mind after big- budget bluster has been forgotten. Iranians are particularly strong on presenting a child's eye view of life and Majid Majidi's film successfully puts you in the body of a blind boy. It's a simple but powerful tale which starts when he locates a baby bird on the ground, climbs a tree and locates the nest to put it back in. This, in other words, is a very determined kid and he has to be because his father is keen to farm him out to be an apprentice carpenter, leaving himself free to marry again. There's nothing as compellingly strange here as Close-Up or, especially, The Apple. This is a straightforward, fictional tale that could have come from any country in the world. But it has a great feeling for the beauty of the countryside and some memorable moments - like when fog rolls in like a blanket along with a feeling of foreboding for our eight-year-old lead character - not SFX, just a director making use of nature. It also has an outstanding performance in the lead role.

Gossip
Rental and DVD (£15.99) Warner Cert 15

A smart beginning: three students decide to extend a college project by starting a rumour and seeing how big it gets. But it soon flounders as the mechanical plot twists become as improbable as the vast, trendy loft apartment they live in and a weirdly old-fashioned ending ties it up as neatly as an old Columbo re-run. James Marshall makes a nicely amoral smoothie.

webTitle: Hull creditors accept mystery buyer's package

fields.headline: Hull creditors accept mystery buyer's package
fields.trailText: Creditors of Hull City have accepted a rescue package put forward by an unnamed buyer at a meeting behind closed doors.
fields.body:
Creditors of Hull City have accepted a rescue package put forward by an unnamed buyer at a meeting behind closed doors. The Third Division club, which has debts of £1.8m, is now expected to be sold for £360,000 to the mystery backer, who has demanded anonymity as a condition of the deal.

But the plan could still fall apart if the club's former chair- man Nick Buchanan, who owns 64% of its shares, decides to decline the offer unless he is told the backer's identity.

Hull were put into administration at the start of last month after surviving a winding-up order over unpaid bills. The prospective buyer has already put £85,000 into the club to allow it to pay players' wages and continue renting its Boothferry Park ground.

The Third Division leaders Chesterfield yesterday notified the Football League that they have instructed solicitors to launch a "strenuous defence" against charges that they have breached transfer regulations, made irregular payments and under-reported gate receipts.

John Nagle, of the Football League, said a tribunal would consider the charges. If proven they could lead to relegation.

Mansfield reported Chesterfield to the League yesterday for non-payment of £36,000 gate receipts from the derby at Field Mill on February 17.

webTitle: Ferguson will fight FA ban on Neville

fields.headline: Ferguson will fight FA ban on Neville
fields.trailText: Manchester United are to appeal against Gary Neville's two-match ban and £30,000 fine for his behaviour at the end of their FA Cup fourth-round defeat by West Ham.
fields.body:
Manchester United will today appeal after the Football Association yesterday banned Gary Neville for two games and fined him £30,000 for his behaviour at the end of their FA Cup fourth-round defeat by West Ham.

Neville could miss the Premiership games against Liverpool and Charlton after being found guilty at an FA disciplinary hearing yesterday of using foul and abusive language towards one of the assistant referees.

Sir Alex Ferguson is incensed by the decision and has authorised the club's lawyers to take the matter to an appeal hearing.

"We are extremely shocked by the severity of this punishment," said Scott Duxbury, the solicitor representing Neville. "We believe it is totally out of line with other recent high-profile cases, not least when Patrick Vieira received a one-match ban after being charged with violent conduct for kicking Olivier Dacourt in the head.

"Gary is very unhappy and we believe understandably so. It is our intention to take the matter further and we will be lodging an official appeal."

Neville clearly did not expect to receive this level of punishment, stating earlier this week that he expected the FA to be "fair and consistent, bearing in mind recent cases".

He added: "Mine is a minor case and not one of violent conduct, where only one-match suspensions have been given recently. Taking this into consideration and also my excellent disciplinary record over the last two years, I think a warning would suffice."

Neville should, however, have been aware that the FA's chief executive Adam Crozier recently advised disciplinary panels to take a tough stance against player misbehaviour. While others may have been treated less severely than the England defender in recent months, his case was among the first to be dealt with since the reinforced crackdown.

Ferguson, meanwhile, is to make an appeal to the club's supporters not to stand up during games after learning that parts of Old Trafford could be closed down because of concerns about safety.

A delegation from Trafford Council will attend Tuesday's Champions League game against Sturm Graz to monitor whether safety regulations are being breached. If they find that to be the case, sections of the 67,500-capacity stadium will be temporarily closed and, because the council would have to give three weeks' notice, that could affect the derby game against Manchester City on April 21.

"There is the serious possibility of an accident and the council cannot afford to turn a blind eye," said councillor Barry Brotherton.

 The Ipswich midfielder Jim Magilton was given a one-match ban and fined £5,000 by the FA for protesting about a penalty decision during Ipswich's 4-1 defeat at Chelsea on January 20.

webTitle: Boro deal for Windass subject to scrutiny

fields.headline: Boro deal for Windass subject to scrutiny
fields.trailText: The deal which saw Dean Windass move from Bradford to Middlesbrough may have to be renegotiated after fears were raised about a possible conflict of interests when the two clubs meet for a Premiership fixture on May 5.
fields.body:
The deal which saw Dean Windass move from Bradford to Middlesbrough may have to be renegotiated after fears were raised about a possible conflict of interests when the two clubs meet for a Premiership fixture on May 5.

The 31-year-old forward yesterday signed a 2-year deal at the Riverside, one understood to involve Middlesbrough paying £600,000 now and a subsequent £400,000 if they avoid relegation.

Though Bradford are almost certain to be relegated by May, Middlesbrough may still be involved in the struggle to save their Premiership place.

However, it is understood that other clubs threatened with relegation have raised questions over the commitment Bradford may display towards winning a game in which a defeat would benefit the club financially.

Windass, who played the first half of Boro's drawn friendly with St Johnstone last night, said: "I don't know what the fee was; it's between the two clubs. Bradford will want to win every game anyway, even if they are down and we are up. I don't think anything like that would come into it."

A Premier League spokesman admitted: "We have not received the transfer documents yet but we will be scrutinising them very carefully."

Wimbledon's Marcus Gayle has joined Rangers for £900,000 although his new manager Dick Advocaat has yet to see him play.

The 30-year-old Jamaica forward, who joined Wimbledon for £250,000 from Brentford almost seven years ago, has signed a 2-year deal at Ibrox. "It came out of the blue really," Gayle said.

Advocaat said that an injury crisis had forced his hand. "I only know him from television but we are very short of strikers. Our scout mentioned him a couple of times and we took information from other people who were quite positive."

Sheffield United have agreed a deal with Gillingham for Carl Asaba, out of contract at the end of the season. The 28-year-old arrives for an initial £92,500, though it will increase if the Blades qualify for the play-offs.

Derby's reserve striker Lee Morris, signed in December 1999 for an initial £3m, has been loaned to Huddersfield for the rest of the season though it is expected that Derby will be able to recall him after a month, if needs be.

 Raul has admitted that one of Real Madrid's objectives in Tuesday's Champions League game against Leeds was for Luis Figo and Claude Makelele to get booked. "That was achieved," he wrote on his website.

Uefa has begun an inquiry into the case of Figo, who they suspect of deliberately incurring the card he was shown three minutes from the whistle and which sees him suspended for their last game in Group D, an irrelevance as they have already won the group.

webTitle: After years of drought, money to finish the job

fields.headline: After years of drought, money to finish the job
fields.standfirst: Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: The English theatre has been saved from erosion. After years of underfunding, leading to fewer productions, smaller casts and the creation of a scrimp and save siege mentality, it can breathe again.
fields.body:
The English theatre has been saved from erosion. After years of underfunding, leading to fewer productions, smaller casts and the creation of a scrimp and save siege mentality, it can breathe again. Yesterday's news that 194 theatres and companies are going to receive an extra £25m in 2003-04 means that the theatre can plan for growth rather than inexorable decline.

Underfunding, so long the norm, is a tragic waste. It means that too much of the available money has to go on meeting constant costs rather than where it belongs: on the stage. Take two London examples. On current funding the year-old Soho theatre, scene of yesterday's jubilant press conference, can afford to originate two-and-a-half productions a year: by 2003 it will have a 130% grant increase. Likewise the excellent Tricycle theatre in north London has funds to create one-and-a-half home productions a year: in two years time its grant will have shot up by 117%.

The really good news, however, was that almost the entire £25m is to go in core funding: theatres will be given the tools and allowed to finish the job. Only two months ago the rumour was that the arts council was going to keep £8m back and allow regional arts boards to bid for it through various schemes and initiatives. Which would have meant more paperwork, form-filling and wasteful bureaucracy.

Indeed possibly the most cheering thing yesterday was to hear Gerry Robinson, the arts council chairman, declare: "I'm passionately anti-schemes and hate the collection of data we have."

Equally radical is the idea of selective distribution of new money. Some companies, often starting from a modest base, get massive increases: 236% for Battersea arts centre, south London; 381% for the Gate in Notting Hill, west London; 238% for Kommedia in Brighton; and 233% for Theatre by the Lake in Keswick. Others have to make do with more modest advances: a surprisingly low 10% for the enterprising Oxford Stage Company.

But the theatres I feel sorry for are the losers: Croydon, Chester, Worcester and York. It is hard to know what precisely they have done wrong. There also needs to be an open appeals procedure for them to make their case direct to the arts council.

So what happens next? And how should the money be spent? Each theatre and company has its own agenda. But there are several golden rules one would like to see applied across the board. For a start, lower ticket prices and an extension of pay-what-you-can nights. I would also like to see more adventurous programming with an emphasis on new plays and rare classics. There is a dreary myth that audiences only want the tried and trusted. I do not believe it for a moment: coming out of a packed Northern Broadsides King John at the Viaduct in Halifax the other night, it was cheering to hear a teenager say she had never enjoyed a Shakespeare play more.

High on my wish list would also be realistic pay and living expenses for actors and a return to the principle of permanent companies. It is good to see one theatre which has played it the company way, the Colchester Mercury, getting a 120% increase.

One niggling thought occurs. If the Conservatives won the next election would they honour the blood transfusion or would they watch it slowly perish of inanition?

 Michael Billington is the Guardian's theatre critic.

Likewise the excellent Tricycle theatre in north London has funds to create one-and-a-half home productions a year: in two years time its grant will have shot up by 117%. The really good news, however, was that almost the entire £25m is to go in core funding: theatres will be given the tools and allowed to finish the job. Only two months ago the rumour was that the arts council was going to keep £8m back and allow regional arts boards to bid for it through various schemes and initiatives. Which would have meant more paperwork, form-filling and wasteful bureaucracy. Indeed possibly the most cheering thing yesterday was to hear Gerry Robinson, the arts council chairman, declare: "I'm passionately anti-schemes and hate the collection of data we have." Equally radical is the idea of selective distribution of new money. Some companies, often starting from a modest base, get massive increases: 236% for Battersea arts centre, south London; 381% for the Gate in Notting Hill, west London; 238% for Kommedia in Brighton; and 233% for Theatre by the Lake in Keswick. Others have to make do with more modest advances: a surprisingly low 10% for the enterprising Oxford Stage Company. But the theatres I feel sorry for are the losers: Croydon, Chester, Worcester and York. It is hard to know what precisely they have done wrong. There also needs to be an open appeals procedure for them to make their case direct to the arts council. So what happens next? And how should the money be spent? Each theatre and company has its own agenda. But there are several golden rules one would like to see applied across the board. For a start, lower ticket prices and an extension of pay-what-you-can nights. I would also like to see more adventurous programming with an emphasis on new plays and rare classics. There is a dreary myth that audiences only want the tried and trusted. I do not believe it for a moment: coming out of a packed Northern Broadsides King John at the Viaduct in Halifax the other night, it was cheering to hear a teenager say she had never enjoyed a Shakespeare play more. High on my wish list would also be realistic pay and living expenses for actors and a return to the principle of permanent companies. It is good to see one theatre which has played it the company way, the Colchester Mercury, getting a 120% increase. One niggling thought occurs. If the Conservatives won the next election would they honour the blood transfusion or would they watch it slowly perish of inanition?  Michael Billington is the Guardian's theatre critic. webTitle: FA Cup preview: Leicester v Wycombe

fields.headline: Essandoh the cyber striker
fields.standfirst: Roy Collins  meets the front man Wycombe found on the internet
fields.trailText: Roy Collins meets the front man Wycombe found on the internet as he prepares to face a 22,000 sell-out at Filbert Street.
fields.body:
Although Lawrie Sanchez always played the straight guy, as a former member of Wimbledon's Crazy Gang and the man who scored their winner against Liverpool in the 1988 FA Cup final, the Wycombe Wanderers manager is well aware that football can occasionally be mad and romantic at the same time.

Should the striker Roy Essandoh's first goal in British football propel Wycombe past Leicester City tomorrow into an FA Cup semi-final, both words are sure to be over-employed by every radio and television commentator in the country.

Sanchez was so desperate after an injury crisis robbed him of eight first-team players, including every forward, that he posted a cri de coeur on the club's website last week. A Teletext worker spotted it and, when he had dried his tears of laughter, put it out as an amusing story for the viewers.

Essandoh's agent, flicking through the Teletext pages on behalf of his out-of-work client, spotted the item and phoned Sanchez, resulting in Essandoh's debut for Wycombe's Chairboys against Port Vale last weekend. Now the striker is in line for the biggest match of his career.

Essandoh, 25, who was born in Belfast but brought up in Ghana, says: "I was at a loose end after leaving VPS Vaasa in Finland. I had two good years there but last season they ran into money troubles and couldn't pay the players. When I left they still owed me a few thousand pounds."

It is just as well, then, that it was not Hull City who came in for him, though even they would have represented a big club to Essandoh after a career trawling through some of football's shallowest waters. He began with Cumbernauld United of the Scottish central league in 1993 before moving on to Motherwell, where he managed five substitute appearances in three years.

Sanchez wanted a striker who was not Cup-tied. Essandoh was not even league-tied, having played only five full games in Britain, all during a six-week trial at East Fife in the Scottish Second Division three years ago. Sadly, not once was he able to whip his shirt over his head in celebration of a goal and nor has he managed to do so at any other clubs here.

He did, however, enjoy some modest success in Finland, scoring nine times last season for Vaasa. He says: "I thought I played pretty well over there and it will be great to test myself here to see how far I've come. I'm only on a two-week contract but, if I can impress the manager, then maybe he will sign me full time."

Essandoh has yet to play in front of any crowd approaching tomorrow's 22,000 sell-out at Filbert Street. When Vaasa won the Finnish league cup last season, only 10,000 fans watched and in his game for East Fife against Stenhousemuir 358 men and their dogs turned up.

He and his new team-mates, some of whose names escape him at the moment, will give it their best shot, though. And after such a disappointing career so far, why should he not dream of the FA Cup spinning a little magic his way? He says: "I know Leicester are a strong team but I think we've got a good chance and we will certainly give it a go."

Perhaps in an attempt to avoid becoming the bridesmaids at Filbert Street Wycombe have adopted the traditional bride's mantra of something old, something new, something borrowed, something blue.

If Essandoh, who played a couple of times as a substitute for Rushden and Diamonds last month, is the new element, the borrowed is his possible strike partner George Clegg, on a month's loan from Manchester United. The midfield man Dave Carroll, 34, last season's player of the year, is the old, though the blue will have to be worn under the Wanderers' shorts since they will be in their change strip of yellow, with red and white quarters.

Against Port Vale Essandoh started his first English league game, though he was brought off after 76 minutes, and he was given the last 13 minutes against Reading on Tuesday. That leaves him hopeful of starting in the big one and dreaming that his name may get another airing on Teletext - as a scorer.

That might sound fanciful but would not be the strangest thing to happen at Wycombe recently. Sanchez, before he turned to the internet, tried to persuade Gianluca Vialli out of retirement. Crazy or what?

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Liverpool tread water through Porto storm
fields.trailText: On the basis that there is no such thing as a bad draw away from home in European football Liverpool emerged from a pedestrian, almost moribund, skirmish with Porto wearing the fixed smiles of contented men.
fields.byline: Ian Ross at the Estadio das Antas
fields.body:
On the basis that there is no such thing as a bad draw away from home in European football Liverpool emerged from a pedestrian, almost moribund, skirmish with Porto wearing the fixed smiles of contented men.

While it is inconceivable that the Portuguese will play with such timidity a second time at Anfield next week, Gérard Houllier's team will, nonetheless, be reasonably confident of laying claim to a Uefa Cup semi-final berth.

Houllier's boys have learned much on their travels this season. This was an assured, competent and diligent display against opponents with a deserved reputation for football of a flamboyant nature.

It was an agonisingly dull evening - in short, precisely what the Merseysiders would have wished for yesterday afternoon as they sat in their hotel watching the rain cascade down from slate-grey skies.

"We now have a good chance but the job is by no means done," said Houllier. " What we musn't do is go into the second game believing that we have already done enough. We resisted well, we played well but they could still break us as they will have far more space when playing away from home."

At the tail-end of a filthy day even the most cultured of feet were prone to error on a surface which favoured the artisan more than the aristocrat.

The Antas stadium pitch was sodden, the tie going ahead only after the Italian referee Pierluigi Collina had undertaken a thorough examination two hours before kick-off.

But an ability to adapt to terrain and climate is a useful attribute and over the past few months Houllier's team have proved smart enough to assess and then modify without apparent discomfort. They are men for all seasons, indeed.

The diminishing band of critics who persist in decrying the Frenchman's methods, if not his achievements, shouted long and loud in the wake of Saturday's weak performance against Leicester City, insisting that their season had slipped into terminal decline.

Houllier's response once on Portuguese soil was to display the sense of adventure which is coming to characterise his Anfield tenure.

As in all four previous away games in this competition Houllier went with two forwards, the victim of the rotation system this time being Emile Heskey, relegated to the bench to accommodate Michael Owen and Robbie Fowler.

With Christian Ziege adding class, if not pace, down the left side of midfield and Vladimir Smicer a creative outlet down the opposite flank, Liverpool always attempted to carry the game to their opponents.

The conditions were so treacherous that much of the football was, of necessity, of a rudimentary nature. But for the most part Liverpool played with intelligence , distributing the ball sensibly and jealously guarding possession.

Curiously on an evening that almost seemed designed to suit the predatory forward chances were at a premium. Indeed the game had crawled to its 24th minute before there was even a hint of an opening. When it came it fell Liverpool's way and it should, probably, have been converted.

Fowler's lobbed pass set Owen free but he could do no more than steer his shot into the stomach of the goalkeeper Sergey Ovchinnikov after he had outpaced Jorge Andrade.

Porto's lethargy became more pronounced as the opening half wore on, although Stéphane Henchoz did have to step in sharply to whip the ball off Jesus Pena's toe as the striker shaped to shoot.

The interval beckoned before Porto seriously threatened to embarrass Liverpool, Sander Westerveld saving well from Carlos Chainho after Anderson Deco's pass had forged an opening.

Steven Gerrard's raking drive from distance on the hour almost interrupted the tedium but it was Porto who went closest to producing a defining moment, Pena screwing his shot wide when superbly placed midway through the second half.

"We defended magnificently," said Houllier, beaming. They did indeed.

Porto (4-3-3): Ovchinnikov; Nelson, Costa (Aloisio, 59min), Andrade, Secretario; Paredes, Deco, Chainho; Drulovic (Candido, 74), Pena, Capucho.

Liverpool (4-4-2): Westerveld; Babbel, Hyypia, Henchoz, Carragher; Smicer, Gerrard, Hamann, Ziege (Murphy, 55); Fowler (Heskey, 70), Owen (Barmby, 80).

Referee : P Collina ( Italy).

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk
